10457: headed. They embarked; and so for ever got the start of their former
10458: captain, had he been at all minded to work them legal retribution.
10459: 
10460: “Some ten days after the French ships sailed, the whale-boat arrived,
10461: and the captain was forced to enlist some of the more civilized
10462: Tahitians, who had been somewhat used to the sea. Chartering a small
10463: native schooner, he returned with them to his vessel; and finding all
10464: right there, again resumed his cruisings.
10465: 
10466: “Where Steelkilt now is, gentlemen, none know; but upon the island of
10467: Nantucket, the widow of Radney still turns to the sea which refuses to
10468: give up its dead; still in dreams sees the awful white whale that
10469: destroyed him.  * * * *
10470: 
10471: “‘Are you through?’ said Don Sebastian, quietly.
10472: 
10473: “‘I am, Don.’
10474: 
10475: “‘Then I entreat you, tell me if to the best of your own convictions,
10476: this your story is in substance really true? It is so passing
10477: wonderful! Did you get it from an unquestionable source? Bear with me
10478: if I seem to press.’
10479: 
10480: “‘Also bear with all of us, sir sailor; for we all join in Don
10481: Sebastian’s suit,’ cried the company, with exceeding interest.
10482: 
10483: “‘Is there a copy of the Holy Evangelists in the Golden Inn,
10484: gentlemen?’
10485: 
10486: “‘Nay,’ said Don Sebastian; ‘but I know a worthy priest near by, who
10487: will quickly procure one for me. I go for it; but are you well advised?
10488: this may grow too serious.’
10489: 
10490: “‘Will you be so good as to bring the priest also, Don?’
10491: 
10492: “‘Though there are no Auto-da-Fés in Lima now,’ said one of the company
10493: to another; ‘I fear our sailor friend runs risk of the archiepiscopacy.
10494: Let us withdraw more out of the moonlight. I see no need of this.’
10495: 
10496: “‘Excuse me for running after you, Don Sebastian; but may I also beg
10497: that you will be particular in procuring the largest sized Evangelists
10498: you can.’
10499: 
10500: * * * * * *
10501: 
10502: “‘This is the priest, he brings you the Evangelists,’ said Don
10503: Sebastian, gravely, returning with a tall and solemn figure.
10504: 
10505: “‘Let me remove my hat. Now, venerable priest, further into the light,
10506: and hold the Holy Book before me that I may touch it.
10507: 
10508: “‘So help me Heaven, and on my honor the story I have told ye,
10509: gentlemen, is in substance and its great items, true. I know it to be
10510: true; it happened on this ball; I trod the ship; I knew the crew; I
10511: have seen and talked with Steelkilt since the death of Radney.’”
10512: 
10513: 
10514: CHAPTER 55. Of the Monstrous Pictures of Whales.
10515: 
10516: I shall ere long paint to you as well as one can without canvas,
10517: something like the true form of the whale as he actually appears to the
10518: eye of the whaleman when in his own absolute body the whale is moored
10519: alongside the whale-ship so that he can be fairly stepped upon there.
10520: It may be worth while, therefore, previously to advert to those curious
10521: imaginary portraits of him which even down to the present day
10522: confidently challenge the faith of the landsman. It is time to set the
10523: world right in this matter, by proving such pictures of the whale all
10524: wrong.
10525: 
10526: It may be that the primal source of all those pictorial delusions will
10527: be found among the oldest Hindoo, Egyptian, and Grecian sculptures. For
10528: ever since those inventive but unscrupulous times when on the marble
10529: panellings of temples, the pedestals of statues, and on shields,
10530: medallions, cups, and coins, the dolphin was drawn in scales of
10531: chain-armor like Saladin’s, and a helmeted head like St. George’s; ever
10532: since then has something of the same sort of license prevailed, not
10533: only in most popular pictures of the whale, but in many scientific
10534: presentations of him.
10535: 
10536: Now, by all odds, the most ancient extant portrait anyways purporting
10537: to be the whale’s, is to be found in the famous cavern-pagoda of
10538: Elephanta, in India. The Brahmins maintain that in the almost endless
10539: sculptures of that immemorial pagoda, all the trades and pursuits,
10540: every conceivable avocation of man, were prefigured ages before any of
10541: them actually came into being. No wonder then, that in some sort our
10542: noble profession of whaling should have been there shadowed forth. The
10543: Hindoo whale referred to, occurs in a separate department of the wall,
10544: depicting the incarnation of Vishnu in the form of leviathan, learnedly
10545: known as the Matse Avatar. But though this sculpture is half man and
10546: half whale, so as only to give the tail of the latter, yet that small
10547: section of him is all wrong. It looks more like the tapering tail of an
10548: anaconda, than the broad palms of the true whale’s majestic flukes.
10549: 
10550: But go to the old Galleries, and look now at a great Christian
10551: painter’s portrait of this fish; for he succeeds no better than the
10552: antediluvian Hindoo. It is Guido’s picture of Perseus rescuing
10553: Andromeda from the sea-monster or whale. Where did Guido get the model
10554: of such a strange creature as that? Nor does Hogarth, in painting the
10555: same scene in his own “Perseus Descending,” make out one whit better.
10556: The huge corpulence of that Hogarthian monster undulates on the
10557: surface, scarcely drawing one inch of water. It has a sort of howdah on
10558: its back, and its distended tusked mouth into which the billows are
10559: rolling, might be taken for the Traitors’ Gate leading from the Thames
10560: by water into the Tower. Then, there are the Prodromus whales of old
10561: Scotch Sibbald, and Jonah’s whale, as depicted in the prints of old
10562: Bibles and the cuts of old primers. What shall be said of these? As for
10563: the book-binder’s whale winding like a vine-stalk round the stock of a
10564: descending anchor—as stamped and gilded on the backs and title-pages of
10565: many books both old and new—that is a very picturesque but purely
10566: fabulous creature, imitated, I take it, from the like figures on
10567: antique vases. Though universally denominated a dolphin, I nevertheless
10568: call this book-binder’s fish an attempt at a whale; because it was so
10569: intended when the device was first introduced. It was introduced by an
10570: old Italian publisher somewhere about the 15th century, during the
10571: Revival of Learning; and in those days, and even down to a
10572: comparatively late period, dolphins were popularly supposed to be a
10573: species of the Leviathan.
10574: 
10575: In the vignettes and other embellishments of some ancient books you
10576: will at times meet with very curious touches at the whale, where all
10577: manner of spouts, jets d’eau, hot springs and cold, Saratoga and
10578: Baden-Baden, come bubbling up from his unexhausted brain. In the
10579: title-page of the original edition of the “Advancement of Learning” you
10580: will find some curious whales.
10581: 
10582: But quitting all these unprofessional attempts, let us glance at those
10583: pictures of leviathan purporting to be sober, scientific delineations,
10584: by those who know. In old Harris’s collection of voyages there are some
10585: plates of whales extracted from a Dutch book of voyages, A.D. 1671,
10586: entitled “A Whaling Voyage to Spitzbergen in the ship Jonas in the
10587: Whale, Peter Peterson of Friesland, master.” In one of those plates the
10588: whales, like great rafts of logs, are represented lying among
10589: ice-isles, with white bears running over their living backs. In another
10590: plate, the prodigious blunder is made of representing the whale with
10591: perpendicular flukes.
10592: 
10593: Then again, there is an imposing quarto, written by one Captain
10594: Colnett, a Post Captain in the English navy, entitled “A Voyage round
10595: Cape Horn into the South Seas, for the purpose of extending the
10596: Spermaceti Whale Fisheries.” In this book is an outline purporting to
10597: be a “Picture of a Physeter or Spermaceti whale, drawn by scale from
10598: one killed on the coast of Mexico, August, 1793, and hoisted on deck.”
10599: I doubt not the captain had this veracious picture taken for the
10600: benefit of his marines. To mention but one thing about it, let me say
10601: that it has an eye which applied, according to the accompanying scale,
10602: to a full grown sperm whale, would make the eye of that whale a
10603: bow-window some five feet long. Ah, my gallant captain, why did ye not
10604: give us Jonah looking out of that eye!
10605: 
10606: Nor are the most conscientious compilations of Natural History for the
10607: benefit of the young and tender, free from the same heinousness of
10608: mistake. Look at that popular work “Goldsmith’s Animated Nature.” In
10609: the abridged London edition of 1807, there are plates of an alleged
10610: “whale” and a “narwhale.” I do not wish to seem inelegant, but this
10611: unsightly whale looks much like an amputated sow; and, as for the
10612: narwhale, one glimpse at it is enough to amaze one, that in this
10613: nineteenth century such a hippogriff could be palmed for genuine upon
10614: any intelligent public of schoolboys.
10615: 
10616: Then, again, in 1825, Bernard Germain, Count de Lacépède, a great
10617: naturalist, published a scientific systemized whale book, wherein are
10618: several pictures of the different species of the Leviathan. All these
10619: are not only incorrect, but the picture of the Mysticetus or Greenland
10620: whale (that is to say, the Right whale), even Scoresby, a long
10621: experienced man as touching that species, declares not to have its
10622: counterpart in nature.
10623: 
10624: But the placing of the cap-sheaf to all this blundering business was
10625: reserved for the scientific Frederick Cuvier, brother to the famous
10626: Baron. In 1836, he published a Natural History of Whales, in which he
10627: gives what he calls a picture of the Sperm Whale. Before showing that
10628: picture to any Nantucketer, you had best provide for your summary
10629: retreat from Nantucket. In a word, Frederick Cuvier’s Sperm Whale is
10630: not a Sperm Whale, but a squash. Of course, he never had the benefit of
10631: a whaling voyage (such men seldom have), but whence he derived that
10632: picture, who can tell? Perhaps he got it as his scientific predecessor
10633: in the same field, Desmarest, got one of his authentic abortions; that
10634: is, from a Chinese drawing. And what sort of lively lads with the
10635: pencil those Chinese are, many queer cups and saucers inform us.
10636: 
10637: As for the sign-painters’ whales seen in the streets hanging over the
10638: shops of oil-dealers, what shall be said of them? They are generally
10639: Richard III. whales, with dromedary humps, and very savage;
10640: breakfasting on three or four sailor tarts, that is whaleboats full of
10641: mariners: their deformities floundering in seas of blood and blue
10642: paint.
10643: 
10644: But these manifold mistakes in depicting the whale are not so very
10645: surprising after all. Consider! Most of the scientific drawings have
10646: been taken from the stranded fish; and these are about as correct as a
10647: drawing of a wrecked ship, with broken back, would correctly represent
10648: the noble animal itself in all its undashed pride of hull and spars.
10649: Though elephants have stood for their full-lengths, the living
10650: Leviathan has never yet fairly floated himself for his portrait. The
10651: living whale, in his full majesty and significance, is only to be seen
10652: at sea in unfathomable waters; and afloat the vast bulk of him is out
10653: of sight, like a launched line-of-battle ship; and out of that element
10654: it is a thing eternally impossible for mortal man to hoist him bodily
10655: into the air, so as to preserve all his mighty swells and undulations.
10656: And, not to speak of the highly presumable difference of contour
10657: between a young sucking whale and a full-grown Platonian Leviathan;
10658: yet, even in the case of one of those young sucking whales hoisted to a
10659: ship’s deck, such is then the outlandish, eel-like, limbered, varying
10660: shape of him, that his precise expression the devil himself could not
10661: catch.
10662: 
10663: But it may be fancied, that from the naked skeleton of the stranded
10664: whale, accurate hints may be derived touching his true form. Not at
10665: all. For it is one of the more curious things about this Leviathan,
10666: that his skeleton gives very little idea of his general shape. Though
10667: Jeremy Bentham’s skeleton, which hangs for candelabra in the library of
10668: one of his executors, correctly conveys the idea of a burly-browed
10669: utilitarian old gentleman, with all Jeremy’s other leading personal
10670: characteristics; yet nothing of this kind could be inferred from any
10671: leviathan’s articulated bones. In fact, as the great Hunter says, the
10672: mere skeleton of the whale bears the same relation to the fully
10673: invested and padded animal as the insect does to the chrysalis that so
10674: roundingly envelopes it. This peculiarity is strikingly evinced in the
10675: head, as in some part of this book will be incidentally shown. It is
10676: also very curiously displayed in the side fin, the bones of which
10677: almost exactly answer to the bones of the human hand, minus only the
10678: thumb. This fin has four regular bone-fingers, the index, middle, ring,
10679: and little finger. But all these are permanently lodged in their fleshy
10680: covering, as the human fingers in an artificial covering. “However
10681: recklessly the whale may sometimes serve us,” said humorous Stubb one
10682: day, “he can never be truly said to handle us without mittens.”
10683: 
10684: For all these reasons, then, any way you may look at it, you must needs
10685: conclude that the great Leviathan is that one creature in the world
10686: which must remain unpainted to the last. True, one portrait may hit the
10687: mark much nearer than another, but none can hit it with any very
10688: considerable degree of exactness. So there is no earthly way of finding
10689: out precisely what the whale really looks like. And the only mode in
10690: which you can derive even a tolerable idea of his living contour, is by
10691: going a whaling yourself; but by so doing, you run no small risk of
10692: being eternally stove and sunk by him. Wherefore, it seems to me you
10693: had best not be too fastidious in your curiosity touching this
10694: Leviathan.
10695: 
10696: 
10697: CHAPTER 56. Of the Less Erroneous Pictures of Whales, and the True
10698: Pictures of Whaling Scenes.
10699: 
10700: In connexion with the monstrous pictures of whales, I am strongly
10701: tempted here to enter upon those still more monstrous stories of them
10702: which are to be found in certain books, both ancient and modern,
10703: especially in Pliny, Purchas, Hackluyt, Harris, Cuvier, etc. But I pass
10704: that matter by.
10705: 
10706: I know of only four published outlines of the great Sperm Whale;
10707: Colnett’s, Huggins’s, Frederick Cuvier’s, and Beale’s. In the previous
10708: chapter Colnett and Cuvier have been referred to. Huggins’s is far
10709: better than theirs; but, by great odds, Beale’s is the best. All
10710: Beale’s drawings of this whale are good, excepting the middle figure in
10711: the picture of three whales in various attitudes, capping his second
10712: chapter. His frontispiece, boats attacking Sperm Whales, though no
10713: doubt calculated to excite the civil scepticism of some parlor men, is
10714: admirably correct and life-like in its general effect. Some of the
10715: Sperm Whale drawings in J. Ross Browne are pretty correct in contour;
10716: but they are wretchedly engraved. That is not his fault though.
10717: 
10718: Of the Right Whale, the best outline pictures are in Scoresby; but they
10719: are drawn on too small a scale to convey a desirable impression. He has
10720: but one picture of whaling scenes, and this is a sad deficiency,
10721: because it is by such pictures only, when at all well done, that you
10722: can derive anything like a truthful idea of the living whale as seen by
10723: his living hunters.
10724: 
10725: But, taken for all in all, by far the finest, though in some details
10726: not the most correct, presentations of whales and whaling scenes to be
10727: anywhere found, are two large French engravings, well executed, and
10728: taken from paintings by one Garnery. Respectively, they represent
10729: attacks on the Sperm and Right Whale. In the first engraving a noble
10730: Sperm Whale is depicted in full majesty of might, just risen beneath
10731: the boat from the profundities of the ocean, and bearing high in the
10732: air upon his back the terrific wreck of the stoven planks. The prow of
10733: the boat is partially unbroken, and is drawn just balancing upon the
10734: monster’s spine; and standing in that prow, for that one single
10735: incomputable flash of time, you behold an oarsman, half shrouded by the
10736: incensed boiling spout of the whale, and in the act of leaping, as if
10737: from a precipice. The action of the whole thing is wonderfully good and
10738: true. The half-emptied line-tub floats on the whitened sea; the wooden
10739: poles of the spilled harpoons obliquely bob in it; the heads of the
10740: swimming crew are scattered about the whale in contrasting expressions
10741: of affright; while in the black stormy distance the ship is bearing
10742: down upon the scene. Serious fault might be found with the anatomical
10743: details of this whale, but let that pass; since, for the life of me, I
10744: could not draw so good a one.
10745: 
10746: In the second engraving, the boat is in the act of drawing alongside
10747: the barnacled flank of a large running Right Whale, that rolls his
10748: black weedy bulk in the sea like some mossy rock-slide from the
10749: Patagonian cliffs. His jets are erect, full, and black like soot; so
10750: that from so abounding a smoke in the chimney, you would think there
10751: must be a brave supper cooking in the great bowels below. Sea fowls are
10752: pecking at the small crabs, shell-fish, and other sea candies and
10753: maccaroni, which the Right Whale sometimes carries on his pestilent
10754: back. And all the while the thick-lipped leviathan is rushing through
10755: the deep, leaving tons of tumultuous white curds in his wake, and
10756: causing the slight boat to rock in the swells like a skiff caught nigh
10757: the paddle-wheels of an ocean steamer. Thus, the foreground is all
10758: raging commotion; but behind, in admirable artistic contrast, is the
10759: glassy level of a sea becalmed, the drooping unstarched sails of the
10760: powerless ship, and the inert mass of a dead whale, a conquered
10761: fortress, with the flag of capture lazily hanging from the whale-pole
10762: inserted into his spout-hole.
10763: 
10764: Who Garnery the painter is, or was, I know not. But my life for it he
10765: was either practically conversant with his subject, or else
10766: marvellously tutored by some experienced whaleman. The French are the
10767: lads for painting action. Go and gaze upon all the paintings of Europe,
10768: and where will you find such a gallery of living and breathing
10769: commotion on canvas, as in that triumphal hall at Versailles; where the
10770: beholder fights his way, pell-mell, through the consecutive great
10771: battles of France; where every sword seems a flash of the Northern
10772: Lights, and the successive armed kings and Emperors dash by, like a
10773: charge of crowned centaurs? Not wholly unworthy of a place in that
10774: gallery, are these sea battle-pieces of Garnery.
10775: 
10776: The natural aptitude of the French for seizing the picturesqueness of
10777: things seems to be peculiarly evinced in what paintings and engravings
10778: they have of their whaling scenes. With not one tenth of England’s
10779: experience in the fishery, and not the thousandth part of that of the
10780: Americans, they have nevertheless furnished both nations with the only
10781: finished sketches at all capable of conveying the real spirit of the
10782: whale hunt. For the most part, the English and American whale
10783: draughtsmen seem entirely content with presenting the mechanical
10784: outline of things, such as the vacant profile of the whale; which, so
10785: far as picturesqueness of effect is concerned, is about tantamount to
10786: sketching the profile of a pyramid. Even Scoresby, the justly renowned
10787: Right whaleman, after giving us a stiff full length of the Greenland
10788: whale, and three or four delicate miniatures of narwhales and
10789: porpoises, treats us to a series of classical engravings of boat hooks,
10790: chopping knives, and grapnels; and with the microscopic diligence of a
10791: Leuwenhoeck submits to the inspection of a shivering world ninety-six
10792: fac-similes of magnified Arctic snow crystals. I mean no disparagement
10793: to the excellent voyager (I honor him for a veteran), but in so
10794: important a matter it was certainly an oversight not to have procured
10795: for every crystal a sworn affidavit taken before a Greenland Justice of
10796: the Peace.
10797: 
10798: In addition to those fine engravings from Garnery, there are two other
10799: French engravings worthy of note, by some one who subscribes himself
10800: “H. Durand.” One of them, though not precisely adapted to our present
10801: purpose, nevertheless deserves mention on other accounts. It is a quiet
10802: noon-scene among the isles of the Pacific; a French whaler anchored,
10803: inshore, in a calm, and lazily taking water on board; the loosened
10804: sails of the ship, and the long leaves of the palms in the background,
10805: both drooping together in the breezeless air. The effect is very fine,
10806: when considered with reference to its presenting the hardy fishermen
10807: under one of their few aspects of oriental repose. The other engraving
10808: is quite a different affair: the ship hove-to upon the open sea, and in
10809: the very heart of the Leviathanic life, with a Right Whale alongside;
10810: the vessel (in the act of cutting-in) hove over to the monster as if to
10811: a quay; and a boat, hurriedly pushing off from this scene of activity,
10812: is about giving chase to whales in the distance. The harpoons and
10813: lances lie levelled for use; three oarsmen are just setting the mast in
10814: its hole; while from a sudden roll of the sea, the little craft stands
10815: half-erect out of the water, like a rearing horse. From the ship, the
10816: smoke of the torments of the boiling whale is going up like the smoke
10817: over a village of smithies; and to windward, a black cloud, rising up
10818: with earnest of squalls and rains, seems to quicken the activity of the
10819: excited seamen.
10820: 
10821: 
10822: CHAPTER 57. Of Whales in Paint; in Teeth; in Wood; in Sheet-Iron; in
10823: Stone; in Mountains; in Stars.
10824: 
10825: On Tower-hill, as you go down to the London docks, you may have seen a
10826: crippled beggar (or _kedger_, as the sailors say) holding a painted
10827: board before him, representing the tragic scene in which he lost his
10828: leg. There are three whales and three boats; and one of the boats
10829: (presumed to contain the missing leg in all its original integrity) is
10830: being crunched by the jaws of the foremost whale. Any time these ten
10831: years, they tell me, has that man held up that picture, and exhibited
10832: that stump to an incredulous world. But the time of his justification
10833: has now come. His three whales are as good whales as were ever
10834: published in Wapping, at any rate; and his stump as unquestionable a
10835: stump as any you will find in the western clearings. But, though for
10836: ever mounted on that stump, never a stump-speech does the poor whaleman
10837: make; but, with downcast eyes, stands ruefully contemplating his own
10838: amputation.
10839: 
10840: Throughout the Pacific, and also in Nantucket, and New Bedford, and Sag
10841: Harbor, you will come across lively sketches of whales and
10842: whaling-scenes, graven by the fishermen themselves on Sperm
10843: Whale-teeth, or ladies’ busks wrought out of the Right Whale-bone, and
10844: other like skrimshander articles, as the whalemen call the numerous
10845: little ingenious contrivances they elaborately carve out of the rough
10846: material, in their hours of ocean leisure. Some of them have little
10847: boxes of dentistical-looking implements, specially intended for the
10848: skrimshandering business. But, in general, they toil with their
10849: jack-knives alone; and, with that almost omnipotent tool of the sailor,
10850: they will turn you out anything you please, in the way of a mariner’s
10851: fancy.
10852: 
10853: Long exile from Christendom and civilization inevitably restores a man
10854: to that condition in which God placed him, _i.e._ what is called
10855: savagery. Your true whale-hunter is as much a savage as an Iroquois. I
10856: myself am a savage, owning no allegiance but to the King of the
10857: Cannibals; and ready at any moment to rebel against him.
10858: 
10859: Now, one of the peculiar characteristics of the savage in his domestic
10860: hours, is his wonderful patience of industry. An ancient Hawaiian
10861: war-club or spear-paddle, in its full multiplicity and elaboration of
10862: carving, is as great a trophy of human perseverance as a Latin lexicon.
10863: For, with but a bit of broken sea-shell or a shark’s tooth, that
10864: miraculous intricacy of wooden net-work has been achieved; and it has
10865: cost steady years of steady application.
10866: 
10867: As with the Hawaiian savage, so with the white sailor-savage. With the
10868: same marvellous patience, and with the same single shark’s tooth, of
10869: his one poor jack-knife, he will carve you a bit of bone sculpture, not
10870: quite as workmanlike, but as close packed in its maziness of design, as
10871: the Greek savage, Achilles’s shield; and full of barbaric spirit and
10872: suggestiveness, as the prints of that fine old Dutch savage, Albert
10873: Durer.
10874: 
10875: Wooden whales, or whales cut in profile out of the small dark slabs of
10876: the noble South Sea war-wood, are frequently met with in the
10877: forecastles of American whalers. Some of them are done with much
10878: accuracy.
10879: 
10880: At some old gable-roofed country houses you will see brass whales hung
10881: by the tail for knockers to the road-side door. When the porter is
10882: sleepy, the anvil-headed whale would be best. But these knocking whales
10883: are seldom remarkable as faithful essays. On the spires of some
10884: old-fashioned churches you will see sheet-iron whales placed there for
10885: weather-cocks; but they are so elevated, and besides that are to all
10886: intents and purposes so labelled with “_Hands off!_” you cannot examine
10887: them closely enough to decide upon their merit.
10888: 
10889: In bony, ribby regions of the earth, where at the base of high broken
10890: cliffs masses of rock lie strewn in fantastic groupings upon the plain,
10891: you will often discover images as of the petrified forms of the
10892: Leviathan partly merged in grass, which of a windy day breaks against
10893: them in a surf of green surges.
10894: 
10895: Then, again, in mountainous countries where the traveller is
10896: continually girdled by amphitheatrical heights; here and there from
10897: some lucky point of view you will catch passing glimpses of the
10898: profiles of whales defined along the undulating ridges. But you must be
10899: a thorough whaleman, to see these sights; and not only that, but if you
10900: wish to return to such a sight again, you must be sure and take the
10901: exact intersecting latitude and longitude of your first stand-point,
10902: else so chance-like are such observations of the hills, that your
10903: precise, previous stand-point would require a laborious re-discovery;
10904: like the Soloma Islands, which still remain incognita, though once
10905: high-ruffed Mendanna trod them and old Figuera chronicled them.
10906: 
10907: Nor when expandingly lifted by your subject, can you fail to trace out
10908: great whales in the starry heavens, and boats in pursuit of them; as
10909: when long filled with thoughts of war the Eastern nations saw armies
10910: locked in battle among the clouds. Thus at the North have I chased
10911: Leviathan round and round the Pole with the revolutions of the bright
10912: points that first defined him to me. And beneath the effulgent
10913: Antarctic skies I have boarded the Argo-Navis, and joined the chase
10914: against the starry Cetus far beyond the utmost stretch of Hydrus and
10915: the Flying Fish.
10916: 
10917: With a frigate’s anchors for my bridle-bitts and fasces of harpoons for
10918: spurs, would I could mount that whale and leap the topmost skies, to
10919: see whether the fabled heavens with all their countless tents really
10920: lie encamped beyond my mortal sight!
10921: 
10922: 
10923: CHAPTER 58. Brit.
10924: 
10925: Steering north-eastward from the Crozetts, we fell in with vast meadows
10926: of brit, the minute, yellow substance, upon which the Right Whale
10927: largely feeds. For leagues and leagues it undulated round us, so that
10928: we seemed to be sailing through boundless fields of ripe and golden
10929: wheat.
10930: 
10931: On the second day, numbers of Right Whales were seen, who, secure from
10932: the attack of a Sperm Whaler like the Pequod, with open jaws sluggishly
10933: swam through the brit, which, adhering to the fringing fibres of that
10934: wondrous Venetian blind in their mouths, was in that manner separated
10935: from the water that escaped at the lip.
10936: 
10937: As morning mowers, who side by side slowly and seethingly advance their
10938: scythes through the long wet grass of marshy meads; even so these
10939: monsters swam, making a strange, grassy, cutting sound; and leaving
10940: behind them endless swaths of blue upon the yellow sea.*
10941: 
10942: *That part of the sea known among whalemen as the “Brazil Banks” does
10943: not bear that name as the Banks of Newfoundland do, because of there
10944: being shallows and soundings there, but because of this remarkable
10945: meadow-like appearance, caused by the vast drifts of brit continually
10946: floating in those latitudes, where the Right Whale is often chased.
10947: 
10948: But it was only the sound they made as they parted the brit which at
10949: all reminded one of mowers. Seen from the mast-heads, especially when
10950: they paused and were stationary for a while, their vast black forms
10951: looked more like lifeless masses of rock than anything else. And as in
10952: the great hunting countries of India, the stranger at a distance will
10953: sometimes pass on the plains recumbent elephants without knowing them
10954: to be such, taking them for bare, blackened elevations of the soil;
10955: even so, often, with him, who for the first time beholds this species
10956: of the leviathans of the sea. And even when recognised at last, their
10957: immense magnitude renders it very hard really to believe that such
10958: bulky masses of overgrowth can possibly be instinct, in all parts, with
10959: the same sort of life that lives in a dog or a horse.
10960: 
10961: Indeed, in other respects, you can hardly regard any creatures of the
10962: deep with the same feelings that you do those of the shore. For though
10963: some old naturalists have maintained that all creatures of the land are
10964: of their kind in the sea; and though taking a broad general view of the
10965: thing, this may very well be; yet coming to specialties, where, for
10966: example, does the ocean furnish any fish that in disposition answers to
10967: the sagacious kindness of the dog? The accursed shark alone can in any
10968: generic respect be said to bear comparative analogy to him.
10969: 
10970: But though, to landsmen in general, the native inhabitants of the seas
10971: have ever been regarded with emotions unspeakably unsocial and
10972: repelling; though we know the sea to be an everlasting terra incognita,
10973: so that Columbus sailed over numberless unknown worlds to discover his
10974: one superficial western one; though, by vast odds, the most terrific of
10975: all mortal disasters have immemorially and indiscriminately befallen
10976: tens and hundreds of thousands of those who have gone upon the waters;
10977: though but a moment’s consideration will teach, that however baby man
10978: may brag of his science and skill, and however much, in a flattering
10979: future, that science and skill may augment; yet for ever and for ever,
10980: to the crack of doom, the sea will insult and murder him, and pulverize
10981: the stateliest, stiffest frigate he can make; nevertheless, by the
10982: continual repetition of these very impressions, man has lost that sense
10983: of the full awfulness of the sea which aboriginally belongs to it.
10984: 
10985: The first boat we read of, floated on an ocean, that with Portuguese
10986: vengeance had whelmed a whole world without leaving so much as a widow.
10987: That same ocean rolls now; that same ocean destroyed the wrecked ships
10988: of last year. Yea, foolish mortals, Noah’s flood is not yet subsided;
10989: two thirds of the fair world it yet covers.
10990: 
10991: Wherein differ the sea and the land, that a miracle upon one is not a
10992: miracle upon the other? Preternatural terrors rested upon the Hebrews,
10993: when under the feet of Korah and his company the live ground opened and
10994: swallowed them up for ever; yet not a modern sun ever sets, but in
10995: precisely the same manner the live sea swallows up ships and crews.
10996: 
10997: But not only is the sea such a foe to man who is an alien to it, but it
10998: is also a fiend to its own off-spring; worse than the Persian host who
10999: murdered his own guests; sparing not the creatures which itself hath
11000: spawned. Like a savage tigress that tossing in the jungle overlays her
11001: own cubs, so the sea dashes even the mightiest whales against the
11002: rocks, and leaves them there side by side with the split wrecks of
11003: ships. No mercy, no power but its own controls it. Panting and snorting
11004: like a mad battle steed that has lost its rider, the masterless ocean
11005: overruns the globe.
11006: 
11007: Consider the subtleness of the sea; how its most dreaded creatures
11008: glide under water, unapparent for the most part, and treacherously
11009: hidden beneath the loveliest tints of azure. Consider also the devilish
11010: brilliance and beauty of many of its most remorseless tribes, as the
11011: dainty embellished shape of many species of sharks. Consider, once
11012: more, the universal cannibalism of the sea; all whose creatures prey
11013: upon each other, carrying on eternal war since the world began.
11014: 
11015: Consider all this; and then turn to this green, gentle, and most docile
11016: earth; consider them both, the sea and the land; and do you not find a
11017: strange analogy to something in yourself? For as this appalling ocean
11018: surrounds the verdant land, so in the soul of man there lies one
11019: insular Tahiti, full of peace and joy, but encompassed by all the
11020: horrors of the half known life. God keep thee! Push not off from that
11021: isle, thou canst never return!
11022: 
11023: 
11024: CHAPTER 59. Squid.
11025: 
11026: Slowly wading through the meadows of brit, the Pequod still held on her
11027: way north-eastward towards the island of Java; a gentle air impelling
11028: her keel, so that in the surrounding serenity her three tall tapering
11029: masts mildly waved to that languid breeze, as three mild palms on a
11030: plain. And still, at wide intervals in the silvery night, the lonely,
11031: alluring jet would be seen.
11032: 
11033: But one transparent blue morning, when a stillness almost preternatural
11034: spread over the sea, however unattended with any stagnant calm; when
11035: the long burnished sun-glade on the waters seemed a golden finger laid
11036: across them, enjoining some secrecy; when the slippered waves whispered
11037: together as they softly ran on; in this profound hush of the visible
11038: sphere a strange spectre was seen by Daggoo from the main-mast-head.
11039: 
11040: In the distance, a great white mass lazily rose, and rising higher and
11041: higher, and disentangling itself from the azure, at last gleamed before
11042: our prow like a snow-slide, new slid from the hills. Thus glistening
11043: for a moment, as slowly it subsided, and sank. Then once more arose,
11044: and silently gleamed. It seemed not a whale; and yet is this Moby Dick?
11045: thought Daggoo. Again the phantom went down, but on re-appearing once
11046: more, with a stiletto-like cry that startled every man from his nod,
11047: the negro yelled out—“There! there again! there she breaches! right
11048: ahead! The White Whale, the White Whale!”
11049: 
11050: Upon this, the seamen rushed to the yard-arms, as in swarming-time the
11051: bees rush to the boughs. Bare-headed in the sultry sun, Ahab stood on
11052: the bowsprit, and with one hand pushed far behind in readiness to wave
11053: his orders to the helmsman, cast his eager glance in the direction
11054: indicated aloft by the outstretched motionless arm of Daggoo.
11055: 
11056: Whether the flitting attendance of the one still and solitary jet had
11057: gradually worked upon Ahab, so that he was now prepared to connect the
11058: ideas of mildness and repose with the first sight of the particular
11059: whale he pursued; however this was, or whether his eagerness betrayed
11060: him; whichever way it might have been, no sooner did he distinctly
11061: perceive the white mass, than with a quick intensity he instantly gave
11062: orders for lowering.
11063: 
11064: The four boats were soon on the water; Ahab’s in advance, and all
11065: swiftly pulling towards their prey. Soon it went down, and while, with
11066: oars suspended, we were awaiting its reappearance, lo! in the same spot
11067: where it sank, once more it slowly rose. Almost forgetting for the
11068: moment all thoughts of Moby Dick, we now gazed at the most wondrous
11069: phenomenon which the secret seas have hitherto revealed to mankind. A
11070: vast pulpy mass, furlongs in length and breadth, of a glancing
11071: cream-colour, lay floating on the water, innumerable long arms
11072: radiating from its centre, and curling and twisting like a nest of
11073: anacondas, as if blindly to clutch at any hapless object within reach.
11074: No perceptible face or front did it have; no conceivable token of
11075: either sensation or instinct; but undulated there on the billows, an
11076: unearthly, formless, chance-like apparition of life.
11077: 
11078: As with a low sucking sound it slowly disappeared again, Starbuck still
11079: gazing at the agitated waters where it had sunk, with a wild voice
11080: exclaimed—“Almost rather had I seen Moby Dick and fought him, than to
11081: have seen thee, thou white ghost!”
11082: 
11083: “What was it, Sir?” said Flask.
11084: 
11085: “The great live squid, which, they say, few whale-ships ever beheld,
11086: and returned to their ports to tell of it.”
11087: 
11088: But Ahab said nothing; turning his boat, he sailed back to the vessel;
11089: the rest as silently following.
11090: 
11091: Whatever superstitions the sperm whalemen in general have connected
11092: with the sight of this object, certain it is, that a glimpse of it
11093: being so very unusual, that circumstance has gone far to invest it with
11094: portentousness. So rarely is it beheld, that though one and all of them
11095: declare it to be the largest animated thing in the ocean, yet very few
11096: of them have any but the most vague ideas concerning its true nature
11097: and form; notwithstanding, they believe it to furnish to the sperm
11098: whale his only food. For though other species of whales find their food
11099: above water, and may be seen by man in the act of feeding, the
11100: spermaceti whale obtains his whole food in unknown zones below the
11101: surface; and only by inference is it that any one can tell of what,
11102: precisely, that food consists. At times, when closely pursued, he will
11103: disgorge what are supposed to be the detached arms of the squid; some
11104: of them thus exhibited exceeding twenty and thirty feet in length. They
11105: fancy that the monster to which these arms belonged ordinarily clings
11106: by them to the bed of the ocean; and that the sperm whale, unlike other
11107: species, is supplied with teeth in order to attack and tear it.
11108: 
11109: There seems some ground to imagine that the great Kraken of Bishop
11110: Pontoppodan may ultimately resolve itself into Squid. The manner in
11111: which the Bishop describes it, as alternately rising and sinking, with
11112: some other particulars he narrates, in all this the two correspond. But
11113: much abatement is necessary with respect to the incredible bulk he
11114: assigns it.
11115: 
11116: By some naturalists who have vaguely heard rumors of the mysterious
11117: creature, here spoken of, it is included among the class of
11118: cuttle-fish, to which, indeed, in certain external respects it would
11119: seem to belong, but only as the Anak of the tribe.
11120: 
11121: 
11122: CHAPTER 60. The Line.
11123: 
11124: With reference to the whaling scene shortly to be described, as well as
11125: for the better understanding of all similar scenes elsewhere presented,
11126: I have here to speak of the magical, sometimes horrible whale-line.
11127: 
11128: The line originally used in the fishery was of the best hemp, slightly
11129: vapored with tar, not impregnated with it, as in the case of ordinary
11130: ropes; for while tar, as ordinarily used, makes the hemp more pliable
11131: to the rope-maker, and also renders the rope itself more convenient to
11132: the sailor for common ship use; yet, not only would the ordinary
11133: quantity too much stiffen the whale-line for the close coiling to which
11134: it must be subjected; but as most seamen are beginning to learn, tar in
11135: general by no means adds to the rope’s durability or strength, however
11136: much it may give it compactness and gloss.
11137: 
11138: Of late years the Manilla rope has in the American fishery almost
11139: entirely superseded hemp as a material for whale-lines; for, though not
11140: so durable as hemp, it is stronger, and far more soft and elastic; and
11141: I will add (since there is an æsthetics in all things), is much more
11142: handsome and becoming to the boat, than hemp. Hemp is a dusky, dark
11143: fellow, a sort of Indian; but Manilla is as a golden-haired Circassian
11144: to behold.
11145: 
11146: The whale-line is only two-thirds of an inch in thickness. At first
11147: sight, you would not think it so strong as it really is. By experiment
11148: its one and fifty yarns will each suspend a weight of one hundred and
11149: twenty pounds; so that the whole rope will bear a strain nearly equal
11150: to three tons. In length, the common sperm whale-line measures
11151: something over two hundred fathoms. Towards the stern of the boat it is
11152: spirally coiled away in the tub, not like the worm-pipe of a still
11153: though, but so as to form one round, cheese-shaped mass of densely
11154: bedded “sheaves,” or layers of concentric spiralizations, without any
11155: hollow but the “heart,” or minute vertical tube formed at the axis of
11156: the cheese. As the least tangle or kink in the coiling would, in
11157: running out, infallibly take somebody’s arm, leg, or entire body off,
11158: the utmost precaution is used in stowing the line in its tub. Some
11159: harpooneers will consume almost an entire morning in this business,
11160: carrying the line high aloft and then reeving it downwards through a
11161: block towards the tub, so as in the act of coiling to free it from all
11162: possible wrinkles and twists.
11163: 
11164: In the English boats two tubs are used instead of one; the same line
11165: being continuously coiled in both tubs. There is some advantage in
11166: this; because these twin-tubs being so small they fit more readily into
11167: the boat, and do not strain it so much; whereas, the American tub,
11168: nearly three feet in diameter and of proportionate depth, makes a
11169: rather bulky freight for a craft whose planks are but one half-inch in
11170: thickness; for the bottom of the whale-boat is like critical ice, which
11171: will bear up a considerable distributed weight, but not very much of a
11172: concentrated one. When the painted canvas cover is clapped on the
11173: American line-tub, the boat looks as if it were pulling off with a
11174: prodigious great wedding-cake to present to the whales.
11175: 
11176: Both ends of the line are exposed; the lower end terminating in an
11177: eye-splice or loop coming up from the bottom against the side of the
11178: tub, and hanging over its edge completely disengaged from everything.
11179: This arrangement of the lower end is necessary on two accounts. First:
11180: In order to facilitate the fastening to it of an additional line from a
11181: neighboring boat, in case the stricken whale should sound so deep as to
11182: threaten to carry off the entire line originally attached to the
11183: harpoon. In these instances, the whale of course is shifted like a mug
11184: of ale, as it were, from the one boat to the other; though the first
11185: boat always hovers at hand to assist its consort. Second: This
11186: arrangement is indispensable for common safety’s sake; for were the
11187: lower end of the line in any way attached to the boat, and were the
11188: whale then to run the line out to the end almost in a single, smoking
11189: minute as he sometimes does, he would not stop there, for the doomed
11190: boat would infallibly be dragged down after him into the profundity of
11191: the sea; and in that case no town-crier would ever find her again.
11192: 
11193: Before lowering the boat for the chase, the upper end of the line is
11194: taken aft from the tub, and passing round the loggerhead there, is
11195: again carried forward the entire length of the boat, resting crosswise
11196: upon the loom or handle of every man’s oar, so that it jogs against his
11197: wrist in rowing; and also passing between the men, as they alternately
11198: sit at the opposite gunwales, to the leaded chocks or grooves in the
11199: extreme pointed prow of the boat, where a wooden pin or skewer the size
11200: of a common quill, prevents it from slipping out. From the chocks it
11201: hangs in a slight festoon over the bows, and is then passed inside the
11202: boat again; and some ten or twenty fathoms (called box-line) being
11203: coiled upon the box in the bows, it continues its way to the gunwale
11204: still a little further aft, and is then attached to the short-warp—the
11205: rope which is immediately connected with the harpoon; but previous to
11206: that connexion, the short-warp goes through sundry mystifications too
11207: tedious to detail.
11208: 
11209: Thus the whale-line folds the whole boat in its complicated coils,
11210: twisting and writhing around it in almost every direction. All the
11211: oarsmen are involved in its perilous contortions; so that to the timid
11212: eye of the landsman, they seem as Indian jugglers, with the deadliest
11213: snakes sportively festooning their limbs. Nor can any son of mortal
11214: woman, for the first time, seat himself amid those hempen intricacies,
11215: and while straining his utmost at the oar, bethink him that at any
11216: unknown instant the harpoon may be darted, and all these horrible
11217: contortions be put in play like ringed lightnings; he cannot be thus
11218: circumstanced without a shudder that makes the very marrow in his bones
11219: to quiver in him like a shaken jelly. Yet habit—strange thing! what
11220: cannot habit accomplish?—Gayer sallies, more merry mirth, better jokes,
11221: and brighter repartees, you never heard over your mahogany, than you
11222: will hear over the half-inch white cedar of the whale-boat, when thus
11223: hung in hangman’s nooses; and, like the six burghers of Calais before
11224: King Edward, the six men composing the crew pull into the jaws of
11225: death, with a halter around every neck, as you may say.
11226: 
11227: Perhaps a very little thought will now enable you to account for those
11228: repeated whaling disasters—some few of which are casually chronicled—of
11229: this man or that man being taken out of the boat by the line, and lost.
11230: For, when the line is darting out, to be seated then in the boat, is
11231: like being seated in the midst of the manifold whizzings of a
11232: steam-engine in full play, when every flying beam, and shaft, and
11233: wheel, is grazing you. It is worse; for you cannot sit motionless in
11234: the heart of these perils, because the boat is rocking like a cradle,
11235: and you are pitched one way and the other, without the slightest
11236: warning; and only by a certain self-adjusting buoyancy and
11237: simultaneousness of volition and action, can you escape being made a
11238: Mazeppa of, and run away with where the all-seeing sun himself could
11239: never pierce you out.
11240: 
11241: Again: as the profound calm which only apparently precedes and
11242: prophesies of the storm, is perhaps more awful than the storm itself;
11243: for, indeed, the calm is but the wrapper and envelope of the storm; and
11244: contains it in itself, as the seemingly harmless rifle holds the fatal
11245: powder, and the ball, and the explosion; so the graceful repose of the
11246: line, as it silently serpentines about the oarsmen before being brought
11247: into actual play—this is a thing which carries more of true terror than
11248: any other aspect of this dangerous affair. But why say more? All men
11249: live enveloped in whale-lines. All are born with halters round their
11250: necks; but it is only when caught in the swift, sudden turn of death,
11251: that mortals realize the silent, subtle, ever-present perils of life.
11252: And if you be a philosopher, though seated in the whale-boat, you would
11253: not at heart feel one whit more of terror, than though seated before
11254: your evening fire with a poker, and not a harpoon, by your side.
11255: 
11256: 
11257: CHAPTER 61. Stubb Kills a Whale.
11258: 
11259: If to Starbuck the apparition of the Squid was a thing of portents, to
11260: Queequeg it was quite a different object.
11261: 
11262: “When you see him ’quid,” said the savage, honing his harpoon in the
11263: bow of his hoisted boat, “then you quick see him ’parm whale.”
11264: 
11265: The next day was exceedingly still and sultry, and with nothing special
11266: to engage them, the Pequod’s crew could hardly resist the spell of
11267: sleep induced by such a vacant sea. For this part of the Indian Ocean
11268: through which we then were voyaging is not what whalemen call a lively
11269: ground; that is, it affords fewer glimpses of porpoises, dolphins,
11270: flying-fish, and other vivacious denizens of more stirring waters, than
11271: those off the Rio de la Plata, or the in-shore ground off Peru.
11272: 
11273: It was my turn to stand at the foremast-head; and with my shoulders
11274: leaning against the slackened royal shrouds, to and fro I idly swayed
11275: in what seemed an enchanted air. No resolution could withstand it; in
11276: that dreamy mood losing all consciousness, at last my soul went out of
11277: my body; though my body still continued to sway as a pendulum will,
11278: long after the power which first moved it is withdrawn.
11279: 
11280: Ere forgetfulness altogether came over me, I had noticed that the
11281: seamen at the main and mizzen-mast-heads were already drowsy. So that
11282: at last all three of us lifelessly swung from the spars, and for every
11283: swing that we made there was a nod from below from the slumbering
11284: helmsman. The waves, too, nodded their indolent crests; and across the
11285: wide trance of the sea, east nodded to west, and the sun over all.
11286: 
11287: Suddenly bubbles seemed bursting beneath my closed eyes; like vices my
11288: hands grasped the shrouds; some invisible, gracious agency preserved
11289: me; with a shock I came back to life. And lo! close under our lee, not
11290: forty fathoms off, a gigantic Sperm Whale lay rolling in the water like
11291: the capsized hull of a frigate, his broad, glossy back, of an Ethiopian
11292: hue, glistening in the sun’s rays like a mirror. But lazily undulating
11293: in the trough of the sea, and ever and anon tranquilly spouting his
11294: vapory jet, the whale looked like a portly burgher smoking his pipe of
11295: a warm afternoon. But that pipe, poor whale, was thy last. As if struck
11296: by some enchanter’s wand, the sleepy ship and every sleeper in it all
11297: at once started into wakefulness; and more than a score of voices from
11298: all parts of the vessel, simultaneously with the three notes from
11299: aloft, shouted forth the accustomed cry, as the great fish slowly and
11300: regularly spouted the sparkling brine into the air.
11301: 
11302: “Clear away the boats! Luff!” cried Ahab. And obeying his own order, he
11303: dashed the helm down before the helmsman could handle the spokes.
11304: 
11305: The sudden exclamations of the crew must have alarmed the whale; and
11306: ere the boats were down, majestically turning, he swam away to the
11307: leeward, but with such a steady tranquillity, and making so few ripples
11308: as he swam, that thinking after all he might not as yet be alarmed,
11309: Ahab gave orders that not an oar should be used, and no man must speak
11310: but in whispers. So seated like Ontario Indians on the gunwales of the
11311: boats, we swiftly but silently paddled along; the calm not admitting of
11312: the noiseless sails being set. Presently, as we thus glided in chase,
11313: the monster perpendicularly flitted his tail forty feet into the air,
11314: and then sank out of sight like a tower swallowed up.
11315: 
11316: “There go flukes!” was the cry, an announcement immediately followed by
11317: Stubb’s producing his match and igniting his pipe, for now a respite
11318: was granted. After the full interval of his sounding had elapsed, the
11319: whale rose again, and being now in advance of the smoker’s boat, and
11320: much nearer to it than to any of the others, Stubb counted upon the
11321: honor of the capture. It was obvious, now, that the whale had at length
11322: become aware of his pursuers. All silence of cautiousness was therefore
11323: no longer of use. Paddles were dropped, and oars came loudly into play.
11324: And still puffing at his pipe, Stubb cheered on his crew to the
11325: assault.
11326: 
11327: Yes, a mighty change had come over the fish. All alive to his jeopardy,
11328: he was going “head out”; that part obliquely projecting from the mad
11329: yeast which he brewed.*
11330: 
11331: *It will be seen in some other place of what a very light substance the
11332: entire interior of the sperm whale’s enormous head consists. Though
11333: apparently the most massive, it is by far the most buoyant part about
11334: him. So that with ease he elevates it in the air, and invariably does
11335: so when going at his utmost speed. Besides, such is the breadth of the
11336: upper part of the front of his head, and such the tapering cut-water
11337: formation of the lower part, that by obliquely elevating his head, he
11338: thereby may be said to transform himself from a bluff-bowed sluggish
11339: galliot into a sharppointed New York pilot-boat.
11340: 
11341: “Start her, start her, my men! Don’t hurry yourselves; take plenty of
11342: time—but start her; start her like thunder-claps, that’s all,” cried
11343: Stubb, spluttering out the smoke as he spoke. “Start her, now; give ’em
11344: the long and strong stroke, Tashtego. Start her, Tash, my boy—start
11345: her, all; but keep cool, keep cool—cucumbers is the word—easy,
11346: easy—only start her like grim death and grinning devils, and raise the
11347: buried dead perpendicular out of their graves, boys—that’s all. Start
11348: her!”
11349: 
11350: “Woo-hoo! Wa-hee!” screamed the Gay-Header in reply, raising some old
11351: war-whoop to the skies; as every oarsman in the strained boat
11352: involuntarily bounced forward with the one tremendous leading stroke
11353: which the eager Indian gave.
11354: 
11355: But his wild screams were answered by others quite as wild. “Kee-hee!
11356: Kee-hee!” yelled Daggoo, straining forwards and backwards on his seat,
11357: like a pacing tiger in his cage.
11358: 
11359: “Ka-la! Koo-loo!” howled Queequeg, as if smacking his lips over a
11360: mouthful of Grenadier’s steak. And thus with oars and yells the keels
11361: cut the sea. Meanwhile, Stubb retaining his place in the van, still
11362: encouraged his men to the onset, all the while puffing the smoke from
11363: his mouth. Like desperadoes they tugged and they strained, till the
11364: welcome cry was heard—“Stand up, Tashtego!—give it to him!” The harpoon
11365: was hurled. “Stern all!” The oarsmen backed water; the same moment
11366: something went hot and hissing along every one of their wrists. It was
11367: the magical line. An instant before, Stubb had swiftly caught two
11368: additional turns with it round the loggerhead, whence, by reason of its
11369: increased rapid circlings, a hempen blue smoke now jetted up and
11370: mingled with the steady fumes from his pipe. As the line passed round
11371: and round the loggerhead; so also, just before reaching that point, it
11372: blisteringly passed through and through both of Stubb’s hands, from
11373: which the hand-cloths, or squares of quilted canvas sometimes worn at
11374: these times, had accidentally dropped. It was like holding an enemy’s
11375: sharp two-edged sword by the blade, and that enemy all the time
11376: striving to wrest it out of your clutch.
11377: 
11378: “Wet the line! wet the line!” cried Stubb to the tub oarsman (him
11379: seated by the tub) who, snatching off his hat, dashed sea-water into
11380: it.* More turns were taken, so that the line began holding its place.
11381: The boat now flew through the boiling water like a shark all fins.
11382: Stubb and Tashtego here changed places—stem for stern—a staggering
11383: business truly in that rocking commotion.
11384: 
11385: *Partly to show the indispensableness of this act, it may here be
11386: stated, that, in the old Dutch fishery, a mop was used to dash the
11387: running line with water; in many other ships, a wooden piggin, or
11388: bailer, is set apart for that purpose. Your hat, however, is the most
11389: convenient.
11390: 
11391: From the vibrating line extending the entire length of the upper part
11392: of the boat, and from its now being more tight than a harpstring, you
11393: would have thought the craft had two keels—one cleaving the water, the
11394: other the air—as the boat churned on through both opposing elements at
11395: once. A continual cascade played at the bows; a ceaseless whirling eddy
11396: in her wake; and, at the slightest motion from within, even but of a
11397: little finger, the vibrating, cracking craft canted over her spasmodic
11398: gunwale into the sea. Thus they rushed; each man with might and main
11399: clinging to his seat, to prevent being tossed to the foam; and the tall
11400: form of Tashtego at the steering oar crouching almost double, in order
11401: to bring down his centre of gravity. Whole Atlantics and Pacifics
11402: seemed passed as they shot on their way, till at length the whale
11403: somewhat slackened his flight.
11404: 
11405: “Haul in—haul in!” cried Stubb to the bowsman! and, facing round
11406: towards the whale, all hands began pulling the boat up to him, while
11407: yet the boat was being towed on. Soon ranging up by his flank, Stubb,
11408: firmly planting his knee in the clumsy cleat, darted dart after dart
11409: into the flying fish; at the word of command, the boat alternately
11410: sterning out of the way of the whale’s horrible wallow, and then
11411: ranging up for another fling.
11412: 
11413: The red tide now poured from all sides of the monster like brooks down
11414: a hill. His tormented body rolled not in brine but in blood, which
11415: bubbled and seethed for furlongs behind in their wake. The slanting sun
11416: playing upon this crimson pond in the sea, sent back its reflection
11417: into every face, so that they all glowed to each other like red men.
11418: And all the while, jet after jet of white smoke was agonizingly shot
11419: from the spiracle of the whale, and vehement puff after puff from the
11420: mouth of the excited headsman; as at every dart, hauling in upon his
11421: crooked lance (by the line attached to it), Stubb straightened it again
11422: and again, by a few rapid blows against the gunwale, then again and
11423: again sent it into the whale.
11424: 
11425: “Pull up—pull up!” he now cried to the bowsman, as the waning whale
11426: relaxed in his wrath. “Pull up!—close to!” and the boat ranged along
11427: the fish’s flank. When reaching far over the bow, Stubb slowly churned
11428: his long sharp lance into the fish, and kept it there, carefully
11429: churning and churning, as if cautiously seeking to feel after some gold
11430: watch that the whale might have swallowed, and which he was fearful of
11431: breaking ere he could hook it out. But that gold watch he sought was
11432: the innermost life of the fish. And now it is struck; for, starting
11433: from his trance into that unspeakable thing called his “flurry,” the
11434: monster horribly wallowed in his blood, overwrapped himself in
11435: impenetrable, mad, boiling spray, so that the imperilled craft,
11436: instantly dropping astern, had much ado blindly to struggle out from
11437: that phrensied twilight into the clear air of the day.
11438: 
11439: And now abating in his flurry, the whale once more rolled out into
11440: view; surging from side to side; spasmodically dilating and contracting
11441: his spout-hole, with sharp, cracking, agonized respirations. At last,
11442: gush after gush of clotted red gore, as if it had been the purple lees
11443: of red wine, shot into the frighted air; and falling back again, ran
11444: dripping down his motionless flanks into the sea. His heart had burst!
11445: 
11446: “He’s dead, Mr. Stubb,” said Daggoo.
11447: 
11448: “Yes; both pipes smoked out!” and withdrawing his own from his mouth,
11449: Stubb scattered the dead ashes over the water; and, for a moment, stood
11450: thoughtfully eyeing the vast corpse he had made.
11451: 
11452: 
11453: CHAPTER 62. The Dart.
11454: 
11455: A word concerning an incident in the last chapter.
11456: 
11457: According to the invariable usage of the fishery, the whale-boat pushes
11458: off from the ship, with the headsman or whale-killer as temporary
11459: steersman, and the harpooneer or whale-fastener pulling the foremost
11460: oar, the one known as the harpooneer-oar. Now it needs a strong,
11461: nervous arm to strike the first iron into the fish; for often, in what
11462: is called a long dart, the heavy implement has to be flung to the
11463: distance of twenty or thirty feet. But however prolonged and exhausting
11464: the chase, the harpooneer is expected to pull his oar meanwhile to the
11465: uttermost; indeed, he is expected to set an example of superhuman
11466: activity to the rest, not only by incredible rowing, but by repeated
11467: loud and intrepid exclamations; and what it is to keep shouting at the
11468: top of one’s compass, while all the other muscles are strained and half
11469: started—what that is none know but those who have tried it. For one, I
11470: cannot bawl very heartily and work very recklessly at one and the same
11471: time. In this straining, bawling state, then, with his back to the
11472: fish, all at once the exhausted harpooneer hears the exciting
11473: cry—“Stand up, and give it to him!” He now has to drop and secure his
11474: oar, turn round on his centre half way, seize his harpoon from the
11475: crotch, and with what little strength may remain, he essays to pitch it
11476: somehow into the whale. No wonder, taking the whole fleet of whalemen
11477: in a body, that out of fifty fair chances for a dart, not five are
11478: successful; no wonder that so many hapless harpooneers are madly cursed
11479: and disrated; no wonder that some of them actually burst their
11480: blood-vessels in the boat; no wonder that some sperm whalemen are
11481: absent four years with four barrels; no wonder that to many ship
11482: owners, whaling is but a losing concern; for it is the harpooneer that
11483: makes the voyage, and if you take the breath out of his body how can
11484: you expect to find it there when most wanted!
11485: 
11486: Again, if the dart be successful, then at the second critical instant,
11487: that is, when the whale starts to run, the boatheader and harpooneer
11488: likewise start to running fore and aft, to the imminent jeopardy of
11489: themselves and every one else. It is then they change places; and the
11490: headsman, the chief officer of the little craft, takes his proper
11491: station in the bows of the boat.
11492: 
11493: Now, I care not who maintains the contrary, but all this is both
11494: foolish and unnecessary. The headsman should stay in the bows from
11495: first to last; he should both dart the harpoon and the lance, and no
11496: rowing whatever should be expected of him, except under circumstances
11497: obvious to any fisherman. I know that this would sometimes involve a
11498: slight loss of speed in the chase; but long experience in various
11499: whalemen of more than one nation has convinced me that in the vast
11500: majority of failures in the fishery, it has not by any means been so
11501: much the speed of the whale as the before described exhaustion of the
11502: harpooneer that has caused them.
11503: 
11504: To insure the greatest efficiency in the dart, the harpooneers of this
11505: world must start to their feet from out of idleness, and not from out
11506: of toil.
11507: 
11508: 
11509: CHAPTER 63. The Crotch.
11510: 
11511: Out of the trunk, the branches grow; out of them, the twigs. So, in
11512: productive subjects, grow the chapters.
11513: 
11514: The crotch alluded to on a previous page deserves independent mention.
11515: It is a notched stick of a peculiar form, some two feet in length,
11516: which is perpendicularly inserted into the starboard gunwale near the
11517: bow, for the purpose of furnishing a rest for the wooden extremity of
11518: the harpoon, whose other naked, barbed end slopingly projects from the
11519: prow. Thereby the weapon is instantly at hand to its hurler, who
11520: snatches it up as readily from its rest as a backwoodsman swings his
11521: rifle from the wall. It is customary to have two harpoons reposing in
11522: the crotch, respectively called the first and second irons.
11523: 
11524: But these two harpoons, each by its own cord, are both connected with
11525: the line; the object being this: to dart them both, if possible, one
11526: instantly after the other into the same whale; so that if, in the
11527: coming drag, one should draw out, the other may still retain a hold. It
11528: is a doubling of the chances. But it very often happens that owing to
11529: the instantaneous, violent, convulsive running of the whale upon
11530: receiving the first iron, it becomes impossible for the harpooneer,
11531: however lightning-like in his movements, to pitch the second iron into
11532: him. Nevertheless, as the second iron is already connected with the
11533: line, and the line is running, hence that weapon must, at all events,
11534: be anticipatingly tossed out of the boat, somehow and somewhere; else
11535: the most terrible jeopardy would involve all hands. Tumbled into the
11536: water, it accordingly is in such cases; the spare coils of box line
11537: (mentioned in a preceding chapter) making this feat, in most instances,
11538: prudently practicable. But this critical act is not always unattended
11539: with the saddest and most fatal casualties.
11540: 
11541: Furthermore: you must know that when the second iron is thrown
11542: overboard, it thenceforth becomes a dangling, sharp-edged terror,
11543: skittishly curvetting about both boat and whale, entangling the lines,
11544: or cutting them, and making a prodigious sensation in all directions.
11545: Nor, in general, is it possible to secure it again until the whale is
11546: fairly captured and a corpse.
11547: 
11548: Consider, now, how it must be in the case of four boats all engaging
11549: one unusually strong, active, and knowing whale; when owing to these
11550: qualities in him, as well as to the thousand concurring accidents of
11551: such an audacious enterprise, eight or ten loose second irons may be
11552: simultaneously dangling about him. For, of course, each boat is
11553: supplied with several harpoons to bend on to the line should the first
11554: one be ineffectually darted without recovery. All these particulars are
11555: faithfully narrated here, as they will not fail to elucidate several
11556: most important, however intricate passages, in scenes hereafter to be
11557: painted.
11558: 
11559: 
11560: CHAPTER 64. Stubb’s Supper.
11561: 
11562: Stubb’s whale had been killed some distance from the ship. It was a
11563: calm; so, forming a tandem of three boats, we commenced the slow
11564: business of towing the trophy to the Pequod. And now, as we eighteen
11565: men with our thirty-six arms, and one hundred and eighty thumbs and
11566: fingers, slowly toiled hour after hour upon that inert, sluggish corpse
11567: in the sea; and it seemed hardly to budge at all, except at long
11568: intervals; good evidence was hereby furnished of the enormousness of
11569: the mass we moved. For, upon the great canal of Hang-Ho, or whatever
11570: they call it, in China, four or five laborers on the foot-path will
11571: draw a bulky freighted junk at the rate of a mile an hour; but this
11572: grand argosy we towed heavily forged along, as if laden with pig-lead
11573: in bulk.
11574: 
11575: Darkness came on; but three lights up and down in the Pequod’s
11576: main-rigging dimly guided our way; till drawing nearer we saw Ahab
11577: dropping one of several more lanterns over the bulwarks. Vacantly
11578: eyeing the heaving whale for a moment, he issued the usual orders for
11579: securing it for the night, and then handing his lantern to a seaman,
11580: went his way into the cabin, and did not come forward again until
11581: morning.
11582: 
11583: Though, in overseeing the pursuit of this whale, Captain Ahab had
11584: evinced his customary activity, to call it so; yet now that the
11585: creature was dead, some vague dissatisfaction, or impatience, or
11586: despair, seemed working in him; as if the sight of that dead body
11587: reminded him that Moby Dick was yet to be slain; and though a thousand
11588: other whales were brought to his ship, all that would not one jot
11589: advance his grand, monomaniac object. Very soon you would have thought
11590: from the sound on the Pequod’s decks, that all hands were preparing to
11591: cast anchor in the deep; for heavy chains are being dragged along the
11592: deck, and thrust rattling out of the port-holes. But by those clanking
11593: links, the vast corpse itself, not the ship, is to be moored. Tied by
11594: the head to the stern, and by the tail to the bows, the whale now lies
11595: with its black hull close to the vessel’s and seen through the darkness
11596: of the night, which obscured the spars and rigging aloft, the two—ship
11597: and whale, seemed yoked together like colossal bullocks, whereof one
11598: reclines while the other remains standing.*
11599: 
11600: *A little item may as well be related here. The strongest and most
11601: reliable hold which the ship has upon the whale when moored alongside,
11602: is by the flukes or tail; and as from its greater density that part is
11603: relatively heavier than any other (excepting the side-fins), its
11604: flexibility even in death, causes it to sink low beneath the surface;
11605: so that with the hand you cannot get at it from the boat, in order to
11606: put the chain round it. But this difficulty is ingeniously overcome: a
11607: small, strong line is prepared with a wooden float at its outer end,
11608: and a weight in its middle, while the other end is secured to the ship.
11609: By adroit management the wooden float is made to rise on the other side
11610: of the mass, so that now having girdled the whale, the chain is readily
11611: made to follow suit; and being slipped along the body, is at last
11612: locked fast round the smallest part of the tail, at the point of
11613: junction with its broad flukes or lobes.
11614: 
11615: If moody Ahab was now all quiescence, at least so far as could be known
11616: on deck, Stubb, his second mate, flushed with conquest, betrayed an
11617: unusual but still good-natured excitement. Such an unwonted bustle was
11618: he in that the staid Starbuck, his official superior, quietly resigned
11619: to him for the time the sole management of affairs. One small, helping
11620: cause of all this liveliness in Stubb, was soon made strangely
11621: manifest. Stubb was a high liver; he was somewhat intemperately fond of
11622: the whale as a flavorish thing to his palate.
11623: 
11624: “A steak, a steak, ere I sleep! You, Daggoo! overboard you go, and cut
11625: me one from his small!”
11626: 
11627: Here be it known, that though these wild fishermen do not, as a general
11628: thing, and according to the great military maxim, make the enemy defray
11629: the current expenses of the war (at least before realizing the proceeds
11630: of the voyage), yet now and then you find some of these Nantucketers
11631: who have a genuine relish for that particular part of the Sperm Whale
11632: designated by Stubb; comprising the tapering extremity of the body.
11633: 
11634: About midnight that steak was cut and cooked; and lighted by two
11635: lanterns of sperm oil, Stubb stoutly stood up to his spermaceti supper
11636: at the capstan-head, as if that capstan were a sideboard. Nor was Stubb
11637: the only banqueter on whale’s flesh that night. Mingling their
11638: mumblings with his own mastications, thousands on thousands of sharks,
11639: swarming round the dead leviathan, smackingly feasted on its fatness.
11640: The few sleepers below in their bunks were often startled by the sharp
11641: slapping of their tails against the hull, within a few inches of the
11642: sleepers’ hearts. Peering over the side you could just see them (as
11643: before you heard them) wallowing in the sullen, black waters, and
11644: turning over on their backs as they scooped out huge globular pieces of
11645: the whale of the bigness of a human head. This particular feat of the
11646: shark seems all but miraculous. How at such an apparently unassailable
11647: surface, they contrive to gouge out such symmetrical mouthfuls, remains
11648: a part of the universal problem of all things. The mark they thus leave
11649: on the whale, may best be likened to the hollow made by a carpenter in
11650: countersinking for a screw.
11651: 
11652: Though amid all the smoking horror and diabolism of a sea-fight, sharks
11653: will be seen longingly gazing up to the ship’s decks, like hungry dogs
11654: round a table where red meat is being carved, ready to bolt down every
11655: killed man that is tossed to them; and though, while the valiant
11656: butchers over the deck-table are thus cannibally carving each other’s
11657: live meat with carving-knives all gilded and tasselled, the sharks,
11658: also, with their jewel-hilted mouths, are quarrelsomely carving away
11659: under the table at the dead meat; and though, were you to turn the
11660: whole affair upside down, it would still be pretty much the same thing,
11661: that is to say, a shocking sharkish business enough for all parties;
11662: and though sharks also are the invariable outriders of all slave ships
11663: crossing the Atlantic, systematically trotting alongside, to be handy
11664: in case a parcel is to be carried anywhere, or a dead slave to be
11665: decently buried; and though one or two other like instances might be
11666: set down, touching the set terms, places, and occasions, when sharks do
11667: most socially congregate, and most hilariously feast; yet is there no
11668: conceivable time or occasion when you will find them in such countless
11669: numbers, and in gayer or more jovial spirits, than around a dead sperm
11670: whale, moored by night to a whaleship at sea. If you have never seen
11671: that sight, then suspend your decision about the propriety of
11672: devil-worship, and the expediency of conciliating the devil.
11673: 
11674: But, as yet, Stubb heeded not the mumblings of the banquet that was
11675: going on so nigh him, no more than the sharks heeded the smacking of
11676: his own epicurean lips.
11677: 
11678: “Cook, cook!—where’s that old Fleece?” he cried at length, widening his
11679: legs still further, as if to form a more secure base for his supper;
11680: and, at the same time darting his fork into the dish, as if stabbing
11681: with his lance; “cook, you cook!—sail this way, cook!”
11682:
