11683: The old black, not in any very high glee at having been previously
11684: roused from his warm hammock at a most unseasonable hour, came
11685: shambling along from his galley, for, like many old blacks, there was
11686: something the matter with his knee-pans, which he did not keep well
11687: scoured like his other pans; this old Fleece, as they called him, came
11688: shuffling and limping along, assisting his step with his tongs, which,
11689: after a clumsy fashion, were made of straightened iron hoops; this old
11690: Ebony floundered along, and in obedience to the word of command, came
11691: to a dead stop on the opposite side of Stubb’s sideboard; when, with
11692: both hands folded before him, and resting on his two-legged cane, he
11693: bowed his arched back still further over, at the same time sideways
11694: inclining his head, so as to bring his best ear into play.
11695: 
11696: “Cook,” said Stubb, rapidly lifting a rather reddish morsel to his
11697: mouth, “don’t you think this steak is rather overdone? You’ve been
11698: beating this steak too much, cook; it’s too tender. Don’t I always say
11699: that to be good, a whale-steak must be tough? There are those sharks
11700: now over the side, don’t you see they prefer it tough and rare? What a
11701: shindy they are kicking up! Cook, go and talk to ’em; tell ’em they are
11702: welcome to help themselves civilly, and in moderation, but they must
11703: keep quiet. Blast me, if I can hear my own voice. Away, cook, and
11704: deliver my message. Here, take this lantern,” snatching one from his
11705: sideboard; “now then, go and preach to ’em!”
11706: 
11707: Sullenly taking the offered lantern, old Fleece limped across the deck
11708: to the bulwarks; and then, with one hand dropping his light low over
11709: the sea, so as to get a good view of his congregation, with the other
11710: hand he solemnly flourished his tongs, and leaning far over the side in
11711: a mumbling voice began addressing the sharks, while Stubb, softly
11712: crawling behind, overheard all that was said.
11713: 
11714: “Fellow-critters: I’se ordered here to say dat you must stop dat dam
11715: noise dare. You hear? Stop dat dam smackin’ ob de lip! Massa Stubb say
11716: dat you can fill your dam bellies up to de hatchings, but by Gor! you
11717: must stop dat dam racket!”
11718: 
11719: “Cook,” here interposed Stubb, accompanying the word with a sudden slap
11720: on the shoulder,—“Cook! why, damn your eyes, you mustn’t swear that way
11721: when you’re preaching. That’s no way to convert sinners, cook!”
11722: 
11723: “Who dat? Den preach to him yourself,” sullenly turning to go.
11724: 
11725: “No, cook; go on, go on.”
11726: 
11727: “Well, den, Belubed fellow-critters:”—
11728: 
11729: “Right!” exclaimed Stubb, approvingly, “coax ’em to it; try that,” and
11730: Fleece continued.
11731: 
11732: “Do you is all sharks, and by natur wery woracious, yet I zay to you,
11733: fellow-critters, dat dat woraciousness—’top dat dam slappin’ ob de
11734: tail! How you tink to hear, spose you keep up such a dam slappin’ and
11735: bitin’ dare?”
11736: 
11737: “Cook,” cried Stubb, collaring him, “I won’t have that swearing. Talk
11738: to ’em gentlemanly.”
11739: 
11740: Once more the sermon proceeded.
11741: 
11742: “Your woraciousness, fellow-critters, I don’t blame ye so much for; dat
11743: is natur, and can’t be helped; but to gobern dat wicked natur, dat is
11744: de pint. You is sharks, sartin; but if you gobern de shark in you, why
11745: den you be angel; for all angel is not’ing more dan de shark well
11746: goberned. Now, look here, bred’ren, just try wonst to be cibil, a
11747: helping yourselbs from dat whale. Don’t be tearin’ de blubber out your
11748: neighbour’s mout, I say. Is not one shark dood right as toder to dat
11749: whale? And, by Gor, none on you has de right to dat whale; dat whale
11750: belong to some one else. I know some o’ you has berry brig mout,
11751: brigger dan oders; but den de brig mouts sometimes has de small
11752: bellies; so dat de brigness of de mout is not to swaller wid, but to
11753: bit off de blubber for de small fry ob sharks, dat can’t get into de
11754: scrouge to help demselves.”
11755: 
11756: “Well done, old Fleece!” cried Stubb, “that’s Christianity; go on.”
11757: 
11758: “No use goin’ on; de dam willains will keep a scougin’ and slappin’
11759: each oder, Massa Stubb; dey don’t hear one word; no use a-preachin’ to
11760: such dam g’uttons as you call ’em, till dare bellies is full, and dare
11761: bellies is bottomless; and when dey do get ’em full, dey wont hear you
11762: den; for den dey sink in de sea, go fast to sleep on de coral, and
11763: can’t hear not’ing at all, no more, for eber and eber.”
11764: 
11765: “Upon my soul, I am about of the same opinion; so give the benediction,
11766: Fleece, and I’ll away to my supper.”
11767: 
11768: Upon this, Fleece, holding both hands over the fishy mob, raised his
11769: shrill voice, and cried—
11770: 
11771: “Cussed fellow-critters! Kick up de damndest row as ever you can; fill
11772: your dam’ bellies ’till dey bust—and den die.”
11773: 
11774: “Now, cook,” said Stubb, resuming his supper at the capstan; “stand
11775: just where you stood before, there, over against me, and pay particular
11776: attention.”
11777: 
11778: “All dention,” said Fleece, again stooping over upon his tongs in the
11779: desired position.
11780: 
11781: “Well,” said Stubb, helping himself freely meanwhile; “I shall now go
11782: back to the subject of this steak. In the first place, how old are you,
11783: cook?”
11784: 
11785: “What dat do wid de ’teak,” said the old black, testily.
11786: 
11787: “Silence! How old are you, cook?”
11788: 
11789: “’Bout ninety, dey say,” he gloomily muttered.
11790: 
11791: “And you have lived in this world hard upon one hundred years, cook,
11792: and don’t know yet how to cook a whale-steak?” rapidly bolting another
11793: mouthful at the last word, so that morsel seemed a continuation of the
11794: question. “Where were you born, cook?”
11795: 
11796: “’Hind de hatchway, in ferry-boat, goin’ ober de Roanoke.”
11797: 
11798: “Born in a ferry-boat! That’s queer, too. But I want to know what
11799: country you were born in, cook!”
11800: 
11801: “Didn’t I say de Roanoke country?” he cried sharply.
11802: 
11803: “No, you didn’t, cook; but I’ll tell you what I’m coming to, cook. You
11804: must go home and be born over again; you don’t know how to cook a
11805: whale-steak yet.”
11806: 
11807: “Bress my soul, if I cook noder one,” he growled, angrily, turning
11808: round to depart.
11809: 
11810: “Come back, cook;—here, hand me those tongs;—now take that bit of steak
11811: there, and tell me if you think that steak cooked as it should be? Take
11812: it, I say”—holding the tongs towards him—“take it, and taste it.”
11813: 
11814: Faintly smacking his withered lips over it for a moment, the old negro
11815: muttered, “Best cooked ’teak I eber taste; joosy, berry joosy.”
11816: 
11817: “Cook,” said Stubb, squaring himself once more; “do you belong to the
11818: church?”
11819: 
11820: “Passed one once in Cape-Down,” said the old man sullenly.
11821: 
11822: “And you have once in your life passed a holy church in Cape-Town,
11823: where you doubtless overheard a holy parson addressing his hearers as
11824: his beloved fellow-creatures, have you, cook! And yet you come here,
11825: and tell me such a dreadful lie as you did just now, eh?” said Stubb.
11826: “Where do you expect to go to, cook?”
11827: 
11828: “Go to bed berry soon,” he mumbled, half-turning as he spoke.
11829: 
11830: “Avast! heave to! I mean when you die, cook. It’s an awful question.
11831: Now what’s your answer?”
11832: 
11833: “When dis old brack man dies,” said the negro slowly, changing his
11834: whole air and demeanor, “he hisself won’t go nowhere; but some bressed
11835: angel will come and fetch him.”
11836: 
11837: “Fetch him? How? In a coach and four, as they fetched Elijah? And fetch
11838: him where?”
11839: 
11840: “Up dere,” said Fleece, holding his tongs straight over his head, and
11841: keeping it there very solemnly.
11842: 
11843: “So, then, you expect to go up into our main-top, do you, cook, when
11844: you are dead? But don’t you know the higher you climb, the colder it
11845: gets? Main-top, eh?”
11846: 
11847: “Didn’t say dat t’all,” said Fleece, again in the sulks.
11848: 
11849: “You said up there, didn’t you? and now look yourself, and see where
11850: your tongs are pointing. But, perhaps you expect to get into heaven by
11851: crawling through the lubber’s hole, cook; but, no, no, cook, you don’t
11852: get there, except you go the regular way, round by the rigging. It’s a
11853: ticklish business, but must be done, or else it’s no go. But none of us
11854: are in heaven yet. Drop your tongs, cook, and hear my orders. Do ye
11855: hear? Hold your hat in one hand, and clap t’other a’top of your heart,
11856: when I’m giving my orders, cook. What! that your heart, there?—that’s
11857: your gizzard! Aloft! aloft!—that’s it—now you have it. Hold it there
11858: now, and pay attention.”
11859: 
11860: “All ’dention,” said the old black, with both hands placed as desired,
11861: vainly wriggling his grizzled head, as if to get both ears in front at
11862: one and the same time.
11863: 
11864: “Well then, cook, you see this whale-steak of yours was so very bad,
11865: that I have put it out of sight as soon as possible; you see that,
11866: don’t you? Well, for the future, when you cook another whale-steak for
11867: my private table here, the capstan, I’ll tell you what to do so as not
11868: to spoil it by overdoing. Hold the steak in one hand, and show a live
11869: coal to it with the other; that done, dish it; d’ye hear? And now
11870: to-morrow, cook, when we are cutting in the fish, be sure you stand by
11871: to get the tips of his fins; have them put in pickle. As for the ends
11872: of the flukes, have them soused, cook. There, now ye may go.”
11873: 
11874: But Fleece had hardly got three paces off, when he was recalled.
11875: 
11876: “Cook, give me cutlets for supper to-morrow night in the mid-watch.
11877: D’ye hear? away you sail, then.—Halloa! stop! make a bow before you
11878: go.—Avast heaving again! Whale-balls for breakfast—don’t forget.”
11879: 
11880: “Wish, by gor! whale eat him, ’stead of him eat whale. I’m bressed if
11881: he ain’t more of shark dan Massa Shark hisself,” muttered the old man,
11882: limping away; with which sage ejaculation he went to his hammock.
11883: 
11884: 
11885: CHAPTER 65. The Whale as a Dish.
11886: 
11887: That mortal man should feed upon the creature that feeds his lamp, and,
11888: like Stubb, eat him by his own light, as you may say; this seems so
11889: outlandish a thing that one must needs go a little into the history and
11890: philosophy of it.
11891: 
11892: It is upon record, that three centuries ago the tongue of the Right
11893: Whale was esteemed a great delicacy in France, and commanded large
11894: prices there. Also, that in Henry VIIIth’s time, a certain cook of the
11895: court obtained a handsome reward for inventing an admirable sauce to be
11896: eaten with barbacued porpoises, which, you remember, are a species of
11897: whale. Porpoises, indeed, are to this day considered fine eating. The
11898: meat is made into balls about the size of billiard balls, and being
11899: well seasoned and spiced might be taken for turtle-balls or veal balls.
11900: The old monks of Dunfermline were very fond of them. They had a great
11901: porpoise grant from the crown.
11902: 
11903: The fact is, that among his hunters at least, the whale would by all
11904: hands be considered a noble dish, were there not so much of him; but
11905: when you come to sit down before a meat-pie nearly one hundred feet
11906: long, it takes away your appetite. Only the most unprejudiced of men
11907: like Stubb, nowadays partake of cooked whales; but the Esquimaux are
11908: not so fastidious. We all know how they live upon whales, and have rare
11909: old vintages of prime old train oil. Zogranda, one of their most famous
11910: doctors, recommends strips of blubber for infants, as being exceedingly
11911: juicy and nourishing. And this reminds me that certain Englishmen, who
11912: long ago were accidentally left in Greenland by a whaling vessel—that
11913: these men actually lived for several months on the mouldy scraps of
11914: whales which had been left ashore after trying out the blubber. Among
11915: the Dutch whalemen these scraps are called “fritters”; which, indeed,
11916: they greatly resemble, being brown and crisp, and smelling something
11917: like old Amsterdam housewives’ dough-nuts or oly-cooks, when fresh.
11918: They have such an eatable look that the most self-denying stranger can
11919: hardly keep his hands off.
11920: 
11921: But what further depreciates the whale as a civilized dish, is his
11922: exceeding richness. He is the great prize ox of the sea, too fat to be
11923: delicately good. Look at his hump, which would be as fine eating as the
11924: buffalo’s (which is esteemed a rare dish), were it not such a solid
11925: pyramid of fat. But the spermaceti itself, how bland and creamy that
11926: is; like the transparent, half-jellied, white meat of a cocoanut in the
11927: third month of its growth, yet far too rich to supply a substitute for
11928: butter. Nevertheless, many whalemen have a method of absorbing it into
11929: some other substance, and then partaking of it. In the long try watches
11930: of the night it is a common thing for the seamen to dip their
11931: ship-biscuit into the huge oil-pots and let them fry there awhile. Many
11932: a good supper have I thus made.
11933: 
11934: In the case of a small Sperm Whale the brains are accounted a fine
11935: dish. The casket of the skull is broken into with an axe, and the two
11936: plump, whitish lobes being withdrawn (precisely resembling two large
11937: puddings), they are then mixed with flour, and cooked into a most
11938: delectable mess, in flavor somewhat resembling calves’ head, which is
11939: quite a dish among some epicures; and every one knows that some young
11940: bucks among the epicures, by continually dining upon calves’ brains, by
11941: and by get to have a little brains of their own, so as to be able to
11942: tell a calf’s head from their own heads; which, indeed, requires
11943: uncommon discrimination. And that is the reason why a young buck with
11944: an intelligent looking calf’s head before him, is somehow one of the
11945: saddest sights you can see. The head looks a sort of reproachfully at
11946: him, with an “Et tu Brute!” expression.
11947: 
11948: It is not, perhaps, entirely because the whale is so excessively
11949: unctuous that landsmen seem to regard the eating of him with
11950: abhorrence; that appears to result, in some way, from the consideration
11951: before mentioned: _i.e._ that a man should eat a newly murdered thing
11952: of the sea, and eat it too by its own light. But no doubt the first man
11953: that ever murdered an ox was regarded as a murderer; perhaps he was
11954: hung; and if he had been put on his trial by oxen, he certainly would
11955: have been; and he certainly deserved it if any murderer does. Go to the
11956: meat-market of a Saturday night and see the crowds of live bipeds
11957: staring up at the long rows of dead quadrupeds. Does not that sight
11958: take a tooth out of the cannibal’s jaw? Cannibals? who is not a
11959: cannibal? I tell you it will be more tolerable for the Fejee that
11960: salted down a lean missionary in his cellar against a coming famine; it
11961: will be more tolerable for that provident Fejee, I say, in the day of
11962: judgment, than for thee, civilized and enlightened gourmand, who
11963: nailest geese to the ground and feastest on their bloated livers in thy
11964: paté-de-foie-gras.
11965: 
11966: But Stubb, he eats the whale by its own light, does he? and that is
11967: adding insult to injury, is it? Look at your knife-handle, there, my
11968: civilized and enlightened gourmand dining off that roast beef, what is
11969: that handle made of?—what but the bones of the brother of the very ox
11970: you are eating? And what do you pick your teeth with, after devouring
11971: that fat goose? With a feather of the same fowl. And with what quill
11972: did the Secretary of the Society for the Suppression of Cruelty to
11973: Ganders formally indite his circulars? It is only within the last month
11974: or two that that society passed a resolution to patronize nothing but
11975: steel pens.
11976: 
11977: 
11978: CHAPTER 66. The Shark Massacre.
11979: 
11980: When in the Southern Fishery, a captured Sperm Whale, after long and
11981: weary toil, is brought alongside late at night, it is not, as a general
11982: thing at least, customary to proceed at once to the business of cutting
11983: him in. For that business is an exceedingly laborious one; is not very
11984: soon completed; and requires all hands to set about it. Therefore, the
11985: common usage is to take in all sail; lash the helm a’lee; and then send
11986: every one below to his hammock till daylight, with the reservation
11987: that, until that time, anchor-watches shall be kept; that is, two and
11988: two for an hour, each couple, the crew in rotation shall mount the deck
11989: to see that all goes well.
11990: 
11991: But sometimes, especially upon the Line in the Pacific, this plan will
11992: not answer at all; because such incalculable hosts of sharks gather
11993: round the moored carcase, that were he left so for six hours, say, on a
11994: stretch, little more than the skeleton would be visible by morning. In
11995: most other parts of the ocean, however, where these fish do not so
11996: largely abound, their wondrous voracity can be at times considerably
11997: diminished, by vigorously stirring them up with sharp whaling-spades, a
11998: procedure notwithstanding, which, in some instances, only seems to
11999: tickle them into still greater activity. But it was not thus in the
12000: present case with the Pequod’s sharks; though, to be sure, any man
12001: unaccustomed to such sights, to have looked over her side that night,
12002: would have almost thought the whole round sea was one huge cheese, and
12003: those sharks the maggots in it.
12004: 
12005: Nevertheless, upon Stubb setting the anchor-watch after his supper was
12006: concluded; and when, accordingly, Queequeg and a forecastle seaman came
12007: on deck, no small excitement was created among the sharks; for
12008: immediately suspending the cutting stages over the side, and lowering
12009: three lanterns, so that they cast long gleams of light over the turbid
12010: sea, these two mariners, darting their long whaling-spades, kept up an
12011: incessant murdering of the sharks,* by striking the keen steel deep
12012: into their skulls, seemingly their only vital part. But in the foamy
12013: confusion of their mixed and struggling hosts, the marksmen could not
12014: always hit their mark; and this brought about new revelations of the
12015: incredible ferocity of the foe. They viciously snapped, not only at
12016: each other’s disembowelments, but like flexible bows, bent round, and
12017: bit their own; till those entrails seemed swallowed over and over again
12018: by the same mouth, to be oppositely voided by the gaping wound. Nor was
12019: this all. It was unsafe to meddle with the corpses and ghosts of these
12020: creatures. A sort of generic or Pantheistic vitality seemed to lurk in
12021: their very joints and bones, after what might be called the individual
12022: life had departed. Killed and hoisted on deck for the sake of his skin,
12023: one of these sharks almost took poor Queequeg’s hand off, when he tried
12024: to shut down the dead lid of his murderous jaw.
12025: 
12026: *The whaling-spade used for cutting-in is made of the very best steel;
12027: is about the bigness of a man’s spread hand; and in general shape,
12028: corresponds to the garden implement after which it is named; only its
12029: sides are perfectly flat, and its upper end considerably narrower than
12030: the lower. This weapon is always kept as sharp as possible; and when
12031: being used is occasionally honed, just like a razor. In its socket, a
12032: stiff pole, from twenty to thirty feet long, is inserted for a handle.
12033: 
12034: “Queequeg no care what god made him shark,” said the savage,
12035: agonizingly lifting his hand up and down; “wedder Fejee god or
12036: Nantucket god; but de god wat made shark must be one dam Ingin.”
12037: 
12038: 
12039: CHAPTER 67. Cutting In.
12040: 
12041: It was a Saturday night, and such a Sabbath as followed! Ex officio
12042: professors of Sabbath breaking are all whalemen. The ivory Pequod was
12043: turned into what seemed a shamble; every sailor a butcher. You would
12044: have thought we were offering up ten thousand red oxen to the sea gods.
12045: 
12046: In the first place, the enormous cutting tackles, among other ponderous
12047: things comprising a cluster of blocks generally painted green, and
12048: which no single man can possibly lift—this vast bunch of grapes was
12049: swayed up to the main-top and firmly lashed to the lower mast-head, the
12050: strongest point anywhere above a ship’s deck. The end of the
12051: hawser-like rope winding through these intricacies, was then conducted
12052: to the windlass, and the huge lower block of the tackles was swung over
12053: the whale; to this block the great blubber hook, weighing some one
12054: hundred pounds, was attached. And now suspended in stages over the
12055: side, Starbuck and Stubb, the mates, armed with their long spades,
12056: began cutting a hole in the body for the insertion of the hook just
12057: above the nearest of the two side-fins. This done, a broad,
12058: semicircular line is cut round the hole, the hook is inserted, and the
12059: main body of the crew striking up a wild chorus, now commence heaving
12060: in one dense crowd at the windlass. When instantly, the entire ship
12061: careens over on her side; every bolt in her starts like the nail-heads
12062: of an old house in frosty weather; she trembles, quivers, and nods her
12063: frighted mast-heads to the sky. More and more she leans over to the
12064: whale, while every gasping heave of the windlass is answered by a
12065: helping heave from the billows; till at last, a swift, startling snap
12066: is heard; with a great swash the ship rolls upwards and backwards from
12067: the whale, and the triumphant tackle rises into sight dragging after it
12068: the disengaged semicircular end of the first strip of blubber. Now as
12069: the blubber envelopes the whale precisely as the rind does an orange,
12070: so is it stripped off from the body precisely as an orange is sometimes
12071: stripped by spiralizing it. For the strain constantly kept up by the
12072: windlass continually keeps the whale rolling over and over in the
12073: water, and as the blubber in one strip uniformly peels off along the
12074: line called the “scarf,” simultaneously cut by the spades of Starbuck
12075: and Stubb, the mates; and just as fast as it is thus peeled off, and
12076: indeed by that very act itself, it is all the time being hoisted higher
12077: and higher aloft till its upper end grazes the main-top; the men at the
12078: windlass then cease heaving, and for a moment or two the prodigious
12079: blood-dripping mass sways to and fro as if let down from the sky, and
12080: every one present must take good heed to dodge it when it swings, else
12081: it may box his ears and pitch him headlong overboard.
12082: 
12083: One of the attending harpooneers now advances with a long, keen weapon
12084: called a boarding-sword, and watching his chance he dexterously slices
12085: out a considerable hole in the lower part of the swaying mass. Into
12086: this hole, the end of the second alternating great tackle is then
12087: hooked so as to retain a hold upon the blubber, in order to prepare for
12088: what follows. Whereupon, this accomplished swordsman, warning all hands
12089: to stand off, once more makes a scientific dash at the mass, and with a
12090: few sidelong, desperate, lunging slicings, severs it completely in
12091: twain; so that while the short lower part is still fast, the long upper
12092: strip, called a blanket-piece, swings clear, and is all ready for
12093: lowering. The heavers forward now resume their song, and while the one
12094: tackle is peeling and hoisting a second strip from the whale, the other
12095: is slowly slackened away, and down goes the first strip through the
12096: main hatchway right beneath, into an unfurnished parlor called the
12097: blubber-room. Into this twilight apartment sundry nimble hands keep
12098: coiling away the long blanket-piece as if it were a great live mass of
12099: plaited serpents. And thus the work proceeds; the two tackles hoisting
12100: and lowering simultaneously; both whale and windlass heaving, the
12101: heavers singing, the blubber-room gentlemen coiling, the mates
12102: scarfing, the ship straining, and all hands swearing occasionally, by
12103: way of assuaging the general friction.
12104: 
12105: 
12106: CHAPTER 68. The Blanket.
12107: 
12108: I have given no small attention to that not unvexed subject, the skin
12109: of the whale. I have had controversies about it with experienced
12110: whalemen afloat, and learned naturalists ashore. My original opinion
12111: remains unchanged; but it is only an opinion.
12112: 
12113: The question is, what and where is the skin of the whale? Already you
12114: know what his blubber is. That blubber is something of the consistence
12115: of firm, close-grained beef, but tougher, more elastic and compact, and
12116: ranges from eight or ten to twelve and fifteen inches in thickness.
12117: 
12118: Now, however preposterous it may at first seem to talk of any
12119: creature’s skin as being of that sort of consistence and thickness, yet
12120: in point of fact these are no arguments against such a presumption;
12121: because you cannot raise any other dense enveloping layer from the
12122: whale’s body but that same blubber; and the outermost enveloping layer
12123: of any animal, if reasonably dense, what can that be but the skin?
12124: True, from the unmarred dead body of the whale, you may scrape off with
12125: your hand an infinitely thin, transparent substance, somewhat
12126: resembling the thinnest shreds of isinglass, only it is almost as
12127: flexible and soft as satin; that is, previous to being dried, when it
12128: not only contracts and thickens, but becomes rather hard and brittle. I
12129: have several such dried bits, which I use for marks in my whale-books.
12130: It is transparent, as I said before; and being laid upon the printed
12131: page, I have sometimes pleased myself with fancying it exerted a
12132: magnifying influence. At any rate, it is pleasant to read about whales
12133: through their own spectacles, as you may say. But what I am driving at
12134: here is this. That same infinitely thin, isinglass substance, which, I
12135: admit, invests the entire body of the whale, is not so much to be
12136: regarded as the skin of the creature, as the skin of the skin, so to
12137: speak; for it were simply ridiculous to say, that the proper skin of
12138: the tremendous whale is thinner and more tender than the skin of a
12139: new-born child. But no more of this.
12140: 
12141: Assuming the blubber to be the skin of the whale; then, when this skin,
12142: as in the case of a very large Sperm Whale, will yield the bulk of one
12143: hundred barrels of oil; and, when it is considered that, in quantity,
12144: or rather weight, that oil, in its expressed state, is only three
12145: fourths, and not the entire substance of the coat; some idea may hence
12146: be had of the enormousness of that animated mass, a mere part of whose
12147: mere integument yields such a lake of liquid as that. Reckoning ten
12148: barrels to the ton, you have ten tons for the net weight of only three
12149: quarters of the stuff of the whale’s skin.
12150: 
12151: In life, the visible surface of the Sperm Whale is not the least among
12152: the many marvels he presents. Almost invariably it is all over
12153: obliquely crossed and re-crossed with numberless straight marks in
12154: thick array, something like those in the finest Italian line
12155: engravings. But these marks do not seem to be impressed upon the
12156: isinglass substance above mentioned, but seem to be seen through it, as
12157: if they were engraved upon the body itself. Nor is this all. In some
12158: instances, to the quick, observant eye, those linear marks, as in a
12159: veritable engraving, but afford the ground for far other delineations.
12160: These are hieroglyphical; that is, if you call those mysterious cyphers
12161: on the walls of pyramids hieroglyphics, then that is the proper word to
12162: use in the present connexion. By my retentive memory of the
12163: hieroglyphics upon one Sperm Whale in particular, I was much struck
12164: with a plate representing the old Indian characters chiselled on the
12165: famous hieroglyphic palisades on the banks of the Upper Mississippi.
12166: Like those mystic rocks, too, the mystic-marked whale remains
12167: undecipherable. This allusion to the Indian rocks reminds me of another
12168: thing. Besides all the other phenomena which the exterior of the Sperm
12169: Whale presents, he not seldom displays the back, and more especially
12170: his flanks, effaced in great part of the regular linear appearance, by
12171: reason of numerous rude scratches, altogether of an irregular, random
12172: aspect. I should say that those New England rocks on the sea-coast,
12173: which Agassiz imagines to bear the marks of violent scraping contact
12174: with vast floating icebergs—I should say, that those rocks must not a
12175: little resemble the Sperm Whale in this particular. It also seems to me
12176: that such scratches in the whale are probably made by hostile contact
12177: with other whales; for I have most remarked them in the large,
12178: full-grown bulls of the species.
12179: 
12180: A word or two more concerning this matter of the skin or blubber of the
12181: whale. It has already been said, that it is stript from him in long
12182: pieces, called blanket-pieces. Like most sea-terms, this one is very
12183: happy and significant. For the whale is indeed wrapt up in his blubber
12184: as in a real blanket or counterpane; or, still better, an Indian poncho
12185: slipt over his head, and skirting his extremity. It is by reason of
12186: this cosy blanketing of his body, that the whale is enabled to keep
12187: himself comfortable in all weathers, in all seas, times, and tides.
12188: What would become of a Greenland whale, say, in those shuddering, icy
12189: seas of the North, if unsupplied with his cosy surtout? True, other
12190: fish are found exceedingly brisk in those Hyperborean waters; but
12191: these, be it observed, are your cold-blooded, lungless fish, whose very
12192: bellies are refrigerators; creatures, that warm themselves under the
12193: lee of an iceberg, as a traveller in winter would bask before an inn
12194: fire; whereas, like man, the whale has lungs and warm blood. Freeze his
12195: blood, and he dies. How wonderful is it then—except after
12196: explanation—that this great monster, to whom corporeal warmth is as
12197: indispensable as it is to man; how wonderful that he should be found at
12198: home, immersed to his lips for life in those Arctic waters! where, when
12199: seamen fall overboard, they are sometimes found, months afterwards,
12200: perpendicularly frozen into the hearts of fields of ice, as a fly is
12201: found glued in amber. But more surprising is it to know, as has been
12202: proved by experiment, that the blood of a Polar whale is warmer than
12203: that of a Borneo negro in summer.
12204: 
12205: It does seem to me, that herein we see the rare virtue of a strong
12206: individual vitality, and the rare virtue of thick walls, and the rare
12207: virtue of interior spaciousness. Oh, man! admire and model thyself
12208: after the whale! Do thou, too, remain warm among ice. Do thou, too,
12209: live in this world without being of it. Be cool at the equator; keep
12210: thy blood fluid at the Pole. Like the great dome of St. Peter’s, and
12211: like the great whale, retain, O man! in all seasons a temperature of
12212: thine own.
12213: 
12214: But how easy and how hopeless to teach these fine things! Of erections,
12215: how few are domed like St. Peter’s! of creatures, how few vast as the
12216: whale!
12217: 
12218: 
12219: CHAPTER 69. The Funeral.
12220: 
12221: “Haul in the chains! Let the carcase go astern!”
12222: 
12223: The vast tackles have now done their duty. The peeled white body of the
12224: beheaded whale flashes like a marble sepulchre; though changed in hue,
12225: it has not perceptibly lost anything in bulk. It is still colossal.
12226: Slowly it floats more and more away, the water round it torn and
12227: splashed by the insatiate sharks, and the air above vexed with
12228: rapacious flights of screaming fowls, whose beaks are like so many
12229: insulting poniards in the whale. The vast white headless phantom floats
12230: further and further from the ship, and every rod that it so floats,
12231: what seem square roods of sharks and cubic roods of fowls, augment the
12232: murderous din. For hours and hours from the almost stationary ship that
12233: hideous sight is seen. Beneath the unclouded and mild azure sky, upon
12234: the fair face of the pleasant sea, wafted by the joyous breezes, that
12235: great mass of death floats on and on, till lost in infinite
12236: perspectives.
12237: 
12238: There’s a most doleful and most mocking funeral! The sea-vultures all
12239: in pious mourning, the air-sharks all punctiliously in black or
12240: speckled. In life but few of them would have helped the whale, I ween,
12241: if peradventure he had needed it; but upon the banquet of his funeral
12242: they most piously do pounce. Oh, horrible vultureism of earth! from
12243: which not the mightiest whale is free.
12244: 
12245: Nor is this the end. Desecrated as the body is, a vengeful ghost
12246: survives and hovers over it to scare. Espied by some timid man-of-war
12247: or blundering discovery-vessel from afar, when the distance obscuring
12248: the swarming fowls, nevertheless still shows the white mass floating in
12249: the sun, and the white spray heaving high against it; straightway the
12250: whale’s unharming corpse, with trembling fingers is set down in the
12251: log—_shoals, rocks, and breakers hereabouts: beware!_ And for years
12252: afterwards, perhaps, ships shun the place; leaping over it as silly
12253: sheep leap over a vacuum, because their leader originally leaped there
12254: when a stick was held. There’s your law of precedents; there’s your
12255: utility of traditions; there’s the story of your obstinate survival of
12256: old beliefs never bottomed on the earth, and now not even hovering in
12257: the air! There’s orthodoxy!
12258: 
12259: Thus, while in life the great whale’s body may have been a real terror
12260: to his foes, in his death his ghost becomes a powerless panic to a
12261: world.
12262: 
12263: Are you a believer in ghosts, my friend? There are other ghosts than
12264: the Cock-Lane one, and far deeper men than Doctor Johnson who believe
12265: in them.
12266: 
12267: 
12268: CHAPTER 70. The Sphynx.
12269: 
12270: It should not have been omitted that previous to completely stripping
12271: the body of the leviathan, he was beheaded. Now, the beheading of the
12272: Sperm Whale is a scientific anatomical feat, upon which experienced
12273: whale surgeons very much pride themselves: and not without reason.
12274: 
12275: Consider that the whale has nothing that can properly be called a neck;
12276: on the contrary, where his head and body seem to join, there, in that
12277: very place, is the thickest part of him. Remember, also, that the
12278: surgeon must operate from above, some eight or ten feet intervening
12279: between him and his subject, and that subject almost hidden in a
12280: discoloured, rolling, and oftentimes tumultuous and bursting sea. Bear
12281: in mind, too, that under these untoward circumstances he has to cut
12282: many feet deep in the flesh; and in that subterraneous manner, without
12283: so much as getting one single peep into the ever-contracting gash thus
12284: made, he must skilfully steer clear of all adjacent, interdicted parts,
12285: and exactly divide the spine at a critical point hard by its insertion
12286: into the skull. Do you not marvel, then, at Stubb’s boast, that he
12287: demanded but ten minutes to behead a sperm whale?
12288: 
12289: When first severed, the head is dropped astern and held there by a
12290: cable till the body is stripped. That done, if it belong to a small
12291: whale it is hoisted on deck to be deliberately disposed of. But, with a
12292: full grown leviathan this is impossible; for the sperm whale’s head
12293: embraces nearly one third of his entire bulk, and completely to suspend
12294: such a burden as that, even by the immense tackles of a whaler, this
12295: were as vain a thing as to attempt weighing a Dutch barn in jewellers’
12296: scales.
12297: 
12298: The Pequod’s whale being decapitated and the body stripped, the head
12299: was hoisted against the ship’s side—about half way out of the sea, so
12300: that it might yet in great part be buoyed up by its native element. And
12301: there with the strained craft steeply leaning over to it, by reason of
12302: the enormous downward drag from the lower mast-head, and every yard-arm
12303: on that side projecting like a crane over the waves; there, that
12304: blood-dripping head hung to the Pequod’s waist like the giant
12305: Holofernes’s from the girdle of Judith.
12306: 
12307: When this last task was accomplished it was noon, and the seamen went
12308: below to their dinner. Silence reigned over the before tumultuous but
12309: now deserted deck. An intense copper calm, like a universal yellow
12310: lotus, was more and more unfolding its noiseless measureless leaves
12311: upon the sea.
12312: 
12313: A short space elapsed, and up into this noiselessness came Ahab alone
12314: from his cabin. Taking a few turns on the quarter-deck, he paused to
12315: gaze over the side, then slowly getting into the main-chains he took
12316: Stubb’s long spade—still remaining there after the whale’s
12317: decapitation—and striking it into the lower part of the half-suspended
12318: mass, placed its other end crutch-wise under one arm, and so stood
12319: leaning over with eyes attentively fixed on this head.
12320: 
12321: It was a black and hooded head; and hanging there in the midst of so
12322: intense a calm, it seemed the Sphynx’s in the desert. “Speak, thou vast
12323: and venerable head,” muttered Ahab, “which, though ungarnished with a
12324: beard, yet here and there lookest hoary with mosses; speak, mighty
12325: head, and tell us the secret thing that is in thee. Of all divers, thou
12326: hast dived the deepest. That head upon which the upper sun now gleams,
12327: has moved amid this world’s foundations. Where unrecorded names and
12328: navies rust, and untold hopes and anchors rot; where in her murderous
12329: hold this frigate earth is ballasted with bones of millions of the
12330: drowned; there, in that awful water-land, there was thy most familiar
12331: home. Thou hast been where bell or diver never went; hast slept by many
12332: a sailor’s side, where sleepless mothers would give their lives to lay
12333: them down. Thou saw’st the locked lovers when leaping from their
12334: flaming ship; heart to heart they sank beneath the exulting wave; true
12335: to each other, when heaven seemed false to them. Thou saw’st the
12336: murdered mate when tossed by pirates from the midnight deck; for hours
12337: he fell into the deeper midnight of the insatiate maw; and his
12338: murderers still sailed on unharmed—while swift lightnings shivered the
12339: neighboring ship that would have borne a righteous husband to
12340: outstretched, longing arms. O head! thou hast seen enough to split the
12341: planets and make an infidel of Abraham, and not one syllable is thine!”
12342: 
12343: “Sail ho!” cried a triumphant voice from the main-mast-head.
12344: 
12345: “Aye? Well, now, that’s cheering,” cried Ahab, suddenly erecting
12346: himself, while whole thunder-clouds swept aside from his brow. “That
12347: lively cry upon this deadly calm might almost convert a better
12348: man.—Where away?”
12349: 
12350: “Three points on the starboard bow, sir, and bringing down her breeze
12351: to us!
12352: 
12353: “Better and better, man. Would now St. Paul would come along that way,
12354: and to my breezelessness bring his breeze! O Nature, and O soul of man!
12355: how far beyond all utterance are your linked analogies! not the
12356: smallest atom stirs or lives on matter, but has its cunning duplicate
12357: in mind.”
12358: 
12359: 
12360: CHAPTER 71. The Jeroboam’s Story.
12361: 
12362: Hand in hand, ship and breeze blew on; but the breeze came faster than
12363: the ship, and soon the Pequod began to rock.
12364: 
12365: By and by, through the glass the stranger’s boats and manned mast-heads
12366: proved her a whale-ship. But as she was so far to windward, and
12367: shooting by, apparently making a passage to some other ground, the
12368: Pequod could not hope to reach her. So the signal was set to see what
12369: response would be made.
12370: 
12371: Here be it said, that like the vessels of military marines, the ships
12372: of the American Whale Fleet have each a private signal; all which
12373: signals being collected in a book with the names of the respective
12374: vessels attached, every captain is provided with it. Thereby, the whale
12375: commanders are enabled to recognise each other upon the ocean, even at
12376: considerable distances and with no small facility.
12377: 
12378: The Pequod’s signal was at last responded to by the stranger’s setting
12379: her own; which proved the ship to be the Jeroboam of Nantucket.
12380: Squaring her yards, she bore down, ranged abeam under the Pequod’s lee,
12381: and lowered a boat; it soon drew nigh; but, as the side-ladder was
12382: being rigged by Starbuck’s order to accommodate the visiting captain,
12383: the stranger in question waved his hand from his boat’s stern in token
12384: of that proceeding being entirely unnecessary. It turned out that the
12385: Jeroboam had a malignant epidemic on board, and that Mayhew, her
12386: captain, was fearful of infecting the Pequod’s company. For, though
12387: himself and boat’s crew remained untainted, and though his ship was
12388: half a rifle-shot off, and an incorruptible sea and air rolling and
12389: flowing between; yet conscientiously adhering to the timid quarantine
12390: of the land, he peremptorily refused to come into direct contact with
12391: the Pequod.
12392: 
12393: But this did by no means prevent all communications. Preserving an
12394: interval of some few yards between itself and the ship, the Jeroboam’s
12395: boat by the occasional use of its oars contrived to keep parallel to
12396: the Pequod, as she heavily forged through the sea (for by this time it
12397: blew very fresh), with her main-topsail aback; though, indeed, at times
12398: by the sudden onset of a large rolling wave, the boat would be pushed
12399: some way ahead; but would be soon skilfully brought to her proper
12400: bearings again. Subject to this, and other the like interruptions now
12401: and then, a conversation was sustained between the two parties; but at
12402: intervals not without still another interruption of a very different
12403: sort.
12404: 
12405: Pulling an oar in the Jeroboam’s boat, was a man of a singular
12406: appearance, even in that wild whaling life where individual
12407: notabilities make up all totalities. He was a small, short, youngish
12408: man, sprinkled all over his face with freckles, and wearing redundant
12409: yellow hair. A long-skirted, cabalistically-cut coat of a faded walnut
12410: tinge enveloped him; the overlapping sleeves of which were rolled up on
12411: his wrists. A deep, settled, fanatic delirium was in his eyes.
12412: 
12413: So soon as this figure had been first descried, Stubb had
12414: exclaimed—“That’s he! that’s he!—the long-togged scaramouch the
12415: Town-Ho’s company told us of!” Stubb here alluded to a strange story
12416: told of the Jeroboam, and a certain man among her crew, some time
12417: previous when the Pequod spoke the Town-Ho. According to this account
12418: and what was subsequently learned, it seemed that the scaramouch in
12419: question had gained a wonderful ascendency over almost everybody in the
12420: Jeroboam. His story was this:
12421: 
12422: He had been originally nurtured among the crazy society of Neskyeuna
12423: Shakers, where he had been a great prophet; in their cracked, secret
12424: meetings having several times descended from heaven by the way of a
12425: trap-door, announcing the speedy opening of the seventh vial, which he
12426: carried in his vest-pocket; but, which, instead of containing
12427: gunpowder, was supposed to be charged with laudanum. A strange,
12428: apostolic whim having seized him, he had left Neskyeuna for Nantucket,
12429: where, with that cunning peculiar to craziness, he assumed a steady,
12430: common-sense exterior, and offered himself as a green-hand candidate
12431: for the Jeroboam’s whaling voyage. They engaged him; but straightway
12432: upon the ship’s getting out of sight of land, his insanity broke out in
12433: a freshet. He announced himself as the archangel Gabriel, and commanded
12434: the captain to jump overboard. He published his manifesto, whereby he
12435: set himself forth as the deliverer of the isles of the sea and
12436: vicar-general of all Oceanica. The unflinching earnestness with which
12437: he declared these things;—the dark, daring play of his sleepless,
12438: excited imagination, and all the preternatural terrors of real
12439: delirium, united to invest this Gabriel in the minds of the majority of
12440: the ignorant crew, with an atmosphere of sacredness. Moreover, they
12441: were afraid of him. As such a man, however, was not of much practical
12442: use in the ship, especially as he refused to work except when he
12443: pleased, the incredulous captain would fain have been rid of him; but
12444: apprised that that individual’s intention was to land him in the first
12445: convenient port, the archangel forthwith opened all his seals and
12446: vials—devoting the ship and all hands to unconditional perdition, in
12447: case this intention was carried out. So strongly did he work upon his
12448: disciples among the crew, that at last in a body they went to the
12449: captain and told him if Gabriel was sent from the ship, not a man of
12450: them would remain. He was therefore forced to relinquish his plan. Nor
12451: would they permit Gabriel to be any way maltreated, say or do what he
12452: would; so that it came to pass that Gabriel had the complete freedom of
12453: the ship. The consequence of all this was, that the archangel cared
12454: little or nothing for the captain and mates; and since the epidemic had
12455: broken out, he carried a higher hand than ever; declaring that the
12456: plague, as he called it, was at his sole command; nor should it be
12457: stayed but according to his good pleasure. The sailors, mostly poor
12458: devils, cringed, and some of them fawned before him; in obedience to
12459: his instructions, sometimes rendering him personal homage, as to a god.
12460: Such things may seem incredible; but, however wondrous, they are true.
12461: Nor is the history of fanatics half so striking in respect to the
12462: measureless self-deception of the fanatic himself, as his measureless
12463: power of deceiving and bedevilling so many others. But it is time to
12464: return to the Pequod.
12465: 
12466: “I fear not thy epidemic, man,” said Ahab from the bulwarks, to Captain
12467: Mayhew, who stood in the boat’s stern; “come on board.”
12468: 
12469: But now Gabriel started to his feet.
12470: 
12471: “Think, think of the fevers, yellow and bilious! Beware of the horrible
12472: plague!”
12473: 
12474: “Gabriel! Gabriel!” cried Captain Mayhew; “thou must either—” But that
12475: instant a headlong wave shot the boat far ahead, and its seethings
12476: drowned all speech.
12477: 
12478: “Hast thou seen the White Whale?” demanded Ahab, when the boat drifted
12479: back.
12480: 
12481: “Think, think of thy whale-boat, stoven and sunk! Beware of the
12482: horrible tail!”
12483: 
12484: “I tell thee again, Gabriel, that—” But again the boat tore ahead as if
12485: dragged by fiends. Nothing was said for some moments, while a
12486: succession of riotous waves rolled by, which by one of those occasional
12487: caprices of the seas were tumbling, not heaving it. Meantime, the
12488: hoisted sperm whale’s head jogged about very violently, and Gabriel was
12489: seen eyeing it with rather more apprehensiveness than his archangel
12490: nature seemed to warrant.
12491: 
12492: When this interlude was over, Captain Mayhew began a dark story
12493: concerning Moby Dick; not, however, without frequent interruptions from
12494: Gabriel, whenever his name was mentioned, and the crazy sea that seemed
12495: leagued with him.
12496: 
12497: It seemed that the Jeroboam had not long left home, when upon speaking
12498: a whale-ship, her people were reliably apprised of the existence of
12499: Moby Dick, and the havoc he had made. Greedily sucking in this
12500: intelligence, Gabriel solemnly warned the captain against attacking the
12501: White Whale, in case the monster should be seen; in his gibbering
12502: insanity, pronouncing the White Whale to be no less a being than the
12503: Shaker God incarnated; the Shakers receiving the Bible. But when, some
12504: year or two afterwards, Moby Dick was fairly sighted from the
12505: mast-heads, Macey, the chief mate, burned with ardour to encounter him;
12506: and the captain himself being not unwilling to let him have the
12507: opportunity, despite all the archangel’s denunciations and
12508: forewarnings, Macey succeeded in persuading five men to man his boat.
12509: With them he pushed off; and, after much weary pulling, and many
12510: perilous, unsuccessful onsets, he at last succeeded in getting one iron
12511: fast. Meantime, Gabriel, ascending to the main-royal mast-head, was
12512: tossing one arm in frantic gestures, and hurling forth prophecies of
12513: speedy doom to the sacrilegious assailants of his divinity. Now, while
12514: Macey, the mate, was standing up in his boat’s bow, and with all the
12515: reckless energy of his tribe was venting his wild exclamations upon the
12516: whale, and essaying to get a fair chance for his poised lance, lo! a
12517: broad white shadow rose from the sea; by its quick, fanning motion,
12518: temporarily taking the breath out of the bodies of the oarsmen. Next
12519: instant, the luckless mate, so full of furious life, was smitten bodily
12520: into the air, and making a long arc in his descent, fell into the sea
12521: at the distance of about fifty yards. Not a chip of the boat was
12522: harmed, nor a hair of any oarsman’s head; but the mate for ever sank.
12523: 
12524: It is well to parenthesize here, that of the fatal accidents in the
12525: Sperm-Whale Fishery, this kind is perhaps almost as frequent as any.
12526: Sometimes, nothing is injured but the man who is thus annihilated;
12527: oftener the boat’s bow is knocked off, or the thigh-board, in which the
12528: headsman stands, is torn from its place and accompanies the body. But
12529: strangest of all is the circumstance, that in more instances than one,
12530: when the body has been recovered, not a single mark of violence is
12531: discernible; the man being stark dead.
12532: 
12533: The whole calamity, with the falling form of Macey, was plainly
12534: descried from the ship. Raising a piercing shriek—“The vial! the vial!”
12535: Gabriel called off the terror-stricken crew from the further hunting of
12536: the whale. This terrible event clothed the archangel with added
12537: influence; because his credulous disciples believed that he had
12538: specifically fore-announced it, instead of only making a general
12539: prophecy, which any one might have done, and so have chanced to hit one
12540: of many marks in the wide margin allowed. He became a nameless terror
12541: to the ship.
12542: 
12543: Mayhew having concluded his narration, Ahab put such questions to him,
12544: that the stranger captain could not forbear inquiring whether he
12545: intended to hunt the White Whale, if opportunity should offer. To which
12546: Ahab answered—“Aye.” Straightway, then, Gabriel once more started to
12547: his feet, glaring upon the old man, and vehemently exclaimed, with
12548: downward pointed finger—“Think, think of the blasphemer—dead, and down
12549: there!—beware of the blasphemer’s end!”
12550: 
12551: Ahab stolidly turned aside; then said to Mayhew, “Captain, I have just
12552: bethought me of my letter-bag; there is a letter for one of thy
12553: officers, if I mistake not. Starbuck, look over the bag.”
12554: 
12555: Every whale-ship takes out a goodly number of letters for various
12556: ships, whose delivery to the persons to whom they may be addressed,
12557: depends upon the mere chance of encountering them in the four oceans.
12558: Thus, most letters never reach their mark; and many are only received
12559: after attaining an age of two or three years or more.
12560: 
12561: Soon Starbuck returned with a letter in his hand. It was sorely
12562: tumbled, damp, and covered with a dull, spotted, green mould, in
12563: consequence of being kept in a dark locker of the cabin. Of such a
12564: letter, Death himself might well have been the post-boy.
12565: 
12566: “Can’st not read it?” cried Ahab. “Give it me, man. Aye, aye, it’s but
12567: a dim scrawl;—what’s this?” As he was studying it out, Starbuck took a
12568: long cutting-spade pole, and with his knife slightly split the end, to
12569: insert the letter there, and in that way, hand it to the boat, without
12570: its coming any closer to the ship.
12571: 
12572: Meantime, Ahab holding the letter, muttered, “Mr. Har—yes, Mr. Harry—(a
12573: woman’s pinny hand,—the man’s wife, I’ll wager)—Aye—Mr. Harry Macey,
12574: Ship Jeroboam;—why it’s Macey, and he’s dead!”
12575: 
12576: “Poor fellow! poor fellow! and from his wife,” sighed Mayhew; “but let
12577: me have it.”
12578: 
12579: “Nay, keep it thyself,” cried Gabriel to Ahab; “thou art soon going
12580: that way.”
12581: 
12582: “Curses throttle thee!” yelled Ahab. “Captain Mayhew, stand by now to
12583: receive it”; and taking the fatal missive from Starbuck’s hands, he
12584: caught it in the slit of the pole, and reached it over towards the
12585: boat. But as he did so, the oarsmen expectantly desisted from rowing;
12586: the boat drifted a little towards the ship’s stern; so that, as if by
12587: magic, the letter suddenly ranged along with Gabriel’s eager hand. He
12588: clutched it in an instant, seized the boat-knife, and impaling the
12589: letter on it, sent it thus loaded back into the ship. It fell at Ahab’s
12590: feet. Then Gabriel shrieked out to his comrades to give way with their
12591: oars, and in that manner the mutinous boat rapidly shot away from the
12592: Pequod.
12593: 
12594: As, after this interlude, the seamen resumed their work upon the jacket
12595: of the whale, many strange things were hinted in reference to this wild
12596: affair.
12597: 
12598: 
12599: CHAPTER 72. The Monkey-Rope.
12600: 
12601: In the tumultuous business of cutting-in and attending to a whale,
12602: there is much running backwards and forwards among the crew. Now hands
12603: are wanted here, and then again hands are wanted there. There is no
12604: staying in any one place; for at one and the same time everything has
12605: to be done everywhere. It is much the same with him who endeavors the
12606: description of the scene. We must now retrace our way a little. It was
12607: mentioned that upon first breaking ground in the whale’s back, the
12608: blubber-hook was inserted into the original hole there cut by the
12609: spades of the mates. But how did so clumsy and weighty a mass as that
12610: same hook get fixed in that hole? It was inserted there by my
12611: particular friend Queequeg, whose duty it was, as harpooneer, to
12612: descend upon the monster’s back for the special purpose referred to.
12613: But in very many cases, circumstances require that the harpooneer shall
12614: remain on the whale till the whole flensing or stripping operation is
12615: concluded. The whale, be it observed, lies almost entirely submerged,
12616: excepting the immediate parts operated upon. So down there, some ten
12617: feet below the level of the deck, the poor harpooneer flounders about,
12618: half on the whale and half in the water, as the vast mass revolves like
12619: a tread-mill beneath him. On the occasion in question, Queequeg figured
12620: in the Highland costume—a shirt and socks—in which to my eyes, at
12621: least, he appeared to uncommon advantage; and no one had a better
12622: chance to observe him, as will presently be seen.
12623: 
12624: Being the savage’s bowsman, that is, the person who pulled the bow-oar
12625: in his boat (the second one from forward), it was my cheerful duty to
12626: attend upon him while taking that hard-scrabble scramble upon the dead
12627: whale’s back. You have seen Italian organ-boys holding a dancing-ape by
12628: a long cord. Just so, from the ship’s steep side, did I hold Queequeg
12629: down there in the sea, by what is technically called in the fishery a
12630: monkey-rope, attached to a strong strip of canvas belted round his
12631: waist.
12632: 
12633: It was a humorously perilous business for both of us. For, before we
12634: proceed further, it must be said that the monkey-rope was fast at both
12635: ends; fast to Queequeg’s broad canvas belt, and fast to my narrow
12636: leather one. So that for better or for worse, we two, for the time,
12637: were wedded; and should poor Queequeg sink to rise no more, then both
12638: usage and honor demanded, that instead of cutting the cord, it should
12639: drag me down in his wake. So, then, an elongated Siamese ligature
12640: united us. Queequeg was my own inseparable twin brother; nor could I
12641: any way get rid of the dangerous liabilities which the hempen bond
12642: entailed.
12643: 
12644: So strongly and metaphysically did I conceive of my situation then,
12645: that while earnestly watching his motions, I seemed distinctly to
12646: perceive that my own individuality was now merged in a joint stock
12647: company of two; that my free will had received a mortal wound; and that
12648: another’s mistake or misfortune might plunge innocent me into unmerited
12649: disaster and death. Therefore, I saw that here was a sort of
12650: interregnum in Providence; for its even-handed equity never could have
12651: so gross an injustice. And yet still further pondering—while I jerked
12652: him now and then from between the whale and ship, which would threaten
12653: to jam him—still further pondering, I say, I saw that this situation of
12654: mine was the precise situation of every mortal that breathes; only, in
12655: most cases, he, one way or other, has this Siamese connexion with a
12656: plurality of other mortals. If your banker breaks, you snap; if your
12657: apothecary by mistake sends you poison in your pills, you die. True,
12658: you may say that, by exceeding caution, you may possibly escape these
12659: and the multitudinous other evil chances of life. But handle Queequeg’s
12660: monkey-rope heedfully as I would, sometimes he jerked it so, that I
12661: came very near sliding overboard. Nor could I possibly forget that, do
12662: what I would, I only had the management of one end of it.*
12663: 
12664: *The monkey-rope is found in all whalers; but it was only in the Pequod
12665: that the monkey and his holder were ever tied together. This
12666: improvement upon the original usage was introduced by no less a man
12667: than Stubb, in order to afford the imperilled harpooneer the strongest
12668: possible guarantee for the faithfulness and vigilance of his
12669: monkey-rope holder.
12670: 
12671: I have hinted that I would often jerk poor Queequeg from between the
12672: whale and the ship—where he would occasionally fall, from the incessant
12673: rolling and swaying of both. But this was not the only jamming jeopardy
12674: he was exposed to. Unappalled by the massacre made upon them during the
12675: night, the sharks now freshly and more keenly allured by the before
12676: pent blood which began to flow from the carcass—the rabid creatures
12677: swarmed round it like bees in a beehive.
12678: 
12679: And right in among those sharks was Queequeg; who often pushed them
12680: aside with his floundering feet. A thing altogether incredible were it
12681: not that attracted by such prey as a dead whale, the otherwise
12682: miscellaneously carnivorous shark will seldom touch a man.
12683: 
12684: Nevertheless, it may well be believed that since they have such a
12685: ravenous finger in the pie, it is deemed but wise to look sharp to
12686: them. Accordingly, besides the monkey-rope, with which I now and then
12687: jerked the poor fellow from too close a vicinity to the maw of what
12688: seemed a peculiarly ferocious shark—he was provided with still another
12689: protection. Suspended over the side in one of the stages, Tashtego and
12690: Daggoo continually flourished over his head a couple of keen
12691: whale-spades, wherewith they slaughtered as many sharks as they could
12692: reach. This procedure of theirs, to be sure, was very disinterested and
12693: benevolent of them. They meant Queequeg’s best happiness, I admit; but
12694: in their hasty zeal to befriend him, and from the circumstance that
12695: both he and the sharks were at times half hidden by the blood-muddled
12696: water, those indiscreet spades of theirs would come nearer amputating a
12697: leg than a tail. But poor Queequeg, I suppose, straining and gasping
12698: there with that great iron hook—poor Queequeg, I suppose, only prayed
12699: to his Yojo, and gave up his life into the hands of his gods.
12700: 
12701: Well, well, my dear comrade and twin-brother, thought I, as I drew in
12702: and then slacked off the rope to every swell of the sea—what matters
12703: it, after all? Are you not the precious image of each and all of us men
12704: in this whaling world? That unsounded ocean you gasp in, is Life; those
12705: sharks, your foes; those spades, your friends; and what between sharks
12706: and spades you are in a sad pickle and peril, poor lad.
12707: 
12708: But courage! there is good cheer in store for you, Queequeg. For now,
12709: as with blue lips and blood-shot eyes the exhausted savage at last
12710: climbs up the chains and stands all dripping and involuntarily
12711: trembling over the side; the steward advances, and with a benevolent,
12712: consolatory glance hands him—what? Some hot Cognac? No! hands him, ye
12713: gods! hands him a cup of tepid ginger and water!
12714: 
12715: “Ginger? Do I smell ginger?” suspiciously asked Stubb, coming near.
12716: “Yes, this must be ginger,” peering into the as yet untasted cup. Then
12717: standing as if incredulous for a while, he calmly walked towards the
12718: astonished steward slowly saying, “Ginger? ginger? and will you have
12719: the goodness to tell me, Mr. Dough-Boy, where lies the virtue of
12720: ginger? Ginger! is ginger the sort of fuel you use, Dough-boy, to
12721: kindle a fire in this shivering cannibal? Ginger!—what the devil is
12722: ginger? Sea-coal? firewood?—lucifer matches?—tinder?—gunpowder?—what
12723: the devil is ginger, I say, that you offer this cup to our poor
12724: Queequeg here.”
12725: 
12726: “There is some sneaking Temperance Society movement about this
12727: business,” he suddenly added, now approaching Starbuck, who had just
12728: come from forward. “Will you look at that kannakin, sir: smell of it,
12729: if you please.” Then watching the mate’s countenance, he added, “The
12730: steward, Mr. Starbuck, had the face to offer that calomel and jalap to
12731: Queequeg, there, this instant off the whale. Is the steward an
12732: apothecary, sir? and may I ask whether this is the sort of bitters by
12733: which he blows back the life into a half-drowned man?”
12734: 
12735: “I trust not,” said Starbuck, “it is poor stuff enough.”
12736: 
12737: “Aye, aye, steward,” cried Stubb, “we’ll teach you to drug a
12738: harpooneer; none of your apothecary’s medicine here; you want to poison
12739: us, do ye? You have got out insurances on our lives and want to murder
12740: us all, and pocket the proceeds, do ye?”
12741: 
12742: “It was not me,” cried Dough-Boy, “it was Aunt Charity that brought the
12743: ginger on board; and bade me never give the harpooneers any spirits,
12744: but only this ginger-jub—so she called it.”
12745: 
12746: “Ginger-jub! you gingerly rascal! take that! and run along with ye to
12747: the lockers, and get something better. I hope I do no wrong, Mr.
12748: Starbuck. It is the captain’s orders—grog for the harpooneer on a
12749: whale.”
12750: 
12751: “Enough,” replied Starbuck, “only don’t hit him again, but—”
12752: 
12753: “Oh, I never hurt when I hit, except when I hit a whale or something of
12754: that sort; and this fellow’s a weazel. What were you about saying,
12755: sir?”
12756: 
12757: “Only this: go down with him, and get what thou wantest thyself.”
12758: 
12759: When Stubb reappeared, he came with a dark flask in one hand, and a
12760: sort of tea-caddy in the other. The first contained strong spirits, and
12761: was handed to Queequeg; the second was Aunt Charity’s gift, and that
12762: was freely given to the waves.
12763: 
12764: 
12765: CHAPTER 73. Stubb and Flask kill a Right Whale; and Then Have a Talk
12766: over Him.
12767: 
12768: It must be borne in mind that all this time we have a Sperm Whale’s
12769: prodigious head hanging to the Pequod’s side. But we must let it
12770: continue hanging there a while till we can get a chance to attend to
12771: it. For the present other matters press, and the best we can do now for
12772: the head, is to pray heaven the tackles may hold.
12773: 
12774: Now, during the past night and forenoon, the Pequod had gradually
12775: drifted into a sea, which, by its occasional patches of yellow brit,
12776: gave unusual tokens of the vicinity of Right Whales, a species of the
12777: Leviathan that but few supposed to be at this particular time lurking
12778: anywhere near. And though all hands commonly disdained the capture of
12779: those inferior creatures; and though the Pequod was not commissioned to
12780: cruise for them at all, and though she had passed numbers of them near
12781: the Crozetts without lowering a boat; yet now that a Sperm Whale had
12782: been brought alongside and beheaded, to the surprise of all, the
12783: announcement was made that a Right Whale should be captured that day,
12784: if opportunity offered.
12785: 
12786: Nor was this long wanting. Tall spouts were seen to leeward; and two
12787: boats, Stubb’s and Flask’s, were detached in pursuit. Pulling further
12788: and further away, they at last became almost invisible to the men at
12789: the mast-head. But suddenly in the distance, they saw a great heap of
12790: tumultuous white water, and soon after news came from aloft that one or
12791: both the boats must be fast. An interval passed and the boats were in
12792: plain sight, in the act of being dragged right towards the ship by the
12793: towing whale. So close did the monster come to the hull, that at first
12794: it seemed as if he meant it malice; but suddenly going down in a
12795: maelstrom, within three rods of the planks, he wholly disappeared from
12796: view, as if diving under the keel. “Cut, cut!” was the cry from the
12797: ship to the boats, which, for one instant, seemed on the point of being
12798: brought with a deadly dash against the vessel’s side. But having plenty
12799: of line yet in the tubs, and the whale not sounding very rapidly, they
12800: paid out abundance of rope, and at the same time pulled with all their
12801: might so as to get ahead of the ship. For a few minutes the struggle
12802: was intensely critical; for while they still slacked out the tightened
12803: line in one direction, and still plied their oars in another, the
12804: contending strain threatened to take them under. But it was only a few
12805: feet advance they sought to gain. And they stuck to it till they did
12806: gain it; when instantly, a swift tremor was felt running like lightning
12807: along the keel, as the strained line, scraping beneath the ship,
12808: suddenly rose to view under her bows, snapping and quivering; and so
12809: flinging off its drippings, that the drops fell like bits of broken
12810: glass on the water, while the whale beyond also rose to sight, and once
12811: more the boats were free to fly. But the fagged whale abated his speed,
12812: and blindly altering his course, went round the stern of the ship
12813: towing the two boats after him, so that they performed a complete
12814: circuit.
12815: 
12816: Meantime, they hauled more and more upon their lines, till close
12817: flanking him on both sides, Stubb answered Flask with lance for lance;
12818: and thus round and round the Pequod the battle went, while the
12819: multitudes of sharks that had before swum round the Sperm Whale’s body,
12820: rushed to the fresh blood that was spilled, thirstily drinking at every
12821: new gash, as the eager Israelites did at the new bursting fountains
12822: that poured from the smitten rock.
12823: 
12824: At last his spout grew thick, and with a frightful roll and vomit, he
12825: turned upon his back a corpse.
12826: 
12827: While the two headsmen were engaged in making fast cords to his flukes,
12828: and in other ways getting the mass in readiness for towing, some
12829: conversation ensued between them.
12830: 
12831: “I wonder what the old man wants with this lump of foul lard,” said
12832: Stubb, not without some disgust at the thought of having to do with so
12833: ignoble a leviathan.
12834: 
12835: “Wants with it?” said Flask, coiling some spare line in the boat’s bow,
12836: “did you never hear that the ship which but once has a Sperm Whale’s
12837: head hoisted on her starboard side, and at the same time a Right
12838: Whale’s on the larboard; did you never hear, Stubb, that that ship can
12839: never afterwards capsize?”
12840: 
12841: “Why not?
12842: 
12843: “I don’t know, but I heard that gamboge ghost of a Fedallah saying so,
12844: and he seems to know all about ships’ charms. But I sometimes think
12845: he’ll charm the ship to no good at last. I don’t half like that chap,
12846: Stubb. Did you ever notice how that tusk of his is a sort of carved
12847: into a snake’s head, Stubb?”
12848: 
12849: “Sink him! I never look at him at all; but if ever I get a chance of a
12850: dark night, and he standing hard by the bulwarks, and no one by; look
12851: down there, Flask”—pointing into the sea with a peculiar motion of both
12852: hands—“Aye, will I! Flask, I take that Fedallah to be the devil in
12853: disguise. Do you believe that cock and bull story about his having been
12854: stowed away on board ship? He’s the devil, I say. The reason why you
12855: don’t see his tail, is because he tucks it up out of sight; he carries
12856: it coiled away in his pocket, I guess. Blast him! now that I think of
12857: it, he’s always wanting oakum to stuff into the toes of his boots.”
12858: 
12859: “He sleeps in his boots, don’t he? He hasn’t got any hammock; but I’ve
12860: seen him lay of nights in a coil of rigging.”
12861: 
12862: “No doubt, and it’s because of his cursed tail; he coils it down, do ye
12863: see, in the eye of the rigging.”
12864: 
12865: “What’s the old man have so much to do with him for?”
12866: 
12867: “Striking up a swap or a bargain, I suppose.”
12868: 
12869: “Bargain?—about what?”
12870: 
12871: “Why, do ye see, the old man is hard bent after that White Whale, and
12872: the devil there is trying to come round him, and get him to swap away
12873: his silver watch, or his soul, or something of that sort, and then
12874: he’ll surrender Moby Dick.”
12875: 
12876: “Pooh! Stubb, you are skylarking; how can Fedallah do that?”
12877: 
12878: “I don’t know, Flask, but the devil is a curious chap, and a wicked
12879: one, I tell ye. Why, they say as how he went a sauntering into the old
12880: flag-ship once, switching his tail about devilish easy and
12881: gentlemanlike, and inquiring if the old governor was at home. Well, he
12882: was at home, and asked the devil what he wanted. The devil, switching
12883: his hoofs, up and says, ‘I want John.’ ‘What for?’ says the old
12884: governor. ‘What business is that of yours,’ says the devil, getting
12885: mad,—‘I want to use him.’ ‘Take him,’ says the governor—and by the
12886: Lord, Flask, if the devil didn’t give John the Asiatic cholera before
12887: he got through with him, I’ll eat this whale in one mouthful. But look
12888: sharp—ain’t you all ready there? Well, then, pull ahead, and let’s get
12889: the whale alongside.”
12890: 
12891: “I think I remember some such story as you were telling,” said Flask,
12892: when at last the two boats were slowly advancing with their burden
12893: towards the ship, “but I can’t remember where.”
12894: 
12895: “Three Spaniards? Adventures of those three bloody-minded soldadoes?
12896: Did ye read it there, Flask? I guess ye did?”
12897: 
12898: “No: never saw such a book; heard of it, though. But now, tell me,
12899: Stubb, do you suppose that that devil you was speaking of just now, was
12900: the same you say is now on board the Pequod?”
12901: 
12902: “Am I the same man that helped kill this whale? Doesn’t the devil live
12903: for ever; who ever heard that the devil was dead? Did you ever see any
12904: parson a wearing mourning for the devil? And if the devil has a
12905: latch-key to get into the admiral’s cabin, don’t you suppose he can
12906: crawl into a porthole? Tell me that, Mr. Flask?”
12907: 
12908: “How old do you suppose Fedallah is, Stubb?”
12909: 
12910: “Do you see that mainmast there?” pointing to the ship; “well, that’s
12911: the figure one; now take all the hoops in the Pequod’s hold, and string
12912: along in a row with that mast, for oughts, do you see; well, that
12913: wouldn’t begin to be Fedallah’s age. Nor all the coopers in creation
12914: couldn’t show hoops enough to make oughts enough.”
12915: 
12916: “But see here, Stubb, I thought you a little boasted just now, that you
12917: meant to give Fedallah a sea-toss, if you got a good chance. Now, if
12918: he’s so old as all those hoops of yours come to, and if he is going to
12919: live for ever, what good will it do to pitch him overboard—tell me
12920: that?
12921: 
12922: “Give him a good ducking, anyhow.”
12923: 
12924: “But he’d crawl back.”
12925: 
12926: “Duck him again; and keep ducking him.”
12927: 
12928: “Suppose he should take it into his head to duck you, though—yes, and
12929: drown you—what then?”
12930: 
12931: “I should like to see him try it; I’d give him such a pair of black
12932: eyes that he wouldn’t dare to show his face in the admiral’s cabin
12933: again for a long while, let alone down in the orlop there, where he
12934: lives, and hereabouts on the upper decks where he sneaks so much. Damn
12935: the devil, Flask; so you suppose I’m afraid of the devil? Who’s afraid
12936: of him, except the old governor who daresn’t catch him and put him in
12937: double-darbies, as he deserves, but lets him go about kidnapping
12938: people; aye, and signed a bond with him, that all the people the devil
12939: kidnapped, he’d roast for him? There’s a governor!”
12940: 
12941: “Do you suppose Fedallah wants to kidnap Captain Ahab?”
12942: 
12943: “Do I suppose it? You’ll know it before long, Flask. But I am going now
12944: to keep a sharp look-out on him; and if I see anything very suspicious
12945: going on, I’ll just take him by the nape of his neck, and say—Look
12946: here, Beelzebub, you don’t do it; and if he makes any fuss, by the Lord
12947: I’ll make a grab into his pocket for his tail, take it to the capstan,
12948: and give him such a wrenching and heaving, that his tail will come
12949: short off at the stump—do you see; and then, I rather guess when he
12950: finds himself docked in that queer fashion, he’ll sneak off without the
12951: poor satisfaction of feeling his tail between his legs.”
12952: 
12953: “And what will you do with the tail, Stubb?”
12954: 
12955: “Do with it? Sell it for an ox whip when we get home;—what else?”
12956: 
12957: “Now, do you mean what you say, and have been saying all along, Stubb?”
12958: 
12959: “Mean or not mean, here we are at the ship.”
12960: 
12961: The boats were here hailed, to tow the whale on the larboard side,
12962: where fluke chains and other necessaries were already prepared for
12963: securing him.
12964: 
12965: “Didn’t I tell you so?” said Flask; “yes, you’ll soon see this right
12966: whale’s head hoisted up opposite that parmacetti’s.”
12967: 
12968: In good time, Flask’s saying proved true. As before, the Pequod steeply
12969: leaned over towards the sperm whale’s head, now, by the counterpoise of
