12970: both heads, she regained her even keel; though sorely strained, you may
12971: well believe. So, when on one side you hoist in Locke’s head, you go
12972: over that way; but now, on the other side, hoist in Kant’s and you come
12973: back again; but in very poor plight. Thus, some minds for ever keep
12974: trimming boat. Oh, ye foolish! throw all these thunder-heads overboard,
12975: and then you will float light and right.
12976: 
12977: In disposing of the body of a right whale, when brought alongside the
12978: ship, the same preliminary proceedings commonly take place as in the
12979: case of a sperm whale; only, in the latter instance, the head is cut
12980: off whole, but in the former the lips and tongue are separately removed
12981: and hoisted on deck, with all the well known black bone attached to
12982: what is called the crown-piece. But nothing like this, in the present
12983: case, had been done. The carcases of both whales had dropped astern;
12984: and the head-laden ship not a little resembled a mule carrying a pair
12985: of overburdening panniers.
12986: 
12987: Meantime, Fedallah was calmly eyeing the right whale’s head, and ever
12988: and anon glancing from the deep wrinkles there to the lines in his own
12989: hand. And Ahab chanced so to stand, that the Parsee occupied his
12990: shadow; while, if the Parsee’s shadow was there at all it seemed only
12991: to blend with, and lengthen Ahab’s. As the crew toiled on, Laplandish
12992: speculations were bandied among them, concerning all these passing
12993: things.
12994: 
12995: 
12996: CHAPTER 74. The Sperm Whale’s Head—Contrasted View.
12997: 
12998: Here, now, are two great whales, laying their heads together; let us
12999: join them, and lay together our own.
13000: 
13001: Of the grand order of folio leviathans, the Sperm Whale and the Right
13002: Whale are by far the most noteworthy. They are the only whales
13003: regularly hunted by man. To the Nantucketer, they present the two
13004: extremes of all the known varieties of the whale. As the external
13005: difference between them is mainly observable in their heads; and as a
13006: head of each is this moment hanging from the Pequod’s side; and as we
13007: may freely go from one to the other, by merely stepping across the
13008: deck:—where, I should like to know, will you obtain a better chance to
13009: study practical cetology than here?
13010: 
13011: In the first place, you are struck by the general contrast between
13012: these heads. Both are massive enough in all conscience; but there is a
13013: certain mathematical symmetry in the Sperm Whale’s which the Right
13014: Whale’s sadly lacks. There is more character in the Sperm Whale’s head.
13015: As you behold it, you involuntarily yield the immense superiority to
13016: him, in point of pervading dignity. In the present instance, too, this
13017: dignity is heightened by the pepper and salt colour of his head at the
13018: summit, giving token of advanced age and large experience. In short, he
13019: is what the fishermen technically call a “grey-headed whale.”
13020: 
13021: Let us now note what is least dissimilar in these heads—namely, the two
13022: most important organs, the eye and the ear. Far back on the side of the
13023: head, and low down, near the angle of either whale’s jaw, if you
13024: narrowly search, you will at last see a lashless eye, which you would
13025: fancy to be a young colt’s eye; so out of all proportion is it to the
13026: magnitude of the head.
13027: 
13028: Now, from this peculiar sideway position of the whale’s eyes, it is
13029: plain that he can never see an object which is exactly ahead, no more
13030: than he can one exactly astern. In a word, the position of the whale’s
13031: eyes corresponds to that of a man’s ears; and you may fancy, for
13032: yourself, how it would fare with you, did you sideways survey objects
13033: through your ears. You would find that you could only command some
13034: thirty degrees of vision in advance of the straight side-line of sight;
13035: and about thirty more behind it. If your bitterest foe were walking
13036: straight towards you, with dagger uplifted in broad day, you would not
13037: be able to see him, any more than if he were stealing upon you from
13038: behind. In a word, you would have two backs, so to speak; but, at the
13039: same time, also, two fronts (side fronts): for what is it that makes
13040: the front of a man—what, indeed, but his eyes?
13041: 
13042: Moreover, while in most other animals that I can now think of, the eyes
13043: are so planted as imperceptibly to blend their visual power, so as to
13044: produce one picture and not two to the brain; the peculiar position of
13045: the whale’s eyes, effectually divided as they are by many cubic feet of
13046: solid head, which towers between them like a great mountain separating
13047: two lakes in valleys; this, of course, must wholly separate the
13048: impressions which each independent organ imparts. The whale, therefore,
13049: must see one distinct picture on this side, and another distinct
13050: picture on that side; while all between must be profound darkness and
13051: nothingness to him. Man may, in effect, be said to look out on the
13052: world from a sentry-box with two joined sashes for his window. But with
13053: the whale, these two sashes are separately inserted, making two
13054: distinct windows, but sadly impairing the view. This peculiarity of the
13055: whale’s eyes is a thing always to be borne in mind in the fishery; and
13056: to be remembered by the reader in some subsequent scenes.
13057: 
13058: A curious and most puzzling question might be started concerning this
13059: visual matter as touching the Leviathan. But I must be content with a
13060: hint. So long as a man’s eyes are open in the light, the act of seeing
13061: is involuntary; that is, he cannot then help mechanically seeing
13062: whatever objects are before him. Nevertheless, any one’s experience
13063: will teach him, that though he can take in an undiscriminating sweep of
13064: things at one glance, it is quite impossible for him, attentively, and
13065: completely, to examine any two things—however large or however small—at
13066: one and the same instant of time; never mind if they lie side by side
13067: and touch each other. But if you now come to separate these two
13068: objects, and surround each by a circle of profound darkness; then, in
13069: order to see one of them, in such a manner as to bring your mind to
13070: bear on it, the other will be utterly excluded from your contemporary
13071: consciousness. How is it, then, with the whale? True, both his eyes, in
13072: themselves, must simultaneously act; but is his brain so much more
13073: comprehensive, combining, and subtle than man’s, that he can at the
13074: same moment of time attentively examine two distinct prospects, one on
13075: one side of him, and the other in an exactly opposite direction? If he
13076: can, then is it as marvellous a thing in him, as if a man were able
13077: simultaneously to go through the demonstrations of two distinct
13078: problems in Euclid. Nor, strictly investigated, is there any
13079: incongruity in this comparison.
13080: 
13081: It may be but an idle whim, but it has always seemed to me, that the
13082: extraordinary vacillations of movement displayed by some whales when
13083: beset by three or four boats; the timidity and liability to queer
13084: frights, so common to such whales; I think that all this indirectly
13085: proceeds from the helpless perplexity of volition, in which their
13086: divided and diametrically opposite powers of vision must involve them.
13087: 
13088: But the ear of the whale is full as curious as the eye. If you are an
13089: entire stranger to their race, you might hunt over these two heads for
13090: hours, and never discover that organ. The ear has no external leaf
13091: whatever; and into the hole itself you can hardly insert a quill, so
13092: wondrously minute is it. It is lodged a little behind the eye. With
13093: respect to their ears, this important difference is to be observed
13094: between the sperm whale and the right. While the ear of the former has
13095: an external opening, that of the latter is entirely and evenly covered
13096: over with a membrane, so as to be quite imperceptible from without.
13097: 
13098: Is it not curious, that so vast a being as the whale should see the
13099: world through so small an eye, and hear the thunder through an ear
13100: which is smaller than a hare’s? But if his eyes were broad as the lens
13101: of Herschel’s great telescope; and his ears capacious as the porches of
13102: cathedrals; would that make him any longer of sight, or sharper of
13103: hearing? Not at all.—Why then do you try to “enlarge” your mind?
13104: Subtilize it.
13105: 
13106: Let us now with whatever levers and steam-engines we have at hand, cant
13107: over the sperm whale’s head, that it may lie bottom up; then, ascending
13108: by a ladder to the summit, have a peep down the mouth; and were it not
13109: that the body is now completely separated from it, with a lantern we
13110: might descend into the great Kentucky Mammoth Cave of his stomach. But
13111: let us hold on here by this tooth, and look about us where we are. What
13112: a really beautiful and chaste-looking mouth! from floor to ceiling,
13113: lined, or rather papered with a glistening white membrane, glossy as
13114: bridal satins.
13115: 
13116: But come out now, and look at this portentous lower jaw, which seems
13117: like the long narrow lid of an immense snuff-box, with the hinge at one
13118: end, instead of one side. If you pry it up, so as to get it overhead,
13119: and expose its rows of teeth, it seems a terrific portcullis; and such,
13120: alas! it proves to many a poor wight in the fishery, upon whom these
13121: spikes fall with impaling force. But far more terrible is it to behold,
13122: when fathoms down in the sea, you see some sulky whale, floating there
13123: suspended, with his prodigious jaw, some fifteen feet long, hanging
13124: straight down at right-angles with his body, for all the world like a
13125: ship’s jib-boom. This whale is not dead; he is only dispirited; out of
13126: sorts, perhaps; hypochondriac; and so supine, that the hinges of his
13127: jaw have relaxed, leaving him there in that ungainly sort of plight, a
13128: reproach to all his tribe, who must, no doubt, imprecate lock-jaws upon
13129: him.
13130: 
13131: In most cases this lower jaw—being easily unhinged by a practised
13132: artist—is disengaged and hoisted on deck for the purpose of extracting
13133: the ivory teeth, and furnishing a supply of that hard white whalebone
13134: with which the fishermen fashion all sorts of curious articles,
13135: including canes, umbrella-stocks, and handles to riding-whips.
13136: 
13137: With a long, weary hoist the jaw is dragged on board, as if it were an
13138: anchor; and when the proper time comes—some few days after the other
13139: work—Queequeg, Daggoo, and Tashtego, being all accomplished dentists,
13140: are set to drawing teeth. With a keen cutting-spade, Queequeg lances
13141: the gums; then the jaw is lashed down to ringbolts, and a tackle being
13142: rigged from aloft, they drag out these teeth, as Michigan oxen drag
13143: stumps of old oaks out of wild wood lands. There are generally
13144: forty-two teeth in all; in old whales, much worn down, but undecayed;
13145: nor filled after our artificial fashion. The jaw is afterwards sawn
13146: into slabs, and piled away like joists for building houses.
13147: 
13148: 
13149: CHAPTER 75. The Right Whale’s Head—Contrasted View.
13150: 
13151: Crossing the deck, let us now have a good long look at the Right
13152: Whale’s head.
13153: 
13154: As in general shape the noble Sperm Whale’s head may be compared to a
13155: Roman war-chariot (especially in front, where it is so broadly
13156: rounded); so, at a broad view, the Right Whale’s head bears a rather
13157: inelegant resemblance to a gigantic galliot-toed shoe. Two hundred
13158: years ago an old Dutch voyager likened its shape to that of a
13159: shoemaker’s last. And in this same last or shoe, that old woman of the
13160: nursery tale, with the swarming brood, might very comfortably be
13161: lodged, she and all her progeny.
13162: 
13163: But as you come nearer to this great head it begins to assume different
13164: aspects, according to your point of view. If you stand on its summit
13165: and look at these two F-shaped spoutholes, you would take the whole
13166: head for an enormous bass-viol, and these spiracles, the apertures in
13167: its sounding-board. Then, again, if you fix your eye upon this strange,
13168: crested, comb-like incrustation on the top of the mass—this green,
13169: barnacled thing, which the Greenlanders call the “crown,” and the
13170: Southern fishers the “bonnet” of the Right Whale; fixing your eyes
13171: solely on this, you would take the head for the trunk of some huge oak,
13172: with a bird’s nest in its crotch. At any rate, when you watch those
13173: live crabs that nestle here on this bonnet, such an idea will be almost
13174: sure to occur to you; unless, indeed, your fancy has been fixed by the
13175: technical term “crown” also bestowed upon it; in which case you will
13176: take great interest in thinking how this mighty monster is actually a
13177: diademed king of the sea, whose green crown has been put together for
13178: him in this marvellous manner. But if this whale be a king, he is a
13179: very sulky looking fellow to grace a diadem. Look at that hanging lower
13180: lip! what a huge sulk and pout is there! a sulk and pout, by
13181: carpenter’s measurement, about twenty feet long and five feet deep; a
13182: sulk and pout that will yield you some 500 gallons of oil and more.
13183: 
13184: A great pity, now, that this unfortunate whale should be hare-lipped.
13185: The fissure is about a foot across. Probably the mother during an
13186: important interval was sailing down the Peruvian coast, when
13187: earthquakes caused the beach to gape. Over this lip, as over a slippery
13188: threshold, we now slide into the mouth. Upon my word were I at
13189: Mackinaw, I should take this to be the inside of an Indian wigwam. Good
13190: Lord! is this the road that Jonah went? The roof is about twelve feet
13191: high, and runs to a pretty sharp angle, as if there were a regular
13192: ridge-pole there; while these ribbed, arched, hairy sides, present us
13193: with those wondrous, half vertical, scimetar-shaped slats of whalebone,
13194: say three hundred on a side, which depending from the upper part of the
13195: head or crown bone, form those Venetian blinds which have elsewhere
13196: been cursorily mentioned. The edges of these bones are fringed with
13197: hairy fibres, through which the Right Whale strains the water, and in
13198: whose intricacies he retains the small fish, when openmouthed he goes
13199: through the seas of brit in feeding time. In the central blinds of
13200: bone, as they stand in their natural order, there are certain curious
13201: marks, curves, hollows, and ridges, whereby some whalemen calculate the
13202: creature’s age, as the age of an oak by its circular rings. Though the
13203: certainty of this criterion is far from demonstrable, yet it has the
13204: savor of analogical probability. At any rate, if we yield to it, we
13205: must grant a far greater age to the Right Whale than at first glance
13206: will seem reasonable.
13207: 
13208: In old times, there seem to have prevailed the most curious fancies
13209: concerning these blinds. One voyager in Purchas calls them the wondrous
13210: “whiskers” inside of the whale’s mouth;* another, “hogs’ bristles”; a
13211: third old gentleman in Hackluyt uses the following elegant language:
13212: “There are about two hundred and fifty fins growing on each side of his
13213: upper _chop_, which arch over his tongue on each side of his mouth.”
13214: 
13215: *This reminds us that the Right Whale really has a sort of whisker, or
13216: rather a moustache, consisting of a few scattered white hairs on the
13217: upper part of the outer end of the lower jaw. Sometimes these tufts
13218: impart a rather brigandish expression to his otherwise solemn
13219: countenance.
13220: 
13221: As every one knows, these same “hogs’ bristles,” “fins,” “whiskers,”
13222: “blinds,” or whatever you please, furnish to the ladies their busks and
13223: other stiffening contrivances. But in this particular, the demand has
13224: long been on the decline. It was in Queen Anne’s time that the bone was
13225: in its glory, the farthingale being then all the fashion. And as those
13226: ancient dames moved about gaily, though in the jaws of the whale, as
13227: you may say; even so, in a shower, with the like thoughtlessness, do we
13228: nowadays fly under the same jaws for protection; the umbrella being a
13229: tent spread over the same bone.
13230: 
13231: But now forget all about blinds and whiskers for a moment, and,
13232: standing in the Right Whale’s mouth, look around you afresh. Seeing all
13233: these colonnades of bone so methodically ranged about, would you not
13234: think you were inside of the great Haarlem organ, and gazing upon its
13235: thousand pipes? For a carpet to the organ we have a rug of the softest
13236: Turkey—the tongue, which is glued, as it were, to the floor of the
13237: mouth. It is very fat and tender, and apt to tear in pieces in hoisting
13238: it on deck. This particular tongue now before us; at a passing glance I
13239: should say it was a six-barreler; that is, it will yield you about that
13240: amount of oil.
13241: 
13242: Ere this, you must have plainly seen the truth of what I started
13243: with—that the Sperm Whale and the Right Whale have almost entirely
13244: different heads. To sum up, then: in the Right Whale’s there is no
13245: great well of sperm; no ivory teeth at all; no long, slender mandible
13246: of a lower jaw, like the Sperm Whale’s. Nor in the Sperm Whale are
13247: there any of those blinds of bone; no huge lower lip; and scarcely
13248: anything of a tongue. Again, the Right Whale has two external
13249: spout-holes, the Sperm Whale only one.
13250: 
13251: Look your last, now, on these venerable hooded heads, while they yet
13252: lie together; for one will soon sink, unrecorded, in the sea; the other
13253: will not be very long in following.
13254: 
13255: Can you catch the expression of the Sperm Whale’s there? It is the same
13256: he died with, only some of the longer wrinkles in the forehead seem now
13257: faded away. I think his broad brow to be full of a prairie-like
13258: placidity, born of a speculative indifference as to death. But mark the
13259: other head’s expression. See that amazing lower lip, pressed by
13260: accident against the vessel’s side, so as firmly to embrace the jaw.
13261: Does not this whole head seem to speak of an enormous practical
13262: resolution in facing death? This Right Whale I take to have been a
13263: Stoic; the Sperm Whale, a Platonian, who might have taken up Spinoza in
13264: his latter years.
13265: 
13266: 
13267: CHAPTER 76. The Battering-Ram.
13268: 
13269: Ere quitting, for the nonce, the Sperm Whale’s head, I would have you,
13270: as a sensible physiologist, simply—particularly remark its front
13271: aspect, in all its compacted collectedness. I would have you
13272: investigate it now with the sole view of forming to yourself some
13273: unexaggerated, intelligent estimate of whatever battering-ram power may
13274: be lodged there. Here is a vital point; for you must either
13275: satisfactorily settle this matter with yourself, or for ever remain an
13276: infidel as to one of the most appalling, but not the less true events,
13277: perhaps anywhere to be found in all recorded history.
13278: 
13279: You observe that in the ordinary swimming position of the Sperm Whale,
13280: the front of his head presents an almost wholly vertical plane to the
13281: water; you observe that the lower part of that front slopes
13282: considerably backwards, so as to furnish more of a retreat for the long
13283: socket which receives the boom-like lower jaw; you observe that the
13284: mouth is entirely under the head, much in the same way, indeed, as
13285: though your own mouth were entirely under your chin. Moreover you
13286: observe that the whale has no external nose; and that what nose he
13287: has—his spout hole—is on the top of his head; you observe that his eyes
13288: and ears are at the sides of his head, nearly one third of his entire
13289: length from the front. Wherefore, you must now have perceived that the
13290: front of the Sperm Whale’s head is a dead, blind wall, without a single
13291: organ or tender prominence of any sort whatsoever. Furthermore, you are
13292: now to consider that only in the extreme, lower, backward sloping part
13293: of the front of the head, is there the slightest vestige of bone; and
13294: not till you get near twenty feet from the forehead do you come to the
13295: full cranial development. So that this whole enormous boneless mass is
13296: as one wad. Finally, though, as will soon be revealed, its contents
13297: partly comprise the most delicate oil; yet, you are now to be apprised
13298: of the nature of the substance which so impregnably invests all that
13299: apparent effeminacy. In some previous place I have described to you how
13300: the blubber wraps the body of the whale, as the rind wraps an orange.
13301: Just so with the head; but with this difference: about the head this
13302: envelope, though not so thick, is of a boneless toughness, inestimable
13303: by any man who has not handled it. The severest pointed harpoon, the
13304: sharpest lance darted by the strongest human arm, impotently rebounds
13305: from it. It is as though the forehead of the Sperm Whale were paved
13306: with horses’ hoofs. I do not think that any sensation lurks in it.
13307: 
13308: Bethink yourself also of another thing. When two large, loaded Indiamen
13309: chance to crowd and crush towards each other in the docks, what do the
13310: sailors do? They do not suspend between them, at the point of coming
13311: contact, any merely hard substance, like iron or wood. No, they hold
13312: there a large, round wad of tow and cork, enveloped in the thickest and
13313: toughest of ox-hide. That bravely and uninjured takes the jam which
13314: would have snapped all their oaken handspikes and iron crow-bars. By
13315: itself this sufficiently illustrates the obvious fact I drive at. But
13316: supplementary to this, it has hypothetically occurred to me, that as
13317: ordinary fish possess what is called a swimming bladder in them,
13318: capable, at will, of distension or contraction; and as the Sperm Whale,
13319: as far as I know, has no such provision in him; considering, too, the
13320: otherwise inexplicable manner in which he now depresses his head
13321: altogether beneath the surface, and anon swims with it high elevated
13322: out of the water; considering the unobstructed elasticity of its
13323: envelope; considering the unique interior of his head; it has
13324: hypothetically occurred to me, I say, that those mystical lung-celled
13325: honeycombs there may possibly have some hitherto unknown and
13326: unsuspected connexion with the outer air, so as to be susceptible to
13327: atmospheric distension and contraction. If this be so, fancy the
13328: irresistibleness of that might, to which the most impalpable and
13329: destructive of all elements contributes.
13330: 
13331: Now, mark. Unerringly impelling this dead, impregnable, uninjurable
13332: wall, and this most buoyant thing within; there swims behind it all a
13333: mass of tremendous life, only to be adequately estimated as piled wood
13334: is—by the cord; and all obedient to one volition, as the smallest
13335: insect. So that when I shall hereafter detail to you all the
13336: specialities and concentrations of potency everywhere lurking in this
13337: expansive monster; when I shall show you some of his more
13338: inconsiderable braining feats; I trust you will have renounced all
13339: ignorant incredulity, and be ready to abide by this; that though the
13340: Sperm Whale stove a passage through the Isthmus of Darien, and mixed
13341: the Atlantic with the Pacific, you would not elevate one hair of your
13342: eye-brow. For unless you own the whale, you are but a provincial and
13343: sentimentalist in Truth. But clear Truth is a thing for salamander
13344: giants only to encounter; how small the chances for the provincials
13345: then? What befell the weakling youth lifting the dread goddess’s veil
13346: at Lais?
13347: 
13348: 
13349: CHAPTER 77. The Great Heidelburgh Tun.
13350: 
13351: Now comes the Baling of the Case. But to comprehend it aright, you must
13352: know something of the curious internal structure of the thing operated
13353: upon.
13354: 
13355: Regarding the Sperm Whale’s head as a solid oblong, you may, on an
13356: inclined plane, sideways divide it into two quoins,* whereof the lower
13357: is the bony structure, forming the cranium and jaws, and the upper an
13358: unctuous mass wholly free from bones; its broad forward end forming the
13359: expanded vertical apparent forehead of the whale. At the middle of the
13360: forehead horizontally subdivide this upper quoin, and then you have two
13361: almost equal parts, which before were naturally divided by an internal
13362: wall of a thick tendinous substance.
13363: 
13364: *Quoin is not a Euclidean term. It belongs to the pure nautical
13365: mathematics. I know not that it has been defined before. A quoin is a
13366: solid which differs from a wedge in having its sharp end formed by the
13367: steep inclination of one side, instead of the mutual tapering of both
13368: sides.
13369: 
13370: The lower subdivided part, called the junk, is one immense honeycomb of
13371: oil, formed by the crossing and recrossing, into ten thousand
13372: infiltrated cells, of tough elastic white fibres throughout its whole
13373: extent. The upper part, known as the Case, may be regarded as the great
13374: Heidelburgh Tun of the Sperm Whale. And as that famous great tierce is
13375: mystically carved in front, so the whale’s vast plaited forehead forms
13376: innumerable strange devices for the emblematical adornment of his
13377: wondrous tun. Moreover, as that of Heidelburgh was always replenished
13378: with the most excellent of the wines of the Rhenish valleys, so the tun
13379: of the whale contains by far the most precious of all his oily
13380: vintages; namely, the highly-prized spermaceti, in its absolutely pure,
13381: limpid, and odoriferous state. Nor is this precious substance found
13382: unalloyed in any other part of the creature. Though in life it remains
13383: perfectly fluid, yet, upon exposure to the air, after death, it soon
13384: begins to concrete; sending forth beautiful crystalline shoots, as when
13385: the first thin delicate ice is just forming in water. A large whale’s
13386: case generally yields about five hundred gallons of sperm, though from
13387: unavoidable circumstances, considerable of it is spilled, leaks, and
13388: dribbles away, or is otherwise irrevocably lost in the ticklish
13389: business of securing what you can.
13390: 
13391: I know not with what fine and costly material the Heidelburgh Tun was
13392: coated within, but in superlative richness that coating could not
13393: possibly have compared with the silken pearl-coloured membrane, like
13394: the lining of a fine pelisse, forming the inner surface of the Sperm
13395: Whale’s case.
13396: 
13397: It will have been seen that the Heidelburgh Tun of the Sperm Whale
13398: embraces the entire length of the entire top of the head; and since—as
13399: has been elsewhere set forth—the head embraces one third of the whole
13400: length of the creature, then setting that length down at eighty feet
13401: for a good sized whale, you have more than twenty-six feet for the
13402: depth of the tun, when it is lengthwise hoisted up and down against a
13403: ship’s side.
13404: 
13405: As in decapitating the whale, the operator’s instrument is brought
13406: close to the spot where an entrance is subsequently forced into the
13407: spermaceti magazine; he has, therefore, to be uncommonly heedful, lest
13408: a careless, untimely stroke should invade the sanctuary and wastingly
13409: let out its invaluable contents. It is this decapitated end of the
13410: head, also, which is at last elevated out of the water, and retained in
13411: that position by the enormous cutting tackles, whose hempen
13412: combinations, on one side, make quite a wilderness of ropes in that
13413: quarter.
13414: 
13415: Thus much being said, attend now, I pray you, to that marvellous and—in
13416: this particular instance—almost fatal operation whereby the Sperm
13417: Whale’s great Heidelburgh Tun is tapped.
13418: 
13419: 
13420: CHAPTER 78. Cistern and Buckets.
13421: 
13422: Nimble as a cat, Tashtego mounts aloft; and without altering his erect
13423: posture, runs straight out upon the overhanging mainyard-arm, to the
13424: part where it exactly projects over the hoisted Tun. He has carried
13425: with him a light tackle called a whip, consisting of only two parts,
13426: travelling through a single-sheaved block. Securing this block, so that
13427: it hangs down from the yard-arm, he swings one end of the rope, till it
13428: is caught and firmly held by a hand on deck. Then, hand-over-hand, down
13429: the other part, the Indian drops through the air, till dexterously he
13430: lands on the summit of the head. There—still high elevated above the
13431: rest of the company, to whom he vivaciously cries—he seems some Turkish
13432: Muezzin calling the good people to prayers from the top of a tower. A
13433: short-handled sharp spade being sent up to him, he diligently searches
13434: for the proper place to begin breaking into the Tun. In this business
13435: he proceeds very heedfully, like a treasure-hunter in some old house,
13436: sounding the walls to find where the gold is masoned in. By the time
13437: this cautious search is over, a stout iron-bound bucket, precisely like
13438: a well-bucket, has been attached to one end of the whip; while the
13439: other end, being stretched across the deck, is there held by two or
13440: three alert hands. These last now hoist the bucket within grasp of the
13441: Indian, to whom another person has reached up a very long pole.
13442: Inserting this pole into the bucket, Tashtego downward guides the
13443: bucket into the Tun, till it entirely disappears; then giving the word
13444: to the seamen at the whip, up comes the bucket again, all bubbling like
13445: a dairy-maid’s pail of new milk. Carefully lowered from its height, the
13446: full-freighted vessel is caught by an appointed hand, and quickly
13447: emptied into a large tub. Then remounting aloft, it again goes through
13448: the same round until the deep cistern will yield no more. Towards the
13449: end, Tashtego has to ram his long pole harder and harder, and deeper
13450: and deeper into the Tun, until some twenty feet of the pole have gone
13451: down.
13452: 
13453: Now, the people of the Pequod had been baling some time in this way;
13454: several tubs had been filled with the fragrant sperm; when all at once
13455: a queer accident happened. Whether it was that Tashtego, that wild
13456: Indian, was so heedless and reckless as to let go for a moment his
13457: one-handed hold on the great cabled tackles suspending the head; or
13458: whether the place where he stood was so treacherous and oozy; or
13459: whether the Evil One himself would have it to fall out so, without
13460: stating his particular reasons; how it was exactly, there is no telling
13461: now; but, on a sudden, as the eightieth or ninetieth bucket came
13462: suckingly up—my God! poor Tashtego—like the twin reciprocating bucket
13463: in a veritable well, dropped head-foremost down into this great Tun of
13464: Heidelburgh, and with a horrible oily gurgling, went clean out of
13465: sight!
13466: 
13467: “Man overboard!” cried Daggoo, who amid the general consternation first
13468: came to his senses. “Swing the bucket this way!” and putting one foot
13469: into it, so as the better to secure his slippery hand-hold on the whip
13470: itself, the hoisters ran him high up to the top of the head, almost
13471: before Tashtego could have reached its interior bottom. Meantime, there
13472: was a terrible tumult. Looking over the side, they saw the before
13473: lifeless head throbbing and heaving just below the surface of the sea,
13474: as if that moment seized with some momentous idea; whereas it was only
13475: the poor Indian unconsciously revealing by those struggles the perilous
13476: depth to which he had sunk.
13477: 
13478: At this instant, while Daggoo, on the summit of the head, was clearing
13479: the whip—which had somehow got foul of the great cutting tackles—a
13480: sharp cracking noise was heard; and to the unspeakable horror of all,
13481: one of the two enormous hooks suspending the head tore out, and with a
13482: vast vibration the enormous mass sideways swung, till the drunk ship
13483: reeled and shook as if smitten by an iceberg. The one remaining hook,
13484: upon which the entire strain now depended, seemed every instant to be
13485: on the point of giving way; an event still more likely from the violent
13486: motions of the head.
13487: 
13488: “Come down, come down!” yelled the seamen to Daggoo, but with one hand
13489: holding on to the heavy tackles, so that if the head should drop, he
13490: would still remain suspended; the negro having cleared the foul line,
13491: rammed down the bucket into the now collapsed well, meaning that the
13492: buried harpooneer should grasp it, and so be hoisted out.
13493: 
13494: “In heaven’s name, man,” cried Stubb, “are you ramming home a cartridge
13495: there?—Avast! How will that help him; jamming that iron-bound bucket on
13496: top of his head? Avast, will ye!”
13497: 
13498: “Stand clear of the tackle!” cried a voice like the bursting of a
13499: rocket.
13500: 
13501: Almost in the same instant, with a thunder-boom, the enormous mass
13502: dropped into the sea, like Niagara’s Table-Rock into the whirlpool; the
13503: suddenly relieved hull rolled away from it, to far down her glittering
13504: copper; and all caught their breath, as half swinging—now over the
13505: sailors’ heads, and now over the water—Daggoo, through a thick mist of
13506: spray, was dimly beheld clinging to the pendulous tackles, while poor,
13507: buried-alive Tashtego was sinking utterly down to the bottom of the
13508: sea! But hardly had the blinding vapor cleared away, when a naked
13509: figure with a boarding-sword in his hand, was for one swift moment seen
13510: hovering over the bulwarks. The next, a loud splash announced that my
13511: brave Queequeg had dived to the rescue. One packed rush was made to the
13512: side, and every eye counted every ripple, as moment followed moment,
13513: and no sign of either the sinker or the diver could be seen. Some hands
13514: now jumped into a boat alongside, and pushed a little off from the
13515: ship.
13516: 
13517: “Ha! ha!” cried Daggoo, all at once, from his now quiet, swinging perch
13518: overhead; and looking further off from the side, we saw an arm thrust
13519: upright from the blue waves; a sight strange to see, as an arm thrust
13520: forth from the grass over a grave.
13521: 
13522: “Both! both!—it is both!”—cried Daggoo again with a joyful shout; and
13523: soon after, Queequeg was seen boldly striking out with one hand, and
13524: with the other clutching the long hair of the Indian. Drawn into the
13525: waiting boat, they were quickly brought to the deck; but Tashtego was
13526: long in coming to, and Queequeg did not look very brisk.
13527: 
13528: Now, how had this noble rescue been accomplished? Why, diving after the
13529: slowly descending head, Queequeg with his keen sword had made side
13530: lunges near its bottom, so as to scuttle a large hole there; then
13531: dropping his sword, had thrust his long arm far inwards and upwards,
13532: and so hauled out poor Tash by the head. He averred, that upon first
13533: thrusting in for him, a leg was presented; but well knowing that that
13534: was not as it ought to be, and might occasion great trouble;—he had
13535: thrust back the leg, and by a dexterous heave and toss, had wrought a
13536: somerset upon the Indian; so that with the next trial, he came forth in
13537: the good old way—head foremost. As for the great head itself, that was
13538: doing as well as could be expected.
13539: 
13540: And thus, through the courage and great skill in obstetrics of
13541: Queequeg, the deliverance, or rather, delivery of Tashtego, was
13542: successfully accomplished, in the teeth, too, of the most untoward and
13543: apparently hopeless impediments; which is a lesson by no means to be
13544: forgotten. Midwifery should be taught in the same course with fencing
13545: and boxing, riding and rowing.
13546: 
13547: I know that this queer adventure of the Gay-Header’s will be sure to
13548: seem incredible to some landsmen, though they themselves may have
13549: either seen or heard of some one’s falling into a cistern ashore; an
13550: accident which not seldom happens, and with much less reason too than
13551: the Indian’s, considering the exceeding slipperiness of the curb of the
13552: Sperm Whale’s well.
13553: 
13554: But, peradventure, it may be sagaciously urged, how is this? We thought
13555: the tissued, infiltrated head of the Sperm Whale, was the lightest and
13556: most corky part about him; and yet thou makest it sink in an element of
13557: a far greater specific gravity than itself. We have thee there. Not at
13558: all, but I have ye; for at the time poor Tash fell in, the case had
13559: been nearly emptied of its lighter contents, leaving little but the
13560: dense tendinous wall of the well—a double welded, hammered substance,
13561: as I have before said, much heavier than the sea water, and a lump of
13562: which sinks in it like lead almost. But the tendency to rapid sinking
13563: in this substance was in the present instance materially counteracted
13564: by the other parts of the head remaining undetached from it, so that it
13565: sank very slowly and deliberately indeed, affording Queequeg a fair
13566: chance for performing his agile obstetrics on the run, as you may say.
13567: Yes, it was a running delivery, so it was.
13568: 
13569: Now, had Tashtego perished in that head, it had been a very precious
13570: perishing; smothered in the very whitest and daintiest of fragrant
13571: spermaceti; coffined, hearsed, and tombed in the secret inner chamber
13572: and sanctum sanctorum of the whale. Only one sweeter end can readily be
13573: recalled—the delicious death of an Ohio honey-hunter, who seeking honey
13574: in the crotch of a hollow tree, found such exceeding store of it, that
13575: leaning too far over, it sucked him in, so that he died embalmed. How
13576: many, think ye, have likewise fallen into Plato’s honey head, and
13577: sweetly perished there?
13578: 
13579: 
13580: CHAPTER 79. The Prairie.
13581: 
13582: To scan the lines of his face, or feel the bumps on the head of this
13583: Leviathan; this is a thing which no Physiognomist or Phrenologist has
13584: as yet undertaken. Such an enterprise would seem almost as hopeful as
13585: for Lavater to have scrutinized the wrinkles on the Rock of Gibraltar,
13586: or for Gall to have mounted a ladder and manipulated the Dome of the
13587: Pantheon. Still, in that famous work of his, Lavater not only treats of
13588: the various faces of men, but also attentively studies the faces of
13589: horses, birds, serpents, and fish; and dwells in detail upon the
13590: modifications of expression discernible therein. Nor have Gall and his
13591: disciple Spurzheim failed to throw out some hints touching the
13592: phrenological characteristics of other beings than man. Therefore,
13593: though I am but ill qualified for a pioneer, in the application of
13594: these two semi-sciences to the whale, I will do my endeavor. I try all
13595: things; I achieve what I can.
13596: 
13597: Physiognomically regarded, the Sperm Whale is an anomalous creature. He
13598: has no proper nose. And since the nose is the central and most
13599: conspicuous of the features; and since it perhaps most modifies and
13600: finally controls their combined expression; hence it would seem that
13601: its entire absence, as an external appendage, must very largely affect
13602: the countenance of the whale. For as in landscape gardening, a spire,
13603: cupola, monument, or tower of some sort, is deemed almost indispensable
13604: to the completion of the scene; so no face can be physiognomically in
13605: keeping without the elevated open-work belfry of the nose. Dash the
13606: nose from Phidias’s marble Jove, and what a sorry remainder!
13607: Nevertheless, Leviathan is of so mighty a magnitude, all his
13608: proportions are so stately, that the same deficiency which in the
13609: sculptured Jove were hideous, in him is no blemish at all. Nay, it is
13610: an added grandeur. A nose to the whale would have been impertinent. As
13611: on your physiognomical voyage you sail round his vast head in your
13612: jolly-boat, your noble conceptions of him are never insulted by the
13613: reflection that he has a nose to be pulled. A pestilent conceit, which
13614: so often will insist upon obtruding even when beholding the mightiest
13615: royal beadle on his throne.
13616: 
13617: In some particulars, perhaps the most imposing physiognomical view to
13618: be had of the Sperm Whale, is that of the full front of his head. This
13619: aspect is sublime.
13620: 
13621: In thought, a fine human brow is like the East when troubled with the
13622: morning. In the repose of the pasture, the curled brow of the bull has
13623: a touch of the grand in it. Pushing heavy cannon up mountain defiles,
13624: the elephant’s brow is majestic. Human or animal, the mystical brow is
13625: as that great golden seal affixed by the German emperors to their
13626: decrees. It signifies—“God: done this day by my hand.” But in most
13627: creatures, nay in man himself, very often the brow is but a mere strip
13628: of alpine land lying along the snow line. Few are the foreheads which
13629: like Shakespeare’s or Melancthon’s rise so high, and descend so low,
13630: that the eyes themselves seem clear, eternal, tideless mountain lakes;
13631: and all above them in the forehead’s wrinkles, you seem to track the
13632: antlered thoughts descending there to drink, as the Highland hunters
13633: track the snow prints of the deer. But in the great Sperm Whale, this
13634: high and mighty god-like dignity inherent in the brow is so immensely
13635: amplified, that gazing on it, in that full front view, you feel the
13636: Deity and the dread powers more forcibly than in beholding any other
13637: object in living nature. For you see no one point precisely; not one
13638: distinct feature is revealed; no nose, eyes, ears, or mouth; no face;
13639: he has none, proper; nothing but that one broad firmament of a
13640: forehead, pleated with riddles; dumbly lowering with the doom of boats,
13641: and ships, and men. Nor, in profile, does this wondrous brow diminish;
13642: though that way viewed its grandeur does not domineer upon you so. In
13643: profile, you plainly perceive that horizontal, semi-crescentic
13644: depression in the forehead’s middle, which, in man, is Lavater’s mark
13645: of genius.
13646: 
13647: But how? Genius in the Sperm Whale? Has the Sperm Whale ever written a
13648: book, spoken a speech? No, his great genius is declared in his doing
13649: nothing particular to prove it. It is moreover declared in his
13650: pyramidical silence. And this reminds me that had the great Sperm Whale
13651: been known to the young Orient World, he would have been deified by
13652: their child-magian thoughts. They deified the crocodile of the Nile,
13653: because the crocodile is tongueless; and the Sperm Whale has no tongue,
13654: or at least it is so exceedingly small, as to be incapable of
13655: protrusion. If hereafter any highly cultured, poetical nation shall
13656: lure back to their birth-right, the merry May-day gods of old; and
13657: livingly enthrone them again in the now egotistical sky; in the now
13658: unhaunted hill; then be sure, exalted to Jove’s high seat, the great
13659: Sperm Whale shall lord it.
13660: 
13661: Champollion deciphered the wrinkled granite hieroglyphics. But there is
13662: no Champollion to decipher the Egypt of every man’s and every being’s
13663: face. Physiognomy, like every other human science, is but a passing
13664: fable. If then, Sir William Jones, who read in thirty languages, could
13665: not read the simplest peasant’s face in its profounder and more subtle
13666: meanings, how may unlettered Ishmael hope to read the awful Chaldee of
13667: the Sperm Whale’s brow? I but put that brow before you. Read it if you
13668: can.
13669: 
13670: 
13671: CHAPTER 80. The Nut.
13672: 
13673: If the Sperm Whale be physiognomically a Sphinx, to the phrenologist
13674: his brain seems that geometrical circle which it is impossible to
13675: square.
13676: 
13677: In the full-grown creature the skull will measure at least twenty feet
13678: in length. Unhinge the lower jaw, and the side view of this skull is as
13679: the side of a moderately inclined plane resting throughout on a level
13680: base. But in life—as we have elsewhere seen—this inclined plane is
13681: angularly filled up, and almost squared by the enormous superincumbent
13682: mass of the junk and sperm. At the high end the skull forms a crater to
13683: bed that part of the mass; while under the long floor of this crater—in
13684: another cavity seldom exceeding ten inches in length and as many in
13685: depth—reposes the mere handful of this monster’s brain. The brain is at
13686: least twenty feet from his apparent forehead in life; it is hidden away
13687: behind its vast outworks, like the innermost citadel within the
13688: amplified fortifications of Quebec. So like a choice casket is it
13689: secreted in him, that I have known some whalemen who peremptorily deny
13690: that the Sperm Whale has any other brain than that palpable semblance
13691: of one formed by the cubic-yards of his sperm magazine. Lying in
13692: strange folds, courses, and convolutions, to their apprehensions, it
13693: seems more in keeping with the idea of his general might to regard that
13694: mystic part of him as the seat of his intelligence.
13695: 
13696: It is plain, then, that phrenologically the head of this Leviathan, in
13697: the creature’s living intact state, is an entire delusion. As for his
13698: true brain, you can then see no indications of it, nor feel any. The
13699: whale, like all things that are mighty, wears a false brow to the
13700: common world.
13701: 
13702: If you unload his skull of its spermy heaps and then take a rear view
13703: of its rear end, which is the high end, you will be struck by its
13704: resemblance to the human skull, beheld in the same situation, and from
13705: the same point of view. Indeed, place this reversed skull (scaled down
13706: to the human magnitude) among a plate of men’s skulls, and you would
13707: involuntarily confound it with them; and remarking the depressions on
13708: one part of its summit, in phrenological phrase you would say—This man
13709: had no self-esteem, and no veneration. And by those negations,
13710: considered along with the affirmative fact of his prodigious bulk and
13711: power, you can best form to yourself the truest, though not the most
13712: exhilarating conception of what the most exalted potency is.
13713: 
13714: But if from the comparative dimensions of the whale’s proper brain, you
13715: deem it incapable of being adequately charted, then I have another idea
13716: for you. If you attentively regard almost any quadruped’s spine, you
13717: will be struck with the resemblance of its vertebræ to a strung
13718: necklace of dwarfed skulls, all bearing rudimental resemblance to the
13719: skull proper. It is a German conceit, that the vertebræ are absolutely
13720: undeveloped skulls. But the curious external resemblance, I take it the
13721: Germans were not the first men to perceive. A foreign friend once
13722: pointed it out to me, in the skeleton of a foe he had slain, and with
13723: the vertebræ of which he was inlaying, in a sort of basso-relievo, the
13724: beaked prow of his canoe. Now, I consider that the phrenologists have
13725: omitted an important thing in not pushing their investigations from the
13726: cerebellum through the spinal canal. For I believe that much of a man’s
13727: character will be found betokened in his backbone. I would rather feel
13728: your spine than your skull, whoever you are. A thin joist of a spine
13729: never yet upheld a full and noble soul. I rejoice in my spine, as in
13730: the firm audacious staff of that flag which I fling half out to the
13731: world.
13732: 
13733: Apply this spinal branch of phrenology to the Sperm Whale. His cranial
13734: cavity is continuous with the first neck-vertebra; and in that vertebra
13735: the bottom of the spinal canal will measure ten inches across, being
13736: eight in height, and of a triangular figure with the base downwards. As
13737: it passes through the remaining vertebræ the canal tapers in size, but
13738: for a considerable distance remains of large capacity. Now, of course,
13739: this canal is filled with much the same strangely fibrous substance—the
13740: spinal cord—as the brain; and directly communicates with the brain. And
13741: what is still more, for many feet after emerging from the brain’s
13742: cavity, the spinal cord remains of an undecreasing girth, almost equal
13743: to that of the brain. Under all these circumstances, would it be
13744: unreasonable to survey and map out the whale’s spine phrenologically?
13745: For, viewed in this light, the wonderful comparative smallness of his
13746: brain proper is more than compensated by the wonderful comparative
13747: magnitude of his spinal cord.
13748: 
13749: But leaving this hint to operate as it may with the phrenologists, I
13750: would merely assume the spinal theory for a moment, in reference to the
13751: Sperm Whale’s hump. This august hump, if I mistake not, rises over one
13752: of the larger vertebræ, and is, therefore, in some sort, the outer
13753: convex mould of it. From its relative situation then, I should call
13754: this high hump the organ of firmness or indomitableness in the Sperm
13755: Whale. And that the great monster is indomitable, you will yet have
13756: reason to know.
13757: 
13758: 
13759: CHAPTER 81. The Pequod Meets The Virgin.
13760: 
13761: The predestinated day arrived, and we duly met the ship Jungfrau,
13762: Derick De Deer, master, of Bremen.
13763: 
13764: At one time the greatest whaling people in the world, the Dutch and
13765: Germans are now among the least; but here and there at very wide
13766: intervals of latitude and longitude, you still occasionally meet with
13767: their flag in the Pacific.
13768: 
13769: For some reason, the Jungfrau seemed quite eager to pay her respects.
13770: While yet some distance from the Pequod, she rounded to, and dropping a
13771: boat, her captain was impelled towards us, impatiently standing in the
13772: bows instead of the stern.
13773: 
13774: “What has he in his hand there?” cried Starbuck, pointing to something
13775: wavingly held by the German. “Impossible!—a lamp-feeder!”
13776: 
13777: “Not that,” said Stubb, “no, no, it’s a coffee-pot, Mr. Starbuck; he’s
13778: coming off to make us our coffee, is the Yarman; don’t you see that big
13779: tin can there alongside of him?—that’s his boiling water. Oh! he’s all
13780: right, is the Yarman.”
13781: 
13782: “Go along with you,” cried Flask, “it’s a lamp-feeder and an oil-can.
13783: He’s out of oil, and has come a-begging.”
13784: 
13785: However curious it may seem for an oil-ship to be borrowing oil on the
13786: whale-ground, and however much it may invertedly contradict the old
13787: proverb about carrying coals to Newcastle, yet sometimes such a thing
13788: really happens; and in the present case Captain Derick De Deer did
13789: indubitably conduct a lamp-feeder as Flask did declare.
13790: 
13791: As he mounted the deck, Ahab abruptly accosted him, without at all
13792: heeding what he had in his hand; but in his broken lingo, the German
13793: soon evinced his complete ignorance of the White Whale; immediately
13794: turning the conversation to his lamp-feeder and oil can, with some
13795: remarks touching his having to turn into his hammock at night in
13796: profound darkness—his last drop of Bremen oil being gone, and not a
13797: single flying-fish yet captured to supply the deficiency; concluding by
13798: hinting that his ship was indeed what in the Fishery is technically
13799: called a _clean_ one (that is, an empty one), well deserving the name
13800: of Jungfrau or the Virgin.
13801: 
13802: His necessities supplied, Derick departed; but he had not gained his
13803: ship’s side, when whales were almost simultaneously raised from the
13804: mast-heads of both vessels; and so eager for the chase was Derick, that
13805: without pausing to put his oil-can and lamp-feeder aboard, he slewed
13806: round his boat and made after the leviathan lamp-feeders.
13807: 
13808: Now, the game having risen to leeward, he and the other three German
13809: boats that soon followed him, had considerably the start of the
13810: Pequod’s keels. There were eight whales, an average pod. Aware of their
13811: danger, they were going all abreast with great speed straight before
13812: the wind, rubbing their flanks as closely as so many spans of horses in
13813: harness. They left a great, wide wake, as though continually unrolling
13814: a great wide parchment upon the sea.
13815: 
13816: Full in this rapid wake, and many fathoms in the rear, swam a huge,
13817: humped old bull, which by his comparatively slow progress, as well as
13818: by the unusual yellowish incrustations overgrowing him, seemed
13819: afflicted with the jaundice, or some other infirmity. Whether this
13820: whale belonged to the pod in advance, seemed questionable; for it is
13821: not customary for such venerable leviathans to be at all social.
13822: Nevertheless, he stuck to their wake, though indeed their back water
13823: must have retarded him, because the white-bone or swell at his broad
13824: muzzle was a dashed one, like the swell formed when two hostile
13825: currents meet. His spout was short, slow, and laborious; coming forth
13826: with a choking sort of gush, and spending itself in torn shreds,
13827: followed by strange subterranean commotions in him, which seemed to
13828: have egress at his other buried extremity, causing the waters behind
13829: him to upbubble.
13830: 
13831: “Who’s got some paregoric?” said Stubb, “he has the stomach-ache, I’m
13832: afraid. Lord, think of having half an acre of stomach-ache! Adverse
13833: winds are holding mad Christmas in him, boys. It’s the first foul wind
13834: I ever knew to blow from astern; but look, did ever whale yaw so
13835: before? it must be, he’s lost his tiller.”
13836: 
13837: As an overladen Indiaman bearing down the Hindostan coast with a deck
13838: load of frightened horses, careens, buries, rolls, and wallows on her
13839: way; so did this old whale heave his aged bulk, and now and then partly
13840: turning over on his cumbrous rib-ends, expose the cause of his devious
13841: wake in the unnatural stump of his starboard fin. Whether he had lost
13842: that fin in battle, or had been born without it, it were hard to say.
13843: 
13844: “Only wait a bit, old chap, and I’ll give ye a sling for that wounded
13845: arm,” cried cruel Flask, pointing to the whale-line near him.
13846: 
13847: “Mind he don’t sling thee with it,” cried Starbuck. “Give way, or the
13848: German will have him.”
13849: 
13850: With one intent all the combined rival boats were pointed for this one
13851: fish, because not only was he the largest, and therefore the most
13852: valuable whale, but he was nearest to them, and the other whales were
13853: going with such great velocity, moreover, as almost to defy pursuit for
13854: the time. At this juncture the Pequod’s keels had shot by the three
13855: German boats last lowered; but from the great start he had had,
13856: Derick’s boat still led the chase, though every moment neared by his
13857: foreign rivals. The only thing they feared, was, that from being
13858: already so nigh to his mark, he would be enabled to dart his iron
13859: before they could completely overtake and pass him. As for Derick, he
13860: seemed quite confident that this would be the case, and occasionally
13861: with a deriding gesture shook his lamp-feeder at the other boats.
13862: 
13863: “The ungracious and ungrateful dog!” cried Starbuck; “he mocks and
13864: dares me with the very poor-box I filled for him not five minutes
13865: ago!”—then in his old intense whisper—“Give way, greyhounds! Dog to
13866: it!”
13867: 
13868: “I tell ye what it is, men”—cried Stubb to his crew—“it’s against my
13869: religion to get mad; but I’d like to eat that villainous
13870: Yarman—Pull—won’t ye? Are ye going to let that rascal beat ye? Do ye
13871: love brandy? A hogshead of brandy, then, to the best man. Come, why
13872: don’t some of ye burst a blood-vessel? Who’s that been dropping an
13873: anchor overboard—we don’t budge an inch—we’re becalmed. Halloo, here’s
13874: grass growing in the boat’s bottom—and by the Lord, the mast there’s
13875: budding. This won’t do, boys. Look at that Yarman! The short and long
13876: of it is, men, will ye spit fire or not?”
13877: 
13878: “Oh! see the suds he makes!” cried Flask, dancing up and down—“What a
13879: hump—Oh, _do_ pile on the beef—lays like a log! Oh! my lads, _do_
13880: spring—slap-jacks and quahogs for supper, you know, my lads—baked clams
13881: and muffins—oh, _do_, _do_, spring,—he’s a hundred barreller—don’t lose
13882: him now—don’t oh, _don’t!_—see that Yarman—Oh, won’t ye pull for your
13883: duff, my lads—such a sog! such a sogger! Don’t ye love sperm? There
13884: goes three thousand dollars, men!—a bank!—a whole bank! The bank of
13885: England!—Oh, _do_, _do_, _do!_—What’s that Yarman about now?”
13886: 
13887: At this moment Derick was in the act of pitching his lamp-feeder at the
13888: advancing boats, and also his oil-can; perhaps with the double view of
13889: retarding his rivals’ way, and at the same time economically
13890: accelerating his own by the momentary impetus of the backward toss.
13891: 
13892: “The unmannerly Dutch dogger!” cried Stubb. “Pull now, men, like fifty
13893: thousand line-of-battle-ship loads of red-haired devils. What d’ye say,
13894: Tashtego; are you the man to snap your spine in two-and-twenty pieces
13895: for the honor of old Gayhead? What d’ye say?”
13896: 
13897: “I say, pull like god-dam,”—cried the Indian.
13898: 
13899: Fiercely, but evenly incited by the taunts of the German, the Pequod’s
13900: three boats now began ranging almost abreast; and, so disposed,
13901: momentarily neared him. In that fine, loose, chivalrous attitude of the
13902: headsman when drawing near to his prey, the three mates stood up
13903: proudly, occasionally backing the after oarsman with an exhilarating
13904: cry of, “There she slides, now! Hurrah for the white-ash breeze! Down
13905: with the Yarman! Sail over him!”
13906: 
13907: But so decided an original start had Derick had, that spite of all
13908: their gallantry, he would have proved the victor in this race, had not
13909: a righteous judgment descended upon him in a crab which caught the
13910: blade of his midship oarsman. While this clumsy lubber was striving to
13911: free his white-ash, and while, in consequence, Derick’s boat was nigh
13912: to capsizing, and he thundering away at his men in a mighty rage;—that
13913: was a good time for Starbuck, Stubb, and Flask. With a shout, they took
13914: a mortal start forwards, and slantingly ranged up on the German’s
13915: quarter. An instant more, and all four boats were diagonically in the
13916: whale’s immediate wake, while stretching from them, on both sides, was
13917: the foaming swell that he made.
13918: 
13919: It was a terrific, most pitiable, and maddening sight. The whale was
13920: now going head out, and sending his spout before him in a continual
13921: tormented jet; while his one poor fin beat his side in an agony of
13922: fright. Now to this hand, now to that, he yawed in his faltering
13923: flight, and still at every billow that he broke, he spasmodically sank
13924: in the sea, or sideways rolled towards the sky his one beating fin. So
13925: have I seen a bird with clipped wing making affrighted broken circles
13926: in the air, vainly striving to escape the piratical hawks. But the bird
13927: has a voice, and with plaintive cries will make known her fear; but the
13928: fear of this vast dumb brute of the sea, was chained up and enchanted
13929: in him; he had no voice, save that choking respiration through his
13930: spiracle, and this made the sight of him unspeakably pitiable; while
13931: still, in his amazing bulk, portcullis jaw, and omnipotent tail, there
13932: was enough to appal the stoutest man who so pitied.
13933: 
13934: Seeing now that but a very few moments more would give the Pequod’s
13935: boats the advantage, and rather than be thus foiled of his game, Derick
13936: chose to hazard what to him must have seemed a most unusually long
13937: dart, ere the last chance would for ever escape.
13938: 
13939: But no sooner did his harpooneer stand up for the stroke, than all
13940: three tigers—Queequeg, Tashtego, Daggoo—instinctively sprang to their
13941: feet, and standing in a diagonal row, simultaneously pointed their
13942: barbs; and darted over the head of the German harpooneer, their three
13943: Nantucket irons entered the whale. Blinding vapors of foam and
13944: white-fire! The three boats, in the first fury of the whale’s headlong
13945: rush, bumped the German’s aside with such force, that both Derick and
13946: his baffled harpooneer were spilled out, and sailed over by the three
13947: flying keels.
13948: 
13949: “Don’t be afraid, my butter-boxes,” cried Stubb, casting a passing
13950: glance upon them as he shot by; “ye’ll be picked up presently—all
13951: right—I saw some sharks astern—St. Bernard’s dogs, you know—relieve
13952: distressed travellers. Hurrah! this is the way to sail now. Every keel
13953: a sunbeam! Hurrah!—Here we go like three tin kettles at the tail of a
13954: mad cougar! This puts me in mind of fastening to an elephant in a
13955: tilbury on a plain—makes the wheel-spokes fly, boys, when you fasten to
13956: him that way; and there’s danger of being pitched out too, when you
13957: strike a hill. Hurrah! this is the way a fellow feels when he’s going
13958: to Davy Jones—all a rush down an endless inclined plane! Hurrah! this
13959: whale carries the everlasting mail!”
13960: 
13961: But the monster’s run was a brief one. Giving a sudden gasp, he
13962: tumultuously sounded. With a grating rush, the three lines flew round
13963: the loggerheads with such a force as to gouge deep grooves in them;
13964: while so fearful were the harpooneers that this rapid sounding would
13965: soon exhaust the lines, that using all their dexterous might, they
13966: caught repeated smoking turns with the rope to hold on; till at
13967: last—owing to the perpendicular strain from the lead-lined chocks of
13968: the boats, whence the three ropes went straight down into the blue—the
13969: gunwales of the bows were almost even with the water, while the three
13970: sterns tilted high in the air. And the whale soon ceasing to sound, for
13971: some time they remained in that attitude, fearful of expending more
13972: line, though the position was a little ticklish. But though boats have
13973: been taken down and lost in this way, yet it is this “holding on,” as
13974: it is called; this hooking up by the sharp barbs of his live flesh from
13975: the back; this it is that often torments the Leviathan into soon rising
13976: again to meet the sharp lance of his foes. Yet not to speak of the
13977: peril of the thing, it is to be doubted whether this course is always
13978: the best; for it is but reasonable to presume, that the longer the
13979: stricken whale stays under water, the more he is exhausted. Because,
13980: owing to the enormous surface of him—in a full grown sperm whale
13981: something less than 2000 square feet—the pressure of the water is
13982: immense. We all know what an astonishing atmospheric weight we
13983: ourselves stand up under; even here, above-ground, in the air; how
13984: vast, then, the burden of a whale, bearing on his back a column of two
13985: hundred fathoms of ocean! It must at least equal the weight of fifty
13986: atmospheres. One whaleman has estimated it at the weight of twenty
13987: line-of-battle ships, with all their guns, and stores, and men on
13988: board.
13989: 
13990: As the three boats lay there on that gently rolling sea, gazing down
13991: into its eternal blue noon; and as not a single groan or cry of any
13992: sort, nay, not so much as a ripple or a bubble came up from its depths;
13993: what landsman would have thought, that beneath all that silence and
13994: placidity, the utmost monster of the seas was writhing and wrenching in
13995: agony! Not eight inches of perpendicular rope were visible at the bows.
13996: Seems it credible that by three such thin threads the great Leviathan
13997: was suspended like the big weight to an eight day clock. Suspended? and
13998: to what? To three bits of board. Is this the creature of whom it was
13999: once so triumphantly said—“Canst thou fill his skin with barbed irons?
14000: or his head with fish-spears? The sword of him that layeth at him
14001: cannot hold, the spear, the dart, nor the habergeon: he esteemeth iron
14002: as straw; the arrow cannot make him flee; darts are counted as stubble;
14003: he laugheth at the shaking of a spear!” This the creature? this he? Oh!
14004: that unfulfilments should follow the prophets. For with the strength of
14005: a thousand thighs in his tail, Leviathan had run his head under the
14006: mountains of the sea, to hide him from the Pequod’s fish-spears!
14007: 
14008: In that sloping afternoon sunlight, the shadows that the three boats
14009: sent down beneath the surface, must have been long enough and broad
14010: enough to shade half Xerxes’ army. Who can tell how appalling to the
14011: wounded whale must have been such huge phantoms flitting over his head!
14012: 
14013: “Stand by, men; he stirs,” cried Starbuck, as the three lines suddenly
14014: vibrated in the water, distinctly conducting upwards to them, as by
14015: magnetic wires, the life and death throbs of the whale, so that every
14016: oarsman felt them in his seat. The next moment, relieved in great part
14017: from the downward strain at the bows, the boats gave a sudden bounce
14018: upwards, as a small icefield will, when a dense herd of white bears are
14019: scared from it into the sea.
14020: 
14021: “Haul in! Haul in!” cried Starbuck again; “he’s rising.”
14022: 
14023: The lines, of which, hardly an instant before, not one hand’s breadth
14024: could have been gained, were now in long quick coils flung back all
14025: dripping into the boats, and soon the whale broke water within two
14026: ship’s lengths of the hunters.
14027: 
14028: His motions plainly denoted his extreme exhaustion. In most land
14029: animals there are certain valves or flood-gates in many of their veins,
14030: whereby when wounded, the blood is in some degree at least instantly
14031: shut off in certain directions. Not so with the whale; one of whose
14032: peculiarities it is to have an entire non-valvular structure of the
14033: blood-vessels, so that when pierced even by so small a point as a
14034: harpoon, a deadly drain is at once begun upon his whole arterial
14035: system; and when this is heightened by the extraordinary pressure of
14036: water at a great distance below the surface, his life may be said to
14037: pour from him in incessant streams. Yet so vast is the quantity of
14038: blood in him, and so distant and numerous its interior fountains, that
14039: he will keep thus bleeding and bleeding for a considerable period; even
14040: as in a drought a river will flow, whose source is in the well-springs
14041: of far-off and undiscernible hills. Even now, when the boats pulled
14042: upon this whale, and perilously drew over his swaying flukes, and the
14043: lances were darted into him, they were followed by steady jets from the
14044: new made wound, which kept continually playing, while the natural
14045: spout-hole in his head was only at intervals, however rapid, sending
14046: its affrighted moisture into the air. From this last vent no blood yet
14047: came, because no vital part of him had thus far been struck. His life,
14048: as they significantly call it, was untouched.
14049: 
14050: As the boats now more closely surrounded him, the whole upper part of
14051: his form, with much of it that is ordinarily submerged, was plainly
14052: revealed. His eyes, or rather the places where his eyes had been, were
14053: beheld. As strange misgrown masses gather in the knot-holes of the
14054: noblest oaks when prostrate, so from the points which the whale’s eyes
14055: had once occupied, now protruded blind bulbs, horribly pitiable to see.
14056: But pity there was none. For all his old age, and his one arm, and his
14057: blind eyes, he must die the death and be murdered, in order to light
14058: the gay bridals and other merry-makings of men, and also to illuminate
14059: the solemn churches that preach unconditional inoffensiveness by all to
14060: all. Still rolling in his blood, at last he partially disclosed a
14061: strangely discoloured bunch or protuberance, the size of a bushel, low
14062: down on the flank.
14063: 
14064: “A nice spot,” cried Flask; “just let me prick him there once.”
14065: 
14066: “Avast!” cried Starbuck, “there’s no need of that!”
14067: 
14068: But humane Starbuck was too late. At the instant of the dart an
14069: ulcerous jet shot from this cruel wound, and goaded by it into more
14070: than sufferable anguish, the whale now spouting thick blood, with swift
14071: fury blindly darted at the craft, bespattering them and their glorying
14072: crews all over with showers of gore, capsizing Flask’s boat and marring
14073: the bows. It was his death stroke. For, by this time, so spent was he
14074: by loss of blood, that he helplessly rolled away from the wreck he had
14075: made; lay panting on his side, impotently flapped with his stumped fin,
14076: then over and over slowly revolved like a waning world; turned up the
14077: white secrets of his belly; lay like a log, and died. It was most
14078: piteous, that last expiring spout. As when by unseen hands the water is
14079: gradually drawn off from some mighty fountain, and with half-stifled
14080: melancholy gurglings the spray-column lowers and lowers to the
14081: ground—so the last long dying spout of the whale.
14082: 
14083: Soon, while the crews were awaiting the arrival of the ship, the body
14084: showed symptoms of sinking with all its treasures unrifled.
14085: Immediately, by Starbuck’s orders, lines were secured to it at
14086: different points, so that ere long every boat was a buoy; the sunken
14087: whale being suspended a few inches beneath them by the cords. By very
14088: heedful management, when the ship drew nigh, the whale was transferred
14089: to her side, and was strongly secured there by the stiffest
14090: fluke-chains, for it was plain that unless artificially upheld, the
14091: body would at once sink to the bottom.
14092: 
14093: It so chanced that almost upon first cutting into him with the spade,
14094: the entire length of a corroded harpoon was found imbedded in his
14095: flesh, on the lower part of the bunch before described. But as the
14096: stumps of harpoons are frequently found in the dead bodies of captured
14097: whales, with the flesh perfectly healed around them, and no prominence
14098: of any kind to denote their place; therefore, there must needs have
14099: been some other unknown reason in the present case fully to account for
14100: the ulceration alluded to. But still more curious was the fact of a
14101: lance-head of stone being found in him, not far from the buried iron,
14102: the flesh perfectly firm about it. Who had darted that stone lance? And
14103: when? It might have been darted by some Nor’ West Indian long before
14104: America was discovered.
14105: 
14106: What other marvels might have been rummaged out of this monstrous
14107: cabinet there is no telling. But a sudden stop was put to further
14108: discoveries, by the ship’s being unprecedentedly dragged over sideways
14109: to the sea, owing to the body’s immensely increasing tendency to sink.
14110: However, Starbuck, who had the ordering of affairs, hung on to it to
14111: the last; hung on to it so resolutely, indeed, that when at length the
14112: ship would have been capsized, if still persisting in locking arms with
14113: the body; then, when the command was given to break clear from it, such
14114: was the immovable strain upon the timber-heads to which the
14115: fluke-chains and cables were fastened, that it was impossible to cast
14116: them off. Meantime everything in the Pequod was aslant. To cross to the
14117: other side of the deck was like walking up the steep gabled roof of a
14118: house. The ship groaned and gasped. Many of the ivory inlayings of her
14119: bulwarks and cabins were started from their places, by the unnatural
14120: dislocation. In vain handspikes and crows were brought to bear upon the
14121: immovable fluke-chains, to pry them adrift from the timberheads; and so
14122: low had the whale now settled that the submerged ends could not be at
14123: all approached, while every moment whole tons of ponderosity seemed
14124: added to the sinking bulk, and the ship seemed on the point of going
14125: over.
14126: 
14127: “Hold on, hold on, won’t ye?” cried Stubb to the body, “don’t be in
14128: such a devil of a hurry to sink! By thunder, men, we must do something
14129: or go for it. No use prying there; avast, I say with your handspikes,
14130: and run one of ye for a prayer book and a pen-knife, and cut the big
14131: chains.”
14132: 
14133: “Knife? Aye, aye,” cried Queequeg, and seizing the carpenter’s heavy
14134: hatchet, he leaned out of a porthole, and steel to iron, began slashing
14135: at the largest fluke-chains. But a few strokes, full of sparks, were
14136: given, when the exceeding strain effected the rest. With a terrific
14137: snap, every fastening went adrift; the ship righted, the carcase sank.
14138: 
14139: Now, this occasional inevitable sinking of the recently killed Sperm
14140: Whale is a very curious thing; nor has any fisherman yet adequately
14141: accounted for it. Usually the dead Sperm Whale floats with great
14142: buoyancy, with its side or belly considerably elevated above the
14143: surface. If the only whales that thus sank were old, meagre, and
14144: broken-hearted creatures, their pads of lard diminished and all their
14145: bones heavy and rheumatic; then you might with some reason assert that
14146: this sinking is caused by an uncommon specific gravity in the fish so
14147: sinking, consequent upon this absence of buoyant matter in him. But it
14148: is not so. For young whales, in the highest health, and swelling with
14149: noble aspirations, prematurely cut off in the warm flush and May of
14150: life, with all their panting lard about them; even these brawny,
14151: buoyant heroes do sometimes sink.
14152: 
14153: Be it said, however, that the Sperm Whale is far less liable to this
14154: accident than any other species. Where one of that sort go down, twenty
14155: Right Whales do. This difference in the species is no doubt imputable
14156: in no small degree to the greater quantity of bone in the Right Whale;
14157: his Venetian blinds alone sometimes weighing more than a ton; from this
14158: incumbrance the Sperm Whale is wholly free. But there are instances
14159: where, after the lapse of many hours or several days, the sunken whale
14160: again rises, more buoyant than in life. But the reason of this is
14161: obvious. Gases are generated in him; he swells to a prodigious
14162: magnitude; becomes a sort of animal balloon. A line-of-battle ship
14163: could hardly keep him under then. In the Shore Whaling, on soundings,
14164: among the Bays of New Zealand, when a Right Whale gives token of
14165: sinking, they fasten buoys to him, with plenty of rope; so that when
14166: the body has gone down, they know where to look for it when it shall
14167: have ascended again.
14168: 
14169: It was not long after the sinking of the body that a cry was heard from
14170: the Pequod’s mast-heads, announcing that the Jungfrau was again
14171: lowering her boats; though the only spout in sight was that of a
14172: Fin-Back, belonging to the species of uncapturable whales, because of
14173: its incredible power of swimming. Nevertheless, the Fin-Back’s spout is
14174: so similar to the Sperm Whale’s, that by unskilful fishermen it is
14175: often mistaken for it. And consequently Derick and all his host were
14176: now in valiant chase of this unnearable brute. The Virgin crowding all
