14177: sail, made after her four young keels, and thus they all disappeared
14178: far to leeward, still in bold, hopeful chase.
14179: 
14180: Oh! many are the Fin-Backs, and many are the Dericks, my friend.
14181: 
14182: 
14183: CHAPTER 82. The Honor and Glory of Whaling.
14184: 
14185: There are some enterprises in which a careful disorderliness is the
14186: true method.
14187: 
14188: The more I dive into this matter of whaling, and push my researches up
14189: to the very spring-head of it so much the more am I impressed with its
14190: great honorableness and antiquity; and especially when I find so many
14191: great demi-gods and heroes, prophets of all sorts, who one way or other
14192: have shed distinction upon it, I am transported with the reflection
14193: that I myself belong, though but subordinately, to so emblazoned a
14194: fraternity.
14195: 
14196: The gallant Perseus, a son of Jupiter, was the first whaleman; and to
14197: the eternal honor of our calling be it said, that the first whale
14198: attacked by our brotherhood was not killed with any sordid intent.
14199: Those were the knightly days of our profession, when we only bore arms
14200: to succor the distressed, and not to fill men’s lamp-feeders. Every one
14201: knows the fine story of Perseus and Andromeda; how the lovely
14202: Andromeda, the daughter of a king, was tied to a rock on the sea-coast,
14203: and as Leviathan was in the very act of carrying her off, Perseus, the
14204: prince of whalemen, intrepidly advancing, harpooned the monster, and
14205: delivered and married the maid. It was an admirable artistic exploit,
14206: rarely achieved by the best harpooneers of the present day; inasmuch as
14207: this Leviathan was slain at the very first dart. And let no man doubt
14208: this Arkite story; for in the ancient Joppa, now Jaffa, on the Syrian
14209: coast, in one of the Pagan temples, there stood for many ages the vast
14210: skeleton of a whale, which the city’s legends and all the inhabitants
14211: asserted to be the identical bones of the monster that Perseus slew.
14212: When the Romans took Joppa, the same skeleton was carried to Italy in
14213: triumph. What seems most singular and suggestively important in this
14214: story, is this: it was from Joppa that Jonah set sail.
14215: 
14216: Akin to the adventure of Perseus and Andromeda—indeed, by some supposed
14217: to be indirectly derived from it—is that famous story of St. George and
14218: the Dragon; which dragon I maintain to have been a whale; for in many
14219: old chronicles whales and dragons are strangely jumbled together, and
14220: often stand for each other. “Thou art as a lion of the waters, and as a
14221: dragon of the sea,” saith Ezekiel; hereby, plainly meaning a whale; in
14222: truth, some versions of the Bible use that word itself. Besides, it
14223: would much subtract from the glory of the exploit had St. George but
14224: encountered a crawling reptile of the land, instead of doing battle
14225: with the great monster of the deep. Any man may kill a snake, but only
14226: a Perseus, a St. George, a Coffin, have the heart in them to march
14227: boldly up to a whale.
14228: 
14229: Let not the modern paintings of this scene mislead us; for though the
14230: creature encountered by that valiant whaleman of old is vaguely
14231: represented of a griffin-like shape, and though the battle is depicted
14232: on land and the saint on horseback, yet considering the great ignorance
14233: of those times, when the true form of the whale was unknown to artists;
14234: and considering that as in Perseus’ case, St. George’s whale might have
14235: crawled up out of the sea on the beach; and considering that the animal
14236: ridden by St. George might have been only a large seal, or sea-horse;
14237: bearing all this in mind, it will not appear altogether incompatible
14238: with the sacred legend and the ancientest draughts of the scene, to
14239: hold this so-called dragon no other than the great Leviathan himself.
14240: In fact, placed before the strict and piercing truth, this whole story
14241: will fare like that fish, flesh, and fowl idol of the Philistines,
14242: Dagon by name; who being planted before the ark of Israel, his horse’s
14243: head and both the palms of his hands fell off from him, and only the
14244: stump or fishy part of him remained. Thus, then, one of our own noble
14245: stamp, even a whaleman, is the tutelary guardian of England; and by
14246: good rights, we harpooneers of Nantucket should be enrolled in the most
14247: noble order of St. George. And therefore, let not the knights of that
14248: honorable company (none of whom, I venture to say, have ever had to do
14249: with a whale like their great patron), let them never eye a Nantucketer
14250: with disdain, since even in our woollen frocks and tarred trowsers we
14251: are much better entitled to St. George’s decoration than they.
14252: 
14253: Whether to admit Hercules among us or not, concerning this I long
14254: remained dubious: for though according to the Greek mythologies, that
14255: antique Crockett and Kit Carson—that brawny doer of rejoicing good
14256: deeds, was swallowed down and thrown up by a whale; still, whether that
14257: strictly makes a whaleman of him, that might be mooted. It nowhere
14258: appears that he ever actually harpooned his fish, unless, indeed, from
14259: the inside. Nevertheless, he may be deemed a sort of involuntary
14260: whaleman; at any rate the whale caught him, if he did not the whale. I
14261: claim him for one of our clan.
14262: 
14263: But, by the best contradictory authorities, this Grecian story of
14264: Hercules and the whale is considered to be derived from the still more
14265: ancient Hebrew story of Jonah and the whale; and vice versâ; certainly
14266: they are very similar. If I claim the demi-god then, why not the
14267: prophet?
14268: 
14269: Nor do heroes, saints, demigods, and prophets alone comprise the whole
14270: roll of our order. Our grand master is still to be named; for like
14271: royal kings of old times, we find the head waters of our fraternity in
14272: nothing short of the great gods themselves. That wondrous oriental
14273: story is now to be rehearsed from the Shaster, which gives us the dread
14274: Vishnoo, one of the three persons in the godhead of the Hindoos; gives
14275: us this divine Vishnoo himself for our Lord;—Vishnoo, who, by the first
14276: of his ten earthly incarnations, has for ever set apart and sanctified
14277: the whale. When Brahma, or the God of Gods, saith the Shaster, resolved
14278: to recreate the world after one of its periodical dissolutions, he gave
14279: birth to Vishnoo, to preside over the work; but the Vedas, or mystical
14280: books, whose perusal would seem to have been indispensable to Vishnoo
14281: before beginning the creation, and which therefore must have contained
14282: something in the shape of practical hints to young architects, these
14283: Vedas were lying at the bottom of the waters; so Vishnoo became
14284: incarnate in a whale, and sounding down in him to the uttermost depths,
14285: rescued the sacred volumes. Was not this Vishnoo a whaleman, then? even
14286: as a man who rides a horse is called a horseman?
14287: 
14288: Perseus, St. George, Hercules, Jonah, and Vishnoo! there’s a
14289: member-roll for you! What club but the whaleman’s can head off like
14290: that?
14291: 
14292: 
14293: CHAPTER 83. Jonah Historically Regarded.
14294: 
14295: Reference was made to the historical story of Jonah and the whale in
14296: the preceding chapter. Now some Nantucketers rather distrust this
14297: historical story of Jonah and the whale. But then there were some
14298: sceptical Greeks and Romans, who, standing out from the orthodox pagans
14299: of their times, equally doubted the story of Hercules and the whale,
14300: and Arion and the dolphin; and yet their doubting those traditions did
14301: not make those traditions one whit the less facts, for all that.
14302: 
14303: One old Sag-Harbor whaleman’s chief reason for questioning the Hebrew
14304: story was this:—He had one of those quaint old-fashioned Bibles,
14305: embellished with curious, unscientific plates; one of which represented
14306: Jonah’s whale with two spouts in his head—a peculiarity only true with
14307: respect to a species of the Leviathan (the Right Whale, and the
14308: varieties of that order), concerning which the fishermen have this
14309: saying, “A penny roll would choke him”; his swallow is so very small.
14310: But, to this, Bishop Jebb’s anticipative answer is ready. It is not
14311: necessary, hints the Bishop, that we consider Jonah as tombed in the
14312: whale’s belly, but as temporarily lodged in some part of his mouth. And
14313: this seems reasonable enough in the good Bishop. For truly, the Right
14314: Whale’s mouth would accommodate a couple of whist-tables, and
14315: comfortably seat all the players. Possibly, too, Jonah might have
14316: ensconced himself in a hollow tooth; but, on second thoughts, the Right
14317: Whale is toothless.
14318: 
14319: Another reason which Sag-Harbor (he went by that name) urged for his
14320: want of faith in this matter of the prophet, was something obscurely in
14321: reference to his incarcerated body and the whale’s gastric juices. But
14322: this objection likewise falls to the ground, because a German exegetist
14323: supposes that Jonah must have taken refuge in the floating body of a
14324: _dead_ whale—even as the French soldiers in the Russian campaign turned
14325: their dead horses into tents, and crawled into them. Besides, it has
14326: been divined by other continental commentators, that when Jonah was
14327: thrown overboard from the Joppa ship, he straightway effected his
14328: escape to another vessel near by, some vessel with a whale for a
14329: figure-head; and, I would add, possibly called “The Whale,” as some
14330: craft are nowadays christened the “Shark,” the “Gull,” the “Eagle.” Nor
14331: have there been wanting learned exegetists who have opined that the
14332: whale mentioned in the book of Jonah merely meant a life-preserver—an
14333: inflated bag of wind—which the endangered prophet swam to, and so was
14334: saved from a watery doom. Poor Sag-Harbor, therefore, seems worsted all
14335: round. But he had still another reason for his want of faith. It was
14336: this, if I remember right: Jonah was swallowed by the whale in the
14337: Mediterranean Sea, and after three days he was vomited up somewhere
14338: within three days’ journey of Nineveh, a city on the Tigris, very much
14339: more than three days’ journey across from the nearest point of the
14340: Mediterranean coast. How is that?
14341: 
14342: But was there no other way for the whale to land the prophet within
14343: that short distance of Nineveh? Yes. He might have carried him round by
14344: the way of the Cape of Good Hope. But not to speak of the passage
14345: through the whole length of the Mediterranean, and another passage up
14346: the Persian Gulf and Red Sea, such a supposition would involve the
14347: complete circumnavigation of all Africa in three days, not to speak of
14348: the Tigris waters, near the site of Nineveh, being too shallow for any
14349: whale to swim in. Besides, this idea of Jonah’s weathering the Cape of
14350: Good Hope at so early a day would wrest the honor of the discovery of
14351: that great headland from Bartholomew Diaz, its reputed discoverer, and
14352: so make modern history a liar.
14353: 
14354: But all these foolish arguments of old Sag-Harbor only evinced his
14355: foolish pride of reason—a thing still more reprehensible in him, seeing
14356: that he had but little learning except what he had picked up from the
14357: sun and the sea. I say it only shows his foolish, impious pride, and
14358: abominable, devilish rebellion against the reverend clergy. For by a
14359: Portuguese Catholic priest, this very idea of Jonah’s going to Nineveh
14360: via the Cape of Good Hope was advanced as a signal magnification of the
14361: general miracle. And so it was. Besides, to this day, the highly
14362: enlightened Turks devoutly believe in the historical story of Jonah.
14363: And some three centuries ago, an English traveller in old Harris’s
14364: Voyages, speaks of a Turkish Mosque built in honor of Jonah, in which
14365: Mosque was a miraculous lamp that burnt without any oil.
14366: 
14367: 
14368: CHAPTER 84. Pitchpoling.
14369: 
14370: To make them run easily and swiftly, the axles of carriages are
14371: anointed; and for much the same purpose, some whalers perform an
14372: analogous operation upon their boat; they grease the bottom. Nor is it
14373: to be doubted that as such a procedure can do no harm, it may possibly
14374: be of no contemptible advantage; considering that oil and water are
14375: hostile; that oil is a sliding thing, and that the object in view is to
14376: make the boat slide bravely. Queequeg believed strongly in anointing
14377: his boat, and one morning not long after the German ship Jungfrau
14378: disappeared, took more than customary pains in that occupation;
14379: crawling under its bottom, where it hung over the side, and rubbing in
14380: the unctuousness as though diligently seeking to insure a crop of hair
14381: from the craft’s bald keel. He seemed to be working in obedience to
14382: some particular presentiment. Nor did it remain unwarranted by the
14383: event.
14384: 
14385: Towards noon whales were raised; but so soon as the ship sailed down to
14386: them, they turned and fled with swift precipitancy; a disordered
14387: flight, as of Cleopatra’s barges from Actium.
14388: 
14389: Nevertheless, the boats pursued, and Stubb’s was foremost. By great
14390: exertion, Tashtego at last succeeded in planting one iron; but the
14391: stricken whale, without at all sounding, still continued his horizontal
14392: flight, with added fleetness. Such unintermitted strainings upon the
14393: planted iron must sooner or later inevitably extract it. It became
14394: imperative to lance the flying whale, or be content to lose him. But to
14395: haul the boat up to his flank was impossible, he swam so fast and
14396: furious. What then remained?
14397: 
14398: Of all the wondrous devices and dexterities, the sleights of hand and
14399: countless subtleties, to which the veteran whaleman is so often forced,
14400: none exceed that fine manœuvre with the lance called pitchpoling. Small
14401: sword, or broad sword, in all its exercises boasts nothing like it. It
14402: is only indispensable with an inveterate running whale; its grand fact
14403: and feature is the wonderful distance to which the long lance is
14404: accurately darted from a violently rocking, jerking boat, under extreme
14405: headway. Steel and wood included, the entire spear is some ten or
14406: twelve feet in length; the staff is much slighter than that of the
14407: harpoon, and also of a lighter material—pine. It is furnished with a
14408: small rope called a warp, of considerable length, by which it can be
14409: hauled back to the hand after darting.
14410: 
14411: But before going further, it is important to mention here, that though
14412: the harpoon may be pitchpoled in the same way with the lance, yet it is
14413: seldom done; and when done, is still less frequently successful, on
14414: account of the greater weight and inferior length of the harpoon as
14415: compared with the lance, which in effect become serious drawbacks. As a
14416: general thing, therefore, you must first get fast to a whale, before
14417: any pitchpoling comes into play.
14418: 
14419: Look now at Stubb; a man who from his humorous, deliberate coolness and
14420: equanimity in the direst emergencies, was specially qualified to excel
14421: in pitchpoling. Look at him; he stands upright in the tossed bow of the
14422: flying boat; wrapt in fleecy foam, the towing whale is forty feet
14423: ahead. Handling the long lance lightly, glancing twice or thrice along
14424: its length to see if it be exactly straight, Stubb whistlingly gathers
14425: up the coil of the warp in one hand, so as to secure its free end in
14426: his grasp, leaving the rest unobstructed. Then holding the lance full
14427: before his waistband’s middle, he levels it at the whale; when,
14428: covering him with it, he steadily depresses the butt-end in his hand,
14429: thereby elevating the point till the weapon stands fairly balanced upon
14430: his palm, fifteen feet in the air. He minds you somewhat of a juggler,
14431: balancing a long staff on his chin. Next moment with a rapid, nameless
14432: impulse, in a superb lofty arch the bright steel spans the foaming
14433: distance, and quivers in the life spot of the whale. Instead of
14434: sparkling water, he now spouts red blood.
14435: 
14436: “That drove the spigot out of him!” cried Stubb. “’Tis July’s immortal
14437: Fourth; all fountains must run wine today! Would now, it were old
14438: Orleans whiskey, or old Ohio, or unspeakable old Monongahela! Then,
14439: Tashtego, lad, I’d have ye hold a canakin to the jet, and we’d drink
14440: round it! Yea, verily, hearts alive, we’d brew choice punch in the
14441: spread of his spout-hole there, and from that live punch-bowl quaff the
14442: living stuff.”
14443: 
14444: Again and again to such gamesome talk, the dexterous dart is repeated,
14445: the spear returning to its master like a greyhound held in skilful
14446: leash. The agonized whale goes into his flurry; the tow-line is
14447: slackened, and the pitchpoler dropping astern, folds his hands, and
14448: mutely watches the monster die.
14449: 
14450: 
14451: CHAPTER 85. The Fountain.
14452: 
14453: That for six thousand years—and no one knows how many millions of ages
14454: before—the great whales should have been spouting all over the sea, and
14455: sprinkling and mistifying the gardens of the deep, as with so many
14456: sprinkling or mistifying pots; and that for some centuries back,
14457: thousands of hunters should have been close by the fountain of the
14458: whale, watching these sprinklings and spoutings—that all this should
14459: be, and yet, that down to this blessed minute (fifteen and a quarter
14460: minutes past one o’clock P.M. of this sixteenth day of December, A.D.
14461: 1851), it should still remain a problem, whether these spoutings are,
14462: after all, really water, or nothing but vapor—this is surely a
14463: noteworthy thing.
14464: 
14465: Let us, then, look at this matter, along with some interesting items
14466: contingent. Every one knows that by the peculiar cunning of their
14467: gills, the finny tribes in general breathe the air which at all times
14468: is combined with the element in which they swim; hence, a herring or a
14469: cod might live a century, and never once raise its head above the
14470: surface. But owing to his marked internal structure which gives him
14471: regular lungs, like a human being’s, the whale can only live by
14472: inhaling the disengaged air in the open atmosphere. Wherefore the
14473: necessity for his periodical visits to the upper world. But he cannot
14474: in any degree breathe through his mouth, for, in his ordinary attitude,
14475: the Sperm Whale’s mouth is buried at least eight feet beneath the
14476: surface; and what is still more, his windpipe has no connexion with his
14477: mouth. No, he breathes through his spiracle alone; and this is on the
14478: top of his head.
14479: 
14480: If I say, that in any creature breathing is only a function
14481: indispensable to vitality, inasmuch as it withdraws from the air a
14482: certain element, which being subsequently brought into contact with the
14483: blood imparts to the blood its vivifying principle, I do not think I
14484: shall err; though I may possibly use some superfluous scientific words.
14485: Assume it, and it follows that if all the blood in a man could be
14486: aerated with one breath, he might then seal up his nostrils and not
14487: fetch another for a considerable time. That is to say, he would then
14488: live without breathing. Anomalous as it may seem, this is precisely the
14489: case with the whale, who systematically lives, by intervals, his full
14490: hour and more (when at the bottom) without drawing a single breath, or
14491: so much as in any way inhaling a particle of air; for, remember, he has
14492: no gills. How is this? Between his ribs and on each side of his spine
14493: he is supplied with a remarkable involved Cretan labyrinth of
14494: vermicelli-like vessels, which vessels, when he quits the surface, are
14495: completely distended with oxygenated blood. So that for an hour or
14496: more, a thousand fathoms in the sea, he carries a surplus stock of
14497: vitality in him, just as the camel crossing the waterless desert
14498: carries a surplus supply of drink for future use in its four
14499: supplementary stomachs. The anatomical fact of this labyrinth is
14500: indisputable; and that the supposition founded upon it is reasonable
14501: and true, seems the more cogent to me, when I consider the otherwise
14502: inexplicable obstinacy of that leviathan in _having his spoutings out_,
14503: as the fishermen phrase it. This is what I mean. If unmolested, upon
14504: rising to the surface, the Sperm Whale will continue there for a period
14505: of time exactly uniform with all his other unmolested risings. Say he
14506: stays eleven minutes, and jets seventy times, that is, respires seventy
14507: breaths; then whenever he rises again, he will be sure to have his
14508: seventy breaths over again, to a minute. Now, if after he fetches a few
14509: breaths you alarm him, so that he sounds, he will be always dodging up
14510: again to make good his regular allowance of air. And not till those
14511: seventy breaths are told, will he finally go down to stay out his full
14512: term below. Remark, however, that in different individuals these rates
14513: are different; but in any one they are alike. Now, why should the whale
14514: thus insist upon having his spoutings out, unless it be to replenish
14515: his reservoir of air, ere descending for good? How obvious is it, too,
14516: that this necessity for the whale’s rising exposes him to all the fatal
14517: hazards of the chase. For not by hook or by net could this vast
14518: leviathan be caught, when sailing a thousand fathoms beneath the
14519: sunlight. Not so much thy skill, then, O hunter, as the great
14520: necessities that strike the victory to thee!
14521: 
14522: In man, breathing is incessantly going on—one breath only serving for
14523: two or three pulsations; so that whatever other business he has to
14524: attend to, waking or sleeping, breathe he must, or die he will. But the
14525: Sperm Whale only breathes about one seventh or Sunday of his time.
14526: 
14527: It has been said that the whale only breathes through his spout-hole;
14528: if it could truthfully be added that his spouts are mixed with water,
14529: then I opine we should be furnished with the reason why his sense of
14530: smell seems obliterated in him; for the only thing about him that at
14531: all answers to his nose is that identical spout-hole; and being so
14532: clogged with two elements, it could not be expected to have the power
14533: of smelling. But owing to the mystery of the spout—whether it be water
14534: or whether it be vapor—no absolute certainty can as yet be arrived at
14535: on this head. Sure it is, nevertheless, that the Sperm Whale has no
14536: proper olfactories. But what does he want of them? No roses, no
14537: violets, no Cologne-water in the sea.
14538: 
14539: Furthermore, as his windpipe solely opens into the tube of his spouting
14540: canal, and as that long canal—like the grand Erie Canal—is furnished
14541: with a sort of locks (that open and shut) for the downward retention of
14542: air or the upward exclusion of water, therefore the whale has no voice;
14543: unless you insult him by saying, that when he so strangely rumbles, he
14544: talks through his nose. But then again, what has the whale to say?
14545: Seldom have I known any profound being that had anything to say to this
14546: world, unless forced to stammer out something by way of getting a
14547: living. Oh! happy that the world is such an excellent listener!
14548: 
14549: Now, the spouting canal of the Sperm Whale, chiefly intended as it is
14550: for the conveyance of air, and for several feet laid along,
14551: horizontally, just beneath the upper surface of his head, and a little
14552: to one side; this curious canal is very much like a gas-pipe laid down
14553: in a city on one side of a street. But the question returns whether
14554: this gas-pipe is also a water-pipe; in other words, whether the spout
14555: of the Sperm Whale is the mere vapor of the exhaled breath, or whether
14556: that exhaled breath is mixed with water taken in at the mouth, and
14557: discharged through the spiracle. It is certain that the mouth
14558: indirectly communicates with the spouting canal; but it cannot be
14559: proved that this is for the purpose of discharging water through the
14560: spiracle. Because the greatest necessity for so doing would seem to be,
14561: when in feeding he accidentally takes in water. But the Sperm Whale’s
14562: food is far beneath the surface, and there he cannot spout even if he
14563: would. Besides, if you regard him very closely, and time him with your
14564: watch, you will find that when unmolested, there is an undeviating
14565: rhyme between the periods of his jets and the ordinary periods of
14566: respiration.
14567: 
14568: But why pester one with all this reasoning on the subject? Speak out!
14569: You have seen him spout; then declare what the spout is; can you not
14570: tell water from air? My dear sir, in this world it is not so easy to
14571: settle these plain things. I have ever found your plain things the
14572: knottiest of all. And as for this whale spout, you might almost stand
14573: in it, and yet be undecided as to what it is precisely.
14574: 
14575: The central body of it is hidden in the snowy sparkling mist enveloping
14576: it; and how can you certainly tell whether any water falls from it,
14577: when, always, when you are close enough to a whale to get a close view
14578: of his spout, he is in a prodigious commotion, the water cascading all
14579: around him. And if at such times you should think that you really
14580: perceived drops of moisture in the spout, how do you know that they are
14581: not merely condensed from its vapor; or how do you know that they are
14582: not those identical drops superficially lodged in the spout-hole
14583: fissure, which is countersunk into the summit of the whale’s head? For
14584: even when tranquilly swimming through the mid-day sea in a calm, with
14585: his elevated hump sun-dried as a dromedary’s in the desert; even then,
14586: the whale always carries a small basin of water on his head, as under a
14587: blazing sun you will sometimes see a cavity in a rock filled up with
14588: rain.
14589: 
14590: Nor is it at all prudent for the hunter to be over curious touching the
14591: precise nature of the whale spout. It will not do for him to be peering
14592: into it, and putting his face in it. You cannot go with your pitcher to
14593: this fountain and fill it, and bring it away. For even when coming into
14594: slight contact with the outer, vapory shreds of the jet, which will
14595: often happen, your skin will feverishly smart, from the acridness of
14596: the thing so touching it. And I know one, who coming into still closer
14597: contact with the spout, whether with some scientific object in view, or
14598: otherwise, I cannot say, the skin peeled off from his cheek and arm.
14599: Wherefore, among whalemen, the spout is deemed poisonous; they try to
14600: evade it. Another thing; I have heard it said, and I do not much doubt
14601: it, that if the jet is fairly spouted into your eyes, it will blind
14602: you. The wisest thing the investigator can do then, it seems to me, is
14603: to let this deadly spout alone.
14604: 
14605: Still, we can hypothesize, even if we cannot prove and establish. My
14606: hypothesis is this: that the spout is nothing but mist. And besides
14607: other reasons, to this conclusion I am impelled, by considerations
14608: touching the great inherent dignity and sublimity of the Sperm Whale; I
14609: account him no common, shallow being, inasmuch as it is an undisputed
14610: fact that he is never found on soundings, or near shores; all other
14611: whales sometimes are. He is both ponderous and profound. And I am
14612: convinced that from the heads of all ponderous profound beings, such as
14613: Plato, Pyrrho, the Devil, Jupiter, Dante, and so on, there always goes
14614: up a certain semi-visible steam, while in the act of thinking deep
14615: thoughts. While composing a little treatise on Eternity, I had the
14616: curiosity to place a mirror before me; and ere long saw reflected
14617: there, a curious involved worming and undulation in the atmosphere over
14618: my head. The invariable moisture of my hair, while plunged in deep
14619: thought, after six cups of hot tea in my thin shingled attic, of an
14620: August noon; this seems an additional argument for the above
14621: supposition.
14622: 
14623: And how nobly it raises our conceit of the mighty, misty monster, to
14624: behold him solemnly sailing through a calm tropical sea; his vast, mild
14625: head overhung by a canopy of vapor, engendered by his incommunicable
14626: contemplations, and that vapor—as you will sometimes see it—glorified
14627: by a rainbow, as if Heaven itself had put its seal upon his thoughts.
14628: For, d’ye see, rainbows do not visit the clear air; they only irradiate
14629: vapor. And so, through all the thick mists of the dim doubts in my
14630: mind, divine intuitions now and then shoot, enkindling my fog with a
14631: heavenly ray. And for this I thank God; for all have doubts; many deny;
14632: but doubts or denials, few along with them, have intuitions. Doubts of
14633: all things earthly, and intuitions of some things heavenly; this
14634: combination makes neither believer nor infidel, but makes a man who
14635: regards them both with equal eye.
14636: 
14637: 
14638: CHAPTER 86. The Tail.
14639: 
14640: Other poets have warbled the praises of the soft eye of the antelope,
14641: and the lovely plumage of the bird that never alights; less celestial,
14642: I celebrate a tail.
14643: 
14644: Reckoning the largest sized Sperm Whale’s tail to begin at that point
14645: of the trunk where it tapers to about the girth of a man, it comprises
14646: upon its upper surface alone, an area of at least fifty square feet.
14647: The compact round body of its root expands into two broad, firm, flat
14648: palms or flukes, gradually shoaling away to less than an inch in
14649: thickness. At the crotch or junction, these flukes slightly overlap,
14650: then sideways recede from each other like wings, leaving a wide vacancy
14651: between. In no living thing are the lines of beauty more exquisitely
14652: defined than in the crescentic borders of these flukes. At its utmost
14653: expansion in the full grown whale, the tail will considerably exceed
14654: twenty feet across.
14655: 
14656: The entire member seems a dense webbed bed of welded sinews; but cut
14657: into it, and you find that three distinct strata compose it:—upper,
14658: middle, and lower. The fibres in the upper and lower layers, are long
14659: and horizontal; those of the middle one, very short, and running
14660: crosswise between the outside layers. This triune structure, as much as
14661: anything else, imparts power to the tail. To the student of old Roman
14662: walls, the middle layer will furnish a curious parallel to the thin
14663: course of tiles always alternating with the stone in those wonderful
14664: relics of the antique, and which undoubtedly contribute so much to the
14665: great strength of the masonry.
14666: 
14667: But as if this vast local power in the tendinous tail were not enough,
14668: the whole bulk of the leviathan is knit over with a warp and woof of
14669: muscular fibres and filaments, which passing on either side the loins
14670: and running down into the flukes, insensibly blend with them, and
14671: largely contribute to their might; so that in the tail the confluent
14672: measureless force of the whole whale seems concentrated to a point.
14673: Could annihilation occur to matter, this were the thing to do it.
14674: 
14675: Nor does this—its amazing strength, at all tend to cripple the graceful
14676: flexion of its motions; where infantileness of ease undulates through a
14677: Titanism of power. On the contrary, those motions derive their most
14678: appalling beauty from it. Real strength never impairs beauty or
14679: harmony, but it often bestows it; and in everything imposingly
14680: beautiful, strength has much to do with the magic. Take away the tied
14681: tendons that all over seem bursting from the marble in the carved
14682: Hercules, and its charm would be gone. As devout Eckerman lifted the
14683: linen sheet from the naked corpse of Goethe, he was overwhelmed with
14684: the massive chest of the man, that seemed as a Roman triumphal arch.
14685: When Angelo paints even God the Father in human form, mark what
14686: robustness is there. And whatever they may reveal of the divine love in
14687: the Son, the soft, curled, hermaphroditical Italian pictures, in which
14688: his idea has been most successfully embodied; these pictures, so
14689: destitute as they are of all brawniness, hint nothing of any power, but
14690: the mere negative, feminine one of submission and endurance, which on
14691: all hands it is conceded, form the peculiar practical virtues of his
14692: teachings.
14693: 
14694: Such is the subtle elasticity of the organ I treat of, that whether
14695: wielded in sport, or in earnest, or in anger, whatever be the mood it
14696: be in, its flexions are invariably marked by exceeding grace. Therein
14697: no fairy’s arm can transcend it.
14698: 
14699: Five great motions are peculiar to it. First, when used as a fin for
14700: progression; Second, when used as a mace in battle; Third, in sweeping;
14701: Fourth, in lobtailing; Fifth, in peaking flukes.
14702: 
14703: First: Being horizontal in its position, the Leviathan’s tail acts in a
14704: different manner from the tails of all other sea creatures. It never
14705: wriggles. In man or fish, wriggling is a sign of inferiority. To the
14706: whale, his tail is the sole means of propulsion. Scroll-wise coiled
14707: forwards beneath the body, and then rapidly sprung backwards, it is
14708: this which gives that singular darting, leaping motion to the monster
14709: when furiously swimming. His side-fins only serve to steer by.
14710: 
14711: Second: It is a little significant, that while one sperm whale only
14712: fights another sperm whale with his head and jaw, nevertheless, in his
14713: conflicts with man, he chiefly and contemptuously uses his tail. In
14714: striking at a boat, he swiftly curves away his flukes from it, and the
14715: blow is only inflicted by the recoil. If it be made in the unobstructed
14716: air, especially if it descend to its mark, the stroke is then simply
14717: irresistible. No ribs of man or boat can withstand it. Your only
14718: salvation lies in eluding it; but if it comes sideways through the
14719: opposing water, then partly owing to the light buoyancy of the
14720: whale-boat, and the elasticity of its materials, a cracked rib or a
14721: dashed plank or two, a sort of stitch in the side, is generally the
14722: most serious result. These submerged side blows are so often received
14723: in the fishery, that they are accounted mere child’s play. Some one
14724: strips off a frock, and the hole is stopped.
14725: 
14726: Third: I cannot demonstrate it, but it seems to me, that in the whale
14727: the sense of touch is concentrated in the tail; for in this respect
14728: there is a delicacy in it only equalled by the daintiness of the
14729: elephant’s trunk. This delicacy is chiefly evinced in the action of
14730: sweeping, when in maidenly gentleness the whale with a certain soft
14731: slowness moves his immense flukes from side to side upon the surface of
14732: the sea; and if he feel but a sailor’s whisker, woe to that sailor,
14733: whiskers and all. What tenderness there is in that preliminary touch!
14734: Had this tail any prehensile power, I should straightway bethink me of
14735: Darmonodes’ elephant that so frequented the flower-market, and with low
14736: salutations presented nosegays to damsels, and then caressed their
14737: zones. On more accounts than one, a pity it is that the whale does not
14738: possess this prehensile virtue in his tail; for I have heard of yet
14739: another elephant, that when wounded in the fight, curved round his
14740: trunk and extracted the dart.
14741: 
14742: Fourth: Stealing unawares upon the whale in the fancied security of the
14743: middle of solitary seas, you find him unbent from the vast corpulence
14744: of his dignity, and kitten-like, he plays on the ocean as if it were a
14745: hearth. But still you see his power in his play. The broad palms of his
14746: tail are flirted high into the air; then smiting the surface, the
14747: thunderous concussion resounds for miles. You would almost think a
14748: great gun had been discharged; and if you noticed the light wreath of
14749: vapor from the spiracle at his other extremity, you would think that
14750: that was the smoke from the touch-hole.
14751: 
14752: Fifth: As in the ordinary floating posture of the leviathan the flukes
14753: lie considerably below the level of his back, they are then completely
14754: out of sight beneath the surface; but when he is about to plunge into
14755: the deeps, his entire flukes with at least thirty feet of his body are
14756: tossed erect in the air, and so remain vibrating a moment, till they
14757: downwards shoot out of view. Excepting the sublime _breach_—somewhere
14758: else to be described—this peaking of the whale’s flukes is perhaps the
14759: grandest sight to be seen in all animated nature. Out of the bottomless
14760: profundities the gigantic tail seems spasmodically snatching at the
14761: highest heaven. So in dreams, have I seen majestic Satan thrusting
14762: forth his tormented colossal claw from the flame Baltic of Hell. But in
14763: gazing at such scenes, it is all in all what mood you are in; if in the
14764: Dantean, the devils will occur to you; if in that of Isaiah, the
14765: archangels. Standing at the mast-head of my ship during a sunrise that
14766: crimsoned sky and sea, I once saw a large herd of whales in the east,
14767: all heading towards the sun, and for a moment vibrating in concert with
14768: peaked flukes. As it seemed to me at the time, such a grand embodiment
14769: of adoration of the gods was never beheld, even in Persia, the home of
14770: the fire worshippers. As Ptolemy Philopater testified of the African
14771: elephant, I then testified of the whale, pronouncing him the most
14772: devout of all beings. For according to King Juba, the military
14773: elephants of antiquity often hailed the morning with their trunks
14774: uplifted in the profoundest silence.
14775: 
14776: The chance comparison in this chapter, between the whale and the
14777: elephant, so far as some aspects of the tail of the one and the trunk
14778: of the other are concerned, should not tend to place those two opposite
14779: organs on an equality, much less the creatures to which they
14780: respectively belong. For as the mightiest elephant is but a terrier to
14781: Leviathan, so, compared with Leviathan’s tail, his trunk is but the
14782: stalk of a lily. The most direful blow from the elephant’s trunk were
14783: as the playful tap of a fan, compared with the measureless crush and
14784: crash of the sperm whale’s ponderous flukes, which in repeated
14785: instances have one after the other hurled entire boats with all their
14786: oars and crews into the air, very much as an Indian juggler tosses his
14787: balls.*
14788: 
14789: *Though all comparison in the way of general bulk between the whale and
14790: the elephant is preposterous, inasmuch as in that particular the
14791: elephant stands in much the same respect to the whale that a dog does
14792: to the elephant; nevertheless, there are not wanting some points of
14793: curious similitude; among these is the spout. It is well known that the
14794: elephant will often draw up water or dust in his trunk, and then
14795: elevating it, jet it forth in a stream.
14796: 
14797: The more I consider this mighty tail, the more do I deplore my
14798: inability to express it. At times there are gestures in it, which,
14799: though they would well grace the hand of man, remain wholly
14800: inexplicable. In an extensive herd, so remarkable, occasionally, are
14801: these mystic gestures, that I have heard hunters who have declared them
14802: akin to Free-Mason signs and symbols; that the whale, indeed, by these
14803: methods intelligently conversed with the world. Nor are there wanting
14804: other motions of the whale in his general body, full of strangeness,
14805: and unaccountable to his most experienced assailant. Dissect him how I
14806: may, then, I but go skin deep; I know him not, and never will. But if I
14807: know not even the tail of this whale, how understand his head? much
14808: more, how comprehend his face, when face he has none? Thou shalt see my
14809: back parts, my tail, he seems to say, but my face shall not be seen.
14810: But I cannot completely make out his back parts; and hint what he will
14811: about his face, I say again he has no face.
14812: 
14813: 
14814: CHAPTER 87. The Grand Armada.
14815: 
14816: The long and narrow peninsula of Malacca, extending south-eastward from
14817: the territories of Birmah, forms the most southerly point of all Asia.
14818: In a continuous line from that peninsula stretch the long islands of
14819: Sumatra, Java, Bally, and Timor; which, with many others, form a vast
14820: mole, or rampart, lengthwise connecting Asia with Australia, and
14821: dividing the long unbroken Indian ocean from the thickly studded
14822: oriental archipelagoes. This rampart is pierced by several sally-ports
14823: for the convenience of ships and whales; conspicuous among which are
14824: the straits of Sunda and Malacca. By the straits of Sunda, chiefly,
14825: vessels bound to China from the west, emerge into the China seas.
14826: 
14827: Those narrow straits of Sunda divide Sumatra from Java; and standing
14828: midway in that vast rampart of islands, buttressed by that bold green
14829: promontory, known to seamen as Java Head; they not a little correspond
14830: to the central gateway opening into some vast walled empire: and
14831: considering the inexhaustible wealth of spices, and silks, and jewels,
14832: and gold, and ivory, with which the thousand islands of that oriental
14833: sea are enriched, it seems a significant provision of nature, that such
14834: treasures, by the very formation of the land, should at least bear the
14835: appearance, however ineffectual, of being guarded from the all-grasping
14836: western world. The shores of the Straits of Sunda are unsupplied with
14837: those domineering fortresses which guard the entrances to the
14838: Mediterranean, the Baltic, and the Propontis. Unlike the Danes, these
14839: Orientals do not demand the obsequious homage of lowered top-sails from
14840: the endless procession of ships before the wind, which for centuries
14841: past, by night and by day, have passed between the islands of Sumatra
14842: and Java, freighted with the costliest cargoes of the east. But while
14843: they freely waive a ceremonial like this, they do by no means renounce
14844: their claim to more solid tribute.
14845: 
14846: Time out of mind the piratical proas of the Malays, lurking among the
14847: low shaded coves and islets of Sumatra, have sallied out upon the
14848: vessels sailing through the straits, fiercely demanding tribute at the
14849: point of their spears. Though by the repeated bloody chastisements they
14850: have received at the hands of European cruisers, the audacity of these
14851: corsairs has of late been somewhat repressed; yet, even at the present
14852: day, we occasionally hear of English and American vessels, which, in
14853: those waters, have been remorselessly boarded and pillaged.
14854: 
14855: With a fair, fresh wind, the Pequod was now drawing nigh to these
14856: straits; Ahab purposing to pass through them into the Javan sea, and
14857: thence, cruising northwards, over waters known to be frequented here
14858: and there by the Sperm Whale, sweep inshore by the Philippine Islands,
14859: and gain the far coast of Japan, in time for the great whaling season
14860: there. By these means, the circumnavigating Pequod would sweep almost
14861: all the known Sperm Whale cruising grounds of the world, previous to
14862: descending upon the Line in the Pacific; where Ahab, though everywhere
14863: else foiled in his pursuit, firmly counted upon giving battle to Moby
14864: Dick, in the sea he was most known to frequent; and at a season when he
14865: might most reasonably be presumed to be haunting it.
14866: 
14867: But how now? in this zoned quest, does Ahab touch no land? does his
14868: crew drink air? Surely, he will stop for water. Nay. For a long time,
14869: now, the circus-running sun has raced within his fiery ring, and needs
14870: no sustenance but what’s in himself. So Ahab. Mark this, too, in the
14871: whaler. While other hulls are loaded down with alien stuff, to be
14872: transferred to foreign wharves; the world-wandering whale-ship carries
14873: no cargo but herself and crew, their weapons and their wants. She has a
14874: whole lake’s contents bottled in her ample hold. She is ballasted with
14875: utilities; not altogether with unusable pig-lead and kentledge. She
14876: carries years’ water in her. Clear old prime Nantucket water; which,
14877: when three years afloat, the Nantucketer, in the Pacific, prefers to
14878: drink before the brackish fluid, but yesterday rafted off in casks,
14879: from the Peruvian or Indian streams. Hence it is, that, while other
14880: ships may have gone to China from New York, and back again, touching at
14881: a score of ports, the whale-ship, in all that interval, may not have
14882: sighted one grain of soil; her crew having seen no man but floating
14883: seamen like themselves. So that did you carry them the news that
14884: another flood had come; they would only answer—“Well, boys, here’s the
14885: ark!”
14886: 
14887: Now, as many Sperm Whales had been captured off the western coast of
14888: Java, in the near vicinity of the Straits of Sunda; indeed, as most of
14889: the ground, roundabout, was generally recognised by the fishermen as an
14890: excellent spot for cruising; therefore, as the Pequod gained more and
14891: more upon Java Head, the look-outs were repeatedly hailed, and
14892: admonished to keep wide awake. But though the green palmy cliffs of the
14893: land soon loomed on the starboard bow, and with delighted nostrils the
14894: fresh cinnamon was snuffed in the air, yet not a single jet was
14895: descried. Almost renouncing all thought of falling in with any game
14896: hereabouts, the ship had well nigh entered the straits, when the
14897: customary cheering cry was heard from aloft, and ere long a spectacle
14898: of singular magnificence saluted us.
14899: 
14900: But here be it premised, that owing to the unwearied activity with
14901: which of late they have been hunted over all four oceans, the Sperm
14902: Whales, instead of almost invariably sailing in small detached
14903: companies, as in former times, are now frequently met with in extensive
14904: herds, sometimes embracing so great a multitude, that it would almost
14905: seem as if numerous nations of them had sworn solemn league and
14906: covenant for mutual assistance and protection. To this aggregation of
14907: the Sperm Whale into such immense caravans, may be imputed the
14908: circumstance that even in the best cruising grounds, you may now
14909: sometimes sail for weeks and months together, without being greeted by
14910: a single spout; and then be suddenly saluted by what sometimes seems
14911: thousands on thousands.
14912: 
14913: Broad on both bows, at the distance of some two or three miles, and
14914: forming a great semicircle, embracing one half of the level horizon, a
14915: continuous chain of whale-jets were up-playing and sparkling in the
14916: noon-day air. Unlike the straight perpendicular twin-jets of the Right
14917: Whale, which, dividing at top, fall over in two branches, like the
14918: cleft drooping boughs of a willow, the single forward-slanting spout of
14919: the Sperm Whale presents a thick curled bush of white mist, continually
14920: rising and falling away to leeward.
14921: 
14922: Seen from the Pequod’s deck, then, as she would rise on a high hill of
14923: the sea, this host of vapory spouts, individually curling up into the
14924: air, and beheld through a blending atmosphere of bluish haze, showed
14925: like the thousand cheerful chimneys of some dense metropolis, descried
14926: of a balmy autumnal morning, by some horseman on a height.
14927: 
14928: As marching armies approaching an unfriendly defile in the mountains,
14929: accelerate their march, all eagerness to place that perilous passage in
14930: their rear, and once more expand in comparative security upon the
14931: plain; even so did this vast fleet of whales now seem hurrying forward
14932: through the straits; gradually contracting the wings of their
14933: semicircle, and swimming on, in one solid, but still crescentic centre.
14934: 
14935: Crowding all sail the Pequod pressed after them; the harpooneers
14936: handling their weapons, and loudly cheering from the heads of their yet
14937: suspended boats. If the wind only held, little doubt had they, that
14938: chased through these Straits of Sunda, the vast host would only deploy
14939: into the Oriental seas to witness the capture of not a few of their
14940: number. And who could tell whether, in that congregated caravan, Moby
14941: Dick himself might not temporarily be swimming, like the worshipped
14942: white-elephant in the coronation procession of the Siamese! So with
14943: stun-sail piled on stun-sail, we sailed along, driving these leviathans
14944: before us; when, of a sudden, the voice of Tashtego was heard, loudly
14945: directing attention to something in our wake.
14946: 
14947: Corresponding to the crescent in our van, we beheld another in our
14948: rear. It seemed formed of detached white vapors, rising and falling
14949: something like the spouts of the whales; only they did not so
14950: completely come and go; for they constantly hovered, without finally
14951: disappearing. Levelling his glass at this sight, Ahab quickly revolved
14952: in his pivot-hole, crying, “Aloft there, and rig whips and buckets to
14953: wet the sails;—Malays, sir, and after us!”
14954: 
14955: As if too long lurking behind the headlands, till the Pequod should
14956: fairly have entered the straits, these rascally Asiatics were now in
14957: hot pursuit, to make up for their over-cautious delay. But when the
14958: swift Pequod, with a fresh leading wind, was herself in hot chase; how
14959: very kind of these tawny philanthropists to assist in speeding her on
14960: to her own chosen pursuit,—mere riding-whips and rowels to her, that
14961: they were. As with glass under arm, Ahab to-and-fro paced the deck; in
14962: his forward turn beholding the monsters he chased, and in the after one
14963: the bloodthirsty pirates chasing _him_; some such fancy as the above
14964: seemed his. And when he glanced upon the green walls of the watery
14965: defile in which the ship was then sailing, and bethought him that
14966: through that gate lay the route to his vengeance, and beheld, how that
14967: through that same gate he was now both chasing and being chased to his
14968: deadly end; and not only that, but a herd of remorseless wild pirates
14969: and inhuman atheistical devils were infernally cheering him on with
14970: their curses;—when all these conceits had passed through his brain,
14971: Ahab’s brow was left gaunt and ribbed, like the black sand beach after
14972: some stormy tide has been gnawing it, without being able to drag the
14973: firm thing from its place.
14974: 
14975: But thoughts like these troubled very few of the reckless crew; and
14976: when, after steadily dropping and dropping the pirates astern, the
14977: Pequod at last shot by the vivid green Cockatoo Point on the Sumatra
14978: side, emerging at last upon the broad waters beyond; then, the
14979: harpooneers seemed more to grieve that the swift whales had been
14980: gaining upon the ship, than to rejoice that the ship had so
14981: victoriously gained upon the Malays. But still driving on in the wake
14982: of the whales, at length they seemed abating their speed; gradually the
14983: ship neared them; and the wind now dying away, word was passed to
14984: spring to the boats. But no sooner did the herd, by some presumed
14985: wonderful instinct of the Sperm Whale, become notified of the three
14986: keels that were after them,—though as yet a mile in their rear,—than
14987: they rallied again, and forming in close ranks and battalions, so that
14988: their spouts all looked like flashing lines of stacked bayonets, moved
14989: on with redoubled velocity.
14990: 
14991: Stripped to our shirts and drawers, we sprang to the white-ash, and
14992: after several hours’ pulling were almost disposed to renounce the
14993: chase, when a general pausing commotion among the whales gave animating
14994: token that they were now at last under the influence of that strange
14995: perplexity of inert irresolution, which, when the fishermen perceive it
14996: in the whale, they say he is gallied. The compact martial columns in
14997: which they had been hitherto rapidly and steadily swimming, were now
14998: broken up in one measureless rout; and like King Porus’ elephants in
14999: the Indian battle with Alexander, they seemed going mad with
15000: consternation. In all directions expanding in vast irregular circles,
15001: and aimlessly swimming hither and thither, by their short thick
15002: spoutings, they plainly betrayed their distraction of panic. This was
15003: still more strangely evinced by those of their number, who, completely
15004: paralysed as it were, helplessly floated like water-logged dismantled
15005: ships on the sea. Had these Leviathans been but a flock of simple
15006: sheep, pursued over the pasture by three fierce wolves, they could not
15007: possibly have evinced such excessive dismay. But this occasional
15008: timidity is characteristic of almost all herding creatures. Though
15009: banding together in tens of thousands, the lion-maned buffaloes of the
15010: West have fled before a solitary horseman. Witness, too, all human
15011: beings, how when herded together in the sheepfold of a theatre’s pit,
15012: they will, at the slightest alarm of fire, rush helter-skelter for the
15013: outlets, crowding, trampling, jamming, and remorselessly dashing each
15014: other to death. Best, therefore, withhold any amazement at the
15015: strangely gallied whales before us, for there is no folly of the beasts
15016: of the earth which is not infinitely outdone by the madness of men.
15017: 
15018: Though many of the whales, as has been said, were in violent motion,
15019: yet it is to be observed that as a whole the herd neither advanced nor
15020: retreated, but collectively remained in one place. As is customary in
15021: those cases, the boats at once separated, each making for some one lone
15022: whale on the outskirts of the shoal. In about three minutes’ time,
15023: Queequeg’s harpoon was flung; the stricken fish darted blinding spray
15024: in our faces, and then running away with us like light, steered
15025: straight for the heart of the herd. Though such a movement on the part
15026: of the whale struck under such circumstances, is in no wise
15027: unprecedented; and indeed is almost always more or less anticipated;
15028: yet does it present one of the more perilous vicissitudes of the
15029: fishery. For as the swift monster drags you deeper and deeper into the
15030: frantic shoal, you bid adieu to circumspect life and only exist in a
15031: delirious throb.
15032: 
15033: As, blind and deaf, the whale plunged forward, as if by sheer power of
15034: speed to rid himself of the iron leech that had fastened to him; as we
15035: thus tore a white gash in the sea, on all sides menaced as we flew, by
15036: the crazed creatures to and fro rushing about us; our beset boat was
15037: like a ship mobbed by ice-isles in a tempest, and striving to steer
15038: through their complicated channels and straits, knowing not at what
15039: moment it may be locked in and crushed.
15040: 
15041: But not a bit daunted, Queequeg steered us manfully; now sheering off
15042: from this monster directly across our route in advance; now edging away
15043: from that, whose colossal flukes were suspended overhead, while all the
15044: time, Starbuck stood up in the bows, lance in hand, pricking out of our
15045: way whatever whales he could reach by short darts, for there was no
15046: time to make long ones. Nor were the oarsmen quite idle, though their
15047: wonted duty was now altogether dispensed with. They chiefly attended to
15048: the shouting part of the business. “Out of the way, Commodore!” cried
15049: one, to a great dromedary that of a sudden rose bodily to the surface,
15050: and for an instant threatened to swamp us. “Hard down with your tail,
15051: there!” cried a second to another, which, close to our gunwale, seemed
15052: calmly cooling himself with his own fan-like extremity.
15053: 
15054: All whaleboats carry certain curious contrivances, originally invented
15055: by the Nantucket Indians, called druggs. Two thick squares of wood of
15056: equal size are stoutly clenched together, so that they cross each
15057: other’s grain at right angles; a line of considerable length is then
15058: attached to the middle of this block, and the other end of the line
15059: being looped, it can in a moment be fastened to a harpoon. It is
15060: chiefly among gallied whales that this drugg is used. For then, more
15061: whales are close round you than you can possibly chase at one time. But
15062: sperm whales are not every day encountered; while you may, then, you
15063: must kill all you can. And if you cannot kill them all at once, you
15064: must wing them, so that they can be afterwards killed at your leisure.
15065: Hence it is, that at times like these the drugg, comes into
15066: requisition. Our boat was furnished with three of them. The first and
15067: second were successfully darted, and we saw the whales staggeringly
15068: running off, fettered by the enormous sidelong resistance of the towing
15069: drugg. They were cramped like malefactors with the chain and ball. But
15070: upon flinging the third, in the act of tossing overboard the clumsy
15071: wooden block, it caught under one of the seats of the boat, and in an
15072: instant tore it out and carried it away, dropping the oarsman in the
15073: boat’s bottom as the seat slid from under him. On both sides the sea
15074: came in at the wounded planks, but we stuffed two or three drawers and
15075: shirts in, and so stopped the leaks for the time.
15076: 
15077: It had been next to impossible to dart these drugged-harpoons, were it
15078: not that as we advanced into the herd, our whale’s way greatly
15079: diminished; moreover, that as we went still further and further from
15080: the circumference of commotion, the direful disorders seemed waning. So
15081: that when at last the jerking harpoon drew out, and the towing whale
15082: sideways vanished; then, with the tapering force of his parting
15083: momentum, we glided between two whales into the innermost heart of the
15084: shoal, as if from some mountain torrent we had slid into a serene
15085: valley lake. Here the storms in the roaring glens between the outermost
15086: whales, were heard but not felt. In this central expanse the sea
15087: presented that smooth satin-like surface, called a sleek, produced by
15088: the subtle moisture thrown off by the whale in his more quiet moods.
15089: Yes, we were now in that enchanted calm which they say lurks at the
15090: heart of every commotion. And still in the distracted distance we
15091: beheld the tumults of the outer concentric circles, and saw successive
15092: pods of whales, eight or ten in each, swiftly going round and round,
15093: like multiplied spans of horses in a ring; and so closely shoulder to
15094: shoulder, that a Titanic circus-rider might easily have over-arched the
15095: middle ones, and so have gone round on their backs. Owing to the
15096: density of the crowd of reposing whales, more immediately surrounding
15097: the embayed axis of the herd, no possible chance of escape was at
15098: present afforded us. We must watch for a breach in the living wall that
15099: hemmed us in; the wall that had only admitted us in order to shut us
15100: up. Keeping at the centre of the lake, we were occasionally visited by
15101: small tame cows and calves; the women and children of this routed host.
15102: 
15103: Now, inclusive of the occasional wide intervals between the revolving
15104: outer circles, and inclusive of the spaces between the various pods in
15105: any one of those circles, the entire area at this juncture, embraced by
15106: the whole multitude, must have contained at least two or three square
15107: miles. At any rate—though indeed such a test at such a time might be
15108: deceptive—spoutings might be discovered from our low boat that seemed
15109: playing up almost from the rim of the horizon. I mention this
15110: circumstance, because, as if the cows and calves had been purposely
15111: locked up in this innermost fold; and as if the wide extent of the herd
15112: had hitherto prevented them from learning the precise cause of its
15113: stopping; or, possibly, being so young, unsophisticated, and every way
15114: innocent and inexperienced; however it may have been, these smaller
15115: whales—now and then visiting our becalmed boat from the margin of the
15116: lake—evinced a wondrous fearlessness and confidence, or else a still
15117: becharmed panic which it was impossible not to marvel at. Like
15118: household dogs they came snuffling round us, right up to our gunwales,
15119: and touching them; till it almost seemed that some spell had suddenly
15120: domesticated them. Queequeg patted their foreheads; Starbuck scratched
15121: their backs with his lance; but fearful of the consequences, for the
15122: time refrained from darting it.
15123: 
15124: But far beneath this wondrous world upon the surface, another and still
15125: stranger world met our eyes as we gazed over the side. For, suspended
15126: in those watery vaults, floated the forms of the nursing mothers of the
15127: whales, and those that by their enormous girth seemed shortly to become
15128: mothers. The lake, as I have hinted, was to a considerable depth
15129: exceedingly transparent; and as human infants while suckling will
15130: calmly and fixedly gaze away from the breast, as if leading two
15131: different lives at the time; and while yet drawing mortal nourishment,
15132: be still spiritually feasting upon some unearthly reminiscence;—even so
15133: did the young of these whales seem looking up towards us, but not at
15134: us, as if we were but a bit of Gulfweed in their new-born sight.
15135: Floating on their sides, the mothers also seemed quietly eyeing us. One
15136: of these little infants, that from certain queer tokens seemed hardly a
15137: day old, might have measured some fourteen feet in length, and some six
15138: feet in girth. He was a little frisky; though as yet his body seemed
15139: scarce yet recovered from that irksome position it had so lately
15140: occupied in the maternal reticule; where, tail to head, and all ready
15141: for the final spring, the unborn whale lies bent like a Tartar’s bow.
15142: The delicate side-fins, and the palms of his flukes, still freshly
15143: retained the plaited crumpled appearance of a baby’s ears newly arrived
15144: from foreign parts.
15145: 
15146: “Line! line!” cried Queequeg, looking over the gunwale; “him fast! him
15147: fast!—Who line him! Who struck?—Two whale; one big, one little!”
15148: 
15149: “What ails ye, man?” cried Starbuck.
15150: 
15151: “Look-e here,” said Queequeg, pointing down.
15152: 
15153: As when the stricken whale, that from the tub has reeled out hundreds
15154: of fathoms of rope; as, after deep sounding, he floats up again, and
15155: shows the slackened curling line buoyantly rising and spiralling
15156: towards the air; so now, Starbuck saw long coils of the umbilical cord
15157: of Madame Leviathan, by which the young cub seemed still tethered to
15158: its dam. Not seldom in the rapid vicissitudes of the chase, this
15159: natural line, with the maternal end loose, becomes entangled with the
15160: hempen one, so that the cub is thereby trapped. Some of the subtlest
15161: secrets of the seas seemed divulged to us in this enchanted pond. We
15162: saw young Leviathan amours in the deep.*
15163: 
15164: *The sperm whale, as with all other species of the Leviathan, but
15165: unlike most other fish, breeds indifferently at all seasons; after a
15166: gestation which may probably be set down at nine months, producing but
15167: one at a time; though in some few known instances giving birth to an
15168: Esau and Jacob:—a contingency provided for in suckling by two teats,
15169: curiously situated, one on each side of the anus; but the breasts
15170: themselves extend upwards from that. When by chance these precious
15171: parts in a nursing whale are cut by the hunter’s lance, the mother’s
15172: pouring milk and blood rivallingly discolour the sea for rods. The milk
15173: is very sweet and rich; it has been tasted by man; it might do well
15174: with strawberries. When overflowing with mutual esteem, the whales
15175: salute _more hominum_.
15176: 
15177: And thus, though surrounded by circle upon circle of consternations and
15178: affrights, did these inscrutable creatures at the centre freely and
15179: fearlessly indulge in all peaceful concernments; yea, serenely revelled
15180: in dalliance and delight. But even so, amid the tornadoed Atlantic of
15181: my being, do I myself still for ever centrally disport in mute calm;
15182: and while ponderous planets of unwaning woe revolve round me, deep down
15183: and deep inland there I still bathe me in eternal mildness of joy.
15184: 
15185: Meanwhile, as we thus lay entranced, the occasional sudden frantic
15186: spectacles in the distance evinced the activity of the other boats,
15187: still engaged in drugging the whales on the frontier of the host; or
15188: possibly carrying on the war within the first circle, where abundance
15189: of room and some convenient retreats were afforded them. But the sight
15190: of the enraged drugged whales now and then blindly darting to and fro
15191: across the circles, was nothing to what at last met our eyes. It is
15192: sometimes the custom when fast to a whale more than commonly powerful
15193: and alert, to seek to hamstring him, as it were, by sundering or
15194: maiming his gigantic tail-tendon. It is done by darting a short-handled
15195: cutting-spade, to which is attached a rope for hauling it back again. A
15196: whale wounded (as we afterwards learned) in this part, but not
15197: effectually, as it seemed, had broken away from the boat, carrying
15198: along with him half of the harpoon line; and in the extraordinary agony
15199: of the wound, he was now dashing among the revolving circles like the
15200: lone mounted desperado Arnold, at the battle of Saratoga, carrying
15201: dismay wherever he went.
15202: 
15203: But agonizing as was the wound of this whale, and an appalling
15204: spectacle enough, any way; yet the peculiar horror with which he seemed
15205: to inspire the rest of the herd, was owing to a cause which at first
15206: the intervening distance obscured from us. But at length we perceived
15207: that by one of the unimaginable accidents of the fishery, this whale
15208: had become entangled in the harpoon-line that he towed; he had also run
15209: away with the cutting-spade in him; and while the free end of the rope
15210: attached to that weapon, had permanently caught in the coils of the
15211: harpoon-line round his tail, the cutting-spade itself had worked loose
15212: from his flesh. So that tormented to madness, he was now churning
15213: through the water, violently flailing with his flexible tail, and
15214: tossing the keen spade about him, wounding and murdering his own
15215: comrades.
15216: 
15217: This terrific object seemed to recall the whole herd from their
15218: stationary fright. First, the whales forming the margin of our lake
15219: began to crowd a little, and tumble against each other, as if lifted by
15220: half spent billows from afar; then the lake itself began faintly to
15221: heave and swell; the submarine bridal-chambers and nurseries vanished;
15222: in more and more contracting orbits the whales in the more central
15223: circles began to swim in thickening clusters. Yes, the long calm was
15224: departing. A low advancing hum was soon heard; and then like to the
15225: tumultuous masses of block-ice when the great river Hudson breaks up in
15226: Spring, the entire host of whales came tumbling upon their inner
15227: centre, as if to pile themselves up in one common mountain. Instantly
15228: Starbuck and Queequeg changed places; Starbuck taking the stern.
15229: 
15230: “Oars! Oars!” he intensely whispered, seizing the helm—“gripe your
15231: oars, and clutch your souls, now! My God, men, stand by! Shove him off,
15232: you Queequeg—the whale there!—prick him!—hit him! Stand up—stand up,
15233: and stay so! Spring, men—pull, men; never mind their backs—scrape
15234: them!—scrape away!”
15235: 
15236: The boat was now all but jammed between two vast black bulks, leaving a
15237: narrow Dardanelles between their long lengths. But by desperate
15238: endeavor we at last shot into a temporary opening; then giving way
15239: rapidly, and at the same time earnestly watching for another outlet.
15240: After many similar hair-breadth escapes, we at last swiftly glided into
15241: what had just been one of the outer circles, but now crossed by random
15242: whales, all violently making for one centre. This lucky salvation was
15243: cheaply purchased by the loss of Queequeg’s hat, who, while standing in
15244: the bows to prick the fugitive whales, had his hat taken clean from his
15245: head by the air-eddy made by the sudden tossing of a pair of broad
15246: flukes close by.
15247: 
15248: Riotous and disordered as the universal commotion now was, it soon
15249: resolved itself into what seemed a systematic movement; for having
15250: clumped together at last in one dense body, they then renewed their
15251: onward flight with augmented fleetness. Further pursuit was useless;
15252: but the boats still lingered in their wake to pick up what drugged
15253: whales might be dropped astern, and likewise to secure one which Flask
15254: had killed and waifed. The waif is a pennoned pole, two or three of
15255: which are carried by every boat; and which, when additional game is at
15256: hand, are inserted upright into the floating body of a dead whale, both
15257: to mark its place on the sea, and also as token of prior possession,
15258: should the boats of any other ship draw near.
15259: 
15260: The result of this lowering was somewhat illustrative of that sagacious
15261: saying in the Fishery,—the more whales the less fish. Of all the
15262: drugged whales only one was captured. The rest contrived to escape for
15263: the time, but only to be taken, as will hereafter be seen, by some
15264: other craft than the Pequod.
15265: 
15266: 
15267: CHAPTER 88. Schools and Schoolmasters.
15268: 
15269: The previous chapter gave account of an immense body or herd of Sperm
15270: Whales, and there was also then given the probable cause inducing those
15271: vast aggregations.
15272: 
15273: Now, though such great bodies are at times encountered, yet, as must
15274: have been seen, even at the present day, small detached bands are
15275: occasionally observed, embracing from twenty to fifty individuals each.
15276: Such bands are known as schools. They generally are of two sorts; those
15277: composed almost entirely of females, and those mustering none but young
15278: vigorous males, or bulls, as they are familiarly designated.
15279: 
15280: In cavalier attendance upon the school of females, you invariably see a
15281: male of full grown magnitude, but not old; who, upon any alarm, evinces
15282: his gallantry by falling in the rear and covering the flight of his
15283: ladies. In truth, this gentleman is a luxurious Ottoman, swimming about
15284: over the watery world, surroundingly accompanied by all the solaces and
15285: endearments of the harem. The contrast between this Ottoman and his
15286: concubines is striking; because, while he is always of the largest
15287: leviathanic proportions, the ladies, even at full growth, are not more
15288: than one-third of the bulk of an average-sized male. They are
15289: comparatively delicate, indeed; I dare say, not to exceed half a dozen
15290: yards round the waist. Nevertheless, it cannot be denied, that upon the
15291: whole they are hereditarily entitled to _en bon point_.
15292: 
15293: It is very curious to watch this harem and its lord in their indolent
15294: ramblings. Like fashionables, they are for ever on the move in
15295: leisurely search of variety. You meet them on the Line in time for the
15296: full flower of the Equatorial feeding season, having just returned,
15297: perhaps, from spending the summer in the Northern seas, and so cheating
15298: summer of all unpleasant weariness and warmth. By the time they have
15299: lounged up and down the promenade of the Equator awhile, they start for
15300: the Oriental waters in anticipation of the cool season there, and so
15301: evade the other excessive temperature of the year.
15302: 
15303: When serenely advancing on one of these journeys, if any strange
15304: suspicious sights are seen, my lord whale keeps a wary eye on his
15305: interesting family. Should any unwarrantably pert young Leviathan
15306: coming that way, presume to draw confidentially close to one of the
15307: ladies, with what prodigious fury the Bashaw assails him, and chases
15308: him away! High times, indeed, if unprincipled young rakes like him are
15309: to be permitted to invade the sanctity of domestic bliss; though do
15310: what the Bashaw will, he cannot keep the most notorious Lothario out of
15311: his bed; for, alas! all fish bed in common. As ashore, the ladies often
15312: cause the most terrible duels among their rival admirers; just so with
15313: the whales, who sometimes come to deadly battle, and all for love. They
15314: fence with their long lower jaws, sometimes locking them together, and
15315: so striving for the supremacy like elks that warringly interweave their
15316: antlers. Not a few are captured having the deep scars of these
15317: encounters,—furrowed heads, broken teeth, scolloped fins; and in some
15318: instances, wrenched and dislocated mouths.
15319: 
15320: But supposing the invader of domestic bliss to betake himself away at
15321: the first rush of the harem’s lord, then is it very diverting to watch
15322: that lord. Gently he insinuates his vast bulk among them again and
15323: revels there awhile, still in tantalizing vicinity to young Lothario,
15324: like pious Solomon devoutly worshipping among his thousand concubines.
15325: Granting other whales to be in sight, the fishermen will seldom give
15326: chase to one of these Grand Turks; for these Grand Turks are too lavish
15327: of their strength, and hence their unctuousness is small. As for the
15328: sons and the daughters they beget, why, those sons and daughters must
15329: take care of themselves; at least, with only the maternal help. For
15330: like certain other omnivorous roving lovers that might be named, my
15331: Lord Whale has no taste for the nursery, however much for the bower;
15332: and so, being a great traveller, he leaves his anonymous babies all
15333: over the world; every baby an exotic. In good time, nevertheless, as
15334: the ardour of youth declines; as years and dumps increase; as
15335: reflection lends her solemn pauses; in short, as a general lassitude
15336: overtakes the sated Turk; then a love of ease and virtue supplants the
15337: love for maidens; our Ottoman enters upon the impotent, repentant,
15338: admonitory stage of life, forswears, disbands the harem, and grown to
15339: an exemplary, sulky old soul, goes about all alone among the meridians
15340: and parallels saying his prayers, and warning each young Leviathan from
15341: his amorous errors.
15342: 
15343: Now, as the harem of whales is called by the fishermen a school, so is
15344: the lord and master of that school technically known as the
15345: schoolmaster. It is therefore not in strict character, however
15346: admirably satirical, that after going to school himself, he should then
15347: go abroad inculcating not what he learned there, but the folly of it.
15348: His title, schoolmaster, would very naturally seem derived from the
