15349: name bestowed upon the harem itself, but some have surmised that the
15350: man who first thus entitled this sort of Ottoman whale, must have read
15351: the memoirs of Vidocq, and informed himself what sort of a
15352: country-schoolmaster that famous Frenchman was in his younger days, and
15353: what was the nature of those occult lessons he inculcated into some of
15354: his pupils.
15355: 
15356: The same secludedness and isolation to which the schoolmaster whale
15357: betakes himself in his advancing years, is true of all aged Sperm
15358: Whales. Almost universally, a lone whale—as a solitary Leviathan is
15359: called—proves an ancient one. Like venerable moss-bearded Daniel Boone,
15360: he will have no one near him but Nature herself; and her he takes to
15361: wife in the wilderness of waters, and the best of wives she is, though
15362: she keeps so many moody secrets.
15363: 
15364: The schools composing none but young and vigorous males, previously
15365: mentioned, offer a strong contrast to the harem schools. For while
15366: those female whales are characteristically timid, the young males, or
15367: forty-barrel-bulls, as they call them, are by far the most pugnacious
15368: of all Leviathans, and proverbially the most dangerous to encounter;
15369: excepting those wondrous grey-headed, grizzled whales, sometimes met,
15370: and these will fight you like grim fiends exasperated by a penal gout.
15371: 
15372: The Forty-barrel-bull schools are larger than the harem schools. Like a
15373: mob of young collegians, they are full of fight, fun, and wickedness,
15374: tumbling round the world at such a reckless, rollicking rate, that no
15375: prudent underwriter would insure them any more than he would a riotous
15376: lad at Yale or Harvard. They soon relinquish this turbulence though,
15377: and when about three-fourths grown, break up, and separately go about
15378: in quest of settlements, that is, harems.
15379: 
15380: Another point of difference between the male and female schools is
15381: still more characteristic of the sexes. Say you strike a
15382: Forty-barrel-bull—poor devil! all his comrades quit him. But strike a
15383: member of the harem school, and her companions swim around her with
15384: every token of concern, sometimes lingering so near her and so long, as
15385: themselves to fall a prey.
15386: 
15387: 
15388: CHAPTER 89. Fast-Fish and Loose-Fish.
15389: 
15390: The allusion to the waif and waif-poles in the last chapter but one,
15391: necessitates some account of the laws and regulations of the whale
15392: fishery, of which the waif may be deemed the grand symbol and badge.
15393: 
15394: It frequently happens that when several ships are cruising in company,
15395: a whale may be struck by one vessel, then escape, and be finally killed
15396: and captured by another vessel; and herein are indirectly comprised
15397: many minor contingencies, all partaking of this one grand feature. For
15398: example,—after a weary and perilous chase and capture of a whale, the
15399: body may get loose from the ship by reason of a violent storm; and
15400: drifting far away to leeward, be retaken by a second whaler, who, in a
15401: calm, snugly tows it alongside, without risk of life or line. Thus the
15402: most vexatious and violent disputes would often arise between the
15403: fishermen, were there not some written or unwritten, universal,
15404: undisputed law applicable to all cases.
15405: 
15406: Perhaps the only formal whaling code authorized by legislative
15407: enactment, was that of Holland. It was decreed by the States-General in
15408: A.D. 1695. But though no other nation has ever had any written whaling
15409: law, yet the American fishermen have been their own legislators and
15410: lawyers in this matter. They have provided a system which for terse
15411: comprehensiveness surpasses Justinian’s Pandects and the By-laws of the
15412: Chinese Society for the Suppression of Meddling with other People’s
15413: Business. Yes; these laws might be engraven on a Queen Anne’s farthing,
15414: or the barb of a harpoon, and worn round the neck, so small are they.
15415: 
15416: I. A Fast-Fish belongs to the party fast to it.
15417: 
15418: II. A Loose-Fish is fair game for anybody who can soonest catch it.
15419: 
15420: But what plays the mischief with this masterly code is the admirable
15421: brevity of it, which necessitates a vast volume of commentaries to
15422: expound it.
15423: 
15424: First: What is a Fast-Fish? Alive or dead a fish is technically fast,
15425: when it is connected with an occupied ship or boat, by any medium at
15426: all controllable by the occupant or occupants,—a mast, an oar, a
15427: nine-inch cable, a telegraph wire, or a strand of cobweb, it is all the
15428: same. Likewise a fish is technically fast when it bears a waif, or any
15429: other recognised symbol of possession; so long as the party waifing it
15430: plainly evince their ability at any time to take it alongside, as well
15431: as their intention so to do.
15432: 
15433: These are scientific commentaries; but the commentaries of the whalemen
15434: themselves sometimes consist in hard words and harder knocks—the
15435: Coke-upon-Littleton of the fist. True, among the more upright and
15436: honorable whalemen allowances are always made for peculiar cases, where
15437: it would be an outrageous moral injustice for one party to claim
15438: possession of a whale previously chased or killed by another party. But
15439: others are by no means so scrupulous.
15440: 
15441: Some fifty years ago there was a curious case of whale-trover litigated
15442: in England, wherein the plaintiffs set forth that after a hard chase of
15443: a whale in the Northern seas; and when indeed they (the plaintiffs) had
15444: succeeded in harpooning the fish; they were at last, through peril of
15445: their lives, obliged to forsake not only their lines, but their boat
15446: itself. Ultimately the defendants (the crew of another ship) came up
15447: with the whale, struck, killed, seized, and finally appropriated it
15448: before the very eyes of the plaintiffs. And when those defendants were
15449: remonstrated with, their captain snapped his fingers in the plaintiffs’
15450: teeth, and assured them that by way of doxology to the deed he had
15451: done, he would now retain their line, harpoons, and boat, which had
15452: remained attached to the whale at the time of the seizure. Wherefore
15453: the plaintiffs now sued for the recovery of the value of their whale,
15454: line, harpoons, and boat.
15455: 
15456: Mr. Erskine was counsel for the defendants; Lord Ellenborough was the
15457: judge. In the course of the defence, the witty Erskine went on to
15458: illustrate his position, by alluding to a recent crim. con. case,
15459: wherein a gentleman, after in vain trying to bridle his wife’s
15460: viciousness, had at last abandoned her upon the seas of life; but in
15461: the course of years, repenting of that step, he instituted an action to
15462: recover possession of her. Erskine was on the other side; and he then
15463: supported it by saying, that though the gentleman had originally
15464: harpooned the lady, and had once had her fast, and only by reason of
15465: the great stress of her plunging viciousness, had at last abandoned
15466: her; yet abandon her he did, so that she became a loose-fish; and
15467: therefore when a subsequent gentleman re-harpooned her, the lady then
15468: became that subsequent gentleman’s property, along with whatever
15469: harpoon might have been found sticking in her.
15470: 
15471: Now in the present case Erskine contended that the examples of the
15472: whale and the lady were reciprocally illustrative of each other.
15473: 
15474: These pleadings, and the counter pleadings, being duly heard, the very
15475: learned judge in set terms decided, to wit,—That as for the boat, he
15476: awarded it to the plaintiffs, because they had merely abandoned it to
15477: save their lives; but that with regard to the controverted whale,
15478: harpoons, and line, they belonged to the defendants; the whale, because
15479: it was a Loose-Fish at the time of the final capture; and the harpoons
15480: and line because when the fish made off with them, it (the fish)
15481: acquired a property in those articles; and hence anybody who afterwards
15482: took the fish had a right to them. Now the defendants afterwards took
15483: the fish; ergo, the aforesaid articles were theirs.
15484: 
15485: A common man looking at this decision of the very learned Judge, might
15486: possibly object to it. But ploughed up to the primary rock of the
15487: matter, the two great principles laid down in the twin whaling laws
15488: previously quoted, and applied and elucidated by Lord Ellenborough in
15489: the above cited case; these two laws touching Fast-Fish and Loose-Fish,
15490: I say, will, on reflection, be found the fundamentals of all human
15491: jurisprudence; for notwithstanding its complicated tracery of
15492: sculpture, the Temple of the Law, like the Temple of the Philistines,
15493: has but two props to stand on.
15494: 
15495: Is it not a saying in every one’s mouth, Possession is half of the law:
15496: that is, regardless of how the thing came into possession? But often
15497: possession is the whole of the law. What are the sinews and souls of
15498: Russian serfs and Republican slaves but Fast-Fish, whereof possession
15499: is the whole of the law? What to the rapacious landlord is the widow’s
15500: last mite but a Fast-Fish? What is yonder undetected villain’s marble
15501: mansion with a door-plate for a waif; what is that but a Fast-Fish?
15502: What is the ruinous discount which Mordecai, the broker, gets from poor
15503: Woebegone, the bankrupt, on a loan to keep Woebegone’s family from
15504: starvation; what is that ruinous discount but a Fast-Fish? What is the
15505: Archbishop of Savesoul’s income of £100,000 seized from the scant bread
15506: and cheese of hundreds of thousands of broken-backed laborers (all sure
15507: of heaven without any of Savesoul’s help) what is that globular
15508: £100,000 but a Fast-Fish? What are the Duke of Dunder’s hereditary
15509: towns and hamlets but Fast-Fish? What to that redoubted harpooneer,
15510: John Bull, is poor Ireland, but a Fast-Fish? What to that apostolic
15511: lancer, Brother Jonathan, is Texas but a Fast-Fish? And concerning all
15512: these, is not Possession the whole of the law?
15513: 
15514: But if the doctrine of Fast-Fish be pretty generally applicable, the
15515: kindred doctrine of Loose-Fish is still more widely so. That is
15516: internationally and universally applicable.
15517: 
15518: What was America in 1492 but a Loose-Fish, in which Columbus struck the
15519: Spanish standard by way of waifing it for his royal master and
15520: mistress? What was Poland to the Czar? What Greece to the Turk? What
15521: India to England? What at last will Mexico be to the United States? All
15522: Loose-Fish.
15523: 
15524: What are the Rights of Man and the Liberties of the World but
15525: Loose-Fish? What all men’s minds and opinions but Loose-Fish? What is
15526: the principle of religious belief in them but a Loose-Fish? What to the
15527: ostentatious smuggling verbalists are the thoughts of thinkers but
15528: Loose-Fish? What is the great globe itself but a Loose-Fish? And what
15529: are you, reader, but a Loose-Fish and a Fast-Fish, too?
15530: 
15531: 
15532: CHAPTER 90. Heads or Tails.
15533: 
15534: “De balena vero sufficit, si rex habeat caput, et regina caudam.”
15535: _Bracton, l. 3, c. 3._
15536: 
15537: Latin from the books of the Laws of England, which taken along with the
15538: context, means, that of all whales captured by anybody on the coast of
15539: that land, the King, as Honorary Grand Harpooneer, must have the head,
15540: and the Queen be respectfully presented with the tail. A division
15541: which, in the whale, is much like halving an apple; there is no
15542: intermediate remainder. Now as this law, under a modified form, is to
15543: this day in force in England; and as it offers in various respects a
15544: strange anomaly touching the general law of Fast and Loose-Fish, it is
15545: here treated of in a separate chapter, on the same courteous principle
15546: that prompts the English railways to be at the expense of a separate
15547: car, specially reserved for the accommodation of royalty. In the first
15548: place, in curious proof of the fact that the above-mentioned law is
15549: still in force, I proceed to lay before you a circumstance that
15550: happened within the last two years.
15551: 
15552: It seems that some honest mariners of Dover, or Sandwich, or some one
15553: of the Cinque Ports, had after a hard chase succeeded in killing and
15554: beaching a fine whale which they had originally descried afar off from
15555: the shore. Now the Cinque Ports are partially or somehow under the
15556: jurisdiction of a sort of policeman or beadle, called a Lord Warden.
15557: Holding the office directly from the crown, I believe, all the royal
15558: emoluments incident to the Cinque Port territories become by assignment
15559: his. By some writers this office is called a sinecure. But not so.
15560: Because the Lord Warden is busily employed at times in fobbing his
15561: perquisites; which are his chiefly by virtue of that same fobbing of
15562: them.
15563: 
15564: Now when these poor sun-burnt mariners, bare-footed, and with their
15565: trowsers rolled high up on their eely legs, had wearily hauled their
15566: fat fish high and dry, promising themselves a good £150 from the
15567: precious oil and bone; and in fantasy sipping rare tea with their
15568: wives, and good ale with their cronies, upon the strength of their
15569: respective shares; up steps a very learned and most Christian and
15570: charitable gentleman, with a copy of Blackstone under his arm; and
15571: laying it upon the whale’s head, he says—“Hands off! this fish, my
15572: masters, is a Fast-Fish. I seize it as the Lord Warden’s.” Upon this
15573: the poor mariners in their respectful consternation—so truly
15574: English—knowing not what to say, fall to vigorously scratching their
15575: heads all round; meanwhile ruefully glancing from the whale to the
15576: stranger. But that did in nowise mend the matter, or at all soften the
15577: hard heart of the learned gentleman with the copy of Blackstone. At
15578: length one of them, after long scratching about for his ideas, made
15579: bold to speak,
15580: 
15581: “Please, sir, who is the Lord Warden?”
15582: 
15583: “The Duke.”
15584: 
15585: “But the duke had nothing to do with taking this fish?”
15586: 
15587: “It is his.”
15588: 
15589: “We have been at great trouble, and peril, and some expense, and is all
15590: that to go to the Duke’s benefit; we getting nothing at all for our
15591: pains but our blisters?”
15592: 
15593: “It is his.”
15594: 
15595: “Is the Duke so very poor as to be forced to this desperate mode of
15596: getting a livelihood?”
15597: 
15598: “It is his.”
15599: 
15600: “I thought to relieve my old bed-ridden mother by part of my share of
15601: this whale.”
15602: 
15603: “It is his.”
15604: 
15605: “Won’t the Duke be content with a quarter or a half?”
15606: 
15607: “It is his.”
15608: 
15609: In a word, the whale was seized and sold, and his Grace the Duke of
15610: Wellington received the money. Thinking that viewed in some particular
15611: lights, the case might by a bare possibility in some small degree be
15612: deemed, under the circumstances, a rather hard one, an honest clergyman
15613: of the town respectfully addressed a note to his Grace, begging him to
15614: take the case of those unfortunate mariners into full consideration. To
15615: which my Lord Duke in substance replied (both letters were published)
15616: that he had already done so, and received the money, and would be
15617: obliged to the reverend gentleman if for the future he (the reverend
15618: gentleman) would decline meddling with other people’s business. Is this
15619: the still militant old man, standing at the corners of the three
15620: kingdoms, on all hands coercing alms of beggars?
15621: 
15622: It will readily be seen that in this case the alleged right of the Duke
15623: to the whale was a delegated one from the Sovereign. We must needs
15624: inquire then on what principle the Sovereign is originally invested
15625: with that right. The law itself has already been set forth. But Plowdon
15626: gives us the reason for it. Says Plowdon, the whale so caught belongs
15627: to the King and Queen, “because of its superior excellence.” And by the
15628: soundest commentators this has ever been held a cogent argument in such
15629: matters.
15630: 
15631: But why should the King have the head, and the Queen the tail? A reason
15632: for that, ye lawyers!
15633: 
15634: In his treatise on “Queen-Gold,” or Queen-pinmoney, an old King’s Bench
15635: author, one William Prynne, thus discourseth: “Ye tail is ye Queen’s,
15636: that ye Queen’s wardrobe may be supplied with ye whalebone.” Now this
15637: was written at a time when the black limber bone of the Greenland or
15638: Right whale was largely used in ladies’ bodices. But this same bone is
15639: not in the tail; it is in the head, which is a sad mistake for a
15640: sagacious lawyer like Prynne. But is the Queen a mermaid, to be
15641: presented with a tail? An allegorical meaning may lurk here.
15642: 
15643: There are two royal fish so styled by the English law writers—the whale
15644: and the sturgeon; both royal property under certain limitations, and
15645: nominally supplying the tenth branch of the crown’s ordinary revenue. I
15646: know not that any other author has hinted of the matter; but by
15647: inference it seems to me that the sturgeon must be divided in the same
15648: way as the whale, the King receiving the highly dense and elastic head
15649: peculiar to that fish, which, symbolically regarded, may possibly be
15650: humorously grounded upon some presumed congeniality. And thus there
15651: seems a reason in all things, even in law.
15652: 
15653: 
15654: CHAPTER 91. The Pequod Meets The Rose-Bud.
15655: 
15656: “In vain it was to rake for Ambergriese in the paunch of this
15657: Leviathan, insufferable fetor denying not inquiry.” _Sir T. Browne,
15658: V.E._
15659: 
15660: It was a week or two after the last whaling scene recounted, and when
15661: we were slowly sailing over a sleepy, vapory, mid-day sea, that the
15662: many noses on the Pequod’s deck proved more vigilant discoverers than
15663: the three pairs of eyes aloft. A peculiar and not very pleasant smell
15664: was smelt in the sea.
15665: 
15666: “I will bet something now,” said Stubb, “that somewhere hereabouts are
15667: some of those drugged whales we tickled the other day. I thought they
15668: would keel up before long.”
15669: 
15670: Presently, the vapors in advance slid aside; and there in the distance
15671: lay a ship, whose furled sails betokened that some sort of whale must
15672: be alongside. As we glided nearer, the stranger showed French colours
15673: from his peak; and by the eddying cloud of vulture sea-fowl that
15674: circled, and hovered, and swooped around him, it was plain that the
15675: whale alongside must be what the fishermen call a blasted whale, that
15676: is, a whale that has died unmolested on the sea, and so floated an
15677: unappropriated corpse. It may well be conceived, what an unsavory odor
15678: such a mass must exhale; worse than an Assyrian city in the plague,
15679: when the living are incompetent to bury the departed. So intolerable
15680: indeed is it regarded by some, that no cupidity could persuade them to
15681: moor alongside of it. Yet are there those who will still do it;
15682: notwithstanding the fact that the oil obtained from such subjects is of
15683: a very inferior quality, and by no means of the nature of
15684: attar-of-rose.
15685: 
15686: Coming still nearer with the expiring breeze, we saw that the Frenchman
15687: had a second whale alongside; and this second whale seemed even more of
15688: a nosegay than the first. In truth, it turned out to be one of those
15689: problematical whales that seem to dry up and die with a sort of
15690: prodigious dyspepsia, or indigestion; leaving their defunct bodies
15691: almost entirely bankrupt of anything like oil. Nevertheless, in the
15692: proper place we shall see that no knowing fisherman will ever turn up
15693: his nose at such a whale as this, however much he may shun blasted
15694: whales in general.
15695: 
15696: The Pequod had now swept so nigh to the stranger, that Stubb vowed he
15697: recognised his cutting spade-pole entangled in the lines that were
15698: knotted round the tail of one of these whales.
15699: 
15700: “There’s a pretty fellow, now,” he banteringly laughed, standing in the
15701: ship’s bows, “there’s a jackal for ye! I well know that these Crappoes
15702: of Frenchmen are but poor devils in the fishery; sometimes lowering
15703: their boats for breakers, mistaking them for Sperm Whale spouts; yes,
15704: and sometimes sailing from their port with their hold full of boxes of
15705: tallow candles, and cases of snuffers, foreseeing that all the oil they
15706: will get won’t be enough to dip the Captain’s wick into; aye, we all
15707: know these things; but look ye, here’s a Crappo that is content with
15708: our leavings, the drugged whale there, I mean; aye, and is content too
15709: with scraping the dry bones of that other precious fish he has there.
15710: Poor devil! I say, pass round a hat, some one, and let’s make him a
15711: present of a little oil for dear charity’s sake. For what oil he’ll get
15712: from that drugged whale there, wouldn’t be fit to burn in a jail; no,
15713: not in a condemned cell. And as for the other whale, why, I’ll agree to
15714: get more oil by chopping up and trying out these three masts of ours,
15715: than he’ll get from that bundle of bones; though, now that I think of
15716: it, it may contain something worth a good deal more than oil; yes,
15717: ambergris. I wonder now if our old man has thought of that. It’s worth
15718: trying. Yes, I’m for it;” and so saying he started for the
15719: quarter-deck.
15720: 
15721: By this time the faint air had become a complete calm; so that whether
15722: or no, the Pequod was now fairly entrapped in the smell, with no hope
15723: of escaping except by its breezing up again. Issuing from the cabin,
15724: Stubb now called his boat’s crew, and pulled off for the stranger.
15725: Drawing across her bow, he perceived that in accordance with the
15726: fanciful French taste, the upper part of her stem-piece was carved in
15727: the likeness of a huge drooping stalk, was painted green, and for
15728: thorns had copper spikes projecting from it here and there; the whole
15729: terminating in a symmetrical folded bulb of a bright red colour. Upon
15730: her head boards, in large gilt letters, he read “Bouton de
15731: Rose,”—Rose-button, or Rose-bud; and this was the romantic name of this
15732: aromatic ship.
15733: 
15734: Though Stubb did not understand the _Bouton_ part of the inscription,
15735: yet the word _rose_, and the bulbous figure-head put together,
15736: sufficiently explained the whole to him.
15737: 
15738: “A wooden rose-bud, eh?” he cried with his hand to his nose, “that will
15739: do very well; but how like all creation it smells!”
15740: 
15741: Now in order to hold direct communication with the people on deck, he
15742: had to pull round the bows to the starboard side, and thus come close
15743: to the blasted whale; and so talk over it.
15744: 
15745: Arrived then at this spot, with one hand still to his nose, he
15746: bawled—“Bouton-de-Rose, ahoy! are there any of you Bouton-de-Roses that
15747: speak English?”
15748: 
15749: “Yes,” rejoined a Guernsey-man from the bulwarks, who turned out to be
15750: the chief-mate.
15751: 
15752: “Well, then, my Bouton-de-Rose-bud, have you seen the White Whale?”
15753: 
15754: “_What_ whale?”
15755: 
15756: “The _White_ Whale—a Sperm Whale—Moby Dick, have ye seen him?
15757: 
15758: “Never heard of such a whale. Cachalot Blanche! White Whale—no.”
15759: 
15760: “Very good, then; good bye now, and I’ll call again in a minute.”
15761: 
15762: Then rapidly pulling back towards the Pequod, and seeing Ahab leaning
15763: over the quarter-deck rail awaiting his report, he moulded his two
15764: hands into a trumpet and shouted—“No, Sir! No!” Upon which Ahab
15765: retired, and Stubb returned to the Frenchman.
15766: 
15767: He now perceived that the Guernsey-man, who had just got into the
15768: chains, and was using a cutting-spade, had slung his nose in a sort of
15769: bag.
15770: 
15771: “What’s the matter with your nose, there?” said Stubb. “Broke it?”
15772: 
15773: “I wish it was broken, or that I didn’t have any nose at all!” answered
15774: the Guernsey-man, who did not seem to relish the job he was at very
15775: much. “But what are you holding _yours_ for?”
15776: 
15777: “Oh, nothing! It’s a wax nose; I have to hold it on. Fine day, ain’t
15778: it? Air rather gardenny, I should say; throw us a bunch of posies, will
15779: ye, Bouton-de-Rose?”
15780: 
15781: “What in the devil’s name do you want here?” roared the Guernseyman,
15782: flying into a sudden passion.
15783: 
15784: “Oh! keep cool—cool? yes, that’s the word! why don’t you pack those
15785: whales in ice while you’re working at ’em? But joking aside, though; do
15786: you know, Rose-bud, that it’s all nonsense trying to get any oil out of
15787: such whales? As for that dried up one, there, he hasn’t a gill in his
15788: whole carcase.”
15789: 
15790: “I know that well enough; but, d’ye see, the Captain here won’t believe
15791: it; this is his first voyage; he was a Cologne manufacturer before. But
15792: come aboard, and mayhap he’ll believe you, if he won’t me; and so I’ll
15793: get out of this dirty scrape.”
15794: 
15795: “Anything to oblige ye, my sweet and pleasant fellow,” rejoined Stubb,
15796: and with that he soon mounted to the deck. There a queer scene
15797: presented itself. The sailors, in tasselled caps of red worsted, were
15798: getting the heavy tackles in readiness for the whales. But they worked
15799: rather slow and talked very fast, and seemed in anything but a good
15800: humor. All their noses upwardly projected from their faces like so many
15801: jib-booms. Now and then pairs of them would drop their work, and run up
15802: to the mast-head to get some fresh air. Some thinking they would catch
15803: the plague, dipped oakum in coal-tar, and at intervals held it to their
15804: nostrils. Others having broken the stems of their pipes almost short
15805: off at the bowl, were vigorously puffing tobacco-smoke, so that it
15806: constantly filled their olfactories.
15807: 
15808: Stubb was struck by a shower of outcries and anathemas proceeding from
15809: the Captain’s round-house abaft; and looking in that direction saw a
15810: fiery face thrust from behind the door, which was held ajar from
15811: within. This was the tormented surgeon, who, after in vain
15812: remonstrating against the proceedings of the day, had betaken himself
15813: to the Captain’s round-house (_cabinet_ he called it) to avoid the
15814: pest; but still, could not help yelling out his entreaties and
15815: indignations at times.
15816: 
15817: Marking all this, Stubb argued well for his scheme, and turning to the
15818: Guernsey-man had a little chat with him, during which the stranger mate
15819: expressed his detestation of his Captain as a conceited ignoramus, who
15820: had brought them all into so unsavory and unprofitable a pickle.
15821: Sounding him carefully, Stubb further perceived that the Guernsey-man
15822: had not the slightest suspicion concerning the ambergris. He therefore
15823: held his peace on that head, but otherwise was quite frank and
15824: confidential with him, so that the two quickly concocted a little plan
15825: for both circumventing and satirizing the Captain, without his at all
15826: dreaming of distrusting their sincerity. According to this little plan
15827: of theirs, the Guernsey-man, under cover of an interpreter’s office,
15828: was to tell the Captain what he pleased, but as coming from Stubb; and
15829: as for Stubb, he was to utter any nonsense that should come uppermost
15830: in him during the interview.
15831: 
15832: By this time their destined victim appeared from his cabin. He was a
15833: small and dark, but rather delicate looking man for a sea-captain, with
15834: large whiskers and moustache, however; and wore a red cotton velvet
15835: vest with watch-seals at his side. To this gentleman, Stubb was now
15836: politely introduced by the Guernsey-man, who at once ostentatiously put
15837: on the aspect of interpreting between them.
15838: 
15839: “What shall I say to him first?” said he.
15840: 
15841: “Why,” said Stubb, eyeing the velvet vest and the watch and seals, “you
15842: may as well begin by telling him that he looks a sort of babyish to me,
15843: though I don’t pretend to be a judge.”
15844: 
15845: “He says, Monsieur,” said the Guernsey-man, in French, turning to his
15846: captain, “that only yesterday his ship spoke a vessel, whose captain
15847: and chief-mate, with six sailors, had all died of a fever caught from a
15848: blasted whale they had brought alongside.”
15849: 
15850: Upon this the captain started, and eagerly desired to know more.
15851: 
15852: “What now?” said the Guernsey-man to Stubb.
15853: 
15854: “Why, since he takes it so easy, tell him that now I have eyed him
15855: carefully, I’m quite certain that he’s no more fit to command a
15856: whale-ship than a St. Jago monkey. In fact, tell him from me he’s a
15857: baboon.”
15858: 
15859: “He vows and declares, Monsieur, that the other whale, the dried one,
15860: is far more deadly than the blasted one; in fine, Monsieur, he conjures
15861: us, as we value our lives, to cut loose from these fish.”
15862: 
15863: Instantly the captain ran forward, and in a loud voice commanded his
15864: crew to desist from hoisting the cutting-tackles, and at once cast
15865: loose the cables and chains confining the whales to the ship.
15866: 
15867: “What now?” said the Guernsey-man, when the Captain had returned to
15868: them.
15869: 
15870: “Why, let me see; yes, you may as well tell him now that—that—in fact,
15871: tell him I’ve diddled him, and (aside to himself) perhaps somebody
15872: else.”
15873: 
15874: “He says, Monsieur, that he’s very happy to have been of any service to
15875: us.”
15876: 
15877: Hearing this, the captain vowed that they were the grateful parties
15878: (meaning himself and mate) and concluded by inviting Stubb down into
15879: his cabin to drink a bottle of Bordeaux.
15880: 
15881: “He wants you to take a glass of wine with him,” said the interpreter.
15882: 
15883: “Thank him heartily; but tell him it’s against my principles to drink
15884: with the man I’ve diddled. In fact, tell him I must go.”
15885: 
15886: “He says, Monsieur, that his principles won’t admit of his drinking;
15887: but that if Monsieur wants to live another day to drink, then Monsieur
15888: had best drop all four boats, and pull the ship away from these whales,
15889: for it’s so calm they won’t drift.”
15890: 
15891: By this time Stubb was over the side, and getting into his boat, hailed
15892: the Guernsey-man to this effect,—that having a long tow-line in his
15893: boat, he would do what he could to help them, by pulling out the
15894: lighter whale of the two from the ship’s side. While the Frenchman’s
15895: boats, then, were engaged in towing the ship one way, Stubb
15896: benevolently towed away at his whale the other way, ostentatiously
15897: slacking out a most unusually long tow-line.
15898: 
15899: Presently a breeze sprang up; Stubb feigned to cast off from the whale;
15900: hoisting his boats, the Frenchman soon increased his distance, while
15901: the Pequod slid in between him and Stubb’s whale. Whereupon Stubb
15902: quickly pulled to the floating body, and hailing the Pequod to give
15903: notice of his intentions, at once proceeded to reap the fruit of his
15904: unrighteous cunning. Seizing his sharp boat-spade, he commenced an
15905: excavation in the body, a little behind the side fin. You would almost
15906: have thought he was digging a cellar there in the sea; and when at
15907: length his spade struck against the gaunt ribs, it was like turning up
15908: old Roman tiles and pottery buried in fat English loam. His boat’s crew
15909: were all in high excitement, eagerly helping their chief, and looking
15910: as anxious as gold-hunters.
15911: 
15912: And all the time numberless fowls were diving, and ducking, and
15913: screaming, and yelling, and fighting around them. Stubb was beginning
15914: to look disappointed, especially as the horrible nosegay increased,
15915: when suddenly from out the very heart of this plague, there stole a
15916: faint stream of perfume, which flowed through the tide of bad smells
15917: without being absorbed by it, as one river will flow into and then
15918: along with another, without at all blending with it for a time.
15919: 
15920: “I have it, I have it,” cried Stubb, with delight, striking something
15921: in the subterranean regions, “a purse! a purse!”
15922: 
15923: Dropping his spade, he thrust both hands in, and drew out handfuls of
15924: something that looked like ripe Windsor soap, or rich mottled old
15925: cheese; very unctuous and savory withal. You might easily dent it with
15926: your thumb; it is of a hue between yellow and ash colour. And this,
15927: good friends, is ambergris, worth a gold guinea an ounce to any
15928: druggist. Some six handfuls were obtained; but more was unavoidably
15929: lost in the sea, and still more, perhaps, might have been secured were
15930: it not for impatient Ahab’s loud command to Stubb to desist, and come
15931: on board, else the ship would bid them good bye.
15932: 
15933: 
15934: CHAPTER 92. Ambergris.
15935: 
15936: Now this ambergris is a very curious substance, and so important as an
15937: article of commerce, that in 1791 a certain Nantucket-born Captain
15938: Coffin was examined at the bar of the English House of Commons on that
15939: subject. For at that time, and indeed until a comparatively late day,
15940: the precise origin of ambergris remained, like amber itself, a problem
15941: to the learned. Though the word ambergris is but the French compound
15942: for grey amber, yet the two substances are quite distinct. For amber,
15943: though at times found on the sea-coast, is also dug up in some far
15944: inland soils, whereas ambergris is never found except upon the sea.
15945: Besides, amber is a hard, transparent, brittle, odorless substance,
15946: used for mouth-pieces to pipes, for beads and ornaments; but ambergris
15947: is soft, waxy, and so highly fragrant and spicy, that it is largely
15948: used in perfumery, in pastiles, precious candles, hair-powders, and
15949: pomatum. The Turks use it in cooking, and also carry it to Mecca, for
15950: the same purpose that frankincense is carried to St. Peter’s in Rome.
15951: Some wine merchants drop a few grains into claret, to flavor it.
15952: 
15953: Who would think, then, that such fine ladies and gentlemen should
15954: regale themselves with an essence found in the inglorious bowels of a
15955: sick whale! Yet so it is. By some, ambergris is supposed to be the
15956: cause, and by others the effect, of the dyspepsia in the whale. How to
15957: cure such a dyspepsia it were hard to say, unless by administering
15958: three or four boat loads of Brandreth’s pills, and then running out of
15959: harm’s way, as laborers do in blasting rocks.
15960: 
15961: I have forgotten to say that there were found in this ambergris,
15962: certain hard, round, bony plates, which at first Stubb thought might be
15963: sailors’ trowsers buttons; but it afterwards turned out that they were
15964: nothing more than pieces of small squid bones embalmed in that manner.
15965: 
15966: Now that the incorruption of this most fragrant ambergris should be
15967: found in the heart of such decay; is this nothing? Bethink thee of that
15968: saying of St. Paul in Corinthians, about corruption and incorruption;
15969: how that we are sown in dishonor, but raised in glory. And likewise
15970: call to mind that saying of Paracelsus about what it is that maketh the
15971: best musk. Also forget not the strange fact that of all things of
15972: ill-savor, Cologne-water, in its rudimental manufacturing stages, is
15973: the worst.
15974: 
15975: I should like to conclude the chapter with the above appeal, but
15976: cannot, owing to my anxiety to repel a charge often made against
15977: whalemen, and which, in the estimation of some already biased minds,
15978: might be considered as indirectly substantiated by what has been said
15979: of the Frenchman’s two whales. Elsewhere in this volume the slanderous
15980: aspersion has been disproved, that the vocation of whaling is
15981: throughout a slatternly, untidy business. But there is another thing to
15982: rebut. They hint that all whales always smell bad. Now how did this
15983: odious stigma originate?
15984: 
15985: I opine, that it is plainly traceable to the first arrival of the
15986: Greenland whaling ships in London, more than two centuries ago. Because
15987: those whalemen did not then, and do not now, try out their oil at sea
15988: as the Southern ships have always done; but cutting up the fresh
15989: blubber in small bits, thrust it through the bung holes of large casks,
15990: and carry it home in that manner; the shortness of the season in those
15991: Icy Seas, and the sudden and violent storms to which they are exposed,
15992: forbidding any other course. The consequence is, that upon breaking
15993: into the hold, and unloading one of these whale cemeteries, in the
15994: Greenland dock, a savor is given forth somewhat similar to that arising
15995: from excavating an old city grave-yard, for the foundations of a
15996: Lying-in Hospital.
15997: 
15998: I partly surmise also, that this wicked charge against whalers may be
15999: likewise imputed to the existence on the coast of Greenland, in former
16000: times, of a Dutch village called Schmerenburgh or Smeerenberg, which
16001: latter name is the one used by the learned Fogo Von Slack, in his great
16002: work on Smells, a text-book on that subject. As its name imports
16003: (smeer, fat; berg, to put up), this village was founded in order to
16004: afford a place for the blubber of the Dutch whale fleet to be tried
16005: out, without being taken home to Holland for that purpose. It was a
16006: collection of furnaces, fat-kettles, and oil sheds; and when the works
16007: were in full operation certainly gave forth no very pleasant savor. But
16008: all this is quite different with a South Sea Sperm Whaler; which in a
16009: voyage of four years perhaps, after completely filling her hold with
16010: oil, does not, perhaps, consume fifty days in the business of boiling
16011: out; and in the state that it is casked, the oil is nearly scentless.
16012: The truth is, that living or dead, if but decently treated, whales as a
16013: species are by no means creatures of ill odor; nor can whalemen be
16014: recognised, as the people of the middle ages affected to detect a Jew
16015: in the company, by the nose. Nor indeed can the whale possibly be
16016: otherwise than fragrant, when, as a general thing, he enjoys such high
16017: health; taking abundance of exercise; always out of doors; though, it
16018: is true, seldom in the open air. I say, that the motion of a Sperm
16019: Whale’s flukes above water dispenses a perfume, as when a musk-scented
16020: lady rustles her dress in a warm parlor. What then shall I liken the
16021: Sperm Whale to for fragrance, considering his magnitude? Must it not be
16022: to that famous elephant, with jewelled tusks, and redolent with myrrh,
16023: which was led out of an Indian town to do honor to Alexander the Great?
16024: 
16025: 
16026: CHAPTER 93. The Castaway.
16027: 
16028: It was but some few days after encountering the Frenchman, that a most
16029: significant event befell the most insignificant of the Pequod’s crew;
16030: an event most lamentable; and which ended in providing the sometimes
16031: madly merry and predestinated craft with a living and ever accompanying
16032: prophecy of whatever shattered sequel might prove her own.
16033: 
16034: Now, in the whale ship, it is not every one that goes in the boats.
16035: Some few hands are reserved called ship-keepers, whose province it is
16036: to work the vessel while the boats are pursuing the whale. As a general
16037: thing, these ship-keepers are as hardy fellows as the men comprising
16038: the boats’ crews. But if there happen to be an unduly slender, clumsy,
16039: or timorous wight in the ship, that wight is certain to be made a
16040: ship-keeper. It was so in the Pequod with the little negro Pippin by
16041: nick-name, Pip by abbreviation. Poor Pip! ye have heard of him before;
16042: ye must remember his tambourine on that dramatic midnight, so
16043: gloomy-jolly.
16044: 
16045: In outer aspect, Pip and Dough-Boy made a match, like a black pony and
16046: a white one, of equal developments, though of dissimilar colour, driven
16047: in one eccentric span. But while hapless Dough-Boy was by nature dull
16048: and torpid in his intellects, Pip, though over tender-hearted, was at
16049: bottom very bright, with that pleasant, genial, jolly brightness
16050: peculiar to his tribe; a tribe, which ever enjoy all holidays and
16051: festivities with finer, freer relish than any other race. For blacks,
16052: the year’s calendar should show naught but three hundred and sixty-five
16053: Fourth of Julys and New Year’s Days. Nor smile so, while I write that
16054: this little black was brilliant, for even blackness has its brilliancy;
16055: behold yon lustrous ebony, panelled in king’s cabinets. But Pip loved
16056: life, and all life’s peaceable securities; so that the panic-striking
16057: business in which he had somehow unaccountably become entrapped, had
16058: most sadly blurred his brightness; though, as ere long will be seen,
16059: what was thus temporarily subdued in him, in the end was destined to be
16060: luridly illumined by strange wild fires, that fictitiously showed him
16061: off to ten times the natural lustre with which in his native Tolland
16062: County in Connecticut, he had once enlivened many a fiddler’s frolic on
16063: the green; and at melodious even-tide, with his gay ha-ha! had turned
16064: the round horizon into one star-belled tambourine. So, though in the
16065: clear air of day, suspended against a blue-veined neck, the
16066: pure-watered diamond drop will healthful glow; yet, when the cunning
16067: jeweller would show you the diamond in its most impressive lustre, he
16068: lays it against a gloomy ground, and then lights it up, not by the sun,
16069: but by some unnatural gases. Then come out those fiery effulgences,
16070: infernally superb; then the evil-blazing diamond, once the divinest
16071: symbol of the crystal skies, looks like some crown-jewel stolen from
16072: the King of Hell. But let us to the story.
16073: 
16074: It came to pass, that in the ambergris affair Stubb’s after-oarsman
16075: chanced so to sprain his hand, as for a time to become quite maimed;
16076: and, temporarily, Pip was put into his place.
16077: 
16078: The first time Stubb lowered with him, Pip evinced much nervousness;
16079: but happily, for that time, escaped close contact with the whale; and
16080: therefore came off not altogether discreditably; though Stubb observing
16081: him, took care, afterwards, to exhort him to cherish his courageousness
16082: to the utmost, for he might often find it needful.
16083: 
16084: Now upon the second lowering, the boat paddled upon the whale; and as
16085: the fish received the darted iron, it gave its customary rap, which
16086: happened, in this instance, to be right under poor Pip’s seat. The
16087: involuntary consternation of the moment caused him to leap, paddle in
16088: hand, out of the boat; and in such a way, that part of the slack whale
16089: line coming against his chest, he breasted it overboard with him, so as
16090: to become entangled in it, when at last plumping into the water. That
16091: instant the stricken whale started on a fierce run, the line swiftly
16092: straightened; and presto! poor Pip came all foaming up to the chocks of
16093: the boat, remorselessly dragged there by the line, which had taken
16094: several turns around his chest and neck.
16095: 
16096: Tashtego stood in the bows. He was full of the fire of the hunt. He
16097: hated Pip for a poltroon. Snatching the boat-knife from its sheath, he
16098: suspended its sharp edge over the line, and turning towards Stubb,
16099: exclaimed interrogatively, “Cut?” Meantime Pip’s blue, choked face
16100: plainly looked, Do, for God’s sake! All passed in a flash. In less than
16101: half a minute, this entire thing happened.
16102: 
16103: “Damn him, cut!” roared Stubb; and so the whale was lost and Pip was
16104: saved.
16105: 
16106: So soon as he recovered himself, the poor little negro was assailed by
16107: yells and execrations from the crew. Tranquilly permitting these
16108: irregular cursings to evaporate, Stubb then in a plain, business-like,
16109: but still half humorous manner, cursed Pip officially; and that done,
16110: unofficially gave him much wholesome advice. The substance was, Never
16111: jump from a boat, Pip, except—but all the rest was indefinite, as the
16112: soundest advice ever is. Now, in general, _Stick to the boat_, is your
16113: true motto in whaling; but cases will sometimes happen when _Leap from
16114: the boat_, is still better. Moreover, as if perceiving at last that if
16115: he should give undiluted conscientious advice to Pip, he would be
16116: leaving him too wide a margin to jump in for the future; Stubb suddenly
16117: dropped all advice, and concluded with a peremptory command, “Stick to
16118: the boat, Pip, or by the Lord, I won’t pick you up if you jump; mind
16119: that. We can’t afford to lose whales by the likes of you; a whale would
16120: sell for thirty times what you would, Pip, in Alabama. Bear that in
16121: mind, and don’t jump any more.” Hereby perhaps Stubb indirectly hinted,
16122: that though man loved his fellow, yet man is a money-making animal,
16123: which propensity too often interferes with his benevolence.
16124: 
16125: But we are all in the hands of the Gods; and Pip jumped again. It was
16126: under very similar circumstances to the first performance; but this
16127: time he did not breast out the line; and hence, when the whale started
16128: to run, Pip was left behind on the sea, like a hurried traveller’s
16129: trunk. Alas! Stubb was but too true to his word. It was a beautiful,
16130: bounteous, blue day; the spangled sea calm and cool, and flatly
16131: stretching away, all round, to the horizon, like gold-beater’s skin
16132: hammered out to the extremest. Bobbing up and down in that sea, Pip’s
16133: ebon head showed like a head of cloves. No boat-knife was lifted when
16134: he fell so rapidly astern. Stubb’s inexorable back was turned upon him;
16135: and the whale was winged. In three minutes, a whole mile of shoreless
16136: ocean was between Pip and Stubb. Out from the centre of the sea, poor
16137: Pip turned his crisp, curling, black head to the sun, another lonely
16138: castaway, though the loftiest and the brightest.
16139: 
16140: Now, in calm weather, to swim in the open ocean is as easy to the
16141: practised swimmer as to ride in a spring-carriage ashore. But the awful
16142: lonesomeness is intolerable. The intense concentration of self in the
16143: middle of such a heartless immensity, my God! who can tell it? Mark,
16144: how when sailors in a dead calm bathe in the open sea—mark how closely
16145: they hug their ship and only coast along her sides.
16146: 
16147: But had Stubb really abandoned the poor little negro to his fate? No;
16148: he did not mean to, at least. Because there were two boats in his wake,
16149: and he supposed, no doubt, that they would of course come up to Pip
16150: very quickly, and pick him up; though, indeed, such considerations
16151: towards oarsmen jeopardized through their own timidity, is not always
16152: manifested by the hunters in all similar instances; and such instances
16153: not unfrequently occur; almost invariably in the fishery, a coward, so
16154: called, is marked with the same ruthless detestation peculiar to
16155: military navies and armies.
16156: 
16157: But it so happened, that those boats, without seeing Pip, suddenly
16158: spying whales close to them on one side, turned, and gave chase; and
16159: Stubb’s boat was now so far away, and he and all his crew so intent
16160: upon his fish, that Pip’s ringed horizon began to expand around him
16161: miserably. By the merest chance the ship itself at last rescued him;
16162: but from that hour the little negro went about the deck an idiot; such,
16163: at least, they said he was. The sea had jeeringly kept his finite body
16164: up, but drowned the infinite of his soul. Not drowned entirely, though.
16165: Rather carried down alive to wondrous depths, where strange shapes of
16166: the unwarped primal world glided to and fro before his passive eyes;
16167: and the miser-merman, Wisdom, revealed his hoarded heaps; and among the
16168: joyous, heartless, ever-juvenile eternities, Pip saw the multitudinous,
16169: God-omnipresent, coral insects, that out of the firmament of waters
16170: heaved the colossal orbs. He saw God’s foot upon the treadle of the
16171: loom, and spoke it; and therefore his shipmates called him mad. So
16172: man’s insanity is heaven’s sense; and wandering from all mortal reason,
16173: man comes at last to that celestial thought, which, to reason, is
16174: absurd and frantic; and weal or woe, feels then uncompromised,
16175: indifferent as his God.
16176: 
16177: For the rest, blame not Stubb too hardly. The thing is common in that
16178: fishery; and in the sequel of the narrative, it will then be seen what
16179: like abandonment befell myself.
16180: 
16181: 
16182: CHAPTER 94. A Squeeze of the Hand.
16183: 
16184: That whale of Stubb’s, so dearly purchased, was duly brought to the
16185: Pequod’s side, where all those cutting and hoisting operations
16186: previously detailed, were regularly gone through, even to the baling of
16187: the Heidelburgh Tun, or Case.
16188: 
16189: While some were occupied with this latter duty, others were employed in
16190: dragging away the larger tubs, so soon as filled with the sperm; and
16191: when the proper time arrived, this same sperm was carefully manipulated
16192: ere going to the try-works, of which anon.
16193: 
16194: It had cooled and crystallized to such a degree, that when, with
16195: several others, I sat down before a large Constantine’s bath of it, I
16196: found it strangely concreted into lumps, here and there rolling about
16197: in the liquid part. It was our business to squeeze these lumps back
16198: into fluid. A sweet and unctuous duty! No wonder that in old times this
16199: sperm was such a favourite cosmetic. Such a clearer! such a sweetener!
16200: such a softener! such a delicious molifier! After having my hands in it
16201: for only a few minutes, my fingers felt like eels, and began, as it
16202: were, to serpentine and spiralise.
16203: 
16204: As I sat there at my ease, cross-legged on the deck; after the bitter
16205: exertion at the windlass; under a blue tranquil sky; the ship under
16206: indolent sail, and gliding so serenely along; as I bathed my hands
16207: among those soft, gentle globules of infiltrated tissues, woven almost
16208: within the hour; as they richly broke to my fingers, and discharged all
16209: their opulence, like fully ripe grapes their wine; as I snuffed up that
16210: uncontaminated aroma,—literally and truly, like the smell of spring
16211: violets; I declare to you, that for the time I lived as in a musky
16212: meadow; I forgot all about our horrible oath; in that inexpressible
16213: sperm, I washed my hands and my heart of it; I almost began to credit
16214: the old Paracelsan superstition that sperm is of rare virtue in
16215: allaying the heat of anger; while bathing in that bath, I felt divinely
16216: free from all ill-will, or petulance, or malice, of any sort
16217: whatsoever.
16218: 
16219: Squeeze! squeeze! squeeze! all the morning long; I squeezed that sperm
16220: till I myself almost melted into it; I squeezed that sperm till a
16221: strange sort of insanity came over me; and I found myself unwittingly
16222: squeezing my co-laborers’ hands in it, mistaking their hands for the
16223: gentle globules. Such an abounding, affectionate, friendly, loving
16224: feeling did this avocation beget; that at last I was continually
16225: squeezing their hands, and looking up into their eyes sentimentally; as
16226: much as to say,—Oh! my dear fellow beings, why should we longer cherish
16227: any social acerbities, or know the slightest ill-humor or envy! Come;
16228: let us squeeze hands all round; nay, let us all squeeze ourselves into
16229: each other; let us squeeze ourselves universally into the very milk and
16230: sperm of kindness.
16231: 
16232: Would that I could keep squeezing that sperm for ever! For now, since
16233: by many prolonged, repeated experiences, I have perceived that in all
16234: cases man must eventually lower, or at least shift, his conceit of
16235: attainable felicity; not placing it anywhere in the intellect or the
16236: fancy; but in the wife, the heart, the bed, the table, the saddle, the
16237: fireside, the country; now that I have perceived all this, I am ready
16238: to squeeze case eternally. In thoughts of the visions of the night, I
16239: saw long rows of angels in paradise, each with his hands in a jar of
16240: spermaceti.
16241: 
16242: Now, while discoursing of sperm, it behooves to speak of other things
16243: akin to it, in the business of preparing the sperm whale for the
16244: try-works.
16245: 
16246: First comes white-horse, so called, which is obtained from the tapering
16247: part of the fish, and also from the thicker portions of his flukes. It
16248: is tough with congealed tendons—a wad of muscle—but still contains some
16249: oil. After being severed from the whale, the white-horse is first cut
16250: into portable oblongs ere going to the mincer. They look much like
16251: blocks of Berkshire marble.
16252: 
16253: Plum-pudding is the term bestowed upon certain fragmentary parts of the
16254: whale’s flesh, here and there adhering to the blanket of blubber, and
16255: often participating to a considerable degree in its unctuousness. It is
16256: a most refreshing, convivial, beautiful object to behold. As its name
16257: imports, it is of an exceedingly rich, mottled tint, with a bestreaked
16258: snowy and golden ground, dotted with spots of the deepest crimson and
16259: purple. It is plums of rubies, in pictures of citron. Spite of reason,
16260: it is hard to keep yourself from eating it. I confess, that once I
16261: stole behind the foremast to try it. It tasted something as I should
16262: conceive a royal cutlet from the thigh of Louis le Gros might have
16263: tasted, supposing him to have been killed the first day after the
16264: venison season, and that particular venison season contemporary with an
16265: unusually fine vintage of the vineyards of Champagne.
16266: 
16267: There is another substance, and a very singular one, which turns up in
16268: the course of this business, but which I feel it to be very puzzling
16269: adequately to describe. It is called slobgollion; an appellation
16270: original with the whalemen, and even so is the nature of the substance.
16271: It is an ineffably oozy, stringy affair, most frequently found in the
16272: tubs of sperm, after a prolonged squeezing, and subsequent decanting. I
16273: hold it to be the wondrously thin, ruptured membranes of the case,
16274: coalescing.
16275: 
16276: Gurry, so called, is a term properly belonging to right whalemen, but
16277: sometimes incidentally used by the sperm fishermen. It designates the
16278: dark, glutinous substance which is scraped off the back of the
16279: Greenland or right whale, and much of which covers the decks of those
16280: inferior souls who hunt that ignoble Leviathan.
16281: 
16282: Nippers. Strictly this word is not indigenous to the whale’s
16283: vocabulary. But as applied by whalemen, it becomes so. A whaleman’s
16284: nipper is a short firm strip of tendinous stuff cut from the tapering
16285: part of Leviathan’s tail: it averages an inch in thickness, and for the
16286: rest, is about the size of the iron part of a hoe. Edgewise moved along
16287: the oily deck, it operates like a leathern squilgee; and by nameless
16288: blandishments, as of magic, allures along with it all impurities.
16289: 
16290: But to learn all about these recondite matters, your best way is at
16291: once to descend into the blubber-room, and have a long talk with its
16292: inmates. This place has previously been mentioned as the receptacle for
16293: the blanket-pieces, when stript and hoisted from the whale. When the
16294: proper time arrives for cutting up its contents, this apartment is a
16295: scene of terror to all tyros, especially by night. On one side, lit by
16296: a dull lantern, a space has been left clear for the workmen. They
16297: generally go in pairs,—a pike-and-gaffman and a spade-man. The
16298: whaling-pike is similar to a frigate’s boarding-weapon of the same
16299: name. The gaff is something like a boat-hook. With his gaff, the
16300: gaffman hooks on to a sheet of blubber, and strives to hold it from
16301: slipping, as the ship pitches and lurches about. Meanwhile, the
16302: spade-man stands on the sheet itself, perpendicularly chopping it into
16303: the portable horse-pieces. This spade is sharp as hone can make it; the
16304: spademan’s feet are shoeless; the thing he stands on will sometimes
16305: irresistibly slide away from him, like a sledge. If he cuts off one of
16306: his own toes, or one of his assistants’, would you be very much
16307: astonished? Toes are scarce among veteran blubber-room men.
16308: 
16309: 
16310: CHAPTER 95. The Cassock.
16311: 
16312: Had you stepped on board the Pequod at a certain juncture of this
16313: post-mortemizing of the whale; and had you strolled forward nigh the
16314: windlass, pretty sure am I that you would have scanned with no small
16315: curiosity a very strange, enigmatical object, which you would have seen
16316: there, lying along lengthwise in the lee scuppers. Not the wondrous
16317: cistern in the whale’s huge head; not the prodigy of his unhinged lower
16318: jaw; not the miracle of his symmetrical tail; none of these would so
16319: surprise you, as half a glimpse of that unaccountable cone,—longer than
16320: a Kentuckian is tall, nigh a foot in diameter at the base, and
16321: jet-black as Yojo, the ebony idol of Queequeg. And an idol, indeed, it
16322: is; or, rather, in old times, its likeness was. Such an idol as that
16323: found in the secret groves of Queen Maachah in Judea; and for
16324: worshipping which, King Asa, her son, did depose her, and destroyed the
16325: idol, and burnt it for an abomination at the brook Kedron, as darkly
16326: set forth in the 15th chapter of the First Book of Kings.
16327: 
16328: Look at the sailor, called the mincer, who now comes along, and
16329: assisted by two allies, heavily backs the grandissimus, as the mariners
16330: call it, and with bowed shoulders, staggers off with it as if he were a
16331: grenadier carrying a dead comrade from the field. Extending it upon the
16332: forecastle deck, he now proceeds cylindrically to remove its dark pelt,
16333: as an African hunter the pelt of a boa. This done he turns the pelt
16334: inside out, like a pantaloon leg; gives it a good stretching, so as
16335: almost to double its diameter; and at last hangs it, well spread, in
16336: the rigging, to dry. Ere long, it is taken down; when removing some
16337: three feet of it, towards the pointed extremity, and then cutting two
16338: slits for arm-holes at the other end, he lengthwise slips himself
16339: bodily into it. The mincer now stands before you invested in the full
16340: canonicals of his calling. Immemorial to all his order, this
16341: investiture alone will adequately protect him, while employed in the
16342: peculiar functions of his office.
16343: 
16344: That office consists in mincing the horse-pieces of blubber for the
16345: pots; an operation which is conducted at a curious wooden horse,
16346: planted endwise against the bulwarks, and with a capacious tub beneath
16347: it, into which the minced pieces drop, fast as the sheets from a rapt
16348: orator’s desk. Arrayed in decent black; occupying a conspicuous pulpit;
16349: intent on bible leaves; what a candidate for an archbishopric, what a
16350: lad for a Pope were this mincer!*
16351: 
16352: *Bible leaves! Bible leaves! This is the invariable cry from the mates
16353: to the mincer. It enjoins him to be careful, and cut his work into as
16354: thin slices as possible, inasmuch as by so doing the business of
16355: boiling out the oil is much accelerated, and its quantity considerably
16356: increased, besides perhaps improving it in quality.
16357: 
16358: 
16359: CHAPTER 96. The Try-Works.
16360: 
16361: Besides her hoisted boats, an American whaler is outwardly
16362: distinguished by her try-works. She presents the curious anomaly of the
16363: most solid masonry joining with oak and hemp in constituting the
16364: completed ship. It is as if from the open field a brick-kiln were
16365: transported to her planks.
16366: 
16367: The try-works are planted between the foremast and mainmast, the most
16368: roomy part of the deck. The timbers beneath are of a peculiar strength,
16369: fitted to sustain the weight of an almost solid mass of brick and
16370: mortar, some ten feet by eight square, and five in height. The
16371: foundation does not penetrate the deck, but the masonry is firmly
16372: secured to the surface by ponderous knees of iron bracing it on all
16373: sides, and screwing it down to the timbers. On the flanks it is cased
16374: with wood, and at top completely covered by a large, sloping, battened
16375: hatchway. Removing this hatch we expose the great try-pots, two in
16376: number, and each of several barrels’ capacity. When not in use, they
16377: are kept remarkably clean. Sometimes they are polished with soapstone
16378: and sand, till they shine within like silver punch-bowls. During the
16379: night-watches some cynical old sailors will crawl into them and coil
16380: themselves away there for a nap. While employed in polishing them—one
16381: man in each pot, side by side—many confidential communications are
16382: carried on, over the iron lips. It is a place also for profound
16383: mathematical meditation. It was in the left hand try-pot of the Pequod,
16384: with the soapstone diligently circling round me, that I was first
16385: indirectly struck by the remarkable fact, that in geometry all bodies
16386: gliding along the cycloid, my soapstone for example, will descend from
16387: any point in precisely the same time.
16388: 
16389: Removing the fire-board from the front of the try-works, the bare
16390: masonry of that side is exposed, penetrated by the two iron mouths of
16391: the furnaces, directly underneath the pots. These mouths are fitted
16392: with heavy doors of iron. The intense heat of the fire is prevented
16393: from communicating itself to the deck, by means of a shallow reservoir
16394: extending under the entire inclosed surface of the works. By a tunnel
16395: inserted at the rear, this reservoir is kept replenished with water as
16396: fast as it evaporates. There are no external chimneys; they open direct
16397: from the rear wall. And here let us go back for a moment.
16398: 
16399: It was about nine o’clock at night that the Pequod’s try-works were
16400: first started on this present voyage. It belonged to Stubb to oversee
16401: the business.
16402: 
16403: “All ready there? Off hatch, then, and start her. You cook, fire the
16404: works.” This was an easy thing, for the carpenter had been thrusting
16405: his shavings into the furnace throughout the passage. Here be it said
16406: that in a whaling voyage the first fire in the try-works has to be fed
16407: for a time with wood. After that no wood is used, except as a means of
16408: quick ignition to the staple fuel. In a word, after being tried out,
16409: the crisp, shrivelled blubber, now called scraps or fritters, still
16410: contains considerable of its unctuous properties. These fritters feed
16411: the flames. Like a plethoric burning martyr, or a self-consuming
16412: misanthrope, once ignited, the whale supplies his own fuel and burns by
16413: his own body. Would that he consumed his own smoke! for his smoke is
16414: horrible to inhale, and inhale it you must, and not only that, but you
16415: must live in it for the time. It has an unspeakable, wild, Hindoo odor
16416: about it, such as may lurk in the vicinity of funereal pyres. It smells
16417: like the left wing of the day of judgment; it is an argument for the
16418: pit.
16419: 
16420: By midnight the works were in full operation. We were clear from the
16421: carcase; sail had been made; the wind was freshening; the wild ocean
16422: darkness was intense. But that darkness was licked up by the fierce
16423: flames, which at intervals forked forth from the sooty flues, and
16424: illuminated every lofty rope in the rigging, as with the famed Greek
16425: fire. The burning ship drove on, as if remorselessly commissioned to
16426: some vengeful deed. So the pitch and sulphur-freighted brigs of the
16427: bold Hydriote, Canaris, issuing from their midnight harbors, with broad
16428: sheets of flame for sails, bore down upon the Turkish frigates, and
16429: folded them in conflagrations.
16430: 
16431: The hatch, removed from the top of the works, now afforded a wide
16432: hearth in front of them. Standing on this were the Tartarean shapes of
16433: the pagan harpooneers, always the whale-ship’s stokers. With huge
16434: pronged poles they pitched hissing masses of blubber into the scalding
16435: pots, or stirred up the fires beneath, till the snaky flames darted,
16436: curling, out of the doors to catch them by the feet. The smoke rolled
16437: away in sullen heaps. To every pitch of the ship there was a pitch of
16438: the boiling oil, which seemed all eagerness to leap into their faces.
16439: Opposite the mouth of the works, on the further side of the wide wooden
16440: hearth, was the windlass. This served for a sea-sofa. Here lounged the
16441: watch, when not otherwise employed, looking into the red heat of the
16442: fire, till their eyes felt scorched in their heads. Their tawny
16443: features, now all begrimed with smoke and sweat, their matted beards,
16444: and the contrasting barbaric brilliancy of their teeth, all these were
16445: strangely revealed in the capricious emblazonings of the works. As they
16446: narrated to each other their unholy adventures, their tales of terror
16447: told in words of mirth; as their uncivilized laughter forked upwards
16448: out of them, like the flames from the furnace; as to and fro, in their
16449: front, the harpooneers wildly gesticulated with their huge pronged
16450: forks and dippers; as the wind howled on, and the sea leaped, and the
16451: ship groaned and dived, and yet steadfastly shot her red hell further
16452: and further into the blackness of the sea and the night, and scornfully
16453: champed the white bone in her mouth, and viciously spat round her on
16454: all sides; then the rushing Pequod, freighted with savages, and laden
16455: with fire, and burning a corpse, and plunging into that blackness of
16456: darkness, seemed the material counterpart of her monomaniac commander’s
16457: soul.
16458: 
16459: So seemed it to me, as I stood at her helm, and for long hours silently
16460: guided the way of this fire-ship on the sea. Wrapped, for that
16461: interval, in darkness myself, I but the better saw the redness, the
16462: madness, the ghastliness of others. The continual sight of the fiend
16463: shapes before me, capering half in smoke and half in fire, these at
16464: last begat kindred visions in my soul, so soon as I began to yield to
16465: that unaccountable drowsiness which ever would come over me at a
16466: midnight helm.
16467: 
16468: But that night, in particular, a strange (and ever since inexplicable)
16469: thing occurred to me. Starting from a brief standing sleep, I was
16470: horribly conscious of something fatally wrong. The jaw-bone tiller
16471: smote my side, which leaned against it; in my ears was the low hum of
16472: sails, just beginning to shake in the wind; I thought my eyes were
16473: open; I was half conscious of putting my fingers to the lids and
16474: mechanically stretching them still further apart. But, spite of all
16475: this, I could see no compass before me to steer by; though it seemed
16476: but a minute since I had been watching the card, by the steady binnacle
16477: lamp illuminating it. Nothing seemed before me but a jet gloom, now and
16478: then made ghastly by flashes of redness. Uppermost was the impression,
16479: that whatever swift, rushing thing I stood on was not so much bound to
16480: any haven ahead as rushing from all havens astern. A stark, bewildered
16481: feeling, as of death, came over me. Convulsively my hands grasped the
16482: tiller, but with the crazy conceit that the tiller was, somehow, in
16483: some enchanted way, inverted. My God! what is the matter with me?
16484: thought I. Lo! in my brief sleep I had turned myself about, and was
16485: fronting the ship’s stern, with my back to her prow and the compass. In
16486: an instant I faced back, just in time to prevent the vessel from flying
16487: up into the wind, and very probably capsizing her. How glad and how
16488: grateful the relief from this unnatural hallucination of the night, and
16489: the fatal contingency of being brought by the lee!
16490: 
16491: Look not too long in the face of the fire, O man! Never dream with thy
16492: hand on the helm! Turn not thy back to the compass; accept the first
16493: hint of the hitching tiller; believe not the artificial fire, when its
16494: redness makes all things look ghastly. To-morrow, in the natural sun,
16495: the skies will be bright; those who glared like devils in the forking
16496: flames, the morn will show in far other, at least gentler, relief; the
16497: glorious, golden, glad sun, the only true lamp—all others but liars!
16498: 
16499: Nevertheless the sun hides not Virginia’s Dismal Swamp, nor Rome’s
16500: accursed Campagna, nor wide Sahara, nor all the millions of miles of
16501: deserts and of griefs beneath the moon. The sun hides not the ocean,
16502: which is the dark side of this earth, and which is two thirds of this
16503: earth. So, therefore, that mortal man who hath more of joy than sorrow
16504: in him, that mortal man cannot be true—not true, or undeveloped. With
16505: books the same. The truest of all men was the Man of Sorrows, and the
16506: truest of all books is Solomon’s, and Ecclesiastes is the fine hammered
16507: steel of woe. “All is vanity.” ALL. This wilful world hath not got hold
16508: of unchristian Solomon’s wisdom yet. But he who dodges hospitals and
16509: jails, and walks fast crossing graveyards, and would rather talk of
16510: operas than hell; calls Cowper, Young, Pascal, Rousseau, poor devils
16511: all of sick men; and throughout a care-free lifetime swears by Rabelais
16512: as passing wise, and therefore jolly;—not that man is fitted to sit
16513: down on tomb-stones, and break the green damp mould with unfathomably
16514: wondrous Solomon.
16515: 
16516: But even Solomon, he says, “the man that wandereth out of the way of
16517: understanding shall remain” (_i.e._, even while living) “in the
16518: congregation of the dead.” Give not thyself up, then, to fire, lest it
16519: invert thee, deaden thee; as for the time it did me. There is a wisdom
16520: that is woe; but there is a woe that is madness. And there is a
16521: Catskill eagle in some souls that can alike dive down into the blackest
16522: gorges, and soar out of them again and become invisible in the sunny
16523: spaces. And even if he for ever flies within the gorge, that gorge is
16524: in the mountains; so that even in his lowest swoop the mountain eagle
16525: is still higher than other birds upon the plain, even though they soar.
16526: 
16527: 
16528: CHAPTER 97. The Lamp.
16529: 
16530: Had you descended from the Pequod’s try-works to the Pequod’s
16531: forecastle, where the off duty watch were sleeping, for one single
16532: moment you would have almost thought you were standing in some
16533: illuminated shrine of canonized kings and counsellors. There they lay
16534: in their triangular oaken vaults, each mariner a chiselled muteness; a
16535: score of lamps flashing upon his hooded eyes.
16536: 
16537: In merchantmen, oil for the sailor is more scarce than the milk of
16538: queens. To dress in the dark, and eat in the dark, and stumble in
16539: darkness to his pallet, this is his usual lot. But the whaleman, as he
16540: seeks the food of light, so he lives in light. He makes his berth an
16541: Aladdin’s lamp, and lays him down in it; so that in the pitchiest night
16542: the ship’s black hull still houses an illumination.
16543: 
16544: See with what entire freedom the whaleman takes his handful of
16545: lamps—often but old bottles and vials, though—to the copper cooler at
16546: the try-works, and replenishes them there, as mugs of ale at a vat. He
16547: burns, too, the purest of oil, in its unmanufactured, and, therefore,
16548: unvitiated state; a fluid unknown to solar, lunar, or astral
16549: contrivances ashore. It is sweet as early grass butter in April. He
16550: goes and hunts for his oil, so as to be sure of its freshness and
16551: genuineness, even as the traveller on the prairie hunts up his own
16552: supper of game.
16553: 
16554: 
16555: CHAPTER 98. Stowing Down and Clearing Up.
16556: 
16557: Already has it been related how the great leviathan is afar off
16558: descried from the mast-head; how he is chased over the watery moors,
16559: and slaughtered in the valleys of the deep; how he is then towed
16560: alongside and beheaded; and how (on the principle which entitled the
16561: headsman of old to the garments in which the beheaded was killed) his
16562: great padded surtout becomes the property of his executioner; how, in
16563: due time, he is condemned to the pots, and, like Shadrach, Meshach, and
16564: Abednego, his spermaceti, oil, and bone pass unscathed through the
16565: fire;—but now it remains to conclude the last chapter of this part of
16566: the description by rehearsing—singing, if I may—the romantic proceeding
16567: of decanting off his oil into the casks and striking them down into the
16568: hold, where once again leviathan returns to his native profundities,
16569: sliding along beneath the surface as before; but, alas! never more to
16570: rise and blow.
16571: 
16572: While still warm, the oil, like hot punch, is received into the
16573: six-barrel casks; and while, perhaps, the ship is pitching and rolling
16574: this way and that in the midnight sea, the enormous casks are slewed
16575: round and headed over, end for end, and sometimes perilously scoot
16576: across the slippery deck, like so many land slides, till at last
16577: man-handled and stayed in their course; and all round the hoops, rap,
16578: rap, go as many hammers as can play upon them, for now, _ex officio_,
16579: every sailor is a cooper.
16580: 
16581: At length, when the last pint is casked, and all is cool, then the
16582: great hatchways are unsealed, the bowels of the ship are thrown open,
16583: and down go the casks to their final rest in the sea. This done, the
16584: hatches are replaced, and hermetically closed, like a closet walled up.
16585: 
16586: In the sperm fishery, this is perhaps one of the most remarkable
16587: incidents in all the business of whaling. One day the planks stream
16588: with freshets of blood and oil; on the sacred quarter-deck enormous
16589: masses of the whale’s head are profanely piled; great rusty casks lie
16590: about, as in a brewery yard; the smoke from the try-works has besooted
16591: all the bulwarks; the mariners go about suffused with unctuousness; the
16592: entire ship seems great leviathan himself; while on all hands the din
16593: is deafening.
16594: 
16595: But a day or two after, you look about you, and prick your ears in this
16596: self-same ship; and were it not for the tell-tale boats and try-works,
16597: you would all but swear you trod some silent merchant vessel, with a
16598: most scrupulously neat commander. The unmanufactured sperm oil
16599: possesses a singularly cleansing virtue. This is the reason why the
16600: decks never look so white as just after what they call an affair of
16601: oil. Besides, from the ashes of the burned scraps of the whale, a
16602: potent lye is readily made; and whenever any adhesiveness from the back
16603: of the whale remains clinging to the side, that lye quickly
16604: exterminates it. Hands go diligently along the bulwarks, and with
16605: buckets of water and rags restore them to their full tidiness. The soot
