16606: is brushed from the lower rigging. All the numerous implements which
16607: have been in use are likewise faithfully cleansed and put away. The
16608: great hatch is scrubbed and placed upon the try-works, completely
16609: hiding the pots; every cask is out of sight; all tackles are coiled in
16610: unseen nooks; and when by the combined and simultaneous industry of
16611: almost the entire ship’s company, the whole of this conscientious duty
16612: is at last concluded, then the crew themselves proceed to their own
16613: ablutions; shift themselves from top to toe; and finally issue to the
16614: immaculate deck, fresh and all aglow, as bridegrooms new-leaped from
16615: out the daintiest Holland.
16616: 
16617: Now, with elated step, they pace the planks in twos and threes, and
16618: humorously discourse of parlors, sofas, carpets, and fine cambrics;
16619: propose to mat the deck; think of having hanging to the top; object not
16620: to taking tea by moonlight on the piazza of the forecastle. To hint to
16621: such musked mariners of oil, and bone, and blubber, were little short
16622: of audacity. They know not the thing you distantly allude to. Away, and
16623: bring us napkins!
16624: 
16625: But mark: aloft there, at the three mast heads, stand three men intent
16626: on spying out more whales, which, if caught, infallibly will again soil
16627: the old oaken furniture, and drop at least one small grease-spot
16628: somewhere. Yes; and many is the time, when, after the severest
16629: uninterrupted labors, which know no night; continuing straight through
16630: for ninety-six hours; when from the boat, where they have swelled their
16631: wrists with all day rowing on the Line,—they only step to the deck to
16632: carry vast chains, and heave the heavy windlass, and cut and slash,
16633: yea, and in their very sweatings to be smoked and burned anew by the
16634: combined fires of the equatorial sun and the equatorial try-works;
16635: when, on the heel of all this, they have finally bestirred themselves
16636: to cleanse the ship, and make a spotless dairy room of it; many is the
16637: time the poor fellows, just buttoning the necks of their clean frocks,
16638: are startled by the cry of “There she blows!” and away they fly to
16639: fight another whale, and go through the whole weary thing again. Oh! my
16640: friends, but this is man-killing! Yet this is life. For hardly have we
16641: mortals by long toilings extracted from this world’s vast bulk its
16642: small but valuable sperm; and then, with weary patience, cleansed
16643: ourselves from its defilements, and learned to live here in clean
16644: tabernacles of the soul; hardly is this done, when—_There she
16645: blows!_—the ghost is spouted up, and away we sail to fight some other
16646: world, and go through young life’s old routine again.
16647: 
16648: Oh! the metempsychosis! Oh! Pythagoras, that in bright Greece, two
16649: thousand years ago, did die, so good, so wise, so mild; I sailed with
16650: thee along the Peruvian coast last voyage—and, foolish as I am, taught
16651: thee, a green simple boy, how to splice a rope!
16652: 
16653: 
16654: CHAPTER 99. The Doubloon.
16655: 
16656: Ere now it has been related how Ahab was wont to pace his quarter-deck,
16657: taking regular turns at either limit, the binnacle and mainmast; but in
16658: the multiplicity of other things requiring narration it has not been
16659: added how that sometimes in these walks, when most plunged in his mood,
16660: he was wont to pause in turn at each spot, and stand there strangely
16661: eyeing the particular object before him. When he halted before the
16662: binnacle, with his glance fastened on the pointed needle in the
16663: compass, that glance shot like a javelin with the pointed intensity of
16664: his purpose; and when resuming his walk he again paused before the
16665: mainmast, then, as the same riveted glance fastened upon the riveted
16666: gold coin there, he still wore the same aspect of nailed firmness, only
16667: dashed with a certain wild longing, if not hopefulness.
16668: 
16669: But one morning, turning to pass the doubloon, he seemed to be newly
16670: attracted by the strange figures and inscriptions stamped on it, as
16671: though now for the first time beginning to interpret for himself in
16672: some monomaniac way whatever significance might lurk in them. And some
16673: certain significance lurks in all things, else all things are little
16674: worth, and the round world itself but an empty cipher, except to sell
16675: by the cartload, as they do hills about Boston, to fill up some morass
16676: in the Milky Way.
16677: 
16678: Now this doubloon was of purest, virgin gold, raked somewhere out of
16679: the heart of gorgeous hills, whence, east and west, over golden sands,
16680: the head-waters of many a Pactolus flows. And though now nailed amidst
16681: all the rustiness of iron bolts and the verdigris of copper spikes,
16682: yet, untouchable and immaculate to any foulness, it still preserved its
16683: Quito glow. Nor, though placed amongst a ruthless crew and every hour
16684: passed by ruthless hands, and through the livelong nights shrouded with
16685: thick darkness which might cover any pilfering approach, nevertheless
16686: every sunrise found the doubloon where the sunset left it last. For it
16687: was set apart and sanctified to one awe-striking end; and however
16688: wanton in their sailor ways, one and all, the mariners revered it as
16689: the white whale’s talisman. Sometimes they talked it over in the weary
16690: watch by night, wondering whose it was to be at last, and whether he
16691: would ever live to spend it.
16692: 
16693: Now those noble golden coins of South America are as medals of the sun
16694: and tropic token-pieces. Here palms, alpacas, and volcanoes; sun’s
16695: disks and stars; ecliptics, horns-of-plenty, and rich banners waving,
16696: are in luxuriant profusion stamped; so that the precious gold seems
16697: almost to derive an added preciousness and enhancing glories, by
16698: passing through those fancy mints, so Spanishly poetic.
16699: 
16700: It so chanced that the doubloon of the Pequod was a most wealthy
16701: example of these things. On its round border it bore the letters,
16702: REPUBLICA DEL ECUADOR: QUITO. So this bright coin came from a country
16703: planted in the middle of the world, and beneath the great equator, and
16704: named after it; and it had been cast midway up the Andes, in the
16705: unwaning clime that knows no autumn. Zoned by those letters you saw the
16706: likeness of three Andes’ summits; from one a flame; a tower on another;
16707: on the third a crowing cock; while arching over all was a segment of
16708: the partitioned zodiac, the signs all marked with their usual
16709: cabalistics, and the keystone sun entering the equinoctial point at
16710: Libra.
16711: 
16712: Before this equatorial coin, Ahab, not unobserved by others, was now
16713: pausing.
16714: 
16715: “There’s something ever egotistical in mountain-tops and towers, and
16716: all other grand and lofty things; look here,—three peaks as proud as
16717: Lucifer. The firm tower, that is Ahab; the volcano, that is Ahab; the
16718: courageous, the undaunted, and victorious fowl, that, too, is Ahab; all
16719: are Ahab; and this round gold is but the image of the rounder globe,
16720: which, like a magician’s glass, to each and every man in turn but
16721: mirrors back his own mysterious self. Great pains, small gains for
16722: those who ask the world to solve them; it cannot solve itself. Methinks
16723: now this coined sun wears a ruddy face; but see! aye, he enters the
16724: sign of storms, the equinox! and but six months before he wheeled out
16725: of a former equinox at Aries! From storm to storm! So be it, then. Born
16726: in throes, ’tis fit that man should live in pains and die in pangs! So
16727: be it, then! Here’s stout stuff for woe to work on. So be it, then.”
16728: 
16729: “No fairy fingers can have pressed the gold, but devil’s claws must
16730: have left their mouldings there since yesterday,” murmured Starbuck to
16731: himself, leaning against the bulwarks. “The old man seems to read
16732: Belshazzar’s awful writing. I have never marked the coin inspectingly.
16733: He goes below; let me read. A dark valley between three mighty,
16734: heaven-abiding peaks, that almost seem the Trinity, in some faint
16735: earthly symbol. So in this vale of Death, God girds us round; and over
16736: all our gloom, the sun of Righteousness still shines a beacon and a
16737: hope. If we bend down our eyes, the dark vale shows her mouldy soil;
16738: but if we lift them, the bright sun meets our glance half way, to
16739: cheer. Yet, oh, the great sun is no fixture; and if, at midnight, we
16740: would fain snatch some sweet solace from him, we gaze for him in vain!
16741: This coin speaks wisely, mildly, truly, but still sadly to me. I will
16742: quit it, lest Truth shake me falsely.”
16743: 
16744: “There now’s the old Mogul,” soliloquized Stubb by the try-works, “he’s
16745: been twigging it; and there goes Starbuck from the same, and both with
16746: faces which I should say might be somewhere within nine fathoms long.
16747: And all from looking at a piece of gold, which did I have it now on
16748: Negro Hill or in Corlaer’s Hook, I’d not look at it very long ere
16749: spending it. Humph! in my poor, insignificant opinion, I regard this as
16750: queer. I have seen doubloons before now in my voyagings; your doubloons
16751: of old Spain, your doubloons of Peru, your doubloons of Chili, your
16752: doubloons of Bolivia, your doubloons of Popayan; with plenty of gold
16753: moidores and pistoles, and joes, and half joes, and quarter joes. What
16754: then should there be in this doubloon of the Equator that is so killing
16755: wonderful? By Golconda! let me read it once. Halloa! here’s signs and
16756: wonders truly! That, now, is what old Bowditch in his Epitome calls the
16757: zodiac, and what my almanac below calls ditto. I’ll get the almanac and
16758: as I have heard devils can be raised with Daboll’s arithmetic, I’ll try
16759: my hand at raising a meaning out of these queer curvicues here with the
16760: Massachusetts calendar. Here’s the book. Let’s see now. Signs and
16761: wonders; and the sun, he’s always among ’em. Hem, hem, hem; here they
16762: are—here they go—all alive:—Aries, or the Ram; Taurus, or the Bull and
16763: Jimimi! here’s Gemini himself, or the Twins. Well; the sun he wheels
16764: among ’em. Aye, here on the coin he’s just crossing the threshold
16765: between two of twelve sitting-rooms all in a ring. Book! you lie there;
16766: the fact is, you books must know your places. You’ll do to give us the
16767: bare words and facts, but we come in to supply the thoughts. That’s my
16768: small experience, so far as the Massachusetts calendar, and Bowditch’s
16769: navigator, and Daboll’s arithmetic go. Signs and wonders, eh? Pity if
16770: there is nothing wonderful in signs, and significant in wonders!
16771: There’s a clue somewhere; wait a bit; hist—hark! By Jove, I have it!
16772: Look you, Doubloon, your zodiac here is the life of man in one round
16773: chapter; and now I’ll read it off, straight out of the book. Come,
16774: Almanack! To begin: there’s Aries, or the Ram—lecherous dog, he begets
16775: us; then, Taurus, or the Bull—he bumps us the first thing; then Gemini,
16776: or the Twins—that is, Virtue and Vice; we try to reach Virtue, when lo!
16777: comes Cancer the Crab, and drags us back; and here, going from Virtue,
16778: Leo, a roaring Lion, lies in the path—he gives a few fierce bites and
16779: surly dabs with his paw; we escape, and hail Virgo, the Virgin! that’s
16780: our first love; we marry and think to be happy for aye, when pop comes
16781: Libra, or the Scales—happiness weighed and found wanting; and while we
16782: are very sad about that, Lord! how we suddenly jump, as Scorpio, or the
16783: Scorpion, stings us in the rear; we are curing the wound, when whang
16784: come the arrows all round; Sagittarius, or the Archer, is amusing
16785: himself. As we pluck out the shafts, stand aside! here’s the
16786: battering-ram, Capricornus, or the Goat; full tilt, he comes rushing,
16787: and headlong we are tossed; when Aquarius, or the Water-bearer, pours
16788: out his whole deluge and drowns us; and to wind up with Pisces, or the
16789: Fishes, we sleep. There’s a sermon now, writ in high heaven, and the
16790: sun goes through it every year, and yet comes out of it all alive and
16791: hearty. Jollily he, aloft there, wheels through toil and trouble; and
16792: so, alow here, does jolly Stubb. Oh, jolly’s the word for aye! Adieu,
16793: Doubloon! But stop; here comes little King-Post; dodge round the
16794: try-works, now, and let’s hear what he’ll have to say. There; he’s
16795: before it; he’ll out with something presently. So, so; he’s beginning.”
16796: 
16797: “I see nothing here, but a round thing made of gold, and whoever raises
16798: a certain whale, this round thing belongs to him. So, what’s all this
16799: staring been about? It is worth sixteen dollars, that’s true; and at
16800: two cents the cigar, that’s nine hundred and sixty cigars. I won’t
16801: smoke dirty pipes like Stubb, but I like cigars, and here’s nine
16802: hundred and sixty of them; so here goes Flask aloft to spy ’em out.”
16803: 
16804: “Shall I call that wise or foolish, now; if it be really wise it has a
16805: foolish look to it; yet, if it be really foolish, then has it a sort of
16806: wiseish look to it. But, avast; here comes our old Manxman—the old
16807: hearse-driver, he must have been, that is, before he took to the sea.
16808: He luffs up before the doubloon; halloa, and goes round on the other
16809: side of the mast; why, there’s a horse-shoe nailed on that side; and
16810: now he’s back again; what does that mean? Hark! he’s muttering—voice
16811: like an old worn-out coffee-mill. Prick ears, and listen!”
16812: 
16813: “If the White Whale be raised, it must be in a month and a day, when
16814: the sun stands in some one of these signs. I’ve studied signs, and know
16815: their marks; they were taught me two score years ago, by the old witch
16816: in Copenhagen. Now, in what sign will the sun then be? The horse-shoe
16817: sign; for there it is, right opposite the gold. And what’s the
16818: horse-shoe sign? The lion is the horse-shoe sign—the roaring and
16819: devouring lion. Ship, old ship! my old head shakes to think of thee.”
16820: 
16821: “There’s another rendering now; but still one text. All sorts of men in
16822: one kind of world, you see. Dodge again! here comes Queequeg—all
16823: tattooing—looks like the signs of the Zodiac himself. What says the
16824: Cannibal? As I live he’s comparing notes; looking at his thigh bone;
16825: thinks the sun is in the thigh, or in the calf, or in the bowels, I
16826: suppose, as the old women talk Surgeon’s Astronomy in the back country.
16827: And by Jove, he’s found something there in the vicinity of his thigh—I
16828: guess it’s Sagittarius, or the Archer. No: he don’t know what to make
16829: of the doubloon; he takes it for an old button off some king’s
16830: trowsers. But, aside again! here comes that ghost-devil, Fedallah; tail
16831: coiled out of sight as usual, oakum in the toes of his pumps as usual.
16832: What does he say, with that look of his? Ah, only makes a sign to the
16833: sign and bows himself; there is a sun on the coin—fire worshipper,
16834: depend upon it. Ho! more and more. This way comes Pip—poor boy! would
16835: he had died, or I; he’s half horrible to me. He too has been watching
16836: all of these interpreters—myself included—and look now, he comes to
16837: read, with that unearthly idiot face. Stand away again and hear him.
16838: Hark!”
16839: 
16840: “I look, you look, he looks; we look, ye look, they look.”
16841: 
16842: “Upon my soul, he’s been studying Murray’s Grammar! Improving his mind,
16843: poor fellow! But what’s that he says now—hist!”
16844: 
16845: “I look, you look, he looks; we look, ye look, they look.”
16846: 
16847: “Why, he’s getting it by heart—hist! again.”
16848: 
16849: “I look, you look, he looks; we look, ye look, they look.”
16850: 
16851: “Well, that’s funny.”
16852: 
16853: “And I, you, and he; and we, ye, and they, are all bats; and I’m a
16854: crow, especially when I stand a’top of this pine tree here. Caw! caw!
16855: caw! caw! caw! caw! Ain’t I a crow? And where’s the scare-crow? There
16856: he stands; two bones stuck into a pair of old trowsers, and two more
16857: poked into the sleeves of an old jacket.”
16858: 
16859: “Wonder if he means me?—complimentary!—poor lad!—I could go hang
16860: myself. Any way, for the present, I’ll quit Pip’s vicinity. I can stand
16861: the rest, for they have plain wits; but he’s too crazy-witty for my
16862: sanity. So, so, I leave him muttering.”
16863: 
16864: “Here’s the ship’s navel, this doubloon here, and they are all on fire
16865: to unscrew it. But, unscrew your navel, and what’s the consequence?
16866: Then again, if it stays here, that is ugly, too, for when aught’s
16867: nailed to the mast it’s a sign that things grow desperate. Ha, ha! old
16868: Ahab! the White Whale; he’ll nail ye! This is a pine tree. My father,
16869: in old Tolland county, cut down a pine tree once, and found a silver
16870: ring grown over in it; some old darkey’s wedding ring. How did it get
16871: there? And so they’ll say in the resurrection, when they come to fish
16872: up this old mast, and find a doubloon lodged in it, with bedded oysters
16873: for the shaggy bark. Oh, the gold! the precious, precious, gold! the
16874: green miser’ll hoard ye soon! Hish! hish! God goes ’mong the worlds
16875: blackberrying. Cook! ho, cook! and cook us! Jenny! hey, hey, hey, hey,
16876: hey, Jenny, Jenny! and get your hoe-cake done!”
16877: 
16878: 
16879: CHAPTER 100. Leg and Arm.
16880: 
16881: The Pequod, of Nantucket, Meets the Samuel Enderby, of London.
16882: 
16883: “Ship, ahoy! Hast seen the White Whale?”
16884: 
16885: So cried Ahab, once more hailing a ship showing English colours,
16886: bearing down under the stern. Trumpet to mouth, the old man was
16887: standing in his hoisted quarter-boat, his ivory leg plainly revealed to
16888: the stranger captain, who was carelessly reclining in his own boat’s
16889: bow. He was a darkly-tanned, burly, good-natured, fine-looking man, of
16890: sixty or thereabouts, dressed in a spacious roundabout, that hung round
16891: him in festoons of blue pilot-cloth; and one empty arm of this jacket
16892: streamed behind him like the broidered arm of a hussar’s surcoat.
16893: 
16894: “Hast seen the White Whale?”
16895: 
16896: “See you this?” and withdrawing it from the folds that had hidden it,
16897: he held up a white arm of sperm whale bone, terminating in a wooden
16898: head like a mallet.
16899: 
16900: “Man my boat!” cried Ahab, impetuously, and tossing about the oars near
16901: him—“Stand by to lower!”
16902: 
16903: In less than a minute, without quitting his little craft, he and his
16904: crew were dropped to the water, and were soon alongside of the
16905: stranger. But here a curious difficulty presented itself. In the
16906: excitement of the moment, Ahab had forgotten that since the loss of his
16907: leg he had never once stepped on board of any vessel at sea but his
16908: own, and then it was always by an ingenious and very handy mechanical
16909: contrivance peculiar to the Pequod, and a thing not to be rigged and
16910: shipped in any other vessel at a moment’s warning. Now, it is no very
16911: easy matter for anybody—except those who are almost hourly used to it,
16912: like whalemen—to clamber up a ship’s side from a boat on the open sea;
16913: for the great swells now lift the boat high up towards the bulwarks,
16914: and then instantaneously drop it half way down to the kelson. So,
16915: deprived of one leg, and the strange ship of course being altogether
16916: unsupplied with the kindly invention, Ahab now found himself abjectly
16917: reduced to a clumsy landsman again; hopelessly eyeing the uncertain
16918: changeful height he could hardly hope to attain.
16919: 
16920: It has before been hinted, perhaps, that every little untoward
16921: circumstance that befell him, and which indirectly sprang from his
16922: luckless mishap, almost invariably irritated or exasperated Ahab. And
16923: in the present instance, all this was heightened by the sight of the
16924: two officers of the strange ship, leaning over the side, by the
16925: perpendicular ladder of nailed cleets there, and swinging towards him a
16926: pair of tastefully-ornamented man-ropes; for at first they did not seem
16927: to bethink them that a one-legged man must be too much of a cripple to
16928: use their sea bannisters. But this awkwardness only lasted a minute,
16929: because the strange captain, observing at a glance how affairs stood,
16930: cried out, “I see, I see!—avast heaving there! Jump, boys, and swing
16931: over the cutting-tackle.”
16932: 
16933: As good luck would have it, they had had a whale alongside a day or two
16934: previous, and the great tackles were still aloft, and the massive
16935: curved blubber-hook, now clean and dry, was still attached to the end.
16936: This was quickly lowered to Ahab, who at once comprehending it all,
16937: slid his solitary thigh into the curve of the hook (it was like sitting
16938: in the fluke of an anchor, or the crotch of an apple tree), and then
16939: giving the word, held himself fast, and at the same time also helped to
16940: hoist his own weight, by pulling hand-over-hand upon one of the running
16941: parts of the tackle. Soon he was carefully swung inside the high
16942: bulwarks, and gently landed upon the capstan head. With his ivory arm
16943: frankly thrust forth in welcome, the other captain advanced, and Ahab,
16944: putting out his ivory leg, and crossing the ivory arm (like two
16945: sword-fish blades) cried out in his walrus way, “Aye, aye, hearty! let
16946: us shake bones together!—an arm and a leg!—an arm that never can
16947: shrink, d’ye see; and a leg that never can run. Where did’st thou see
16948: the White Whale?—how long ago?”
16949: 
16950: “The White Whale,” said the Englishman, pointing his ivory arm towards
16951: the East, and taking a rueful sight along it, as if it had been a
16952: telescope; “there I saw him, on the Line, last season.”
16953: 
16954: “And he took that arm off, did he?” asked Ahab, now sliding down from
16955: the capstan, and resting on the Englishman’s shoulder, as he did so.
16956: 
16957: “Aye, he was the cause of it, at least; and that leg, too?”
16958: 
16959: “Spin me the yarn,” said Ahab; “how was it?”
16960: 
16961: “It was the first time in my life that I ever cruised on the Line,”
16962: began the Englishman. “I was ignorant of the White Whale at that time.
16963: Well, one day we lowered for a pod of four or five whales, and my boat
16964: fastened to one of them; a regular circus horse he was, too, that went
16965: milling and milling round so, that my boat’s crew could only trim dish,
16966: by sitting all their sterns on the outer gunwale. Presently up breaches
16967: from the bottom of the sea a bouncing great whale, with a milky-white
16968: head and hump, all crows’ feet and wrinkles.”
16969: 
16970: “It was he, it was he!” cried Ahab, suddenly letting out his suspended
16971: breath.
16972: 
16973: “And harpoons sticking in near his starboard fin.”
16974: 
16975: “Aye, aye—they were mine—_my_ irons,” cried Ahab, exultingly—“but on!”
16976: 
16977: “Give me a chance, then,” said the Englishman, good-humoredly. “Well,
16978: this old great-grandfather, with the white head and hump, runs all
16979: afoam into the pod, and goes to snapping furiously at my fast-line!
16980: 
16981: “Aye, I see!—wanted to part it; free the fast-fish—an old trick—I know
16982: him.”
16983: 
16984: “How it was exactly,” continued the one-armed commander, “I do not
16985: know; but in biting the line, it got foul of his teeth, caught there
16986: somehow; but we didn’t know it then; so that when we afterwards pulled
16987: on the line, bounce we came plump on to his hump! instead of the other
16988: whale’s; that went off to windward, all fluking. Seeing how matters
16989: stood, and what a noble great whale it was—the noblest and biggest I
16990: ever saw, sir, in my life—I resolved to capture him, spite of the
16991: boiling rage he seemed to be in. And thinking the hap-hazard line would
16992: get loose, or the tooth it was tangled to might draw (for I have a
16993: devil of a boat’s crew for a pull on a whale-line); seeing all this, I
16994: say, I jumped into my first mate’s boat—Mr. Mounttop’s here (by the
16995: way, Captain—Mounttop; Mounttop—the captain);—as I was saying, I jumped
16996: into Mounttop’s boat, which, d’ye see, was gunwale and gunwale with
16997: mine, then; and snatching the first harpoon, let this old
16998: great-grandfather have it. But, Lord, look you, sir—hearts and souls
16999: alive, man—the next instant, in a jiff, I was blind as a bat—both eyes
17000: out—all befogged and bedeadened with black foam—the whale’s tail
17001: looming straight up out of it, perpendicular in the air, like a marble
17002: steeple. No use sterning all, then; but as I was groping at midday,
17003: with a blinding sun, all crown-jewels; as I was groping, I say, after
17004: the second iron, to toss it overboard—down comes the tail like a Lima
17005: tower, cutting my boat in two, leaving each half in splinters; and,
17006: flukes first, the white hump backed through the wreck, as though it was
17007: all chips. We all struck out. To escape his terrible flailings, I
17008: seized hold of my harpoon-pole sticking in him, and for a moment clung
17009: to that like a sucking fish. But a combing sea dashed me off, and at
17010: the same instant, the fish, taking one good dart forwards, went down
17011: like a flash; and the barb of that cursed second iron towing along near
17012: me caught me here” (clapping his hand just below his shoulder); “yes,
17013: caught me just here, I say, and bore me down to Hell’s flames, I was
17014: thinking; when, when, all of a sudden, thank the good God, the barb
17015: ript its way along the flesh—clear along the whole length of my
17016: arm—came out nigh my wrist, and up I floated;—and that gentleman there
17017: will tell you the rest (by the way, captain—Dr. Bunger, ship’s surgeon:
17018: Bunger, my lad,—the captain). Now, Bunger boy, spin your part of the
17019: yarn.”
17020: 
17021: The professional gentleman thus familiarly pointed out, had been all
17022: the time standing near them, with nothing specific visible, to denote
17023: his gentlemanly rank on board. His face was an exceedingly round but
17024: sober one; he was dressed in a faded blue woollen frock or shirt, and
17025: patched trowsers; and had thus far been dividing his attention between
17026: a marlingspike he held in one hand, and a pill-box held in the other,
17027: occasionally casting a critical glance at the ivory limbs of the two
17028: crippled captains. But, at his superior’s introduction of him to Ahab,
17029: he politely bowed, and straightway went on to do his captain’s bidding.
17030: 
17031: “It was a shocking bad wound,” began the whale-surgeon; “and, taking my
17032: advice, Captain Boomer here, stood our old Sammy—”
17033: 
17034: “Samuel Enderby is the name of my ship,” interrupted the one-armed
17035: captain, addressing Ahab; “go on, boy.”
17036: 
17037: “Stood our old Sammy off to the northward, to get out of the blazing
17038: hot weather there on the Line. But it was no use—I did all I could; sat
17039: up with him nights; was very severe with him in the matter of diet—”
17040: 
17041: “Oh, very severe!” chimed in the patient himself; then suddenly
17042: altering his voice, “Drinking hot rum toddies with me every night, till
17043: he couldn’t see to put on the bandages; and sending me to bed, half
17044: seas over, about three o’clock in the morning. Oh, ye stars! he sat up
17045: with me indeed, and was very severe in my diet. Oh! a great watcher,
17046: and very dietetically severe, is Dr. Bunger. (Bunger, you dog, laugh
17047: out! why don’t ye? You know you’re a precious jolly rascal.) But, heave
17048: ahead, boy, I’d rather be killed by you than kept alive by any other
17049: man.”
17050: 
17051: “My captain, you must have ere this perceived, respected sir”—said the
17052: imperturbable godly-looking Bunger, slightly bowing to Ahab—“is apt to
17053: be facetious at times; he spins us many clever things of that sort. But
17054: I may as well say—en passant, as the French remark—that I myself—that
17055: is to say, Jack Bunger, late of the reverend clergy—am a strict total
17056: abstinence man; I never drink—”
17057: 
17058: “Water!” cried the captain; “he never drinks it; it’s a sort of fits to
17059: him; fresh water throws him into the hydrophobia; but go on—go on with
17060: the arm story.”
17061: 
17062: “Yes, I may as well,” said the surgeon, coolly. “I was about observing,
17063: sir, before Captain Boomer’s facetious interruption, that spite of my
17064: best and severest endeavors, the wound kept getting worse and worse;
17065: the truth was, sir, it was as ugly gaping wound as surgeon ever saw;
17066: more than two feet and several inches long. I measured it with the lead
17067: line. In short, it grew black; I knew what was threatened, and off it
17068: came. But I had no hand in shipping that ivory arm there; that thing is
17069: against all rule”—pointing at it with the marlingspike—“that is the
17070: captain’s work, not mine; he ordered the carpenter to make it; he had
17071: that club-hammer there put to the end, to knock some one’s brains out
17072: with, I suppose, as he tried mine once. He flies into diabolical
17073: passions sometimes. Do ye see this dent, sir”—removing his hat, and
17074: brushing aside his hair, and exposing a bowl-like cavity in his skull,
17075: but which bore not the slightest scarry trace, or any token of ever
17076: having been a wound—“Well, the captain there will tell you how that
17077: came here; he knows.”
17078: 
17079: “No, I don’t,” said the captain, “but his mother did; he was born with
17080: it. Oh, you solemn rogue, you—you Bunger! was there ever such another
17081: Bunger in the watery world? Bunger, when you die, you ought to die in
17082: pickle, you dog; you should be preserved to future ages, you rascal.”
17083: 
17084: “What became of the White Whale?” now cried Ahab, who thus far had been
17085: impatiently listening to this by-play between the two Englishmen.
17086: 
17087: “Oh!” cried the one-armed captain, “oh, yes! Well; after he sounded, we
17088: didn’t see him again for some time; in fact, as I before hinted, I
17089: didn’t then know what whale it was that had served me such a trick,
17090: till some time afterwards, when coming back to the Line, we heard about
17091: Moby Dick—as some call him—and then I knew it was he.”
17092: 
17093: “Did’st thou cross his wake again?”
17094: 
17095: “Twice.”
17096: 
17097: “But could not fasten?”
17098: 
17099: “Didn’t want to try to: ain’t one limb enough? What should I do without
17100: this other arm? And I’m thinking Moby Dick doesn’t bite so much as he
17101: swallows.”
17102: 
17103: “Well, then,” interrupted Bunger, “give him your left arm for bait to
17104: get the right. Do you know, gentlemen”—very gravely and mathematically
17105: bowing to each Captain in succession—“Do you know, gentlemen, that the
17106: digestive organs of the whale are so inscrutably constructed by Divine
17107: Providence, that it is quite impossible for him to completely digest
17108: even a man’s arm? And he knows it too. So that what you take for the
17109: White Whale’s malice is only his awkwardness. For he never means to
17110: swallow a single limb; he only thinks to terrify by feints. But
17111: sometimes he is like the old juggling fellow, formerly a patient of
17112: mine in Ceylon, that making believe swallow jack-knives, once upon a
17113: time let one drop into him in good earnest, and there it stayed for a
17114: twelvemonth or more; when I gave him an emetic, and he heaved it up in
17115: small tacks, d’ye see. No possible way for him to digest that
17116: jack-knife, and fully incorporate it into his general bodily system.
17117: Yes, Captain Boomer, if you are quick enough about it, and have a mind
17118: to pawn one arm for the sake of the privilege of giving decent burial
17119: to the other, why in that case the arm is yours; only let the whale
17120: have another chance at you shortly, that’s all.”
17121: 
17122: “No, thank ye, Bunger,” said the English Captain, “he’s welcome to the
17123: arm he has, since I can’t help it, and didn’t know him then; but not to
17124: another one. No more White Whales for me; I’ve lowered for him once,
17125: and that has satisfied me. There would be great glory in killing him, I
17126: know that; and there is a ship-load of precious sperm in him, but, hark
17127: ye, he’s best let alone; don’t you think so, Captain?”—glancing at the
17128: ivory leg.
17129: 
17130: “He is. But he will still be hunted, for all that. What is best let
17131: alone, that accursed thing is not always what least allures. He’s all a
17132: magnet! How long since thou saw’st him last? Which way heading?”
17133: 
17134: “Bless my soul, and curse the foul fiend’s,” cried Bunger, stoopingly
17135: walking round Ahab, and like a dog, strangely snuffing; “this man’s
17136: blood—bring the thermometer!—it’s at the boiling point!—his pulse makes
17137: these planks beat!—sir!”—taking a lancet from his pocket, and drawing
17138: near to Ahab’s arm.
17139: 
17140: “Avast!” roared Ahab, dashing him against the bulwarks—“Man the boat!
17141: Which way heading?”
17142: 
17143: “Good God!” cried the English Captain, to whom the question was put.
17144: “What’s the matter? He was heading east, I think.—Is your Captain
17145: crazy?” whispering Fedallah.
17146: 
17147: But Fedallah, putting a finger on his lip, slid over the bulwarks to
17148: take the boat’s steering oar, and Ahab, swinging the cutting-tackle
17149: towards him, commanded the ship’s sailors to stand by to lower.
17150: 
17151: In a moment he was standing in the boat’s stern, and the Manilla men
17152: were springing to their oars. In vain the English Captain hailed him.
17153: With back to the stranger ship, and face set like a flint to his own,
17154: Ahab stood upright till alongside of the Pequod.
17155: 
17156: 
17157: CHAPTER 101. The Decanter.
17158: 
17159: Ere the English ship fades from sight, be it set down here, that she
17160: hailed from London, and was named after the late Samuel Enderby,
17161: merchant of that city, the original of the famous whaling house of
17162: Enderby & Sons; a house which in my poor whaleman’s opinion, comes not
17163: far behind the united royal houses of the Tudors and Bourbons, in point
17164: of real historical interest. How long, prior to the year of our Lord
17165: 1775, this great whaling house was in existence, my numerous
17166: fish-documents do not make plain; but in that year (1775) it fitted out
17167: the first English ships that ever regularly hunted the Sperm Whale;
17168: though for some score of years previous (ever since 1726) our valiant
17169: Coffins and Maceys of Nantucket and the Vineyard had in large fleets
17170: pursued that Leviathan, but only in the North and South Atlantic: not
17171: elsewhere. Be it distinctly recorded here, that the Nantucketers were
17172: the first among mankind to harpoon with civilized steel the great Sperm
17173: Whale; and that for half a century they were the only people of the
17174: whole globe who so harpooned him.
17175: 
17176: In 1778, a fine ship, the Amelia, fitted out for the express purpose,
17177: and at the sole charge of the vigorous Enderbys, boldly rounded Cape
17178: Horn, and was the first among the nations to lower a whale-boat of any
17179: sort in the great South Sea. The voyage was a skilful and lucky one;
17180: and returning to her berth with her hold full of the precious sperm,
17181: the Amelia’s example was soon followed by other ships, English and
17182: American, and thus the vast Sperm Whale grounds of the Pacific were
17183: thrown open. But not content with this good deed, the indefatigable
17184: house again bestirred itself: Samuel and all his Sons—how many, their
17185: mother only knows—and under their immediate auspices, and partly, I
17186: think, at their expense, the British government was induced to send the
17187: sloop-of-war Rattler on a whaling voyage of discovery into the South
17188: Sea. Commanded by a naval Post-Captain, the Rattler made a rattling
17189: voyage of it, and did some service; how much does not appear. But this
17190: is not all. In 1819, the same house fitted out a discovery whale ship
17191: of their own, to go on a tasting cruise to the remote waters of Japan.
17192: That ship—well called the “Syren”—made a noble experimental cruise; and
17193: it was thus that the great Japanese Whaling Ground first became
17194: generally known. The Syren in this famous voyage was commanded by a
17195: Captain Coffin, a Nantucketer.
17196: 
17197: All honor to the Enderbies, therefore, whose house, I think, exists to
17198: the present day; though doubtless the original Samuel must long ago
17199: have slipped his cable for the great South Sea of the other world.
17200: 
17201: The ship named after him was worthy of the honor, being a very fast
17202: sailer and a noble craft every way. I boarded her once at midnight
17203: somewhere off the Patagonian coast, and drank good flip down in the
17204: forecastle. It was a fine gam we had, and they were all trumps—every
17205: soul on board. A short life to them, and a jolly death. And that fine
17206: gam I had—long, very long after old Ahab touched her planks with his
17207: ivory heel—it minds me of the noble, solid, Saxon hospitality of that
17208: ship; and may my parson forget me, and the devil remember me, if I ever
17209: lose sight of it. Flip? Did I say we had flip? Yes, and we flipped it
17210: at the rate of ten gallons the hour; and when the squall came (for it’s
17211: squally off there by Patagonia), and all hands—visitors and all—were
17212: called to reef topsails, we were so top-heavy that we had to swing each
17213: other aloft in bowlines; and we ignorantly furled the skirts of our
17214: jackets into the sails, so that we hung there, reefed fast in the
17215: howling gale, a warning example to all drunken tars. However, the masts
17216: did not go overboard; and by and by we scrambled down, so sober, that
17217: we had to pass the flip again, though the savage salt spray bursting
17218: down the forecastle scuttle, rather too much diluted and pickled it to
17219: my taste.
17220: 
17221: The beef was fine—tough, but with body in it. They said it was
17222: bull-beef; others, that it was dromedary beef; but I do not know, for
17223: certain, how that was. They had dumplings too; small, but substantial,
17224: symmetrically globular, and indestructible dumplings. I fancied that
17225: you could feel them, and roll them about in you after they were
17226: swallowed. If you stooped over too far forward, you risked their
17227: pitching out of you like billiard-balls. The bread—but that couldn’t be
17228: helped; besides, it was an anti-scorbutic; in short, the bread
17229: contained the only fresh fare they had. But the forecastle was not very
17230: light, and it was very easy to step over into a dark corner when you
17231: ate it. But all in all, taking her from truck to helm, considering the
17232: dimensions of the cook’s boilers, including his own live parchment
17233: boilers; fore and aft, I say, the Samuel Enderby was a jolly ship; of
17234: good fare and plenty; fine flip and strong; crack fellows all, and
17235: capital from boot heels to hat-band.
17236: 
17237: But why was it, think ye, that the Samuel Enderby, and some other
17238: English whalers I know of—not all though—were such famous, hospitable
17239: ships; that passed round the beef, and the bread, and the can, and the
17240: joke; and were not soon weary of eating, and drinking, and laughing? I
17241: will tell you. The abounding good cheer of these English whalers is
17242: matter for historical research. Nor have I been at all sparing of
17243: historical whale research, when it has seemed needed.
17244: 
17245: The English were preceded in the whale fishery by the Hollanders,
17246: Zealanders, and Danes; from whom they derived many terms still extant
17247: in the fishery; and what is yet more, their fat old fashions, touching
17248: plenty to eat and drink. For, as a general thing, the English
17249: merchant-ship scrimps her crew; but not so the English whaler. Hence,
17250: in the English, this thing of whaling good cheer is not normal and
17251: natural, but incidental and particular; and, therefore, must have some
17252: special origin, which is here pointed out, and will be still further
17253: elucidated.
17254: 
17255: During my researches in the Leviathanic histories, I stumbled upon an
17256: ancient Dutch volume, which, by the musty whaling smell of it, I knew
17257: must be about whalers. The title was, “Dan Coopman,” wherefore I
17258: concluded that this must be the invaluable memoirs of some Amsterdam
17259: cooper in the fishery, as every whale ship must carry its cooper. I was
17260: reinforced in this opinion by seeing that it was the production of one
17261: “Fitz Swackhammer.” But my friend Dr. Snodhead, a very learned man,
17262: professor of Low Dutch and High German in the college of Santa Claus
17263: and St. Pott’s, to whom I handed the work for translation, giving him a
17264: box of sperm candles for his trouble—this same Dr. Snodhead, so soon as
17265: he spied the book, assured me that “Dan Coopman” did not mean “The
17266: Cooper,” but “The Merchant.” In short, this ancient and learned Low
17267: Dutch book treated of the commerce of Holland; and, among other
17268: subjects, contained a very interesting account of its whale fishery.
17269: And in this chapter it was, headed, “Smeer,” or “Fat,” that I found a
17270: long detailed list of the outfits for the larders and cellars of 180
17271: sail of Dutch whalemen; from which list, as translated by Dr. Snodhead,
17272: I transcribe the following:
17273: 
17274: 400,000 lbs. of beef. 60,000 lbs. Friesland pork. 150,000 lbs. of stock
17275: fish. 550,000 lbs. of biscuit. 72,000 lbs. of soft bread. 2,800 firkins
17276: of butter. 20,000 lbs. Texel & Leyden cheese. 144,000 lbs. cheese
17277: (probably an inferior article). 550 ankers of Geneva. 10,800 barrels of
17278: beer.
17279: 
17280: Most statistical tables are parchingly dry in the reading; not so in
17281: the present case, however, where the reader is flooded with whole
17282: pipes, barrels, quarts, and gills of good gin and good cheer.
17283: 
17284: At the time, I devoted three days to the studious digesting of all this
17285: beer, beef, and bread, during which many profound thoughts were
17286: incidentally suggested to me, capable of a transcendental and Platonic
17287: application; and, furthermore, I compiled supplementary tables of my
17288: own, touching the probable quantity of stock-fish, etc., consumed by
17289: every Low Dutch harpooneer in that ancient Greenland and Spitzbergen
17290: whale fishery. In the first place, the amount of butter, and Texel and
17291: Leyden cheese consumed, seems amazing. I impute it, though, to their
17292: naturally unctuous natures, being rendered still more unctuous by the
17293: nature of their vocation, and especially by their pursuing their game
17294: in those frigid Polar Seas, on the very coasts of that Esquimaux
17295: country where the convivial natives pledge each other in bumpers of
17296: train oil.
17297: 
17298: The quantity of beer, too, is very large, 10,800 barrels. Now, as those
17299: polar fisheries could only be prosecuted in the short summer of that
17300: climate, so that the whole cruise of one of these Dutch whalemen,
17301: including the short voyage to and from the Spitzbergen sea, did not
17302: much exceed three months, say, and reckoning 30 men to each of their
17303: fleet of 180 sail, we have 5,400 Low Dutch seamen in all; therefore, I
17304: say, we have precisely two barrels of beer per man, for a twelve weeks’
17305: allowance, exclusive of his fair proportion of that 550 ankers of gin.
17306: Now, whether these gin and beer harpooneers, so fuddled as one might
17307: fancy them to have been, were the right sort of men to stand up in a
17308: boat’s head, and take good aim at flying whales; this would seem
17309: somewhat improbable. Yet they did aim at them, and hit them too. But
17310: this was very far North, be it remembered, where beer agrees well with
17311: the constitution; upon the Equator, in our southern fishery, beer would
17312: be apt to make the harpooneer sleepy at the mast-head and boozy in his
17313: boat; and grievous loss might ensue to Nantucket and New Bedford.
17314: 
17315: But no more; enough has been said to show that the old Dutch whalers of
17316: two or three centuries ago were high livers; and that the English
17317: whalers have not neglected so excellent an example. For, say they, when
17318: cruising in an empty ship, if you can get nothing better out of the
17319: world, get a good dinner out of it, at least. And this empties the
17320: decanter.
17321: 
17322: 
17323: CHAPTER 102. A Bower in the Arsacides.
17324: 
17325: Hitherto, in descriptively treating of the Sperm Whale, I have chiefly
17326: dwelt upon the marvels of his outer aspect; or separately and in detail
17327: upon some few interior structural features. But to a large and thorough
17328: sweeping comprehension of him, it behooves me now to unbutton him still
17329: further, and untagging the points of his hose, unbuckling his garters,
17330: and casting loose the hooks and the eyes of the joints of his innermost
17331: bones, set him before you in his ultimatum; that is to say, in his
17332: unconditional skeleton.
17333: 
17334: But how now, Ishmael? How is it, that you, a mere oarsman in the
17335: fishery, pretend to know aught about the subterranean parts of the
17336: whale? Did erudite Stubb, mounted upon your capstan, deliver lectures
17337: on the anatomy of the Cetacea; and by help of the windlass, hold up a
17338: specimen rib for exhibition? Explain thyself, Ishmael. Can you land a
17339: full-grown whale on your deck for examination, as a cook dishes a
17340: roast-pig? Surely not. A veritable witness have you hitherto been,
17341: Ishmael; but have a care how you seize the privilege of Jonah alone;
17342: the privilege of discoursing upon the joists and beams; the rafters,
17343: ridge-pole, sleepers, and under-pinnings, making up the frame-work of
17344: leviathan; and belike of the tallow-vats, dairy-rooms, butteries, and
17345: cheeseries in his bowels.
17346: 
17347: I confess, that since Jonah, few whalemen have penetrated very far
17348: beneath the skin of the adult whale; nevertheless, I have been blessed
17349: with an opportunity to dissect him in miniature. In a ship I belonged
17350: to, a small cub Sperm Whale was once bodily hoisted to the deck for his
17351: poke or bag, to make sheaths for the barbs of the harpoons, and for the
17352: heads of the lances. Think you I let that chance go, without using my
17353: boat-hatchet and jack-knife, and breaking the seal and reading all the
17354: contents of that young cub?
17355: 
17356: And as for my exact knowledge of the bones of the leviathan in their
17357: gigantic, full grown development, for that rare knowledge I am indebted
17358: to my late royal friend Tranquo, king of Tranque, one of the Arsacides.
17359: For being at Tranque, years ago, when attached to the trading-ship Dey
17360: of Algiers, I was invited to spend part of the Arsacidean holidays with
17361: the lord of Tranque, at his retired palm villa at Pupella; a sea-side
17362: glen not very far distant from what our sailors called Bamboo-Town, his
17363: capital.
17364: 
17365: Among many other fine qualities, my royal friend Tranquo, being gifted
17366: with a devout love for all matters of barbaric vertu, had brought
17367: together in Pupella whatever rare things the more ingenious of his
17368: people could invent; chiefly carved woods of wonderful devices,
17369: chiselled shells, inlaid spears, costly paddles, aromatic canoes; and
17370: all these distributed among whatever natural wonders, the
17371: wonder-freighted, tribute-rendering waves had cast upon his shores.
17372: 
17373: Chief among these latter was a great Sperm Whale, which, after an
17374: unusually long raging gale, had been found dead and stranded, with his
17375: head against a cocoa-nut tree, whose plumage-like, tufted droopings
17376: seemed his verdant jet. When the vast body had at last been stripped of
17377: its fathom-deep enfoldings, and the bones become dust dry in the sun,
17378: then the skeleton was carefully transported up the Pupella glen, where
17379: a grand temple of lordly palms now sheltered it.
17380: 
17381: The ribs were hung with trophies; the vertebræ were carved with
17382: Arsacidean annals, in strange hieroglyphics; in the skull, the priests
17383: kept up an unextinguished aromatic flame, so that the mystic head again
17384: sent forth its vapory spout; while, suspended from a bough, the
17385: terrific lower jaw vibrated over all the devotees, like the hair-hung
17386: sword that so affrighted Damocles.
17387: 
17388: It was a wondrous sight. The wood was green as mosses of the Icy Glen;
17389: the trees stood high and haughty, feeling their living sap; the
17390: industrious earth beneath was as a weaver’s loom, with a gorgeous
17391: carpet on it, whereof the ground-vine tendrils formed the warp and
17392: woof, and the living flowers the figures. All the trees, with all their
17393: laden branches; all the shrubs, and ferns, and grasses; the
17394: message-carrying air; all these unceasingly were active. Through the
17395: lacings of the leaves, the great sun seemed a flying shuttle weaving
17396: the unwearied verdure. Oh, busy weaver! unseen weaver!—pause!—one
17397: word!—whither flows the fabric? what palace may it deck? wherefore all
17398: these ceaseless toilings? Speak, weaver!—stay thy hand!—but one single
17399: word with thee! Nay—the shuttle flies—the figures float from forth the
17400: loom; the freshet-rushing carpet for ever slides away. The weaver-god,
17401: he weaves; and by that weaving is he deafened, that he hears no mortal
17402: voice; and by that humming, we, too, who look on the loom are deafened;
17403: and only when we escape it shall we hear the thousand voices that speak
17404: through it. For even so it is in all material factories. The spoken
17405: words that are inaudible among the flying spindles; those same words
17406: are plainly heard without the walls, bursting from the opened
17407: casements. Thereby have villainies been detected. Ah, mortal! then, be
17408: heedful; for so, in all this din of the great world’s loom, thy
17409: subtlest thinkings may be overheard afar.
17410: 
17411: Now, amid the green, life-restless loom of that Arsacidean wood, the
17412: great, white, worshipped skeleton lay lounging—a gigantic idler! Yet,
17413: as the ever-woven verdant warp and woof intermixed and hummed around
17414: him, the mighty idler seemed the cunning weaver; himself all woven over
17415: with the vines; every month assuming greener, fresher verdure; but
17416: himself a skeleton. Life folded Death; Death trellised Life; the grim
17417: god wived with youthful Life, and begat him curly-headed glories.
17418: 
17419: Now, when with royal Tranquo I visited this wondrous whale, and saw the
17420: skull an altar, and the artificial smoke ascending from where the real
17421: jet had issued, I marvelled that the king should regard a chapel as an
17422: object of vertu. He laughed. But more I marvelled that the priests
17423: should swear that smoky jet of his was genuine. To and fro I paced
17424: before this skeleton—brushed the vines aside—broke through the ribs—and
17425: with a ball of Arsacidean twine, wandered, eddied long amid its many
17426: winding, shaded colonnades and arbours. But soon my line was out; and
17427: following it back, I emerged from the opening where I entered. I saw no
17428: living thing within; naught was there but bones.
17429: 
17430: Cutting me a green measuring-rod, I once more dived within the
17431: skeleton. From their arrow-slit in the skull, the priests perceived me
17432: taking the altitude of the final rib, “How now!” they shouted; “Dar’st
17433: thou measure this our god! That’s for us.” “Aye, priests—well, how long
17434: do ye make him, then?” But hereupon a fierce contest rose among them,
17435: concerning feet and inches; they cracked each other’s sconces with
17436: their yard-sticks—the great skull echoed—and seizing that lucky chance,
17437: I quickly concluded my own admeasurements.
17438: 
17439: These admeasurements I now propose to set before you. But first, be it
17440: recorded, that, in this matter, I am not free to utter any fancied
17441: measurement I please. Because there are skeleton authorities you can
17442: refer to, to test my accuracy. There is a Leviathanic Museum, they tell
17443: me, in Hull, England, one of the whaling ports of that country, where
17444: they have some fine specimens of fin-backs and other whales. Likewise,
17445: I have heard that in the museum of Manchester, in New Hampshire, they
17446: have what the proprietors call “the only perfect specimen of a
17447: Greenland or River Whale in the United States.” Moreover, at a place in
17448: Yorkshire, England, Burton Constable by name, a certain Sir Clifford
17449: Constable has in his possession the skeleton of a Sperm Whale, but of
17450: moderate size, by no means of the full-grown magnitude of my friend
17451: King Tranquo’s.
17452: 
17453: In both cases, the stranded whales to which these two skeletons
17454: belonged, were originally claimed by their proprietors upon similar
17455: grounds. King Tranquo seizing his because he wanted it; and Sir
17456: Clifford, because he was lord of the seignories of those parts. Sir
17457: Clifford’s whale has been articulated throughout; so that, like a great
17458: chest of drawers, you can open and shut him, in all his bony
17459: cavities—spread out his ribs like a gigantic fan—and swing all day upon
17460: his lower jaw. Locks are to be put upon some of his trap-doors and
17461: shutters; and a footman will show round future visitors with a bunch of
17462: keys at his side. Sir Clifford thinks of charging twopence for a peep
17463: at the whispering gallery in the spinal column; threepence to hear the
17464: echo in the hollow of his cerebellum; and sixpence for the unrivalled
17465: view from his forehead.
17466: 
17467: The skeleton dimensions I shall now proceed to set down are copied
17468: verbatim from my right arm, where I had them tattooed; as in my wild
17469: wanderings at that period, there was no other secure way of preserving
17470: such valuable statistics. But as I was crowded for space, and wished
17471: the other parts of my body to remain a blank page for a poem I was then
17472: composing—at least, what untattooed parts might remain—I did not
17473: trouble myself with the odd inches; nor, indeed, should inches at all
17474: enter into a congenial admeasurement of the whale.
17475: 
17476: 
17477: CHAPTER 103. Measurement of The Whale’s Skeleton.
17478: 
17479: In the first place, I wish to lay before you a particular, plain
17480: statement, touching the living bulk of this leviathan, whose skeleton
17481: we are briefly to exhibit. Such a statement may prove useful here.
17482: 
17483: According to a careful calculation I have made, and which I partly base
17484: upon Captain Scoresby’s estimate, of seventy tons for the largest sized
17485: Greenland whale of sixty feet in length; according to my careful
17486: calculation, I say, a Sperm Whale of the largest magnitude, between
17487: eighty-five and ninety feet in length, and something less than forty
17488: feet in its fullest circumference, such a whale will weigh at least
17489: ninety tons; so that, reckoning thirteen men to a ton, he would
17490: considerably outweigh the combined population of a whole village of one
17491: thousand one hundred inhabitants.
17492: 
17493: Think you not then that brains, like yoked cattle, should be put to
17494: this leviathan, to make him at all budge to any landsman’s imagination?
17495: 
17496: Having already in various ways put before you his skull, spout-hole,
17497: jaw, teeth, tail, forehead, fins, and divers other parts, I shall now
17498: simply point out what is most interesting in the general bulk of his
17499: unobstructed bones. But as the colossal skull embraces so very large a
17500: proportion of the entire extent of the skeleton; as it is by far the
17501: most complicated part; and as nothing is to be repeated concerning it
17502: in this chapter, you must not fail to carry it in your mind, or under
17503: your arm, as we proceed, otherwise you will not gain a complete notion
17504: of the general structure we are about to view.
17505: 
17506: In length, the Sperm Whale’s skeleton at Tranque measured seventy-two
17507: feet; so that when fully invested and extended in life, he must have
17508: been ninety feet long; for in the whale, the skeleton loses about one
17509: fifth in length compared with the living body. Of this seventy-two
17510: feet, his skull and jaw comprised some twenty feet, leaving some fifty
17511: feet of plain back-bone. Attached to this back-bone, for something less
17512: than a third of its length, was the mighty circular basket of ribs
17513: which once enclosed his vitals.
17514: 
17515: To me this vast ivory-ribbed chest, with the long, unrelieved spine,
17516: extending far away from it in a straight line, not a little resembled
17517: the hull of a great ship new-laid upon the stocks, when only some
17518: twenty of her naked bow-ribs are inserted, and the keel is otherwise,
17519: for the time, but a long, disconnected timber.
17520: 
17521: The ribs were ten on a side. The first, to begin from the neck, was
17522: nearly six feet long; the second, third, and fourth were each
17523: successively longer, till you came to the climax of the fifth, or one
17524: of the middle ribs, which measured eight feet and some inches. From
17525: that part, the remaining ribs diminished, till the tenth and last only
17526: spanned five feet and some inches. In general thickness, they all bore
17527: a seemly correspondence to their length. The middle ribs were the most
17528: arched. In some of the Arsacides they are used for beams whereon to lay
17529: footpath bridges over small streams.
17530: 
17531: In considering these ribs, I could not but be struck anew with the
17532: circumstance, so variously repeated in this book, that the skeleton of
17533: the whale is by no means the mould of his invested form. The largest of
17534: the Tranque ribs, one of the middle ones, occupied that part of the
17535: fish which, in life, is greatest in depth. Now, the greatest depth of
17536: the invested body of this particular whale must have been at least
17537: sixteen feet; whereas, the corresponding rib measured but little more
17538: than eight feet. So that this rib only conveyed half of the true notion
17539: of the living magnitude of that part. Besides, for some way, where I
17540: now saw but a naked spine, all that had been once wrapped round with
17541: tons of added bulk in flesh, muscle, blood, and bowels. Still more, for
17542: the ample fins, I here saw but a few disordered joints; and in place of
17543: the weighty and majestic, but boneless flukes, an utter blank!
17544: 
17545: How vain and foolish, then, thought I, for timid untravelled man to try
17546: to comprehend aright this wondrous whale, by merely poring over his
17547: dead attenuated skeleton, stretched in this peaceful wood. No. Only in
17548: the heart of quickest perils; only when within the eddyings of his
17549: angry flukes; only on the profound unbounded sea, can the fully
17550: invested whale be truly and livingly found out.
17551: 
17552: But the spine. For that, the best way we can consider it is, with a
17553: crane, to pile its bones high up on end. No speedy enterprise. But now
17554: it’s done, it looks much like Pompey’s Pillar.
17555: 
17556: There are forty and odd vertebræ in all, which in the skeleton are not
17557: locked together. They mostly lie like the great knobbed blocks on a
17558: Gothic spire, forming solid courses of heavy masonry. The largest, a
17559: middle one, is in width something less than three feet, and in depth
17560: more than four. The smallest, where the spine tapers away into the
17561: tail, is only two inches in width, and looks something like a white
17562: billiard-ball. I was told that there were still smaller ones, but they
17563: had been lost by some little cannibal urchins, the priest’s children,
17564: who had stolen them to play marbles with. Thus we see how that the
17565: spine of even the hugest of living things tapers off at last into
17566: simple child’s play.
17567: 
17568: 
17569: CHAPTER 104. The Fossil Whale.
17570: 
17571: From his mighty bulk the whale affords a most congenial theme whereon
17572: to enlarge, amplify, and generally expatiate. Would you, you could not
17573: compress him. By good rights he should only be treated of in imperial
17574: folio. Not to tell over again his furlongs from spiracle to tail, and
17575: the yards he measures about the waist; only think of the gigantic
17576: involutions of his intestines, where they lie in him like great cables
17577: and hawsers coiled away in the subterranean orlop-deck of a
17578: line-of-battle-ship.
17579: 
17580: Since I have undertaken to manhandle this Leviathan, it behooves me to
17581: approve myself omnisciently exhaustive in the enterprise; not
17582: overlooking the minutest seminal germs of his blood, and spinning him
17583: out to the uttermost coil of his bowels. Having already described him
17584: in most of his present habitatory and anatomical peculiarities, it now
17585: remains to magnify him in an archæological, fossiliferous, and
17586: antediluvian point of view. Applied to any other creature than the
17587: Leviathan—to an ant or a flea—such portly terms might justly be deemed
17588: unwarrantably grandiloquent. But when Leviathan is the text, the case
17589: is altered. Fain am I to stagger to this emprise under the weightiest
17590: words of the dictionary. And here be it said, that whenever it has been
17591: convenient to consult one in the course of these dissertations, I have
17592: invariably used a huge quarto edition of Johnson, expressly purchased
17593: for that purpose; because that famous lexicographer’s uncommon personal
17594: bulk more fitted him to compile a lexicon to be used by a whale author
17595: like me.
17596: 
17597: One often hears of writers that rise and swell with their subject,
17598: though it may seem but an ordinary one. How, then, with me, writing of
17599: this Leviathan? Unconsciously my chirography expands into placard
17600: capitals. Give me a condor’s quill! Give me Vesuvius’ crater for an
17601: inkstand! Friends, hold my arms! For in the mere act of penning my
17602: thoughts of this Leviathan, they weary me, and make me faint with their
17603: outreaching comprehensiveness of sweep, as if to include the whole
17604: circle of the sciences, and all the generations of whales, and men, and
17605: mastodons, past, present, and to come, with all the revolving panoramas
17606: of empire on earth, and throughout the whole universe, not excluding
17607: its suburbs. Such, and so magnifying, is the virtue of a large and
17608: liberal theme! We expand to its bulk. To produce a mighty book, you
17609: must choose a mighty theme. No great and enduring volume can ever be
17610: written on the flea, though many there be who have tried it.
17611: 
17612: Ere entering upon the subject of Fossil Whales, I present my
17613: credentials as a geologist, by stating that in my miscellaneous time I
17614: have been a stone-mason, and also a great digger of ditches, canals and
17615: wells, wine-vaults, cellars, and cisterns of all sorts. Likewise, by
17616: way of preliminary, I desire to remind the reader, that while in the
17617: earlier geological strata there are found the fossils of monsters now
17618: almost completely extinct; the subsequent relics discovered in what are
17619: called the Tertiary formations seem the connecting, or at any rate
17620: intercepted links, between the antichronical creatures, and those whose
17621: remote posterity are said to have entered the Ark; all the Fossil
17622: Whales hitherto discovered belong to the Tertiary period, which is the
17623: last preceding the superficial formations. And though none of them
17624: precisely answer to any known species of the present time, they are yet
17625: sufficiently akin to them in general respects, to justify their taking
17626: rank as Cetacean fossils.
17627: 
17628: Detached broken fossils of pre-adamite whales, fragments of their bones
17629: and skeletons, have within thirty years past, at various intervals,
17630: been found at the base of the Alps, in Lombardy, in France, in England,
17631: in Scotland, and in the States of Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama.
17632: Among the more curious of such remains is part of a skull, which in the
17633: year 1779 was disinterred in the Rue Dauphine in Paris, a short street
17634: opening almost directly upon the palace of the Tuileries; and bones
17635: disinterred in excavating the great docks of Antwerp, in Napoleon’s
17636: time. Cuvier pronounced these fragments to have belonged to some
17637: utterly unknown Leviathanic species.
17638: 
17639: But by far the most wonderful of all Cetacean relics was the almost
17640: complete vast skeleton of an extinct monster, found in the year 1842,
17641: on the plantation of Judge Creagh, in Alabama. The awe-stricken
17642: credulous slaves in the vicinity took it for the bones of one of the
17643: fallen angels. The Alabama doctors declared it a huge reptile, and
17644: bestowed upon it the name of Basilosaurus. But some specimen bones of
17645: it being taken across the sea to Owen, the English Anatomist, it turned
17646: out that this alleged reptile was a whale, though of a departed
17647: species. A significant illustration of the fact, again and again
17648: repeated in this book, that the skeleton of the whale furnishes but
17649: little clue to the shape of his fully invested body. So Owen
17650: rechristened the monster Zeuglodon; and in his paper read before the
17651: London Geological Society, pronounced it, in substance, one of the most
17652: extraordinary creatures which the mutations of the globe have blotted
17653: out of existence.
17654: 
17655: When I stand among these mighty Leviathan skeletons, skulls, tusks,
17656: jaws, ribs, and vertebræ, all characterized by partial resemblances to
17657: the existing breeds of sea-monsters; but at the same time bearing on
17658: the other hand similar affinities to the annihilated antichronical
17659: Leviathans, their incalculable seniors; I am, by a flood, borne back to
17660: that wondrous period, ere time itself can be said to have begun; for
17661: time began with man. Here Saturn’s grey chaos rolls over me, and I
17662: obtain dim, shuddering glimpses into those Polar eternities; when
17663: wedged bastions of ice pressed hard upon what are now the Tropics; and
17664: in all the 25,000 miles of this world’s circumference, not an
17665: inhabitable hand’s breadth of land was visible. Then the whole world
17666: was the whale’s; and, king of creation, he left his wake along the
17667: present lines of the Andes and the Himmalehs. Who can show a pedigree
17668: like Leviathan? Ahab’s harpoon had shed older blood than the Pharaoh’s.
17669: Methuselah seems a school-boy. I look round to shake hands with Shem. I
17670: am horror-struck at this antemosaic, unsourced existence of the
17671: unspeakable terrors of the whale, which, having been before all time,
17672: must needs exist after all humane ages are over.
17673: 
17674: But not alone has this Leviathan left his pre-adamite traces in the
17675: stereotype plates of nature, and in limestone and marl bequeathed his
17676: ancient bust; but upon Egyptian tablets, whose antiquity seems to claim
17677: for them an almost fossiliferous character, we find the unmistakable
17678: print of his fin. In an apartment of the great temple of Denderah, some
17679: fifty years ago, there was discovered upon the granite ceiling a
17680: sculptured and painted planisphere, abounding in centaurs, griffins,
17681: and dolphins, similar to the grotesque figures on the celestial globe
17682: of the moderns. Gliding among them, old Leviathan swam as of yore; was
17683: there swimming in that planisphere, centuries before Solomon was
17684: cradled.
17685: 
17686: Nor must there be omitted another strange attestation of the antiquity
17687: of the whale, in his own osseous post-diluvian reality, as set down by
17688: the venerable John Leo, the old Barbary traveller.
17689: 
17690: “Not far from the Sea-side, they have a Temple, the Rafters and Beams
17691: of which are made of Whale-Bones; for Whales of a monstrous size are
17692: oftentimes cast up dead upon that shore. The Common People imagine,
17693: that by a secret Power bestowed by God upon the Temple, no Whale can
17694: pass it without immediate death. But the truth of the Matter is, that
17695: on either side of the Temple, there are Rocks that shoot two Miles into
17696: the Sea, and wound the Whales when they light upon ’em. They keep a
17697: Whale’s Rib of an incredible length for a Miracle, which lying upon the
17698: Ground with its convex part uppermost, makes an Arch, the Head of which
17699: cannot be reached by a Man upon a Camel’s Back. This Rib (says John
17700: Leo) is said to have layn there a hundred Years before I saw it. Their
17701: Historians affirm, that a Prophet who prophesy’d of Mahomet, came from
17702: this Temple, and some do not stand to assert, that the Prophet Jonas
17703: was cast forth by the Whale at the Base of the Temple.”
17704: 
17705: In this Afric Temple of the Whale I leave you, reader, and if you be a
17706: Nantucketer, and a whaleman, you will silently worship there.
17707: 
17708: 
17709: CHAPTER 105. Does the Whale’s Magnitude Diminish?—Will He Perish?
17710: 
17711: Inasmuch, then, as this Leviathan comes floundering down upon us from
17712: the head-waters of the Eternities, it may be fitly inquired, whether,
17713: in the long course of his generations, he has not degenerated from the
17714: original bulk of his sires.
17715: 
17716: But upon investigation we find, that not only are the whales of the
17717: present day superior in magnitude to those whose fossil remains are
17718: found in the Tertiary system (embracing a distinct geological period
17719: prior to man), but of the whales found in that Tertiary system, those
17720: belonging to its latter formations exceed in size those of its earlier
17721: ones.
17722: 
17723: Of all the pre-adamite whales yet exhumed, by far the largest is the
17724: Alabama one mentioned in the last chapter, and that was less than
17725: seventy feet in length in the skeleton. Whereas, we have already seen,
17726: that the tape-measure gives seventy-two feet for the skeleton of a
17727: large sized modern whale. And I have heard, on whalemen’s authority,
17728: that Sperm Whales have been captured near a hundred feet long at the
17729: time of capture.
17730: 
17731: But may it not be, that while the whales of the present hour are an
17732: advance in magnitude upon those of all previous geological periods; may
17733: it not be, that since Adam’s time they have degenerated?
17734: 
17735: Assuredly, we must conclude so, if we are to credit the accounts of
17736: such gentlemen as Pliny, and the ancient naturalists generally. For
17737: Pliny tells us of whales that embraced acres of living bulk, and
17738: Aldrovandus of others which measured eight hundred feet in length—Rope
17739: Walks and Thames Tunnels of Whales! And even in the days of Banks and
17740: Solander, Cooke’s naturalists, we find a Danish member of the Academy
17741: of Sciences setting down certain Iceland Whales (reydan-siskur, or
17742: Wrinkled Bellies) at one hundred and twenty yards; that is, three
17743: hundred and sixty feet. And Lacépède, the French naturalist, in his
17744: elaborate history of whales, in the very beginning of his work (page
17745: 3), sets down the Right Whale at one hundred metres, three hundred and
17746: twenty-eight feet. And this work was published so late as A.D. 1825.
17747: 
17748: But will any whaleman believe these stories? No. The whale of to-day is
17749: as big as his ancestors in Pliny’s time. And if ever I go where Pliny
17750: is, I, a whaleman (more than he was), will make bold to tell him so.
17751: Because I cannot understand how it is, that while the Egyptian mummies
17752: that were buried thousands of years before even Pliny was born, do not
17753: measure so much in their coffins as a modern Kentuckian in his socks;
17754: and while the cattle and other animals sculptured on the oldest
17755: Egyptian and Nineveh tablets, by the relative proportions in which they
17756: are drawn, just as plainly prove that the high-bred, stall-fed, prize
17757: cattle of Smithfield, not only equal, but far exceed in magnitude the
17758: fattest of Pharaoh’s fat kine; in the face of all this, I will not
17759: admit that of all animals the whale alone should have degenerated.
17760: 
17761: But still another inquiry remains; one often agitated by the more
17762: recondite Nantucketers. Whether owing to the almost omniscient
17763: look-outs at the mast-heads of the whale-ships, now penetrating even
17764: through Behring’s straits, and into the remotest secret drawers and
17765: lockers of the world; and the thousand harpoons and lances darted along
17766: all continental coasts; the moot point is, whether Leviathan can long
17767: endure so wide a chase, and so remorseless a havoc; whether he must not
17768: at last be exterminated from the waters, and the last whale, like the
17769: last man, smoke his last pipe, and then himself evaporate in the final
17770: puff.
17771: 
17772: Comparing the humped herds of whales with the humped herds of buffalo,
17773: which, not forty years ago, overspread by tens of thousands the
17774: prairies of Illinois and Missouri, and shook their iron manes and
17775: scowled with their thunder-clotted brows upon the sites of populous
17776: river-capitals, where now the polite broker sells you land at a dollar
17777: an inch; in such a comparison an irresistible argument would seem
17778: furnished, to show that the hunted whale cannot now escape speedy
17779: extinction.
17780: 
17781: But you must look at this matter in every light. Though so short a
17782: period ago—not a good lifetime—the census of the buffalo in Illinois
17783: exceeded the census of men now in London, and though at the present day
17784: not one horn or hoof of them remains in all that region; and though the
17785: cause of this wondrous extermination was the spear of man; yet the far
17786: different nature of the whale-hunt peremptorily forbids so inglorious
17787: an end to the Leviathan. Forty men in one ship hunting the Sperm Whales
17788: for forty-eight months think they have done extremely well, and thank
17789: God, if at last they carry home the oil of forty fish. Whereas, in the
17790: days of the old Canadian and Indian hunters and trappers of the West,
17791: when the far west (in whose sunset suns still rise) was a wilderness
17792: and a virgin, the same number of moccasined men, for the same number of
17793: months, mounted on horse instead of sailing in ships, would have slain
17794: not forty, but forty thousand and more buffaloes; a fact that, if need
17795: were, could be statistically stated.
17796: 
17797: Nor, considered aright, does it seem any argument in favour of the
17798: gradual extinction of the Sperm Whale, for example, that in former
17799: years (the latter part of the last century, say) these Leviathans, in
17800: small pods, were encountered much oftener than at present, and, in
17801: consequence, the voyages were not so prolonged, and were also much more
17802: remunerative. Because, as has been elsewhere noticed, those whales,
17803: influenced by some views to safety, now swim the seas in immense
17804: caravans, so that to a large degree the scattered solitaries, yokes,
17805: and pods, and schools of other days are now aggregated into vast but
17806: widely separated, unfrequent armies. That is all. And equally
17807: fallacious seems the conceit, that because the so-called whale-bone
17808: whales no longer haunt many grounds in former years abounding with
17809: them, hence that species also is declining. For they are only being
17810: driven from promontory to cape; and if one coast is no longer enlivened
17811: with their jets, then, be sure, some other and remoter strand has been
17812: very recently startled by the unfamiliar spectacle.
17813: 
17814: Furthermore: concerning these last mentioned Leviathans, they have two
17815: firm fortresses, which, in all human probability, will for ever remain
17816: impregnable. And as upon the invasion of their valleys, the frosty
17817: Swiss have retreated to their mountains; so, hunted from the savannas
17818: and glades of the middle seas, the whale-bone whales can at last resort
