17819: to their Polar citadels, and diving under the ultimate glassy barriers
17820: and walls there, come up among icy fields and floes; and in a charmed
17821: circle of everlasting December, bid defiance to all pursuit from man.
17822: 
17823: But as perhaps fifty of these whale-bone whales are harpooned for one
17824: cachalot, some philosophers of the forecastle have concluded that this
17825: positive havoc has already very seriously diminished their battalions.
17826: But though for some time past a number of these whales, not less than
17827: 13,000, have been annually slain on the nor’ west coast by the
17828: Americans alone; yet there are considerations which render even this
17829: circumstance of little or no account as an opposing argument in this
17830: matter.
17831: 
17832: Natural as it is to be somewhat incredulous concerning the populousness
17833: of the more enormous creatures of the globe, yet what shall we say to
17834: Harto, the historian of Goa, when he tells us that at one hunting the
17835: King of Siam took 4,000 elephants; that in those regions elephants are
17836: numerous as droves of cattle in the temperate climes. And there seems
17837: no reason to doubt that if these elephants, which have now been hunted
17838: for thousands of years, by Semiramis, by Porus, by Hannibal, and by all
17839: the successive monarchs of the East—if they still survive there in
17840: great numbers, much more may the great whale outlast all hunting, since
17841: he has a pasture to expatiate in, which is precisely twice as large as
17842: all Asia, both Americas, Europe and Africa, New Holland, and all the
17843: Isles of the sea combined.
17844: 
17845: Moreover: we are to consider, that from the presumed great longevity of
17846: whales, their probably attaining the age of a century and more,
17847: therefore at any one period of time, several distinct adult generations
17848: must be contemporary. And what that is, we may soon gain some idea of,
17849: by imagining all the grave-yards, cemeteries, and family vaults of
17850: creation yielding up the live bodies of all the men, women, and
17851: children who were alive seventy-five years ago; and adding this
17852: countless host to the present human population of the globe.
17853: 
17854: Wherefore, for all these things, we account the whale immortal in his
17855: species, however perishable in his individuality. He swam the seas
17856: before the continents broke water; he once swam over the site of the
17857: Tuileries, and Windsor Castle, and the Kremlin. In Noah’s flood he
17858: despised Noah’s Ark; and if ever the world is to be again flooded, like
17859: the Netherlands, to kill off its rats, then the eternal whale will
17860: still survive, and rearing upon the topmost crest of the equatorial
17861: flood, spout his frothed defiance to the skies.
17862: 
17863: 
17864: CHAPTER 106. Ahab’s Leg.
17865: 
17866: The precipitating manner in which Captain Ahab had quitted the Samuel
17867: Enderby of London, had not been unattended with some small violence to
17868: his own person. He had lighted with such energy upon a thwart of his
17869: boat that his ivory leg had received a half-splintering shock. And when
17870: after gaining his own deck, and his own pivot-hole there, he so
17871: vehemently wheeled round with an urgent command to the steersman (it
17872: was, as ever, something about his not steering inflexibly enough);
17873: then, the already shaken ivory received such an additional twist and
17874: wrench, that though it still remained entire, and to all appearances
17875: lusty, yet Ahab did not deem it entirely trustworthy.
17876: 
17877: And, indeed, it seemed small matter for wonder, that for all his
17878: pervading, mad recklessness, Ahab did at times give careful heed to the
17879: condition of that dead bone upon which he partly stood. For it had not
17880: been very long prior to the Pequod’s sailing from Nantucket, that he
17881: had been found one night lying prone upon the ground, and insensible;
17882: by some unknown, and seemingly inexplicable, unimaginable casualty, his
17883: ivory limb having been so violently displaced, that it had stake-wise
17884: smitten, and all but pierced his groin; nor was it without extreme
17885: difficulty that the agonizing wound was entirely cured.
17886: 
17887: Nor, at the time, had it failed to enter his monomaniac mind, that all
17888: the anguish of that then present suffering was but the direct issue of
17889: a former woe; and he too plainly seemed to see, that as the most
17890: poisonous reptile of the marsh perpetuates his kind as inevitably as
17891: the sweetest songster of the grove; so, equally with every felicity,
17892: all miserable events do naturally beget their like. Yea, more than
17893: equally, thought Ahab; since both the ancestry and posterity of Grief
17894: go further than the ancestry and posterity of Joy. For, not to hint of
17895: this: that it is an inference from certain canonic teachings, that
17896: while some natural enjoyments here shall have no children born to them
17897: for the other world, but, on the contrary, shall be followed by the
17898: joy-childlessness of all hell’s despair; whereas, some guilty mortal
17899: miseries shall still fertilely beget to themselves an eternally
17900: progressive progeny of griefs beyond the grave; not at all to hint of
17901: this, there still seems an inequality in the deeper analysis of the
17902: thing. For, thought Ahab, while even the highest earthly felicities
17903: ever have a certain unsignifying pettiness lurking in them, but, at
17904: bottom, all heartwoes, a mystic significance, and, in some men, an
17905: archangelic grandeur; so do their diligent tracings-out not belie the
17906: obvious deduction. To trail the genealogies of these high mortal
17907: miseries, carries us at last among the sourceless primogenitures of the
17908: gods; so that, in the face of all the glad, hay-making suns, and soft
17909: cymballing, round harvest-moons, we must needs give in to this: that
17910: the gods themselves are not for ever glad. The ineffaceable, sad
17911: birth-mark in the brow of man, is but the stamp of sorrow in the
17912: signers.
17913: 
17914: Unwittingly here a secret has been divulged, which perhaps might more
17915: properly, in set way, have been disclosed before. With many other
17916: particulars concerning Ahab, always had it remained a mystery to some,
17917: why it was, that for a certain period, both before and after the
17918: sailing of the Pequod, he had hidden himself away with such
17919: Grand-Lama-like exclusiveness; and, for that one interval, sought
17920: speechless refuge, as it were, among the marble senate of the dead.
17921: Captain Peleg’s bruited reason for this thing appeared by no means
17922: adequate; though, indeed, as touching all Ahab’s deeper part, every
17923: revelation partook more of significant darkness than of explanatory
17924: light. But, in the end, it all came out; this one matter did, at least.
17925: That direful mishap was at the bottom of his temporary recluseness. And
17926: not only this, but to that ever-contracting, dropping circle ashore,
17927: who, for any reason, possessed the privilege of a less banned approach
17928: to him; to that timid circle the above hinted casualty—remaining, as it
17929: did, moodily unaccounted for by Ahab—invested itself with terrors, not
17930: entirely underived from the land of spirits and of wails. So that,
17931: through their zeal for him, they had all conspired, so far as in them
17932: lay, to muffle up the knowledge of this thing from others; and hence it
17933: was, that not till a considerable interval had elapsed, did it
17934: transpire upon the Pequod’s decks.
17935: 
17936: But be all this as it may; let the unseen, ambiguous synod in the air,
17937: or the vindictive princes and potentates of fire, have to do or not
17938: with earthly Ahab, yet, in this present matter of his leg, he took
17939: plain practical procedures;—he called the carpenter.
17940: 
17941: And when that functionary appeared before him, he bade him without
17942: delay set about making a new leg, and directed the mates to see him
17943: supplied with all the studs and joists of jaw-ivory (Sperm Whale) which
17944: had thus far been accumulated on the voyage, in order that a careful
17945: selection of the stoutest, clearest-grained stuff might be secured.
17946: This done, the carpenter received orders to have the leg completed that
17947: night; and to provide all the fittings for it, independent of those
17948: pertaining to the distrusted one in use. Moreover, the ship’s forge was
17949: ordered to be hoisted out of its temporary idleness in the hold; and,
17950: to accelerate the affair, the blacksmith was commanded to proceed at
17951: once to the forging of whatever iron contrivances might be needed.
17952: 
17953: 
17954: CHAPTER 107. The Carpenter.
17955: 
17956: Seat thyself sultanically among the moons of Saturn, and take high
17957: abstracted man alone; and he seems a wonder, a grandeur, and a woe. But
17958: from the same point, take mankind in mass, and for the most part, they
17959: seem a mob of unnecessary duplicates, both contemporary and hereditary.
17960: But most humble though he was, and far from furnishing an example of
17961: the high, humane abstraction; the Pequod’s carpenter was no duplicate;
17962: hence, he now comes in person on this stage.
17963: 
17964: Like all sea-going ship carpenters, and more especially those belonging
17965: to whaling vessels, he was, to a certain off-handed, practical extent,
17966: alike experienced in numerous trades and callings collateral to his
17967: own; the carpenter’s pursuit being the ancient and outbranching trunk
17968: of all those numerous handicrafts which more or less have to do with
17969: wood as an auxiliary material. But, besides the application to him of
17970: the generic remark above, this carpenter of the Pequod was singularly
17971: efficient in those thousand nameless mechanical emergencies continually
17972: recurring in a large ship, upon a three or four years’ voyage, in
17973: uncivilized and far-distant seas. For not to speak of his readiness in
17974: ordinary duties:—repairing stove boats, sprung spars, reforming the
17975: shape of clumsy-bladed oars, inserting bull’s eyes in the deck, or new
17976: tree-nails in the side planks, and other miscellaneous matters more
17977: directly pertaining to his special business; he was moreover
17978: unhesitatingly expert in all manner of conflicting aptitudes, both
17979: useful and capricious.
17980: 
17981: The one grand stage where he enacted all his various parts so manifold,
17982: was his vice-bench; a long rude ponderous table furnished with several
17983: vices, of different sizes, and both of iron and of wood. At all times
17984: except when whales were alongside, this bench was securely lashed
17985: athwartships against the rear of the Try-works.
17986: 
17987: A belaying pin is found too large to be easily inserted into its hole:
17988: the carpenter claps it into one of his ever-ready vices, and
17989: straightway files it smaller. A lost land-bird of strange plumage
17990: strays on board, and is made a captive: out of clean shaved rods of
17991: right-whale bone, and cross-beams of sperm whale ivory, the carpenter
17992: makes a pagoda-looking cage for it. An oarsman sprains his wrist: the
17993: carpenter concocts a soothing lotion. Stubb longed for vermillion stars
17994: to be painted upon the blade of his every oar; screwing each oar in his
17995: big vice of wood, the carpenter symmetrically supplies the
17996: constellation. A sailor takes a fancy to wear shark-bone ear-rings: the
17997: carpenter drills his ears. Another has the toothache: the carpenter out
17998: pincers, and clapping one hand upon his bench bids him be seated there;
17999: but the poor fellow unmanageably winces under the unconcluded
18000: operation; whirling round the handle of his wooden vice, the carpenter
18001: signs him to clap his jaw in that, if he would have him draw the tooth.
18002: 
18003: Thus, this carpenter was prepared at all points, and alike indifferent
18004: and without respect in all. Teeth he accounted bits of ivory; heads he
18005: deemed but top-blocks; men themselves he lightly held for capstans. But
18006: while now upon so wide a field thus variously accomplished and with
18007: such liveliness of expertness in him, too; all this would seem to argue
18008: some uncommon vivacity of intelligence. But not precisely so. For
18009: nothing was this man more remarkable, than for a certain impersonal
18010: stolidity as it were; impersonal, I say; for it so shaded off into the
18011: surrounding infinite of things, that it seemed one with the general
18012: stolidity discernible in the whole visible world; which while
18013: pauselessly active in uncounted modes, still eternally holds its peace,
18014: and ignores you, though you dig foundations for cathedrals. Yet was
18015: this half-horrible stolidity in him, involving, too, as it appeared, an
18016: all-ramifying heartlessness;—yet was it oddly dashed at times, with an
18017: old, crutch-like, antediluvian, wheezing humorousness, not unstreaked
18018: now and then with a certain grizzled wittiness; such as might have
18019: served to pass the time during the midnight watch on the bearded
18020: forecastle of Noah’s ark. Was it that this old carpenter had been a
18021: life-long wanderer, whose much rolling, to and fro, not only had
18022: gathered no moss; but what is more, had rubbed off whatever small
18023: outward clingings might have originally pertained to him? He was a
18024: stript abstract; an unfractioned integral; uncompromised as a new-born
18025: babe; living without premeditated reference to this world or the next.
18026: You might almost say, that this strange uncompromisedness in him
18027: involved a sort of unintelligence; for in his numerous trades, he did
18028: not seem to work so much by reason or by instinct, or simply because he
18029: had been tutored to it, or by any intermixture of all these, even or
18030: uneven; but merely by a kind of deaf and dumb, spontaneous literal
18031: process. He was a pure manipulator; his brain, if he had ever had one,
18032: must have early oozed along into the muscles of his fingers. He was
18033: like one of those unreasoning but still highly useful, _multum in
18034: parvo_, Sheffield contrivances, assuming the exterior—though a little
18035: swelled—of a common pocket knife; but containing, not only blades of
18036: various sizes, but also screw-drivers, cork-screws, tweezers, awls,
18037: pens, rulers, nail-filers, countersinkers. So, if his superiors wanted
18038: to use the carpenter for a screw-driver, all they had to do was to open
18039: that part of him, and the screw was fast: or if for tweezers, take him
18040: up by the legs, and there they were.
18041: 
18042: Yet, as previously hinted, this omnitooled, open-and-shut carpenter,
18043: was, after all, no mere machine of an automaton. If he did not have a
18044: common soul in him, he had a subtle something that somehow anomalously
18045: did its duty. What that was, whether essence of quicksilver, or a few
18046: drops of hartshorn, there is no telling. But there it was; and there it
18047: had abided for now some sixty years or more. And this it was, this same
18048: unaccountable, cunning life-principle in him; this it was, that kept
18049: him a great part of the time soliloquizing; but only like an
18050: unreasoning wheel, which also hummingly soliloquizes; or rather, his
18051: body was a sentry-box and this soliloquizer on guard there, and talking
18052: all the time to keep himself awake.
18053: 
18054: 
18055: CHAPTER 108. Ahab and the Carpenter.
18056: 
18057: The Deck—First Night Watch.
18058: 
18059: (_Carpenter standing before his vice-bench, and by the light of two
18060: lanterns busily filing the ivory joist for the leg, which joist is
18061: firmly fixed in the vice. Slabs of ivory, leather straps, pads, screws,
18062: and various tools of all sorts lying about the bench. Forward, the red
18063: flame of the forge is seen, where the blacksmith is at work._)
18064: 
18065: Drat the file, and drat the bone! That is hard which should be soft,
18066: and that is soft which should be hard. So we go, who file old jaws and
18067: shinbones. Let’s try another. Aye, now, this works better (_sneezes_).
18068: Halloa, this bone dust is (_sneezes_)—why it’s (_sneezes_)—yes it’s
18069: (_sneezes_)—bless my soul, it won’t let me speak! This is what an old
18070: fellow gets now for working in dead lumber. Saw a live tree, and you
18071: don’t get this dust; amputate a live bone, and you don’t get it
18072: (_sneezes_). Come, come, you old Smut, there, bear a hand, and let’s
18073: have that ferule and buckle-screw; I’ll be ready for them presently.
18074: Lucky now (_sneezes_) there’s no knee-joint to make; that might puzzle
18075: a little; but a mere shinbone—why it’s easy as making hop-poles; only I
18076: should like to put a good finish on. Time, time; if I but only had the
18077: time, I could turn him out as neat a leg now as ever (_sneezes_)
18078: scraped to a lady in a parlor. Those buckskin legs and calves of legs
18079: I’ve seen in shop windows wouldn’t compare at all. They soak water,
18080: they do; and of course get rheumatic, and have to be doctored
18081: (_sneezes_) with washes and lotions, just like live legs. There; before
18082: I saw it off, now, I must call his old Mogulship, and see whether the
18083: length will be all right; too short, if anything, I guess. Ha! that’s
18084: the heel; we are in luck; here he comes, or it’s somebody else, that’s
18085: certain.
18086: 
18087: AHAB (_advancing_). (_During the ensuing scene, the carpenter continues
18088: sneezing at times._)
18089: 
18090: Well, manmaker!
18091: 
18092: Just in time, sir. If the captain pleases, I will now mark the length.
18093: Let me measure, sir.
18094: 
18095: Measured for a leg! good. Well, it’s not the first time. About it!
18096: There; keep thy finger on it. This is a cogent vice thou hast here,
18097: carpenter; let me feel its grip once. So, so; it does pinch some.
18098: 
18099: Oh, sir, it will break bones—beware, beware!
18100: 
18101: No fear; I like a good grip; I like to feel something in this slippery
18102: world that can hold, man. What’s Prometheus about there?—the
18103: blacksmith, I mean—what’s he about?
18104: 
18105: He must be forging the buckle-screw, sir, now.
18106: 
18107: Right. It’s a partnership; he supplies the muscle part. He makes a
18108: fierce red flame there!
18109: 
18110: Aye, sir; he must have the white heat for this kind of fine work.
18111: 
18112: Um-m. So he must. I do deem it now a most meaning thing, that that old
18113: Greek, Prometheus, who made men, they say, should have been a
18114: blacksmith, and animated them with fire; for what’s made in fire must
18115: properly belong to fire; and so hell’s probable. How the soot flies!
18116: This must be the remainder the Greek made the Africans of. Carpenter,
18117: when he’s through with that buckle, tell him to forge a pair of steel
18118: shoulder-blades; there’s a pedlar aboard with a crushing pack.
18119: 
18120: Sir?
18121: 
18122: Hold; while Prometheus is about it, I’ll order a complete man after a
18123: desirable pattern. Imprimis, fifty feet high in his socks; then, chest
18124: modelled after the Thames Tunnel; then, legs with roots to ’em, to stay
18125: in one place; then, arms three feet through the wrist; no heart at all,
18126: brass forehead, and about a quarter of an acre of fine brains; and let
18127: me see—shall I order eyes to see outwards? No, but put a sky-light on
18128: top of his head to illuminate inwards. There, take the order, and away.
18129: 
18130: Now, what’s he speaking about, and who’s he speaking to, I should like
18131: to know? Shall I keep standing here? (_aside_).
18132: 
18133: ’Tis but indifferent architecture to make a blind dome; here’s one. No,
18134: no, no; I must have a lantern.
18135: 
18136: Ho, ho! That’s it, hey? Here are two, sir; one will serve my turn.
18137: 
18138: What art thou thrusting that thief-catcher into my face for, man?
18139: Thrusted light is worse than presented pistols.
18140: 
18141: I thought, sir, that you spoke to carpenter.
18142: 
18143: Carpenter? why that’s—but no;—a very tidy, and, I may say, an extremely
18144: gentlemanlike sort of business thou art in here, carpenter;—or would’st
18145: thou rather work in clay?
18146: 
18147: Sir?—Clay? clay, sir? That’s mud; we leave clay to ditchers, sir.
18148: 
18149: The fellow’s impious! What art thou sneezing about?
18150: 
18151: Bone is rather dusty, sir.
18152: 
18153: Take the hint, then; and when thou art dead, never bury thyself under
18154: living people’s noses.
18155: 
18156: Sir?—oh! ah!—I guess so;—yes—oh, dear!
18157: 
18158: Look ye, carpenter, I dare say thou callest thyself a right good
18159: workmanlike workman, eh? Well, then, will it speak thoroughly well for
18160: thy work, if, when I come to mount this leg thou makest, I shall
18161: nevertheless feel another leg in the same identical place with it; that
18162: is, carpenter, my old lost leg; the flesh and blood one, I mean. Canst
18163: thou not drive that old Adam away?
18164: 
18165: Truly, sir, I begin to understand somewhat now. Yes, I have heard
18166: something curious on that score, sir; how that a dismasted man never
18167: entirely loses the feeling of his old spar, but it will be still
18168: pricking him at times. May I humbly ask if it be really so, sir?
18169: 
18170: It is, man. Look, put thy live leg here in the place where mine once
18171: was; so, now, here is only one distinct leg to the eye, yet two to the
18172: soul. Where thou feelest tingling life; there, exactly there, there to
18173: a hair, do I. Is’t a riddle?
18174: 
18175: I should humbly call it a poser, sir.
18176: 
18177: Hist, then. How dost thou know that some entire, living, thinking thing
18178: may not be invisibly and uninterpenetratingly standing precisely where
18179: thou now standest; aye, and standing there in thy spite? In thy most
18180: solitary hours, then, dost thou not fear eavesdroppers? Hold, don’t
18181: speak! And if I still feel the smart of my crushed leg, though it be
18182: now so long dissolved; then, why mayst not thou, carpenter, feel the
18183: fiery pains of hell for ever, and without a body? Hah!
18184: 
18185: Good Lord! Truly, sir, if it comes to that, I must calculate over
18186: again; I think I didn’t carry a small figure, sir.
18187: 
18188: Look ye, pudding-heads should never grant premises.—How long before the
18189: leg is done?
18190: 
18191: Perhaps an hour, sir.
18192: 
18193: Bungle away at it then, and bring it to me (_turns to go_). Oh, Life!
18194: Here I am, proud as Greek god, and yet standing debtor to this
18195: blockhead for a bone to stand on! Cursed be that mortal
18196: inter-indebtedness which will not do away with ledgers. I would be free
18197: as air; and I’m down in the whole world’s books. I am so rich, I could
18198: have given bid for bid with the wealthiest Prætorians at the auction of
18199: the Roman empire (which was the world’s); and yet I owe for the flesh
18200: in the tongue I brag with. By heavens! I’ll get a crucible, and into
18201: it, and dissolve myself down to one small, compendious vertebra. So.
18202: 
18203: CARPENTER (_resuming his work_).
18204: 
18205: Well, well, well! Stubb knows him best of all, and Stubb always says
18206: he’s queer; says nothing but that one sufficient little word queer;
18207: he’s queer, says Stubb; he’s queer—queer, queer; and keeps dinning it
18208: into Mr. Starbuck all the time—queer—sir—queer, queer, very queer. And
18209: here’s his leg! Yes, now that I think of it, here’s his bedfellow! has
18210: a stick of whale’s jaw-bone for a wife! And this is his leg; he’ll
18211: stand on this. What was that now about one leg standing in three
18212: places, and all three places standing in one hell—how was that? Oh! I
18213: don’t wonder he looked so scornful at me! I’m a sort of
18214: strange-thoughted sometimes, they say; but that’s only haphazard-like.
18215: Then, a short, little old body like me, should never undertake to wade
18216: out into deep waters with tall, heron-built captains; the water chucks
18217: you under the chin pretty quick, and there’s a great cry for
18218: life-boats. And here’s the heron’s leg! long and slim, sure enough!
18219: Now, for most folks one pair of legs lasts a lifetime, and that must be
18220: because they use them mercifully, as a tender-hearted old lady uses her
18221: roly-poly old coach-horses. But Ahab; oh he’s a hard driver. Look,
18222: driven one leg to death, and spavined the other for life, and now wears
18223: out bone legs by the cord. Halloa, there, you Smut! bear a hand there
18224: with those screws, and let’s finish it before the resurrection fellow
18225: comes a-calling with his horn for all legs, true or false, as
18226: brewery-men go round collecting old beer barrels, to fill ’em up again.
18227: What a leg this is! It looks like a real live leg, filed down to
18228: nothing but the core; he’ll be standing on this to-morrow; he’ll be
18229: taking altitudes on it. Halloa! I almost forgot the little oval slate,
18230: smoothed ivory, where he figures up the latitude. So, so; chisel, file,
18231: and sand-paper, now!
18232: 
18233: 
18234: CHAPTER 109. Ahab and Starbuck in the Cabin.
18235: 
18236: According to usage they were pumping the ship next morning; and lo! no
18237: inconsiderable oil came up with the water; the casks below must have
18238: sprung a bad leak. Much concern was shown; and Starbuck went down into
18239: the cabin to report this unfavourable affair.*
18240: 
18241: *In Sperm-whalemen with any considerable quantity of oil on board, it
18242: is a regular semi-weekly duty to conduct a hose into the hold, and
18243: drench the casks with sea-water; which afterwards, at varying
18244: intervals, is removed by the ship’s pumps. Hereby the casks are sought
18245: to be kept damply tight; while by the changed character of the
18246: withdrawn water, the mariners readily detect any serious leakage in the
18247: precious cargo.
18248: 
18249: Now, from the South and West the Pequod was drawing nigh to Formosa and
18250: the Bashee Isles, between which lies one of the tropical outlets from
18251: the China waters into the Pacific. And so Starbuck found Ahab with a
18252: general chart of the oriental archipelagoes spread before him; and
18253: another separate one representing the long eastern coasts of the
18254: Japanese islands—Niphon, Matsmai, and Sikoke. With his snow-white new
18255: ivory leg braced against the screwed leg of his table, and with a long
18256: pruning-hook of a jack-knife in his hand, the wondrous old man, with
18257: his back to the gangway door, was wrinkling his brow, and tracing his
18258: old courses again.
18259: 
18260: “Who’s there?” hearing the footstep at the door, but not turning round
18261: to it. “On deck! Begone!”
18262: 
18263: “Captain Ahab mistakes; it is I. The oil in the hold is leaking, sir.
18264: We must up Burtons and break out.”
18265: 
18266: “Up Burtons and break out? Now that we are nearing Japan; heave-to here
18267: for a week to tinker a parcel of old hoops?”
18268: 
18269: “Either do that, sir, or waste in one day more oil than we may make
18270: good in a year. What we come twenty thousand miles to get is worth
18271: saving, sir.”
18272: 
18273: “So it is, so it is; if we get it.”
18274: 
18275: “I was speaking of the oil in the hold, sir.”
18276: 
18277: “And I was not speaking or thinking of that at all. Begone! Let it
18278: leak! I’m all aleak myself. Aye! leaks in leaks! not only full of leaky
18279: casks, but those leaky casks are in a leaky ship; and that’s a far
18280: worse plight than the Pequod’s, man. Yet I don’t stop to plug my leak;
18281: for who can find it in the deep-loaded hull; or how hope to plug it,
18282: even if found, in this life’s howling gale? Starbuck! I’ll not have the
18283: Burtons hoisted.”
18284: 
18285: “What will the owners say, sir?”
18286: 
18287: “Let the owners stand on Nantucket beach and outyell the Typhoons. What
18288: cares Ahab? Owners, owners? Thou art always prating to me, Starbuck,
18289: about those miserly owners, as if the owners were my conscience. But
18290: look ye, the only real owner of anything is its commander; and hark ye,
18291: my conscience is in this ship’s keel.—On deck!”
18292: 
18293: “Captain Ahab,” said the reddening mate, moving further into the cabin,
18294: with a daring so strangely respectful and cautious that it almost
18295: seemed not only every way seeking to avoid the slightest outward
18296: manifestation of itself, but within also seemed more than half
18297: distrustful of itself; “A better man than I might well pass over in
18298: thee what he would quickly enough resent in a younger man; aye, and in
18299: a happier, Captain Ahab.”
18300: 
18301: “Devils! Dost thou then so much as dare to critically think of me?—On
18302: deck!”
18303: 
18304: “Nay, sir, not yet; I do entreat. And I do dare, sir—to be forbearing!
18305: Shall we not understand each other better than hitherto, Captain Ahab?”
18306: 
18307: Ahab seized a loaded musket from the rack (forming part of most
18308: South-Sea-men’s cabin furniture), and pointing it towards Starbuck,
18309: exclaimed: “There is one God that is Lord over the earth, and one
18310: Captain that is lord over the Pequod.—On deck!”
18311: 
18312: For an instant in the flashing eyes of the mate, and his fiery cheeks,
18313: you would have almost thought that he had really received the blaze of
18314: the levelled tube. But, mastering his emotion, he half calmly rose, and
18315: as he quitted the cabin, paused for an instant and said: “Thou hast
18316: outraged, not insulted me, sir; but for that I ask thee not to beware
18317: of Starbuck; thou wouldst but laugh; but let Ahab beware of Ahab;
18318: beware of thyself, old man.”
18319: 
18320: “He waxes brave, but nevertheless obeys; most careful bravery that!”
18321: murmured Ahab, as Starbuck disappeared. “What’s that he said—Ahab
18322: beware of Ahab—there’s something there!” Then unconsciously using the
18323: musket for a staff, with an iron brow he paced to and fro in the little
18324: cabin; but presently the thick plaits of his forehead relaxed, and
18325: returning the gun to the rack, he went to the deck.
18326: 
18327: “Thou art but too good a fellow, Starbuck,” he said lowly to the mate;
18328: then raising his voice to the crew: “Furl the t’gallant-sails, and
18329: close-reef the top-sails, fore and aft; back the main-yard; up Burton,
18330: and break out in the main-hold.”
18331: 
18332: It were perhaps vain to surmise exactly why it was, that as respecting
18333: Starbuck, Ahab thus acted. It may have been a flash of honesty in him;
18334: or mere prudential policy which, under the circumstance, imperiously
18335: forbade the slightest symptom of open disaffection, however transient,
18336: in the important chief officer of his ship. However it was, his orders
18337: were executed; and the Burtons were hoisted.
18338: 
18339: 
18340: CHAPTER 110. Queequeg in His Coffin.
18341: 
18342: Upon searching, it was found that the casks last struck into the hold
18343: were perfectly sound, and that the leak must be further off. So, it
18344: being calm weather, they broke out deeper and deeper, disturbing the
18345: slumbers of the huge ground-tier butts; and from that black midnight
18346: sending those gigantic moles into the daylight above. So deep did they
18347: go; and so ancient, and corroded, and weedy the aspect of the lowermost
18348: puncheons, that you almost looked next for some mouldy corner-stone
18349: cask containing coins of Captain Noah, with copies of the posted
18350: placards, vainly warning the infatuated old world from the flood.
18351: Tierce after tierce, too, of water, and bread, and beef, and shooks of
18352: staves, and iron bundles of hoops, were hoisted out, till at last the
18353: piled decks were hard to get about; and the hollow hull echoed under
18354: foot, as if you were treading over empty catacombs, and reeled and
18355: rolled in the sea like an air-freighted demijohn. Top-heavy was the
18356: ship as a dinnerless student with all Aristotle in his head. Well was
18357: it that the Typhoons did not visit them then.
18358: 
18359: Now, at this time it was that my poor pagan companion, and fast
18360: bosom-friend, Queequeg, was seized with a fever, which brought him nigh
18361: to his endless end.
18362: 
18363: Be it said, that in this vocation of whaling, sinecures are unknown;
18364: dignity and danger go hand in hand; till you get to be Captain, the
18365: higher you rise the harder you toil. So with poor Queequeg, who, as
18366: harpooneer, must not only face all the rage of the living whale, but—as
18367: we have elsewhere seen—mount his dead back in a rolling sea; and
18368: finally descend into the gloom of the hold, and bitterly sweating all
18369: day in that subterraneous confinement, resolutely manhandle the
18370: clumsiest casks and see to their stowage. To be short, among whalemen,
18371: the harpooneers are the holders, so called.
18372: 
18373: Poor Queequeg! when the ship was about half disembowelled, you should
18374: have stooped over the hatchway, and peered down upon him there; where,
18375: stripped to his woollen drawers, the tattooed savage was crawling about
18376: amid that dampness and slime, like a green spotted lizard at the bottom
18377: of a well. And a well, or an ice-house, it somehow proved to him, poor
18378: pagan; where, strange to say, for all the heat of his sweatings, he
18379: caught a terrible chill which lapsed into a fever; and at last, after
18380: some days’ suffering, laid him in his hammock, close to the very sill
18381: of the door of death. How he wasted and wasted away in those few
18382: long-lingering days, till there seemed but little left of him but his
18383: frame and tattooing. But as all else in him thinned, and his
18384: cheek-bones grew sharper, his eyes, nevertheless, seemed growing fuller
18385: and fuller; they became of a strange softness of lustre; and mildly but
18386: deeply looked out at you there from his sickness, a wondrous testimony
18387: to that immortal health in him which could not die, or be weakened. And
18388: like circles on the water, which, as they grow fainter, expand; so his
18389: eyes seemed rounding and rounding, like the rings of Eternity. An awe
18390: that cannot be named would steal over you as you sat by the side of
18391: this waning savage, and saw as strange things in his face, as any
18392: beheld who were bystanders when Zoroaster died. For whatever is truly
18393: wondrous and fearful in man, never yet was put into words or books. And
18394: the drawing near of Death, which alike levels all, alike impresses all
18395: with a last revelation, which only an author from the dead could
18396: adequately tell. So that—let us say it again—no dying Chaldee or Greek
18397: had higher and holier thoughts than those, whose mysterious shades you
18398: saw creeping over the face of poor Queequeg, as he quietly lay in his
18399: swaying hammock, and the rolling sea seemed gently rocking him to his
18400: final rest, and the ocean’s invisible flood-tide lifted him higher and
18401: higher towards his destined heaven.
18402: 
18403: Not a man of the crew but gave him up; and, as for Queequeg himself,
18404: what he thought of his case was forcibly shown by a curious favour he
18405: asked. He called one to him in the grey morning watch, when the day was
18406: just breaking, and taking his hand, said that while in Nantucket he had
18407: chanced to see certain little canoes of dark wood, like the rich
18408: war-wood of his native isle; and upon inquiry, he had learned that all
18409: whalemen who died in Nantucket, were laid in those same dark canoes,
18410: and that the fancy of being so laid had much pleased him; for it was
18411: not unlike the custom of his own race, who, after embalming a dead
18412: warrior, stretched him out in his canoe, and so left him to be floated
18413: away to the starry archipelagoes; for not only do they believe that the
18414: stars are isles, but that far beyond all visible horizons, their own
18415: mild, uncontinented seas, interflow with the blue heavens; and so form
18416: the white breakers of the milky way. He added, that he shuddered at the
18417: thought of being buried in his hammock, according to the usual
18418: sea-custom, tossed like something vile to the death-devouring sharks.
18419: No: he desired a canoe like those of Nantucket, all the more congenial
18420: to him, being a whaleman, that like a whale-boat these coffin-canoes
18421: were without a keel; though that involved but uncertain steering, and
18422: much lee-way adown the dim ages.
18423: 
18424: Now, when this strange circumstance was made known aft, the carpenter
18425: was at once commanded to do Queequeg’s bidding, whatever it might
18426: include. There was some heathenish, coffin-coloured old lumber aboard,
18427: which, upon a long previous voyage, had been cut from the aboriginal
18428: groves of the Lackaday islands, and from these dark planks the coffin
18429: was recommended to be made. No sooner was the carpenter apprised of the
18430: order, than taking his rule, he forthwith with all the indifferent
18431: promptitude of his character, proceeded into the forecastle and took
18432: Queequeg’s measure with great accuracy, regularly chalking Queequeg’s
18433: person as he shifted the rule.
18434: 
18435: “Ah! poor fellow! he’ll have to die now,” ejaculated the Long Island
18436: sailor.
18437: 
18438: Going to his vice-bench, the carpenter for convenience sake and general
18439: reference, now transferringly measured on it the exact length the
18440: coffin was to be, and then made the transfer permanent by cutting two
18441: notches at its extremities. This done, he marshalled the planks and his
18442: tools, and to work.
18443: 
18444: When the last nail was driven, and the lid duly planed and fitted, he
18445: lightly shouldered the coffin and went forward with it, inquiring
18446: whether they were ready for it yet in that direction.
18447: 
18448: Overhearing the indignant but half-humorous cries with which the people
18449: on deck began to drive the coffin away, Queequeg, to every one’s
18450: consternation, commanded that the thing should be instantly brought to
18451: him, nor was there any denying him; seeing that, of all mortals, some
18452: dying men are the most tyrannical; and certainly, since they will
18453: shortly trouble us so little for evermore, the poor fellows ought to be
18454: indulged.
18455: 
18456: Leaning over in his hammock, Queequeg long regarded the coffin with an
18457: attentive eye. He then called for his harpoon, had the wooden stock
18458: drawn from it, and then had the iron part placed in the coffin along
18459: with one of the paddles of his boat. All by his own request, also,
18460: biscuits were then ranged round the sides within: a flask of fresh
18461: water was placed at the head, and a small bag of woody earth scraped up
18462: in the hold at the foot; and a piece of sail-cloth being rolled up for
18463: a pillow, Queequeg now entreated to be lifted into his final bed, that
18464: he might make trial of its comforts, if any it had. He lay without
18465: moving a few minutes, then told one to go to his bag and bring out his
18466: little god, Yojo. Then crossing his arms on his breast with Yojo
18467: between, he called for the coffin lid (hatch he called it) to be placed
18468: over him. The head part turned over with a leather hinge, and there lay
18469: Queequeg in his coffin with little but his composed countenance in
18470: view. “Rarmai” (it will do; it is easy), he murmured at last, and
18471: signed to be replaced in his hammock.
18472: 
18473: But ere this was done, Pip, who had been slily hovering near by all
18474: this while, drew nigh to him where he lay, and with soft sobbings, took
18475: him by the hand; in the other, holding his tambourine.
18476: 
18477: “Poor rover! will ye never have done with all this weary roving? where
18478: go ye now? But if the currents carry ye to those sweet Antilles where
18479: the beaches are only beat with water-lilies, will ye do one little
18480: errand for me? Seek out one Pip, who’s now been missing long: I think
18481: he’s in those far Antilles. If ye find him, then comfort him; for he
18482: must be very sad; for look! he’s left his tambourine behind;—I found
18483: it. Rig-a-dig, dig, dig! Now, Queequeg, die; and I’ll beat ye your
18484: dying march.”
18485: 
18486: “I have heard,” murmured Starbuck, gazing down the scuttle, “that in
18487: violent fevers, men, all ignorance, have talked in ancient tongues; and
18488: that when the mystery is probed, it turns out always that in their
18489: wholly forgotten childhood those ancient tongues had been really spoken
18490: in their hearing by some lofty scholars. So, to my fond faith, poor
18491: Pip, in this strange sweetness of his lunacy, brings heavenly vouchers
18492: of all our heavenly homes. Where learned he that, but there?—Hark! he
18493: speaks again: but more wildly now.”
18494: 
18495: “Form two and two! Let’s make a General of him! Ho, where’s his
18496: harpoon? Lay it across here.—Rig-a-dig, dig, dig! huzza! Oh for a game
18497: cock now to sit upon his head and crow! Queequeg dies game!—mind ye
18498: that; Queequeg dies game!—take ye good heed of that; Queequeg dies
18499: game! I say; game, game, game! but base little Pip, he died a coward;
18500: died all a’shiver;—out upon Pip! Hark ye; if ye find Pip, tell all the
18501: Antilles he’s a runaway; a coward, a coward, a coward! Tell them he
18502: jumped from a whale-boat! I’d never beat my tambourine over base Pip,
18503: and hail him General, if he were once more dying here. No, no! shame
18504: upon all cowards—shame upon them! Let ’em go drown like Pip, that
18505: jumped from a whale-boat. Shame! shame!”
18506: 
18507: During all this, Queequeg lay with closed eyes, as if in a dream. Pip
18508: was led away, and the sick man was replaced in his hammock.
18509: 
18510: But now that he had apparently made every preparation for death; now
18511: that his coffin was proved a good fit, Queequeg suddenly rallied; soon
18512: there seemed no need of the carpenter’s box: and thereupon, when some
18513: expressed their delighted surprise, he, in substance, said, that the
18514: cause of his sudden convalescence was this;—at a critical moment, he
18515: had just recalled a little duty ashore, which he was leaving undone;
18516: and therefore had changed his mind about dying: he could not die yet,
18517: he averred. They asked him, then, whether to live or die was a matter
18518: of his own sovereign will and pleasure. He answered, certainly. In a
18519: word, it was Queequeg’s conceit, that if a man made up his mind to
18520: live, mere sickness could not kill him: nothing but a whale, or a gale,
18521: or some violent, ungovernable, unintelligent destroyer of that sort.
18522: 
18523: Now, there is this noteworthy difference between savage and civilized;
18524: that while a sick, civilized man may be six months convalescing,
18525: generally speaking, a sick savage is almost half-well again in a day.
18526: So, in good time my Queequeg gained strength; and at length after
18527: sitting on the windlass for a few indolent days (but eating with a
18528: vigorous appetite) he suddenly leaped to his feet, threw out his arms
18529: and legs, gave himself a good stretching, yawned a little bit, and then
18530: springing into the head of his hoisted boat, and poising a harpoon,
18531: pronounced himself fit for a fight.
18532: 
18533: With a wild whimsiness, he now used his coffin for a sea-chest; and
18534: emptying into it his canvas bag of clothes, set them in order there.
18535: Many spare hours he spent, in carving the lid with all manner of
18536: grotesque figures and drawings; and it seemed that hereby he was
18537: striving, in his rude way, to copy parts of the twisted tattooing on
18538: his body. And this tattooing had been the work of a departed prophet
18539: and seer of his island, who, by those hieroglyphic marks, had written
18540: out on his body a complete theory of the heavens and the earth, and a
18541: mystical treatise on the art of attaining truth; so that Queequeg in
18542: his own proper person was a riddle to unfold; a wondrous work in one
18543: volume; but whose mysteries not even himself could read, though his own
18544: live heart beat against them; and these mysteries were therefore
18545: destined in the end to moulder away with the living parchment whereon
18546: they were inscribed, and so be unsolved to the last. And this thought
18547: it must have been which suggested to Ahab that wild exclamation of his,
18548: when one morning turning away from surveying poor Queequeg—“Oh,
18549: devilish tantalization of the gods!”
18550: 
18551: 
18552: CHAPTER 111. The Pacific.
18553: 
18554: When gliding by the Bashee isles we emerged at last upon the great
18555: South Sea; were it not for other things, I could have greeted my dear
18556: Pacific with uncounted thanks, for now the long supplication of my
18557: youth was answered; that serene ocean rolled eastwards from me a
18558: thousand leagues of blue.
18559: 
18560: There is, one knows not what sweet mystery about this sea, whose gently
18561: awful stirrings seem to speak of some hidden soul beneath; like those
18562: fabled undulations of the Ephesian sod over the buried Evangelist St.
18563: John. And meet it is, that over these sea-pastures, wide-rolling watery
18564: prairies and Potters’ Fields of all four continents, the waves should
18565: rise and fall, and ebb and flow unceasingly; for here, millions of
18566: mixed shades and shadows, drowned dreams, somnambulisms, reveries; all
18567: that we call lives and souls, lie dreaming, dreaming, still; tossing
18568: like slumberers in their beds; the ever-rolling waves but made so by
18569: their restlessness.
18570: 
18571: To any meditative Magian rover, this serene Pacific, once beheld, must
18572: ever after be the sea of his adoption. It rolls the midmost waters of
18573: the world, the Indian ocean and Atlantic being but its arms. The same
18574: waves wash the moles of the new-built Californian towns, but yesterday
18575: planted by the recentest race of men, and lave the faded but still
18576: gorgeous skirts of Asiatic lands, older than Abraham; while all between
18577: float milky-ways of coral isles, and low-lying, endless, unknown
18578: Archipelagoes, and impenetrable Japans. Thus this mysterious, divine
18579: Pacific zones the world’s whole bulk about; makes all coasts one bay to
18580: it; seems the tide-beating heart of earth. Lifted by those eternal
18581: swells, you needs must own the seductive god, bowing your head to Pan.
18582: 
18583: But few thoughts of Pan stirred Ahab’s brain, as standing like an iron
18584: statue at his accustomed place beside the mizen rigging, with one
18585: nostril he unthinkingly snuffed the sugary musk from the Bashee isles
18586: (in whose sweet woods mild lovers must be walking), and with the other
18587: consciously inhaled the salt breath of the new found sea; that sea in
18588: which the hated White Whale must even then be swimming. Launched at
18589: length upon these almost final waters, and gliding towards the Japanese
18590: cruising-ground, the old man’s purpose intensified itself. His firm
18591: lips met like the lips of a vice; the Delta of his forehead’s veins
18592: swelled like overladen brooks; in his very sleep, his ringing cry ran
18593: through the vaulted hull, “Stern all! the White Whale spouts thick
18594: blood!”
18595: 
18596: 
18597: CHAPTER 112. The Blacksmith.
18598: 
18599: Availing himself of the mild, summer-cool weather that now reigned in
18600: these latitudes, and in preparation for the peculiarly active pursuits
18601: shortly to be anticipated, Perth, the begrimed, blistered old
18602: blacksmith, had not removed his portable forge to the hold again, after
18603: concluding his contributory work for Ahab’s leg, but still retained it
18604: on deck, fast lashed to ringbolts by the foremast; being now almost
18605: incessantly invoked by the headsmen, and harpooneers, and bowsmen to do
18606: some little job for them; altering, or repairing, or new shaping their
18607: various weapons and boat furniture. Often he would be surrounded by an
18608: eager circle, all waiting to be served; holding boat-spades,
18609: pike-heads, harpoons, and lances, and jealously watching his every
18610: sooty movement, as he toiled. Nevertheless, this old man’s was a
18611: patient hammer wielded by a patient arm. No murmur, no impatience, no
18612: petulance did come from him. Silent, slow, and solemn; bowing over
18613: still further his chronically broken back, he toiled away, as if toil
18614: were life itself, and the heavy beating of his hammer the heavy beating
18615: of his heart. And so it was.—Most miserable!
18616: 
18617: A peculiar walk in this old man, a certain slight but painful appearing
18618: yawing in his gait, had at an early period of the voyage excited the
18619: curiosity of the mariners. And to the importunity of their persisted
18620: questionings he had finally given in; and so it came to pass that every
18621: one now knew the shameful story of his wretched fate.
18622: 
18623: Belated, and not innocently, one bitter winter’s midnight, on the road
18624: running between two country towns, the blacksmith half-stupidly felt
18625: the deadly numbness stealing over him, and sought refuge in a leaning,
18626: dilapidated barn. The issue was, the loss of the extremities of both
18627: feet. Out of this revelation, part by part, at last came out the four
18628: acts of the gladness, and the one long, and as yet uncatastrophied
18629: fifth act of the grief of his life’s drama.
18630: 
18631: He was an old man, who, at the age of nearly sixty, had postponedly
18632: encountered that thing in sorrow’s technicals called ruin. He had been
18633: an artisan of famed excellence, and with plenty to do; owned a house
18634: and garden; embraced a youthful, daughter-like, loving wife, and three
18635: blithe, ruddy children; every Sunday went to a cheerful-looking church,
18636: planted in a grove. But one night, under cover of darkness, and further
18637: concealed in a most cunning disguisement, a desperate burglar slid into
18638: his happy home, and robbed them all of everything. And darker yet to
18639: tell, the blacksmith himself did ignorantly conduct this burglar into
18640: his family’s heart. It was the Bottle Conjuror! Upon the opening of
18641: that fatal cork, forth flew the fiend, and shrivelled up his home. Now,
18642: for prudent, most wise, and economic reasons, the blacksmith’s shop was
18643: in the basement of his dwelling, but with a separate entrance to it; so
18644: that always had the young and loving healthy wife listened with no
18645: unhappy nervousness, but with vigorous pleasure, to the stout ringing
18646: of her young-armed old husband’s hammer; whose reverberations, muffled
18647: by passing through the floors and walls, came up to her, not unsweetly,
18648: in her nursery; and so, to stout Labor’s iron lullaby, the blacksmith’s
18649: infants were rocked to slumber.
18650: 
18651: Oh, woe on woe! Oh, Death, why canst thou not sometimes be timely?
18652: Hadst thou taken this old blacksmith to thyself ere his full ruin came
18653: upon him, then had the young widow had a delicious grief, and her
18654: orphans a truly venerable, legendary sire to dream of in their after
18655: years; and all of them a care-killing competency. But Death plucked
18656: down some virtuous elder brother, on whose whistling daily toil solely
18657: hung the responsibilities of some other family, and left the worse than
18658: useless old man standing, till the hideous rot of life should make him
18659: easier to harvest.
18660: 
18661: Why tell the whole? The blows of the basement hammer every day grew
18662: more and more between; and each blow every day grew fainter than the
18663: last; the wife sat frozen at the window, with tearless eyes,
18664: glitteringly gazing into the weeping faces of her children; the bellows
18665: fell; the forge choked up with cinders; the house was sold; the mother
18666: dived down into the long church-yard grass; her children twice followed
18667: her thither; and the houseless, familyless old man staggered off a
18668: vagabond in crape; his every woe unreverenced; his grey head a scorn to
18669: flaxen curls!
18670: 
18671: Death seems the only desirable sequel for a career like this; but Death
18672: is only a launching into the region of the strange Untried; it is but
18673: the first salutation to the possibilities of the immense Remote, the
18674: Wild, the Watery, the Unshored; therefore, to the death-longing eyes of
18675: such men, who still have left in them some interior compunctions
18676: against suicide, does the all-contributed and all-receptive ocean
18677: alluringly spread forth his whole plain of unimaginable, taking
18678: terrors, and wonderful, new-life adventures; and from the hearts of
18679: infinite Pacifics, the thousand mermaids sing to them—“Come hither,
18680: broken-hearted; here is another life without the guilt of intermediate
18681: death; here are wonders supernatural, without dying for them. Come
18682: hither! bury thyself in a life which, to your now equally abhorred and
18683: abhorring, landed world, is more oblivious than death. Come hither! put
18684: up _thy_ gravestone, too, within the churchyard, and come hither, till
18685: we marry thee!”
18686: 
18687: Hearkening to these voices, East and West, by early sunrise, and by
18688: fall of eve, the blacksmith’s soul responded, Aye, I come! And so Perth
18689: went a-whaling.
18690: 
18691: 
18692: CHAPTER 113. The Forge.
18693: 
18694: With matted beard, and swathed in a bristling shark-skin apron, about
18695: mid-day, Perth was standing between his forge and anvil, the latter
18696: placed upon an iron-wood log, with one hand holding a pike-head in the
18697: coals, and with the other at his forge’s lungs, when Captain Ahab came
18698: along, carrying in his hand a small rusty-looking leathern bag. While
18699: yet a little distance from the forge, moody Ahab paused; till at last,
18700: Perth, withdrawing his iron from the fire, began hammering it upon the
18701: anvil—the red mass sending off the sparks in thick hovering flights,
18702: some of which flew close to Ahab.
18703: 
18704: “Are these thy Mother Carey’s chickens, Perth? they are always flying
18705: in thy wake; birds of good omen, too, but not to all;—look here, they
18706: burn; but thou—thou liv’st among them without a scorch.”
18707: 
18708: “Because I am scorched all over, Captain Ahab,” answered Perth, resting
18709: for a moment on his hammer; “I am past scorching; not easily can’st
18710: thou scorch a scar.”
18711: 
18712: “Well, well; no more. Thy shrunk voice sounds too calmly, sanely woeful
18713: to me. In no Paradise myself, I am impatient of all misery in others
18714: that is not mad. Thou should’st go mad, blacksmith; say, why dost thou
18715: not go mad? How can’st thou endure without being mad? Do the heavens
18716: yet hate thee, that thou can’st not go mad?—What wert thou making
18717: there?”
18718: 
18719: “Welding an old pike-head, sir; there were seams and dents in it.”
18720: 
18721: “And can’st thou make it all smooth again, blacksmith, after such hard
18722: usage as it had?”
18723: 
18724: “I think so, sir.”
18725: 
18726: “And I suppose thou can’st smoothe almost any seams and dents; never
18727: mind how hard the metal, blacksmith?”
18728: 
18729: “Aye, sir, I think I can; all seams and dents but one.”
18730: 
18731: “Look ye here, then,” cried Ahab, passionately advancing, and leaning
18732: with both hands on Perth’s shoulders; “look ye here—_here_—can ye
18733: smoothe out a seam like this, blacksmith,” sweeping one hand across his
18734: ribbed brow; “if thou could’st, blacksmith, glad enough would I lay my
18735: head upon thy anvil, and feel thy heaviest hammer between my eyes.
18736: Answer! Can’st thou smoothe this seam?”
18737: 
18738: “Oh! that is the one, sir! Said I not all seams and dents but one?”
18739: 
18740: “Aye, blacksmith, it is the one; aye, man, it is unsmoothable; for
18741: though thou only see’st it here in my flesh, it has worked down into
18742: the bone of my skull—_that_ is all wrinkles! But, away with child’s
18743: play; no more gaffs and pikes to-day. Look ye here!” jingling the
18744: leathern bag, as if it were full of gold coins. “I, too, want a harpoon
18745: made; one that a thousand yoke of fiends could not part, Perth;
18746: something that will stick in a whale like his own fin-bone. There’s the
18747: stuff,” flinging the pouch upon the anvil. “Look ye, blacksmith, these
18748: are the gathered nail-stubbs of the steel shoes of racing horses.”
18749: 
18750: “Horse-shoe stubbs, sir? Why, Captain Ahab, thou hast here, then, the
18751: best and stubbornest stuff we blacksmiths ever work.”
18752: 
18753: “I know it, old man; these stubbs will weld together like glue from the
18754: melted bones of murderers. Quick! forge me the harpoon. And forge me
18755: first, twelve rods for its shank; then wind, and twist, and hammer
18756: these twelve together like the yarns and strands of a tow-line. Quick!
18757: I’ll blow the fire.”
18758: 
18759: When at last the twelve rods were made, Ahab tried them, one by one, by
18760: spiralling them, with his own hand, round a long, heavy iron bolt. “A
18761: flaw!” rejecting the last one. “Work that over again, Perth.”
18762: 
18763: This done, Perth was about to begin welding the twelve into one, when
18764: Ahab stayed his hand, and said he would weld his own iron. As, then,
18765: with regular, gasping hems, he hammered on the anvil, Perth passing to
18766: him the glowing rods, one after the other, and the hard pressed forge
18767: shooting up its intense straight flame, the Parsee passed silently, and
18768: bowing over his head towards the fire, seemed invoking some curse or
18769: some blessing on the toil. But, as Ahab looked up, he slid aside.
18770: 
18771: “What’s that bunch of lucifers dodging about there for?” muttered
18772: Stubb, looking on from the forecastle. “That Parsee smells fire like a
18773: fusee; and smells of it himself, like a hot musket’s powder-pan.”
18774: 
18775: At last the shank, in one complete rod, received its final heat; and as
18776: Perth, to temper it, plunged it all hissing into the cask of water near
18777: by, the scalding steam shot up into Ahab’s bent face.
18778: 
18779: “Would’st thou brand me, Perth?” wincing for a moment with the pain;
18780: “have I been but forging my own branding-iron, then?”
18781: 
18782: “Pray God, not that; yet I fear something, Captain Ahab. Is not this
18783: harpoon for the White Whale?”
18784: 
18785: “For the white fiend! But now for the barbs; thou must make them
18786: thyself, man. Here are my razors—the best of steel; here, and make the
18787: barbs sharp as the needle-sleet of the Icy Sea.”
18788: 
18789: For a moment, the old blacksmith eyed the razors as though he would
18790: fain not use them.
18791: 
18792: “Take them, man, I have no need for them; for I now neither shave, sup,
18793: nor pray till—but here—to work!”
18794: 
18795: Fashioned at last into an arrowy shape, and welded by Perth to the
18796: shank, the steel soon pointed the end of the iron; and as the
18797: blacksmith was about giving the barbs their final heat, prior to
18798: tempering them, he cried to Ahab to place the water-cask near.
18799: 
18800: “No, no—no water for that; I want it of the true death-temper. Ahoy,
18801: there! Tashtego, Queequeg, Daggoo! What say ye, pagans! Will ye give me
18802: as much blood as will cover this barb?” holding it high up. A cluster
18803: of dark nods replied, Yes. Three punctures were made in the heathen
18804: flesh, and the White Whale’s barbs were then tempered.
18805: 
18806: “Ego non baptizo te in nomine patris, sed in nomine diaboli!”
18807: deliriously howled Ahab, as the malignant iron scorchingly devoured the
18808: baptismal blood.
18809: 
18810: Now, mustering the spare poles from below, and selecting one of
18811: hickory, with the bark still investing it, Ahab fitted the end to the
18812: socket of the iron. A coil of new tow-line was then unwound, and some
18813: fathoms of it taken to the windlass, and stretched to a great tension.
18814: Pressing his foot upon it, till the rope hummed like a harp-string,
18815: then eagerly bending over it, and seeing no strandings, Ahab exclaimed,
18816: “Good! and now for the seizings.”
18817: 
18818: At one extremity the rope was unstranded, and the separate spread yarns
18819: were all braided and woven round the socket of the harpoon; the pole
18820: was then driven hard up into the socket; from the lower end the rope
18821: was traced half-way along the pole’s length, and firmly secured so,
18822: with intertwistings of twine. This done, pole, iron, and rope—like the
18823: Three Fates—remained inseparable, and Ahab moodily stalked away with
18824: the weapon; the sound of his ivory leg, and the sound of the hickory
18825: pole, both hollowly ringing along every plank. But ere he entered his
18826: cabin, light, unnatural, half-bantering, yet most piteous sound was
18827: heard. Oh, Pip! thy wretched laugh, thy idle but unresting eye; all thy
18828: strange mummeries not unmeaningly blended with the black tragedy of the
18829: melancholy ship, and mocked it!
18830: 
18831: 
18832: CHAPTER 114. The Gilder.
18833: 
18834: Penetrating further and further into the heart of the Japanese cruising
18835: ground, the Pequod was soon all astir in the fishery. Often, in mild,
18836: pleasant weather, for twelve, fifteen, eighteen, and twenty hours on
18837: the stretch, they were engaged in the boats, steadily pulling, or
18838: sailing, or paddling after the whales, or for an interlude of sixty or
18839: seventy minutes calmly awaiting their uprising; though with but small
18840: success for their pains.
18841: 
18842: At such times, under an abated sun; afloat all day upon smooth, slow
18843: heaving swells; seated in his boat, light as a birch canoe; and so
18844: sociably mixing with the soft waves themselves, that like hearth-stone
18845: cats they purr against the gunwale; these are the times of dreamy
18846: quietude, when beholding the tranquil beauty and brilliancy of the
18847: ocean’s skin, one forgets the tiger heart that pants beneath it; and
18848: would not willingly remember, that this velvet paw but conceals a
18849: remorseless fang.
18850: 
18851: These are the times, when in his whale-boat the rover softly feels a
18852: certain filial, confident, land-like feeling towards the sea; that he
18853: regards it as so much flowery earth; and the distant ship revealing
18854: only the tops of her masts, seems struggling forward, not through high
18855: rolling waves, but through the tall grass of a rolling prairie: as when
18856: the western emigrants’ horses only show their erected ears, while their
18857: hidden bodies widely wade through the amazing verdure.
18858: 
18859: The long-drawn virgin vales; the mild blue hill-sides; as over these
18860: there steals the hush, the hum; you almost swear that play-wearied
18861: children lie sleeping in these solitudes, in some glad May-time, when
18862: the flowers of the woods are plucked. And all this mixes with your most
18863: mystic mood; so that fact and fancy, half-way meeting, interpenetrate,
18864: and form one seamless whole.
18865: 
18866: Nor did such soothing scenes, however temporary, fail of at least as
18867: temporary an effect on Ahab. But if these secret golden keys did seem
18868: to open in him his own secret golden treasuries, yet did his breath
18869: upon them prove but tarnishing.
18870: 
18871: Oh, grassy glades! oh, ever vernal endless landscapes in the soul; in
18872: ye,—though long parched by the dead drought of the earthy life,—in ye,
18873: men yet may roll, like young horses in new morning clover; and for some
18874: few fleeting moments, feel the cool dew of the life immortal on them.
18875: Would to God these blessed calms would last. But the mingled, mingling
18876: threads of life are woven by warp and woof: calms crossed by storms, a
18877: storm for every calm. There is no steady unretracing progress in this
18878: life; we do not advance through fixed gradations, and at the last one
18879: pause:—through infancy’s unconscious spell, boyhood’s thoughtless
18880: faith, adolescence’ doubt (the common doom), then scepticism, then
18881: disbelief, resting at last in manhood’s pondering repose of If. But
18882: once gone through, we trace the round again; and are infants, boys, and
18883: men, and Ifs eternally. Where lies the final harbor, whence we unmoor
18884: no more? In what rapt ether sails the world, of which the weariest will
18885: never weary? Where is the foundling’s father hidden? Our souls are like
18886: those orphans whose unwedded mothers die in bearing them: the secret of
18887: our paternity lies in their grave, and we must there to learn it.
18888: 
18889: And that same day, too, gazing far down from his boat’s side into that
18890: same golden sea, Starbuck lowly murmured:—
18891: 
18892: “Loveliness unfathomable, as ever lover saw in his young bride’s
18893: eye!—Tell me not of thy teeth-tiered sharks, and thy kidnapping
18894: cannibal ways. Let faith oust fact; let fancy oust memory; I look deep
18895: down and do believe.”
18896: 
18897: And Stubb, fish-like, with sparkling scales, leaped up in that same
18898: golden light:—
18899: 
18900: “I am Stubb, and Stubb has his history; but here Stubb takes oaths that
18901: he has always been jolly!”
18902: 
18903: 
18904: CHAPTER 115. The Pequod Meets The Bachelor.
18905: 
18906: And jolly enough were the sights and the sounds that came bearing down
18907: before the wind, some few weeks after Ahab’s harpoon had been welded.
18908: 
18909: It was a Nantucket ship, the Bachelor, which had just wedged in her
18910: last cask of oil, and bolted down her bursting hatches; and now, in
18911: glad holiday apparel, was joyously, though somewhat vain-gloriously,
18912: sailing round among the widely-separated ships on the ground, previous
18913: to pointing her prow for home.
18914: 
18915: The three men at her mast-head wore long streamers of narrow red
18916: bunting at their hats; from the stern, a whale-boat was suspended,
18917: bottom down; and hanging captive from the bowsprit was seen the long
18918: lower jaw of the last whale they had slain. Signals, ensigns, and jacks
18919: of all colours were flying from her rigging, on every side. Sideways
18920: lashed in each of her three basketed tops were two barrels of sperm;
18921: above which, in her top-mast cross-trees, you saw slender breakers of
18922: the same precious fluid; and nailed to her main truck was a brazen
18923: lamp.
18924: 
18925: As was afterwards learned, the Bachelor had met with the most
18926: surprising success; all the more wonderful, for that while cruising in
18927: the same seas numerous other vessels had gone entire months without
18928: securing a single fish. Not only had barrels of beef and bread been
18929: given away to make room for the far more valuable sperm, but additional
18930: supplemental casks had been bartered for, from the ships she had met;
18931: and these were stowed along the deck, and in the captain’s and
18932: officers’ state-rooms. Even the cabin table itself had been knocked
18933: into kindling-wood; and the cabin mess dined off the broad head of an
18934: oil-butt, lashed down to the floor for a centrepiece. In the
18935: forecastle, the sailors had actually caulked and pitched their chests,
18936: and filled them; it was humorously added, that the cook had clapped a
18937: head on his largest boiler, and filled it; that the steward had plugged
18938: his spare coffee-pot and filled it; that the harpooneers had headed the
18939: sockets of their irons and filled them; that indeed everything was
18940: filled with sperm, except the captain’s pantaloons pockets, and those
18941: he reserved to thrust his hands into, in self-complacent testimony of
18942: his entire satisfaction.
18943: 
18944: As this glad ship of good luck bore down upon the moody Pequod, the
18945: barbarian sound of enormous drums came from her forecastle; and drawing
18946: still nearer, a crowd of her men were seen standing round her huge
18947: try-pots, which, covered with the parchment-like _poke_ or stomach skin
18948: of the black fish, gave forth a loud roar to every stroke of the
18949: clenched hands of the crew. On the quarter-deck, the mates and
18950: harpooneers were dancing with the olive-hued girls who had eloped with
18951: them from the Polynesian Isles; while suspended in an ornamented boat,
18952: firmly secured aloft between the foremast and mainmast, three Long
18953: Island negroes, with glittering fiddle-bows of whale ivory, were
18954: presiding over the hilarious jig. Meanwhile, others of the ship’s
18955: company were tumultuously busy at the masonry of the try-works, from
18956: which the huge pots had been removed. You would have almost thought
18957: they were pulling down the cursed Bastille, such wild cries they
18958: raised, as the now useless brick and mortar were being hurled into the
18959: sea.
18960: 
18961: Lord and master over all this scene, the captain stood erect on the
18962: ship’s elevated quarter-deck, so that the whole rejoicing drama was
18963: full before him, and seemed merely contrived for his own individual
18964: diversion.
18965: 
18966: And Ahab, he too was standing on his quarter-deck, shaggy and black,
18967: with a stubborn gloom; and as the two ships crossed each other’s
18968: wakes—one all jubilations for things passed, the other all forebodings
18969: as to things to come—their two captains in themselves impersonated the
18970: whole striking contrast of the scene.
18971: 
18972: “Come aboard, come aboard!” cried the gay Bachelor’s commander, lifting
18973: a glass and a bottle in the air.
18974: 
18975: “Hast seen the White Whale?” gritted Ahab in reply.
18976: 
18977: “No; only heard of him; but don’t believe in him at all,” said the
18978: other good-humoredly. “Come aboard!”
18979: 
18980: “Thou art too damned jolly. Sail on. Hast lost any men?”
18981: 
18982: “Not enough to speak of—two islanders, that’s all;—but come aboard, old
18983: hearty, come along. I’ll soon take that black from your brow. Come
18984: along, will ye (merry’s the play); a full ship and homeward-bound.”
18985: 
18986: “How wondrous familiar is a fool!” muttered Ahab; then aloud, “Thou art
18987: a full ship and homeward bound, thou sayst; well, then, call me an
18988: empty ship, and outward-bound. So go thy ways, and I will mine. Forward
18989: there! Set all sail, and keep her to the wind!”
18990: 
18991: And thus, while the one ship went cheerily before the breeze, the other
18992: stubbornly fought against it; and so the two vessels parted; the crew
18993: of the Pequod looking with grave, lingering glances towards the
18994: receding Bachelor; but the Bachelor’s men never heeding their gaze for
18995: the lively revelry they were in. And as Ahab, leaning over the
18996: taffrail, eyed the homeward-bound craft, he took from his pocket a
18997: small vial of sand, and then looking from the ship to the vial, seemed
18998: thereby bringing two remote associations together, for that vial was
18999: filled with Nantucket soundings.
19000: 
19001: 
19002: CHAPTER 116. The Dying Whale.
19003: 
19004: Not seldom in this life, when, on the right side, fortune’s favourites
19005: sail close by us, we, though all adroop before, catch somewhat of the
19006: rushing breeze, and joyfully feel our bagging sails fill out. So seemed
19007: it with the Pequod. For next day after encountering the gay Bachelor,
19008: whales were seen and four were slain; and one of them by Ahab.
19009: 
19010: It was far down the afternoon; and when all the spearings of the
19011: crimson fight were done: and floating in the lovely sunset sea and sky,
19012: sun and whale both stilly died together; then, such a sweetness and
19013: such plaintiveness, such inwreathing orisons curled up in that rosy
19014: air, that it almost seemed as if far over from the deep green convent
19015: valleys of the Manilla isles, the Spanish land-breeze, wantonly turned
19016: sailor, had gone to sea, freighted with these vesper hymns.
19017: 
19018: Soothed again, but only soothed to deeper gloom, Ahab, who had sterned
19019: off from the whale, sat intently watching his final wanings from the
19020: now tranquil boat. For that strange spectacle observable in all sperm
19021: whales dying—the turning sunwards of the head, and so expiring—that
19022: strange spectacle, beheld of such a placid evening, somehow to Ahab
19023: conveyed a wondrousness unknown before.
19024: 
19025: “He turns and turns him to it,—how slowly, but how steadfastly, his
19026: homage-rendering and invoking brow, with his last dying motions. He too
19027: worships fire; most faithful, broad, baronial vassal of the sun!—Oh
19028: that these too-favouring eyes should see these too-favouring sights.
19029: Look! here, far water-locked; beyond all hum of human weal or woe; in
19030: these most candid and impartial seas; where to traditions no rocks
19031: furnish tablets; where for long Chinese ages, the billows have still
19032: rolled on speechless and unspoken to, as stars that shine upon the
19033: Niger’s unknown source; here, too, life dies sunwards full of faith;
19034: but see! no sooner dead, than death whirls round the corpse, and it
19035: heads some other way.
19036: 
19037: “Oh, thou dark Hindoo half of nature, who of drowned bones hast builded
19038: thy separate throne somewhere in the heart of these unverdured seas;
19039: thou art an infidel, thou queen, and too truly speakest to me in the
19040: wide-slaughtering Typhoon, and the hushed burial of its after calm. Nor
19041: has this thy whale sunwards turned his dying head, and then gone round
19042: again, without a lesson to me.
19043: 
19044: “Oh, trebly hooped and welded hip of power! Oh, high aspiring,
19045: rainbowed jet!—that one strivest, this one jettest all in vain! In
19046: vain, oh whale, dost thou seek intercedings with yon all-quickening
19047: sun, that only calls forth life, but gives it not again. Yet dost thou,
19048: darker half, rock me with a prouder, if a darker faith. All thy
19049: unnamable imminglings float beneath me here; I am buoyed by breaths of
19050: once living things, exhaled as air, but water now.
19051: 
19052: “Then hail, for ever hail, O sea, in whose eternal tossings the wild
19053: fowl finds his only rest. Born of earth, yet suckled by the sea; though
19054: hill and valley mothered me, ye billows are my foster-brothers!”
19055: 
19056: 
19057: CHAPTER 117. The Whale Watch.
19058: 
19059: The four whales slain that evening had died wide apart; one, far to
19060: windward; one, less distant, to leeward; one ahead; one astern. These
19061: last three were brought alongside ere nightfall; but the windward one
19062: could not be reached till morning; and the boat that had killed it lay
19063: by its side all night; and that boat was Ahab’s.
19064: 
19065: The waif-pole was thrust upright into the dead whale’s spout-hole; and
19066: the lantern hanging from its top, cast a troubled flickering glare upon
19067: the black, glossy back, and far out upon the midnight waves, which
19068: gently chafed the whale’s broad flank, like soft surf upon a beach.
19069: 
19070: Ahab and all his boat’s crew seemed asleep but the Parsee; who
19071: crouching in the bow, sat watching the sharks, that spectrally played
19072: round the whale, and tapped the light cedar planks with their tails. A
19073: sound like the moaning in squadrons over Asphaltites of unforgiven
19074: ghosts of Gomorrah, ran shuddering through the air.
19075: 
19076: Started from his slumbers, Ahab, face to face, saw the Parsee; and
19077: hooped round by the gloom of the night they seemed the last men in a
19078: flooded world. “I have dreamed it again,” said he.
19079: 
19080: “Of the hearses? Have I not said, old man, that neither hearse nor
19081: coffin can be thine?”
19082: 
19083: “And who are hearsed that die on the sea?”
19084: 
19085: “But I said, old man, that ere thou couldst die on this voyage, two
19086: hearses must verily be seen by thee on the sea; the first not made by
19087: mortal hands; and the visible wood of the last one must be grown in
19088: America.”
19089: 
19090: “Aye, aye! a strange sight that, Parsee:—a hearse and its plumes
19091: floating over the ocean with the waves for the pall-bearers. Ha! Such a
19092: sight we shall not soon see.”
19093: 
19094: “Believe it or not, thou canst not die till it be seen, old man.”
19095: 
19096: “And what was that saying about thyself?”
19097: 
19098: “Though it come to the last, I shall still go before thee thy pilot.”
19099: 
19100: “And when thou art so gone before—if that ever befall—then ere I can
19101: follow, thou must still appear to me, to pilot me still?—Was it not so?
19102: Well, then, did I believe all ye say, oh my pilot! I have here two
19103: pledges that I shall yet slay Moby Dick and survive it.”
19104: 
19105: “Take another pledge, old man,” said the Parsee, as his eyes lighted up
19106: like fire-flies in the gloom—“Hemp only can kill thee.”
