19107: 
19108: “The gallows, ye mean.—I am immortal then, on land and on sea,” cried
19109: Ahab, with a laugh of derision;—“Immortal on land and on sea!”
19110: 
19111: Both were silent again, as one man. The grey dawn came on, and the
19112: slumbering crew arose from the boat’s bottom, and ere noon the dead
19113: whale was brought to the ship.
19114: 
19115: 
19116: CHAPTER 118. The Quadrant.
19117: 
19118: The season for the Line at length drew near; and every day when Ahab,
19119: coming from his cabin, cast his eyes aloft, the vigilant helmsman would
19120: ostentatiously handle his spokes, and the eager mariners quickly run to
19121: the braces, and would stand there with all their eyes centrally fixed
19122: on the nailed doubloon; impatient for the order to point the ship’s
19123: prow for the equator. In good time the order came. It was hard upon
19124: high noon; and Ahab, seated in the bows of his high-hoisted boat, was
19125: about taking his wonted daily observation of the sun to determine his
19126: latitude.
19127: 
19128: Now, in that Japanese sea, the days in summer are as freshets of
19129: effulgences. That unblinkingly vivid Japanese sun seems the blazing
19130: focus of the glassy ocean’s immeasurable burning-glass. The sky looks
19131: lacquered; clouds there are none; the horizon floats; and this
19132: nakedness of unrelieved radiance is as the insufferable splendors of
19133: God’s throne. Well that Ahab’s quadrant was furnished with coloured
19134: glasses, through which to take sight of that solar fire. So, swinging
19135: his seated form to the roll of the ship, and with his
19136: astrological-looking instrument placed to his eye, he remained in that
19137: posture for some moments to catch the precise instant when the sun
19138: should gain its precise meridian. Meantime while his whole attention
19139: was absorbed, the Parsee was kneeling beneath him on the ship’s deck,
19140: and with face thrown up like Ahab’s, was eyeing the same sun with him;
19141: only the lids of his eyes half hooded their orbs, and his wild face was
19142: subdued to an earthly passionlessness. At length the desired
19143: observation was taken; and with his pencil upon his ivory leg, Ahab
19144: soon calculated what his latitude must be at that precise instant. Then
19145: falling into a moment’s revery, he again looked up towards the sun and
19146: murmured to himself: “Thou sea-mark! thou high and mighty Pilot! thou
19147: tellest me truly where I _am_—but canst thou cast the least hint where
19148: I _shall_ be? Or canst thou tell where some other thing besides me is
19149: this moment living? Where is Moby Dick? This instant thou must be
19150: eyeing him. These eyes of mine look into the very eye that is even now
19151: beholding him; aye, and into the eye that is even now equally beholding
19152: the objects on the unknown, thither side of thee, thou sun!”
19153: 
19154: Then gazing at his quadrant, and handling, one after the other, its
19155: numerous cabalistical contrivances, he pondered again, and muttered:
19156: “Foolish toy! babies’ plaything of haughty Admirals, and Commodores,
19157: and Captains; the world brags of thee, of thy cunning and might; but
19158: what after all canst thou do, but tell the poor, pitiful point, where
19159: thou thyself happenest to be on this wide planet, and the hand that
19160: holds thee: no! not one jot more! Thou canst not tell where one drop of
19161: water or one grain of sand will be to-morrow noon; and yet with thy
19162: impotence thou insultest the sun! Science! Curse thee, thou vain toy;
19163: and cursed be all the things that cast man’s eyes aloft to that heaven,
19164: whose live vividness but scorches him, as these old eyes are even now
19165: scorched with thy light, O sun! Level by nature to this earth’s horizon
19166: are the glances of man’s eyes; not shot from the crown of his head, as
19167: if God had meant him to gaze on his firmament. Curse thee, thou
19168: quadrant!” dashing it to the deck, “no longer will I guide my earthly
19169: way by thee; the level ship’s compass, and the level dead-reckoning, by
19170: log and by line; _these_ shall conduct me, and show me my place on the
19171: sea. Aye,” lighting from the boat to the deck, “thus I trample on thee,
19172: thou paltry thing that feebly pointest on high; thus I split and
19173: destroy thee!”
19174: 
19175: As the frantic old man thus spoke and thus trampled with his live and
19176: dead feet, a sneering triumph that seemed meant for Ahab, and a
19177: fatalistic despair that seemed meant for himself—these passed over the
19178: mute, motionless Parsee’s face. Unobserved he rose and glided away;
19179: while, awestruck by the aspect of their commander, the seamen clustered
19180: together on the forecastle, till Ahab, troubledly pacing the deck,
19181: shouted out—“To the braces! Up helm!—square in!”
19182: 
19183: In an instant the yards swung round; and as the ship half-wheeled upon
19184: her heel, her three firm-seated graceful masts erectly poised upon her
19185: long, ribbed hull, seemed as the three Horatii pirouetting on one
19186: sufficient steed.
19187: 
19188: Standing between the knight-heads, Starbuck watched the Pequod’s
19189: tumultuous way, and Ahab’s also, as he went lurching along the deck.
19190: 
19191: “I have sat before the dense coal fire and watched it all aglow, full
19192: of its tormented flaming life; and I have seen it wane at last, down,
19193: down, to dumbest dust. Old man of oceans! of all this fiery life of
19194: thine, what will at length remain but one little heap of ashes!”
19195: 
19196: “Aye,” cried Stubb, “but sea-coal ashes—mind ye that, Mr.
19197: Starbuck—sea-coal, not your common charcoal. Well, well; I heard Ahab
19198: mutter, ‘Here some one thrusts these cards into these old hands of
19199: mine; swears that I must play them, and no others.’ And damn me, Ahab,
19200: but thou actest right; live in the game, and die in it!”
19201: 
19202: 
19203: CHAPTER 119. The Candles.
19204: 
19205: Warmest climes but nurse the cruellest fangs: the tiger of Bengal
19206: crouches in spiced groves of ceaseless verdure. Skies the most
19207: effulgent but basket the deadliest thunders: gorgeous Cuba knows
19208: tornadoes that never swept tame northern lands. So, too, it is, that in
19209: these resplendent Japanese seas the mariner encounters the direst of
19210: all storms, the Typhoon. It will sometimes burst from out that
19211: cloudless sky, like an exploding bomb upon a dazed and sleepy town.
19212: 
19213: Towards evening of that day, the Pequod was torn of her canvas, and
19214: bare-poled was left to fight a Typhoon which had struck her directly
19215: ahead. When darkness came on, sky and sea roared and split with the
19216: thunder, and blazed with the lightning, that showed the disabled masts
19217: fluttering here and there with the rags which the first fury of the
19218: tempest had left for its after sport.
19219: 
19220: Holding by a shroud, Starbuck was standing on the quarter-deck; at
19221: every flash of the lightning glancing aloft, to see what additional
19222: disaster might have befallen the intricate hamper there; while Stubb
19223: and Flask were directing the men in the higher hoisting and firmer
19224: lashing of the boats. But all their pains seemed naught. Though lifted
19225: to the very top of the cranes, the windward quarter boat (Ahab’s) did
19226: not escape. A great rolling sea, dashing high up against the reeling
19227: ship’s high teetering side, stove in the boat’s bottom at the stern,
19228: and left it again, all dripping through like a sieve.
19229: 
19230: “Bad work, bad work! Mr. Starbuck,” said Stubb, regarding the wreck,
19231: “but the sea will have its way. Stubb, for one, can’t fight it. You
19232: see, Mr. Starbuck, a wave has such a great long start before it leaps,
19233: all round the world it runs, and then comes the spring! But as for me,
19234: all the start I have to meet it, is just across the deck here. But
19235: never mind; it’s all in fun: so the old song says;”—(_sings_.)
19236: 
19237: 
19238:   Oh! jolly is the gale, And a joker is the whale, A’ flourishin’ his
19239:   tail,— Such a funny, sporty, gamy, jesty, joky, hoky-poky lad, is the
19240:   Ocean, oh!
19241: 
19242:   The scud all a flyin’, That’s his flip only foamin’; When he stirs in
19243:   the spicin’,— Such a funny, sporty, gamy, jesty, joky, hoky-poky lad,
19244:   is the Ocean, oh!
19245: 
19246:   Thunder splits the ships, But he only smacks his lips, A tastin’ of
19247:   this flip,— Such a funny, sporty, gamy, jesty, joky, hoky-poky lad,
19248:   is the Ocean, oh!
19249: 
19250: 
19251: 
19252: “Avast Stubb,” cried Starbuck, “let the Typhoon sing, and strike his
19253: harp here in our rigging; but if thou art a brave man thou wilt hold
19254: thy peace.”
19255: 
19256: “But I am not a brave man; never said I was a brave man; I am a coward;
19257: and I sing to keep up my spirits. And I tell you what it is, Mr.
19258: Starbuck, there’s no way to stop my singing in this world but to cut my
19259: throat. And when that’s done, ten to one I sing ye the doxology for a
19260: wind-up.”
19261: 
19262: “Madman! look through my eyes if thou hast none of thine own.”
19263: 
19264: “What! how can you see better of a dark night than anybody else, never
19265: mind how foolish?”
19266: 
19267: “Here!” cried Starbuck, seizing Stubb by the shoulder, and pointing his
19268: hand towards the weather bow, “markest thou not that the gale comes
19269: from the eastward, the very course Ahab is to run for Moby Dick? the
19270: very course he swung to this day noon? now mark his boat there; where
19271: is that stove? In the stern-sheets, man; where he is wont to stand—his
19272: stand-point is stove, man! Now jump overboard, and sing away, if thou
19273: must!
19274: 
19275: “I don’t half understand ye: what’s in the wind?”
19276: 
19277: “Yes, yes, round the Cape of Good Hope is the shortest way to
19278: Nantucket,” soliloquized Starbuck suddenly, heedless of Stubb’s
19279: question. “The gale that now hammers at us to stave us, we can turn it
19280: into a fair wind that will drive us towards home. Yonder, to windward,
19281: all is blackness of doom; but to leeward, homeward—I see it lightens up
19282: there; but not with the lightning.”
19283: 
19284: At that moment in one of the intervals of profound darkness, following
19285: the flashes, a voice was heard at his side; and almost at the same
19286: instant a volley of thunder peals rolled overhead.
19287: 
19288: “Who’s there?”
19289: 
19290: “Old Thunder!” said Ahab, groping his way along the bulwarks to his
19291: pivot-hole; but suddenly finding his path made plain to him by elbowed
19292: lances of fire.
19293: 
19294: Now, as the lightning rod to a spire on shore is intended to carry off
19295: the perilous fluid into the soil; so the kindred rod which at sea some
19296: ships carry to each mast, is intended to conduct it into the water. But
19297: as this conductor must descend to considerable depth, that its end may
19298: avoid all contact with the hull; and as moreover, if kept constantly
19299: towing there, it would be liable to many mishaps, besides interfering
19300: not a little with some of the rigging, and more or less impeding the
19301: vessel’s way in the water; because of all this, the lower parts of a
19302: ship’s lightning-rods are not always overboard; but are generally made
19303: in long slender links, so as to be the more readily hauled up into the
19304: chains outside, or thrown down into the sea, as occasion may require.
19305: 
19306: “The rods! the rods!” cried Starbuck to the crew, suddenly admonished
19307: to vigilance by the vivid lightning that had just been darting
19308: flambeaux, to light Ahab to his post. “Are they overboard? drop them
19309: over, fore and aft. Quick!”
19310: 
19311: “Avast!” cried Ahab; “let’s have fair play here, though we be the
19312: weaker side. Yet I’ll contribute to raise rods on the Himmalehs and
19313: Andes, that all the world may be secured; but out on privileges! Let
19314: them be, sir.”
19315: 
19316: “Look aloft!” cried Starbuck. “The corpusants! the corpusants!”
19317: 
19318: All the yard-arms were tipped with a pallid fire; and touched at each
19319: tri-pointed lightning-rod-end with three tapering white flames, each of
19320: the three tall masts was silently burning in that sulphurous air, like
19321: three gigantic wax tapers before an altar.
19322: 
19323: “Blast the boat! let it go!” cried Stubb at this instant, as a swashing
19324: sea heaved up under his own little craft, so that its gunwale violently
19325: jammed his hand, as he was passing a lashing. “Blast it!”—but slipping
19326: backward on the deck, his uplifted eyes caught the flames; and
19327: immediately shifting his tone he cried—“The corpusants have mercy on us
19328: all!”
19329: 
19330: To sailors, oaths are household words; they will swear in the trance of
19331: the calm, and in the teeth of the tempest; they will imprecate curses
19332: from the topsail-yard-arms, when most they teeter over to a seething
19333: sea; but in all my voyagings, seldom have I heard a common oath when
19334: God’s burning finger has been laid on the ship; when His “Mene, Mene,
19335: Tekel Upharsin” has been woven into the shrouds and the cordage.
19336: 
19337: While this pallidness was burning aloft, few words were heard from the
19338: enchanted crew; who in one thick cluster stood on the forecastle, all
19339: their eyes gleaming in that pale phosphorescence, like a far away
19340: constellation of stars. Relieved against the ghostly light, the
19341: gigantic jet negro, Daggoo, loomed up to thrice his real stature, and
19342: seemed the black cloud from which the thunder had come. The parted
19343: mouth of Tashtego revealed his shark-white teeth, which strangely
19344: gleamed as if they too had been tipped by corpusants; while lit up by
19345: the preternatural light, Queequeg’s tattooing burned like Satanic blue
19346: flames on his body.
19347: 
19348: The tableau all waned at last with the pallidness aloft; and once more
19349: the Pequod and every soul on her decks were wrapped in a pall. A moment
19350: or two passed, when Starbuck, going forward, pushed against some one.
19351: It was Stubb. “What thinkest thou now, man; I heard thy cry; it was not
19352: the same in the song.”
19353: 
19354: “No, no, it wasn’t; I said the corpusants have mercy on us all; and I
19355: hope they will, still. But do they only have mercy on long faces?—have
19356: they no bowels for a laugh? And look ye, Mr. Starbuck—but it’s too dark
19357: to look. Hear me, then: I take that mast-head flame we saw for a sign
19358: of good luck; for those masts are rooted in a hold that is going to be
19359: chock a’ block with sperm-oil, d’ye see; and so, all that sperm will
19360: work up into the masts, like sap in a tree. Yes, our three masts will
19361: yet be as three spermaceti candles—that’s the good promise we saw.”
19362: 
19363: At that moment Starbuck caught sight of Stubb’s face slowly beginning
19364: to glimmer into sight. Glancing upwards, he cried: “See! see!” and once
19365: more the high tapering flames were beheld with what seemed redoubled
19366: supernaturalness in their pallor.
19367: 
19368: “The corpusants have mercy on us all,” cried Stubb, again.
19369: 
19370: At the base of the mainmast, full beneath the doubloon and the flame,
19371: the Parsee was kneeling in Ahab’s front, but with his head bowed away
19372: from him; while near by, from the arched and overhanging rigging, where
19373: they had just been engaged securing a spar, a number of the seamen,
19374: arrested by the glare, now cohered together, and hung pendulous, like a
19375: knot of numbed wasps from a drooping, orchard twig. In various
19376: enchanted attitudes, like the standing, or stepping, or running
19377: skeletons in Herculaneum, others remained rooted to the deck; but all
19378: their eyes upcast.
19379: 
19380: “Aye, aye, men!” cried Ahab. “Look up at it; mark it well; the white
19381: flame but lights the way to the White Whale! Hand me those mainmast
19382: links there; I would fain feel this pulse, and let mine beat against
19383: it; blood against fire! So.”
19384: 
19385: Then turning—the last link held fast in his left hand, he put his foot
19386: upon the Parsee; and with fixed upward eye, and high-flung right arm,
19387: he stood erect before the lofty tri-pointed trinity of flames.
19388: 
19389: “Oh! thou clear spirit of clear fire, whom on these seas I as Persian
19390: once did worship, till in the sacramental act so burned by thee, that
19391: to this hour I bear the scar; I now know thee, thou clear spirit, and I
19392: now know that thy right worship is defiance. To neither love nor
19393: reverence wilt thou be kind; and e’en for hate thou canst but kill; and
19394: all are killed. No fearless fool now fronts thee. I own thy speechless,
19395: placeless power; but to the last gasp of my earthquake life will
19396: dispute its unconditional, unintegral mastery in me. In the midst of
19397: the personified impersonal, a personality stands here. Though but a
19398: point at best; whencesoe’er I came; wheresoe’er I go; yet while I
19399: earthly live, the queenly personality lives in me, and feels her royal
19400: rights. But war is pain, and hate is woe. Come in thy lowest form of
19401: love, and I will kneel and kiss thee; but at thy highest, come as mere
19402: supernal power; and though thou launchest navies of full-freighted
19403: worlds, there’s that in here that still remains indifferent. Oh, thou
19404: clear spirit, of thy fire thou madest me, and like a true child of
19405: fire, I breathe it back to thee.”
19406: 
19407: [_Sudden, repeated flashes of lightning; the nine flames leap
19408: lengthwise to thrice their previous height; Ahab, with the rest, closes
19409: his eyes, his right hand pressed hard upon them._]
19410: 
19411: “I own thy speechless, placeless power; said I not so? Nor was it wrung
19412: from me; nor do I now drop these links. Thou canst blind; but I can
19413: then grope. Thou canst consume; but I can then be ashes. Take the
19414: homage of these poor eyes, and shutter-hands. I would not take it. The
19415: lightning flashes through my skull; mine eye-balls ache and ache; my
19416: whole beaten brain seems as beheaded, and rolling on some stunning
19417: ground. Oh, oh! Yet blindfold, yet will I talk to thee. Light though
19418: thou be, thou leapest out of darkness; but I am darkness leaping out of
19419: light, leaping out of thee! The javelins cease; open eyes; see, or not?
19420: There burn the flames! Oh, thou magnanimous! now I do glory in my
19421: genealogy. But thou art but my fiery father; my sweet mother, I know
19422: not. Oh, cruel! what hast thou done with her? There lies my puzzle; but
19423: thine is greater. Thou knowest not how came ye, hence callest thyself
19424: unbegotten; certainly knowest not thy beginning, hence callest thyself
19425: unbegun. I know that of me, which thou knowest not of thyself, oh, thou
19426: omnipotent. There is some unsuffusing thing beyond thee, thou clear
19427: spirit, to whom all thy eternity is but time, all thy creativeness
19428: mechanical. Through thee, thy flaming self, my scorched eyes do dimly
19429: see it. Oh, thou foundling fire, thou hermit immemorial, thou too hast
19430: thy incommunicable riddle, thy unparticipated grief. Here again with
19431: haughty agony, I read my sire. Leap! leap up, and lick the sky! I leap
19432: with thee; I burn with thee; would fain be welded with thee; defyingly
19433: I worship thee!”
19434: 
19435: “The boat! the boat!” cried Starbuck, “look at thy boat, old man!”
19436: 
19437: Ahab’s harpoon, the one forged at Perth’s fire, remained firmly lashed
19438: in its conspicuous crotch, so that it projected beyond his whale-boat’s
19439: bow; but the sea that had stove its bottom had caused the loose leather
19440: sheath to drop off; and from the keen steel barb there now came a
19441: levelled flame of pale, forked fire. As the silent harpoon burned there
19442: like a serpent’s tongue, Starbuck grasped Ahab by the arm—“God, God is
19443: against thee, old man; forbear! ’tis an ill voyage! ill begun, ill
19444: continued; let me square the yards, while we may, old man, and make a
19445: fair wind of it homewards, to go on a better voyage than this.”
19446: 
19447: Overhearing Starbuck, the panic-stricken crew instantly ran to the
19448: braces—though not a sail was left aloft. For the moment all the aghast
19449: mate’s thoughts seemed theirs; they raised a half mutinous cry. But
19450: dashing the rattling lightning links to the deck, and snatching the
19451: burning harpoon, Ahab waved it like a torch among them; swearing to
19452: transfix with it the first sailor that but cast loose a rope’s end.
19453: Petrified by his aspect, and still more shrinking from the fiery dart
19454: that he held, the men fell back in dismay, and Ahab again spoke:—
19455: 
19456: “All your oaths to hunt the White Whale are as binding as mine; and
19457: heart, soul, and body, lungs and life, old Ahab is bound. And that ye
19458: may know to what tune this heart beats; look ye here; thus I blow out
19459: the last fear!” And with one blast of his breath he extinguished the
19460: flame.
19461: 
19462: As in the hurricane that sweeps the plain, men fly the neighborhood of
19463: some lone, gigantic elm, whose very height and strength but render it
19464: so much the more unsafe, because so much the more a mark for
19465: thunderbolts; so at those last words of Ahab’s many of the mariners did
19466: run from him in a terror of dismay.
19467: 
19468: 
19469: CHAPTER 120. The Deck Towards the End of the First Night Watch.
19470: 
19471: _Ahab standing by the helm. Starbuck approaching him._
19472: 
19473: “We must send down the main-top-sail yard, sir. The band is working
19474: loose and the lee lift is half-stranded. Shall I strike it, sir?”
19475: 
19476: “Strike nothing; lash it. If I had sky-sail poles, I’d sway them up
19477: now.”
19478: 
19479: “Sir!—in God’s name!—sir?”
19480: 
19481: “Well.”
19482: 
19483: “The anchors are working, sir. Shall I get them inboard?”
19484: 
19485: “Strike nothing, and stir nothing, but lash everything. The wind rises,
19486: but it has not got up to my table-lands yet. Quick, and see to it.—By
19487: masts and keels! he takes me for the hunch-backed skipper of some
19488: coasting smack. Send down my main-top-sail yard! Ho, gluepots! Loftiest
19489: trucks were made for wildest winds, and this brain-truck of mine now
19490: sails amid the cloud-scud. Shall I strike that? Oh, none but cowards
19491: send down their brain-trucks in tempest time. What a hooroosh aloft
19492: there! I would e’en take it for sublime, did I not know that the colic
19493: is a noisy malady. Oh, take medicine, take medicine!”
19494: 
19495: 
19496: CHAPTER 121. Midnight.—The Forecastle Bulwarks.
19497: 
19498: _Stubb and Flask mounted on them, and passing additional lashings over
19499: the anchors there hanging._
19500: 
19501: “No, Stubb; you may pound that knot there as much as you please, but
19502: you will never pound into me what you were just now saying. And how
19503: long ago is it since you said the very contrary? Didn’t you once say
19504: that whatever ship Ahab sails in, that ship should pay something extra
19505: on its insurance policy, just as though it were loaded with powder
19506: barrels aft and boxes of lucifers forward? Stop, now; didn’t you say
19507: so?”
19508: 
19509: “Well, suppose I did? What then? I’ve part changed my flesh since that
19510: time, why not my mind? Besides, supposing we _are_ loaded with powder
19511: barrels aft and lucifers forward; how the devil could the lucifers get
19512: afire in this drenching spray here? Why, my little man, you have pretty
19513: red hair, but you couldn’t get afire now. Shake yourself; you’re
19514: Aquarius, or the water-bearer, Flask; might fill pitchers at your coat
19515: collar. Don’t you see, then, that for these extra risks the Marine
19516: Insurance companies have extra guarantees? Here are hydrants, Flask.
19517: But hark, again, and I’ll answer ye the other thing. First take your
19518: leg off from the crown of the anchor here, though, so I can pass the
19519: rope; now listen. What’s the mighty difference between holding a mast’s
19520: lightning-rod in the storm, and standing close by a mast that hasn’t
19521: got any lightning-rod at all in a storm? Don’t you see, you
19522: timber-head, that no harm can come to the holder of the rod, unless the
19523: mast is first struck? What are you talking about, then? Not one ship in
19524: a hundred carries rods, and Ahab,—aye, man, and all of us,—were in no
19525: more danger then, in my poor opinion, than all the crews in ten
19526: thousand ships now sailing the seas. Why, you King-Post, you, I suppose
19527: you would have every man in the world go about with a small
19528: lightning-rod running up the corner of his hat, like a militia
19529: officer’s skewered feather, and trailing behind like his sash. Why
19530: don’t ye be sensible, Flask? it’s easy to be sensible; why don’t ye,
19531: then? any man with half an eye can be sensible.”
19532: 
19533: “I don’t know that, Stubb. You sometimes find it rather hard.”
19534: 
19535: “Yes, when a fellow’s soaked through, it’s hard to be sensible, that’s
19536: a fact. And I am about drenched with this spray. Never mind; catch the
19537: turn there, and pass it. Seems to me we are lashing down these anchors
19538: now as if they were never going to be used again. Tying these two
19539: anchors here, Flask, seems like tying a man’s hands behind him. And
19540: what big generous hands they are, to be sure. These are your iron
19541: fists, hey? What a hold they have, too! I wonder, Flask, whether the
19542: world is anchored anywhere; if she is, she swings with an uncommon long
19543: cable, though. There, hammer that knot down, and we’ve done. So; next
19544: to touching land, lighting on deck is the most satisfactory. I say,
19545: just wring out my jacket skirts, will ye? Thank ye. They laugh at
19546: long-togs so, Flask; but seems to me, a long tailed coat ought always
19547: to be worn in all storms afloat. The tails tapering down that way,
19548: serve to carry off the water, d’ye see. Same with cocked hats; the
19549: cocks form gable-end eave-troughs, Flask. No more monkey-jackets and
19550: tarpaulins for me; I must mount a swallow-tail, and drive down a
19551: beaver; so. Halloa! whew! there goes my tarpaulin overboard; Lord,
19552: Lord, that the winds that come from heaven should be so unmannerly!
19553: This is a nasty night, lad.”
19554: 
19555: 
19556: CHAPTER 122. Midnight Aloft.—Thunder and Lightning.
19557: 
19558: _The main-top-sail yard_.—_Tashtego passing new lashings around it_.
19559: 
19560: “Um, um, um. Stop that thunder! Plenty too much thunder up here. What’s
19561: the use of thunder? Um, um, um. We don’t want thunder; we want rum;
19562: give us a glass of rum. Um, um, um!”
19563: 
19564: 
19565: CHAPTER 123. The Musket.
19566: 
19567: During the most violent shocks of the Typhoon, the man at the Pequod’s
19568: jaw-bone tiller had several times been reelingly hurled to the deck by
19569: its spasmodic motions, even though preventer tackles had been attached
19570: to it—for they were slack—because some play to the tiller was
19571: indispensable.
19572: 
19573: In a severe gale like this, while the ship is but a tossed shuttlecock
19574: to the blast, it is by no means uncommon to see the needles in the
19575: compasses, at intervals, go round and round. It was thus with the
19576: Pequod’s; at almost every shock the helmsman had not failed to notice
19577: the whirling velocity with which they revolved upon the cards; it is a
19578: sight that hardly anyone can behold without some sort of unwonted
19579: emotion.
19580: 
19581: Some hours after midnight, the Typhoon abated so much, that through the
19582: strenuous exertions of Starbuck and Stubb—one engaged forward and the
19583: other aft—the shivered remnants of the jib and fore and main-top-sails
19584: were cut adrift from the spars, and went eddying away to leeward, like
19585: the feathers of an albatross, which sometimes are cast to the winds
19586: when that storm-tossed bird is on the wing.
19587: 
19588: The three corresponding new sails were now bent and reefed, and a
19589: storm-trysail was set further aft; so that the ship soon went through
19590: the water with some precision again; and the course—for the present,
19591: East-south-east—which he was to steer, if practicable, was once more
19592: given to the helmsman. For during the violence of the gale, he had only
19593: steered according to its vicissitudes. But as he was now bringing the
19594: ship as near her course as possible, watching the compass meanwhile,
19595: lo! a good sign! the wind seemed coming round astern; aye, the foul
19596: breeze became fair!
19597: 
19598: Instantly the yards were squared, to the lively song of “_Ho! the fair
19599: wind! oh-ye-ho, cheerly men!_” the crew singing for joy, that so
19600: promising an event should so soon have falsified the evil portents
19601: preceding it.
19602: 
19603: In compliance with the standing order of his commander—to report
19604: immediately, and at any one of the twenty-four hours, any decided
19605: change in the affairs of the deck,—Starbuck had no sooner trimmed the
19606: yards to the breeze—however reluctantly and gloomily,—than he
19607: mechanically went below to apprise Captain Ahab of the circumstance.
19608: 
19609: Ere knocking at his state-room, he involuntarily paused before it a
19610: moment. The cabin lamp—taking long swings this way and that—was burning
19611: fitfully, and casting fitful shadows upon the old man’s bolted door,—a
19612: thin one, with fixed blinds inserted, in place of upper panels. The
19613: isolated subterraneousness of the cabin made a certain humming silence
19614: to reign there, though it was hooped round by all the roar of the
19615: elements. The loaded muskets in the rack were shiningly revealed, as
19616: they stood upright against the forward bulkhead. Starbuck was an
19617: honest, upright man; but out of Starbuck’s heart, at that instant when
19618: he saw the muskets, there strangely evolved an evil thought; but so
19619: blent with its neutral or good accompaniments that for the instant he
19620: hardly knew it for itself.
19621: 
19622: “He would have shot me once,” he murmured, “yes, there’s the very
19623: musket that he pointed at me;—that one with the studded stock; let me
19624: touch it—lift it. Strange, that I, who have handled so many deadly
19625: lances, strange, that I should shake so now. Loaded? I must see. Aye,
19626: aye; and powder in the pan;—that’s not good. Best spill it?—wait. I’ll
19627: cure myself of this. I’ll hold the musket boldly while I think.—I come
19628: to report a fair wind to him. But how fair? Fair for death and
19629: doom,—_that’s_ fair for Moby Dick. It’s a fair wind that’s only fair
19630: for that accursed fish.—The very tube he pointed at me!—the very one;
19631: _this_ one—I hold it here; he would have killed me with the very thing
19632: I handle now.—Aye and he would fain kill all his crew. Does he not say
19633: he will not strike his spars to any gale? Has he not dashed his
19634: heavenly quadrant? and in these same perilous seas, gropes he not his
19635: way by mere dead reckoning of the error-abounding log? and in this very
19636: Typhoon, did he not swear that he would have no lightning-rods? But
19637: shall this crazed old man be tamely suffered to drag a whole ship’s
19638: company down to doom with him?—Yes, it would make him the wilful
19639: murderer of thirty men and more, if this ship come to any deadly harm;
19640: and come to deadly harm, my soul swears this ship will, if Ahab have
19641: his way. If, then, he were this instant—put aside, that crime would not
19642: be his. Ha! is he muttering in his sleep? Yes, just there,—in there,
19643: he’s sleeping. Sleeping? aye, but still alive, and soon awake again. I
19644: can’t withstand thee, then, old man. Not reasoning; not remonstrance;
19645: not entreaty wilt thou hearken to; all this thou scornest. Flat
19646: obedience to thy own flat commands, this is all thou breathest. Aye,
19647: and say’st the men have vow’d thy vow; say’st all of us are Ahabs.
19648: Great God forbid!—But is there no other way? no lawful way?—Make him a
19649: prisoner to be taken home? What! hope to wrest this old man’s living
19650: power from his own living hands? Only a fool would try it. Say he were
19651: pinioned even; knotted all over with ropes and hawsers; chained down to
19652: ring-bolts on this cabin floor; he would be more hideous than a caged
19653: tiger, then. I could not endure the sight; could not possibly fly his
19654: howlings; all comfort, sleep itself, inestimable reason would leave me
19655: on the long intolerable voyage. What, then, remains? The land is
19656: hundreds of leagues away, and locked Japan the nearest. I stand alone
19657: here upon an open sea, with two oceans and a whole continent between me
19658: and law.—Aye, aye, ’tis so.—Is heaven a murderer when its lightning
19659: strikes a would-be murderer in his bed, tindering sheets and skin
19660: together?—And would I be a murderer, then, if”—and slowly, stealthily,
19661: and half sideways looking, he placed the loaded musket’s end against
19662: the door.
19663: 
19664: “On this level, Ahab’s hammock swings within; his head this way. A
19665: touch, and Starbuck may survive to hug his wife and child again.—Oh
19666: Mary! Mary!—boy! boy! boy!—But if I wake thee not to death, old man,
19667: who can tell to what unsounded deeps Starbuck’s body this day week may
19668: sink, with all the crew! Great God, where art Thou? Shall I? shall
19669: I?—The wind has gone down and shifted, sir; the fore and main topsails
19670: are reefed and set; she heads her course.”
19671: 
19672: “Stern all! Oh Moby Dick, I clutch thy heart at last!”
19673: 
19674: Such were the sounds that now came hurtling from out the old man’s
19675: tormented sleep, as if Starbuck’s voice had caused the long dumb dream
19676: to speak.
19677: 
19678: The yet levelled musket shook like a drunkard’s arm against the panel;
19679: Starbuck seemed wrestling with an angel; but turning from the door, he
19680: placed the death-tube in its rack, and left the place.
19681: 
19682: “He’s too sound asleep, Mr. Stubb; go thou down, and wake him, and tell
19683: him. I must see to the deck here. Thou know’st what to say.”
19684: 
19685: 
19686: CHAPTER 124. The Needle.
19687: 
19688: Next morning the not-yet-subsided sea rolled in long slow billows of
19689: mighty bulk, and striving in the Pequod’s gurgling track, pushed her on
19690: like giants’ palms outspread. The strong, unstaggering breeze abounded
19691: so, that sky and air seemed vast outbellying sails; the whole world
19692: boomed before the wind. Muffled in the full morning light, the
19693: invisible sun was only known by the spread intensity of his place;
19694: where his bayonet rays moved on in stacks. Emblazonings, as of crowned
19695: Babylonian kings and queens, reigned over everything. The sea was as a
19696: crucible of molten gold, that bubblingly leaps with light and heat.
19697: 
19698: Long maintaining an enchanted silence, Ahab stood apart; and every time
19699: the tetering ship loweringly pitched down her bowsprit, he turned to
19700: eye the bright sun’s rays produced ahead; and when she profoundly
19701: settled by the stern, he turned behind, and saw the sun’s rearward
19702: place, and how the same yellow rays were blending with his undeviating
19703: wake.
19704: 
19705: “Ha, ha, my ship! thou mightest well be taken now for the sea-chariot
19706: of the sun. Ho, ho! all ye nations before my prow, I bring the sun to
19707: ye! Yoke on the further billows; hallo! a tandem, I drive the sea!”
19708: 
19709: But suddenly reined back by some counter thought, he hurried towards
19710: the helm, huskily demanding how the ship was heading.
19711: 
19712: “East-sou-east, sir,” said the frightened steersman.
19713: 
19714: “Thou liest!” smiting him with his clenched fist. “Heading East at this
19715: hour in the morning, and the sun astern?”
19716: 
19717: Upon this every soul was confounded; for the phenomenon just then
19718: observed by Ahab had unaccountably escaped every one else; but its very
19719: blinding palpableness must have been the cause.
19720: 
19721: Thrusting his head half way into the binnacle, Ahab caught one glimpse
19722: of the compasses; his uplifted arm slowly fell; for a moment he almost
19723: seemed to stagger. Standing behind him Starbuck looked, and lo! the two
19724: compasses pointed East, and the Pequod was as infallibly going West.
19725: 
19726: But ere the first wild alarm could get out abroad among the crew, the
19727: old man with a rigid laugh exclaimed, “I have it! It has happened
19728: before. Mr. Starbuck, last night’s thunder turned our compasses—that’s
19729: all. Thou hast before now heard of such a thing, I take it.”
19730: 
19731: “Aye; but never before has it happened to me, sir,” said the pale mate,
19732: gloomily.
19733: 
19734: Here, it must needs be said, that accidents like this have in more than
19735: one case occurred to ships in violent storms. The magnetic energy, as
19736: developed in the mariner’s needle, is, as all know, essentially one
19737: with the electricity beheld in heaven; hence it is not to be much
19738: marvelled at, that such things should be. Instances where the lightning
19739: has actually struck the vessel, so as to smite down some of the spars
19740: and rigging, the effect upon the needle has at times been still more
19741: fatal; all its loadstone virtue being annihilated, so that the before
19742: magnetic steel was of no more use than an old wife’s knitting needle.
19743: But in either case, the needle never again, of itself, recovers the
19744: original virtue thus marred or lost; and if the binnacle compasses be
19745: affected, the same fate reaches all the others that may be in the ship;
19746: even were the lowermost one inserted into the kelson.
19747: 
19748: Deliberately standing before the binnacle, and eyeing the transpointed
19749: compasses, the old man, with the sharp of his extended hand, now took
19750: the precise bearing of the sun, and satisfied that the needles were
19751: exactly inverted, shouted out his orders for the ship’s course to be
19752: changed accordingly. The yards were hard up; and once more the Pequod
19753: thrust her undaunted bows into the opposing wind, for the supposed fair
19754: one had only been juggling her.
19755: 
19756: Meanwhile, whatever were his own secret thoughts, Starbuck said
19757: nothing, but quietly he issued all requisite orders; while Stubb and
19758: Flask—who in some small degree seemed then to be sharing his
19759: feelings—likewise unmurmuringly acquiesced. As for the men, though some
19760: of them lowly rumbled, their fear of Ahab was greater than their fear
19761: of Fate. But as ever before, the pagan harpooneers remained almost
19762: wholly unimpressed; or if impressed, it was only with a certain
19763: magnetism shot into their congenial hearts from inflexible Ahab’s.
19764: 
19765: For a space the old man walked the deck in rolling reveries. But
19766: chancing to slip with his ivory heel, he saw the crushed copper
19767: sight-tubes of the quadrant he had the day before dashed to the deck.
19768: 
19769: “Thou poor, proud heaven-gazer and sun’s pilot! yesterday I wrecked
19770: thee, and to-day the compasses would fain have wrecked me. So, so. But
19771: Ahab is lord over the level loadstone yet. Mr. Starbuck—a lance without
19772: a pole; a top-maul, and the smallest of the sail-maker’s needles.
19773: Quick!”
19774: 
19775: Accessory, perhaps, to the impulse dictating the thing he was now about
19776: to do, were certain prudential motives, whose object might have been to
19777: revive the spirits of his crew by a stroke of his subtile skill, in a
19778: matter so wondrous as that of the inverted compasses. Besides, the old
19779: man well knew that to steer by transpointed needles, though clumsily
19780: practicable, was not a thing to be passed over by superstitious
19781: sailors, without some shudderings and evil portents.
19782: 
19783: “Men,” said he, steadily turning upon the crew, as the mate handed him
19784: the things he had demanded, “my men, the thunder turned old Ahab’s
19785: needles; but out of this bit of steel Ahab can make one of his own,
19786: that will point as true as any.”
19787: 
19788: Abashed glances of servile wonder were exchanged by the sailors, as
19789: this was said; and with fascinated eyes they awaited whatever magic
19790: might follow. But Starbuck looked away.
19791: 
19792: With a blow from the top-maul Ahab knocked off the steel head of the
19793: lance, and then handing to the mate the long iron rod remaining, bade
19794: him hold it upright, without its touching the deck. Then, with the
19795: maul, after repeatedly smiting the upper end of this iron rod, he
19796: placed the blunted needle endwise on the top of it, and less strongly
19797: hammered that, several times, the mate still holding the rod as before.
19798: Then going through some small strange motions with it—whether
19799: indispensable to the magnetizing of the steel, or merely intended to
19800: augment the awe of the crew, is uncertain—he called for linen thread;
19801: and moving to the binnacle, slipped out the two reversed needles there,
19802: and horizontally suspended the sail-needle by its middle, over one of
19803: the compass-cards. At first, the steel went round and round, quivering
19804: and vibrating at either end; but at last it settled to its place, when
19805: Ahab, who had been intently watching for this result, stepped frankly
19806: back from the binnacle, and pointing his stretched arm towards it,
19807: exclaimed,—“Look ye, for yourselves, if Ahab be not lord of the level
19808: loadstone! The sun is East, and that compass swears it!”
19809: 
19810: One after another they peered in, for nothing but their own eyes could
19811: persuade such ignorance as theirs, and one after another they slunk
19812: away.
19813: 
19814: In his fiery eyes of scorn and triumph, you then saw Ahab in all his
19815: fatal pride.
19816: 
19817: 
19818: CHAPTER 125. The Log and Line.
19819: 
19820: While now the fated Pequod had been so long afloat this voyage, the log
19821: and line had but very seldom been in use. Owing to a confident reliance
19822: upon other means of determining the vessel’s place, some merchantmen,
19823: and many whalemen, especially when cruising, wholly neglect to heave
19824: the log; though at the same time, and frequently more for form’s sake
19825: than anything else, regularly putting down upon the customary slate the
19826: course steered by the ship, as well as the presumed average rate of
19827: progression every hour. It had been thus with the Pequod. The wooden
19828: reel and angular log attached hung, long untouched, just beneath the
19829: railing of the after bulwarks. Rains and spray had damped it; sun and
19830: wind had warped it; all the elements had combined to rot a thing that
19831: hung so idly. But heedless of all this, his mood seized Ahab, as he
19832: happened to glance upon the reel, not many hours after the magnet
19833: scene, and he remembered how his quadrant was no more, and recalled his
19834: frantic oath about the level log and line. The ship was sailing
19835: plungingly; astern the billows rolled in riots.
19836: 
19837: “Forward, there! Heave the log!”
19838: 
19839: Two seamen came. The golden-hued Tahitian and the grizzly Manxman.
19840: “Take the reel, one of ye, I’ll heave.”
19841: 
19842: They went towards the extreme stern, on the ship’s lee side, where the
19843: deck, with the oblique energy of the wind, was now almost dipping into
19844: the creamy, sidelong-rushing sea.
19845: 
19846: The Manxman took the reel, and holding it high up, by the projecting
19847: handle-ends of the spindle, round which the spool of line revolved, so
19848: stood with the angular log hanging downwards, till Ahab advanced to
19849: him.
19850: 
19851: Ahab stood before him, and was lightly unwinding some thirty or forty
19852: turns to form a preliminary hand-coil to toss overboard, when the old
19853: Manxman, who was intently eyeing both him and the line, made bold to
19854: speak.
19855: 
19856: “Sir, I mistrust it; this line looks far gone, long heat and wet have
19857: spoiled it.”
19858: 
19859: “’Twill hold, old gentleman. Long heat and wet, have they spoiled thee?
19860: Thou seem’st to hold. Or, truer perhaps, life holds thee; not thou it.”
19861: 
19862: “I hold the spool, sir. But just as my captain says. With these grey
19863: hairs of mine ’tis not worth while disputing, ’specially with a
19864: superior, who’ll ne’er confess.”
19865: 
19866: “What’s that? There now’s a patched professor in Queen Nature’s
19867: granite-founded College; but methinks he’s too subservient. Where wert
19868: thou born?”
19869: 
19870: “In the little rocky Isle of Man, sir.”
19871: 
19872: “Excellent! Thou’st hit the world by that.”
19873: 
19874: “I know not, sir, but I was born there.”
19875: 
19876: “In the Isle of Man, hey? Well, the other way, it’s good. Here’s a man
19877: from Man; a man born in once independent Man, and now unmanned of Man;
19878: which is sucked in—by what? Up with the reel! The dead, blind wall
19879: butts all inquiring heads at last. Up with it! So.”
19880: 
19881: The log was heaved. The loose coils rapidly straightened out in a long
19882: dragging line astern, and then, instantly, the reel began to whirl. In
19883: turn, jerkingly raised and lowered by the rolling billows, the towing
19884: resistance of the log caused the old reelman to stagger strangely.
19885: 
19886: “Hold hard!”
19887: 
19888: Snap! the overstrained line sagged down in one long festoon; the
19889: tugging log was gone.
19890: 
19891: “I crush the quadrant, the thunder turns the needles, and now the mad
19892: sea parts the log-line. But Ahab can mend all. Haul in here, Tahitian;
19893: reel up, Manxman. And look ye, let the carpenter make another log, and
19894: mend thou the line. See to it.”
19895: 
19896: “There he goes now; to him nothing’s happened; but to me, the skewer
19897: seems loosening out of the middle of the world. Haul in, haul in,
19898: Tahitian! These lines run whole, and whirling out: come in broken, and
19899: dragging slow. Ha, Pip? come to help; eh, Pip?”
19900: 
19901: “Pip? whom call ye Pip? Pip jumped from the whale-boat. Pip’s missing.
19902: Let’s see now if ye haven’t fished him up here, fisherman. It drags
19903: hard; I guess he’s holding on. Jerk him, Tahiti! Jerk him off; we haul
19904: in no cowards here. Ho! there’s his arm just breaking water. A hatchet!
19905: a hatchet! cut it off—we haul in no cowards here. Captain Ahab! sir,
19906: sir! here’s Pip, trying to get on board again.”
19907: 
19908: “Peace, thou crazy loon,” cried the Manxman, seizing him by the arm.
19909: “Away from the quarter-deck!”
19910: 
19911: “The greater idiot ever scolds the lesser,” muttered Ahab, advancing.
19912: “Hands off from that holiness! Where sayest thou Pip was, boy?
19913: 
19914: “Astern there, sir, astern! Lo! lo!”
19915: 
19916: “And who art thou, boy? I see not my reflection in the vacant pupils of
19917: thy eyes. Oh God! that man should be a thing for immortal souls to
19918: sieve through! Who art thou, boy?”
19919: 
19920: “Bell-boy, sir; ship’s-crier; ding, dong, ding! Pip! Pip! Pip! One
19921: hundred pounds of clay reward for Pip; five feet high—looks
19922: cowardly—quickest known by that! Ding, dong, ding! Who’s seen Pip the
19923: coward?”
19924: 
19925: “There can be no hearts above the snow-line. Oh, ye frozen heavens!
19926: look down here. Ye did beget this luckless child, and have abandoned
19927: him, ye creative libertines. Here, boy; Ahab’s cabin shall be Pip’s
19928: home henceforth, while Ahab lives. Thou touchest my inmost centre, boy;
19929: thou art tied to me by cords woven of my heart-strings. Come, let’s
19930: down.”
19931: 
19932: “What’s this? here’s velvet shark-skin,” intently gazing at Ahab’s
19933: hand, and feeling it. “Ah, now, had poor Pip but felt so kind a thing
19934: as this, perhaps he had ne’er been lost! This seems to me, sir, as a
19935: man-rope; something that weak souls may hold by. Oh, sir, let old Perth
19936: now come and rivet these two hands together; the black one with the
19937: white, for I will not let this go.”
19938: 
19939: “Oh, boy, nor will I thee, unless I should thereby drag thee to worse
19940: horrors than are here. Come, then, to my cabin. Lo! ye believers in
19941: gods all goodness, and in man all ill, lo you! see the omniscient gods
19942: oblivious of suffering man; and man, though idiotic, and knowing not
19943: what he does, yet full of the sweet things of love and gratitude. Come!
19944: I feel prouder leading thee by thy black hand, than though I grasped an
19945: Emperor’s!”
19946: 
19947: “There go two daft ones now,” muttered the old Manxman. “One daft with
19948: strength, the other daft with weakness. But here’s the end of the
19949: rotten line—all dripping, too. Mend it, eh? I think we had best have a
19950: new line altogether. I’ll see Mr. Stubb about it.”
19951: 
19952: 
19953: CHAPTER 126. The Life-Buoy.
19954: 
19955: Steering now south-eastward by Ahab’s levelled steel, and her progress
19956: solely determined by Ahab’s level log and line; the Pequod held on her
19957: path towards the Equator. Making so long a passage through such
19958: unfrequented waters, descrying no ships, and ere long, sideways
19959: impelled by unvarying trade winds, over waves monotonously mild; all
19960: these seemed the strange calm things preluding some riotous and
19961: desperate scene.
19962: 
19963: At last, when the ship drew near to the outskirts, as it were, of the
19964: Equatorial fishing-ground, and in the deep darkness that goes before
19965: the dawn, was sailing by a cluster of rocky islets; the watch—then
19966: headed by Flask—was startled by a cry so plaintively wild and
19967: unearthly—like half-articulated wailings of the ghosts of all Herod’s
19968: murdered Innocents—that one and all, they started from their reveries,
19969: and for the space of some moments stood, or sat, or leaned all
19970: transfixedly listening, like the carved Roman slave, while that wild
19971: cry remained within hearing. The Christian or civilized part of the
19972: crew said it was mermaids, and shuddered; but the pagan harpooneers
19973: remained unappalled. Yet the grey Manxman—the oldest mariner of
19974: all—declared that the wild thrilling sounds that were heard, were the
19975: voices of newly drowned men in the sea.
19976: 
19977: Below in his hammock, Ahab did not hear of this till grey dawn, when he
19978: came to the deck; it was then recounted to him by Flask, not
19979: unaccompanied with hinted dark meanings. He hollowly laughed, and thus
19980: explained the wonder.
19981: 
19982: Those rocky islands the ship had passed were the resort of great
19983: numbers of seals, and some young seals that had lost their dams, or
19984: some dams that had lost their cubs, must have risen nigh the ship and
19985: kept company with her, crying and sobbing with their human sort of
19986: wail. But this only the more affected some of them, because most
19987: mariners cherish a very superstitious feeling about seals, arising not
19988: only from their peculiar tones when in distress, but also from the
19989: human look of their round heads and semi-intelligent faces, seen
19990: peeringly uprising from the water alongside. In the sea, under certain
19991: circumstances, seals have more than once been mistaken for men.
19992: 
19993: But the bodings of the crew were destined to receive a most plausible
19994: confirmation in the fate of one of their number that morning. At
19995: sun-rise this man went from his hammock to his mast-head at the fore;
19996: and whether it was that he was not yet half waked from his sleep (for
19997: sailors sometimes go aloft in a transition state), whether it was thus
19998: with the man, there is now no telling; but, be that as it may, he had
19999: not been long at his perch, when a cry was heard—a cry and a
20000: rushing—and looking up, they saw a falling phantom in the air; and
20001: looking down, a little tossed heap of white bubbles in the blue of the
20002: sea.
20003: 
20004: The life-buoy—a long slender cask—was dropped from the stern, where it
20005: always hung obedient to a cunning spring; but no hand rose to seize it,
20006: and the sun having long beat upon this cask it had shrunken, so that it
20007: slowly filled, and that parched wood also filled at its every pore; and
20008: the studded iron-bound cask followed the sailor to the bottom, as if to
20009: yield him his pillow, though in sooth but a hard one.
20010: 
20011: And thus the first man of the Pequod that mounted the mast to look out
20012: for the White Whale, on the White Whale’s own peculiar ground; that man
20013: was swallowed up in the deep. But few, perhaps, thought of that at the
20014: time. Indeed, in some sort, they were not grieved at this event, at
20015: least as a portent; for they regarded it, not as a foreshadowing of
20016: evil in the future, but as the fulfilment of an evil already presaged.
20017: They declared that now they knew the reason of those wild shrieks they
20018: had heard the night before. But again the old Manxman said nay.
20019: 
20020: The lost life-buoy was now to be replaced; Starbuck was directed to see
20021: to it; but as no cask of sufficient lightness could be found, and as in
20022: the feverish eagerness of what seemed the approaching crisis of the
20023: voyage, all hands were impatient of any toil but what was directly
20024: connected with its final end, whatever that might prove to be;
20025: therefore, they were going to leave the ship’s stern unprovided with a
20026: buoy, when by certain strange signs and inuendoes Queequeg hinted a
20027: hint concerning his coffin.
20028: 
20029: “A life-buoy of a coffin!” cried Starbuck, starting.
20030: 
20031: “Rather queer, that, I should say,” said Stubb.
20032: 
20033: “It will make a good enough one,” said Flask, “the carpenter here can
20034: arrange it easily.”
20035: 
20036: “Bring it up; there’s nothing else for it,” said Starbuck, after a
20037: melancholy pause. “Rig it, carpenter; do not look at me so—the coffin,
20038: I mean. Dost thou hear me? Rig it.”
20039: 
20040: “And shall I nail down the lid, sir?” moving his hand as with a hammer.
20041: 
20042: “Aye.”
20043: 
20044: “And shall I caulk the seams, sir?” moving his hand as with a
20045: caulking-iron.
20046: 
20047: “Aye.”
20048: 
20049: “And shall I then pay over the same with pitch, sir?” moving his hand
20050: as with a pitch-pot.
20051: 
20052: “Away! what possesses thee to this? Make a life-buoy of the coffin, and
20053: no more.—Mr. Stubb, Mr. Flask, come forward with me.”
20054: 
20055: “He goes off in a huff. The whole he can endure; at the parts he
20056: baulks. Now I don’t like this. I make a leg for Captain Ahab, and he
20057: wears it like a gentleman; but I make a bandbox for Queequeg, and he
20058: won’t put his head into it. Are all my pains to go for nothing with
20059: that coffin? And now I’m ordered to make a life-buoy of it. It’s like
20060: turning an old coat; going to bring the flesh on the other side now. I
20061: don’t like this cobbling sort of business—I don’t like it at all; it’s
20062: undignified; it’s not my place. Let tinkers’ brats do tinkerings; we
20063: are their betters. I like to take in hand none but clean, virgin,
20064: fair-and-square mathematical jobs, something that regularly begins at
20065: the beginning, and is at the middle when midway, and comes to an end at
20066: the conclusion; not a cobbler’s job, that’s at an end in the middle,
20067: and at the beginning at the end. It’s the old woman’s tricks to be
20068: giving cobbling jobs. Lord! what an affection all old women have for
20069: tinkers. I know an old woman of sixty-five who ran away with a
20070: bald-headed young tinker once. And that’s the reason I never would work
20071: for lonely widow old women ashore, when I kept my job-shop in the
20072: Vineyard; they might have taken it into their lonely old heads to run
20073: off with me. But heigh-ho! there are no caps at sea but snow-caps. Let
20074: me see. Nail down the lid; caulk the seams; pay over the same with
20075: pitch; batten them down tight, and hang it with the snap-spring over
20076: the ship’s stern. Were ever such things done before with a coffin? Some
20077: superstitious old carpenters, now, would be tied up in the rigging, ere
20078: they would do the job. But I’m made of knotty Aroostook hemlock; I
20079: don’t budge. Cruppered with a coffin! Sailing about with a grave-yard
20080: tray! But never mind. We workers in woods make bridal-bedsteads and
20081: card-tables, as well as coffins and hearses. We work by the month, or
20082: by the job, or by the profit; not for us to ask the why and wherefore
20083: of our work, unless it be too confounded cobbling, and then we stash it
20084: if we can. Hem! I’ll do the job, now, tenderly. I’ll have me—let’s
20085: see—how many in the ship’s company, all told? But I’ve forgotten. Any
20086: way, I’ll have me thirty separate, Turk’s-headed life-lines, each three
20087: feet long hanging all round to the coffin. Then, if the hull go down,
20088: there’ll be thirty lively fellows all fighting for one coffin, a sight
20089: not seen very often beneath the sun! Come hammer, caulking-iron,
20090: pitch-pot, and marling-spike! Let’s to it.”
20091: 
20092: 
20093: CHAPTER 127. The Deck.
20094: 
20095: _The coffin laid upon two line-tubs, between the vice-bench and the
20096: open hatchway; the Carpenter caulking its seams; the string of twisted
20097: oakum slowly unwinding from a large roll of it placed in the bosom of
20098: his frock.—Ahab comes slowly from the cabin-gangway, and hears Pip
20099: following him._
20100: 
20101: “Back, lad; I will be with ye again presently. He goes! Not this hand
20102: complies with my humor more genially than that boy.—Middle aisle of a
20103: church! What’s here?”
20104: 
20105: “Life-buoy, sir. Mr. Starbuck’s orders. Oh, look, sir! Beware the
20106: hatchway!”
20107: 
20108: “Thank ye, man. Thy coffin lies handy to the vault.”
20109: 
20110: “Sir? The hatchway? oh! So it does, sir, so it does.”
20111: 
20112: “Art not thou the leg-maker? Look, did not this stump come from thy
20113: shop?”
20114: 
20115: “I believe it did, sir; does the ferrule stand, sir?”
20116: 
20117: “Well enough. But art thou not also the undertaker?”
20118: 
20119: “Aye, sir; I patched up this thing here as a coffin for Queequeg; but
20120: they’ve set me now to turning it into something else.”
20121: 
20122: “Then tell me; art thou not an arrant, all-grasping, intermeddling,
20123: monopolising, heathenish old scamp, to be one day making legs, and the
20124: next day coffins to clap them in, and yet again life-buoys out of those
20125: same coffins? Thou art as unprincipled as the gods, and as much of a
20126: jack-of-all-trades.”
20127: 
20128: “But I do not mean anything, sir. I do as I do.”
20129: 
20130: “The gods again. Hark ye, dost thou not ever sing working about a
20131: coffin? The Titans, they say, hummed snatches when chipping out the
20132: craters for volcanoes; and the grave-digger in the play sings, spade in
20133: hand. Dost thou never?”
20134: 
20135: “Sing, sir? Do I sing? Oh, I’m indifferent enough, sir, for that; but
20136: the reason why the grave-digger made music must have been because there
20137: was none in his spade, sir. But the caulking mallet is full of it. Hark
20138: to it.”
20139: 
20140: “Aye, and that’s because the lid there’s a sounding-board; and what in
20141: all things makes the sounding-board is this—there’s naught beneath. And
20142: yet, a coffin with a body in it rings pretty much the same, Carpenter.
20143: Hast thou ever helped carry a bier, and heard the coffin knock against
20144: the churchyard gate, going in?
20145: 
20146: “Faith, sir, I’ve——”
20147: 
20148: “Faith? What’s that?”
20149: 
20150: “Why, faith, sir, it’s only a sort of exclamation-like—that’s all,
20151: sir.”
20152: 
20153: “Um, um; go on.”
20154: 
20155: “I was about to say, sir, that——”
20156: 
20157: “Art thou a silk-worm? Dost thou spin thy own shroud out of thyself?
20158: Look at thy bosom! Despatch! and get these traps out of sight.”
20159: 
20160: “He goes aft. That was sudden, now; but squalls come sudden in hot
20161: latitudes. I’ve heard that the Isle of Albemarle, one of the
20162: Gallipagos, is cut by the Equator right in the middle. Seems to me some
20163: sort of Equator cuts yon old man, too, right in his middle. He’s always
20164: under the Line—fiery hot, I tell ye! He’s looking this way—come, oakum;
20165: quick. Here we go again. This wooden mallet is the cork, and I’m the
20166: professor of musical glasses—tap, tap!”
20167: 
20168: (_Ahab to himself_.)
20169: 
20170: “There’s a sight! There’s a sound! The greyheaded woodpecker tapping
20171: the hollow tree! Blind and dumb might well be envied now. See! that
20172: thing rests on two line-tubs, full of tow-lines. A most malicious wag,
20173: that fellow. Rat-tat! So man’s seconds tick! Oh! how immaterial are all
20174: materials! What things real are there, but imponderable thoughts? Here
20175: now’s the very dreaded symbol of grim death, by a mere hap, made the
20176: expressive sign of the help and hope of most endangered life. A
20177: life-buoy of a coffin! Does it go further? Can it be that in some
20178: spiritual sense the coffin is, after all, but an immortality-preserver!
20179: I’ll think of that. But no. So far gone am I in the dark side of earth,
20180: that its other side, the theoretic bright one, seems but uncertain
20181: twilight to me. Will ye never have done, Carpenter, with that accursed
20182: sound? I go below; let me not see that thing here when I return again.
20183: Now, then, Pip, we’ll talk this over; I do suck most wondrous
20184: philosophies from thee! Some unknown conduits from the unknown worlds
20185: must empty into thee!”
20186: 
20187: 
20188: CHAPTER 128. The Pequod Meets The Rachel.
20189: 
20190: Next day, a large ship, the Rachel, was descried, bearing directly down
20191: upon the Pequod, all her spars thickly clustering with men. At the time
20192: the Pequod was making good speed through the water; but as the
20193: broad-winged windward stranger shot nigh to her, the boastful sails all
20194: fell together as blank bladders that are burst, and all life fled from
20195: the smitten hull.
20196: 
20197: “Bad news; she brings bad news,” muttered the old Manxman. But ere her
20198: commander, who, with trumpet to mouth, stood up in his boat; ere he
20199: could hopefully hail, Ahab’s voice was heard.
20200: 
20201: “Hast seen the White Whale?”
20202: 
20203: “Aye, yesterday. Have ye seen a whale-boat adrift?”
20204: 
20205: Throttling his joy, Ahab negatively answered this unexpected question;
20206: and would then have fain boarded the stranger, when the stranger
20207: captain himself, having stopped his vessel’s way, was seen descending
20208: her side. A few keen pulls, and his boat-hook soon clinched the
20209: Pequod’s main-chains, and he sprang to the deck. Immediately he was
20210: recognised by Ahab for a Nantucketer he knew. But no formal salutation
20211: was exchanged.
20212: 
20213: “Where was he?—not killed!—not killed!” cried Ahab, closely advancing.
20214: “How was it?”
20215: 
20216: It seemed that somewhat late on the afternoon of the day previous,
20217: while three of the stranger’s boats were engaged with a shoal of
20218: whales, which had led them some four or five miles from the ship; and
20219: while they were yet in swift chase to windward, the white hump and head
20220: of Moby Dick had suddenly loomed up out of the water, not very far to
20221: leeward; whereupon, the fourth rigged boat—a reserved one—had been
20222: instantly lowered in chase. After a keen sail before the wind, this
20223: fourth boat—the swiftest keeled of all—seemed to have succeeded in
20224: fastening—at least, as well as the man at the mast-head could tell
20225: anything about it. In the distance he saw the diminished dotted boat;
20226: and then a swift gleam of bubbling white water; and after that nothing
20227: more; whence it was concluded that the stricken whale must have
20228: indefinitely run away with his pursuers, as often happens. There was
20229: some apprehension, but no positive alarm, as yet. The recall signals
20230: were placed in the rigging; darkness came on; and forced to pick up her
20231: three far to windward boats—ere going in quest of the fourth one in the
20232: precisely opposite direction—the ship had not only been necessitated to
20233: leave that boat to its fate till near midnight, but, for the time, to
20234: increase her distance from it. But the rest of her crew being at last
20235: safe aboard, she crowded all sail—stunsail on stunsail—after the
20236: missing boat; kindling a fire in her try-pots for a beacon; and every
20237: other man aloft on the look-out. But though when she had thus sailed a
20238: sufficient distance to gain the presumed place of the absent ones when
20239: last seen; though she then paused to lower her spare boats to pull all
20240: around her; and not finding anything, had again dashed on; again
20241: paused, and lowered her boats; and though she had thus continued doing
20242: till daylight; yet not the least glimpse of the missing keel had been
20243: seen.
20244: 
20245: The story told, the stranger Captain immediately went on to reveal his
20246: object in boarding the Pequod. He desired that ship to unite with his
20247: own in the search; by sailing over the sea some four or five miles
20248: apart, on parallel lines, and so sweeping a double horizon, as it were.
20249: 
20250: “I will wager something now,” whispered Stubb to Flask, “that some one
20251: in that missing boat wore off that Captain’s best coat; mayhap, his
20252: watch—he’s so cursed anxious to get it back. Who ever heard of two
20253: pious whale-ships cruising after one missing whale-boat in the height
20254: of the whaling season? See, Flask, only see how pale he looks—pale in
20255: the very buttons of his eyes—look—it wasn’t the coat—it must have been
20256: the—”
20257: 
20258: “My boy, my own boy is among them. For God’s sake—I beg, I
20259: conjure”—here exclaimed the stranger Captain to Ahab, who thus far had
20260: but icily received his petition. “For eight-and-forty hours let me
20261: charter your ship—I will gladly pay for it, and roundly pay for it—if
20262: there be no other way—for eight-and-forty hours only—only that—you
20263: must, oh, you must, and you _shall_ do this thing.”
20264: 
20265: “His son!” cried Stubb, “oh, it’s his son he’s lost! I take back the
20266: coat and watch—what says Ahab? We must save that boy.”
20267: 
20268: “He’s drowned with the rest on ’em, last night,” said the old Manx
20269: sailor standing behind them; “I heard; all of ye heard their spirits.”
20270: 
20271: Now, as it shortly turned out, what made this incident of the Rachel’s
20272: the more melancholy, was the circumstance, that not only was one of the
20273: Captain’s sons among the number of the missing boat’s crew; but among
20274: the number of the other boat’s crews, at the same time, but on the
20275: other hand, separated from the ship during the dark vicissitudes of the
20276: chase, there had been still another son; as that for a time, the
20277: wretched father was plunged to the bottom of the cruellest perplexity;
20278: which was only solved for him by his chief mate’s instinctively
20279: adopting the ordinary procedure of a whale-ship in such emergencies,
20280: that is, when placed between jeopardized but divided boats, always to
20281: pick up the majority first. But the captain, for some unknown
20282: constitutional reason, had refrained from mentioning all this, and not
20283: till forced to it by Ahab’s iciness did he allude to his one yet
20284: missing boy; a little lad, but twelve years old, whose father with the
20285: earnest but unmisgiving hardihood of a Nantucketer’s paternal love, had
20286: thus early sought to initiate him in the perils and wonders of a
20287: vocation almost immemorially the destiny of all his race. Nor does it
20288: unfrequently occur, that Nantucket captains will send a son of such
20289: tender age away from them, for a protracted three or four years’ voyage
20290: in some other ship than their own; so that their first knowledge of a
20291: whaleman’s career shall be unenervated by any chance display of a
20292: father’s natural but untimely partiality, or undue apprehensiveness and
20293: concern.
20294: 
20295: Meantime, now the stranger was still beseeching his poor boon of Ahab;
20296: and Ahab still stood like an anvil, receiving every shock, but without
20297: the least quivering of his own.
20298: 
20299: “I will not go,” said the stranger, “till you say _aye_ to me. Do to me
20300: as you would have me do to you in the like case. For _you_ too have a
20301: boy, Captain Ahab—though but a child, and nestling safely at home now—a
20302: child of your old age too—Yes, yes, you relent; I see it—run, run, men,
20303: now, and stand by to square in the yards.”
20304: 
20305: “Avast,” cried Ahab—“touch not a rope-yarn”; then in a voice that
20306: prolongingly moulded every word—“Captain Gardiner, I will not do it.
20307: Even now I lose time. Good-bye, good-bye. God bless ye, man, and may I
20308: forgive myself, but I must go. Mr. Starbuck, look at the binnacle
20309: watch, and in three minutes from this present instant warn off all
20310: strangers: then brace forward again, and let the ship sail as before.”
20311: 
20312: Hurriedly turning, with averted face, he descended into his cabin,
20313: leaving the strange captain transfixed at this unconditional and utter
20314: rejection of his so earnest suit. But starting from his enchantment,
20315: Gardiner silently hurried to the side; more fell than stepped into his
20316: boat, and returned to his ship.
20317: 
20318: Soon the two ships diverged their wakes; and long as the strange vessel
20319: was in view, she was seen to yaw hither and thither at every dark spot,
20320: however small, on the sea. This way and that her yards were swung
20321: round; starboard and larboard, she continued to tack; now she beat
20322: against a head sea; and again it pushed her before it; while all the
20323: while, her masts and yards were thickly clustered with men, as three
20324: tall cherry trees, when the boys are cherrying among the boughs.
20325: 
20326: But by her still halting course and winding, woeful way, you plainly
20327: saw that this ship that so wept with spray, still remained without
20328: comfort. She was Rachel, weeping for her children, because they were
20329: not.
20330: 
20331: 
20332: CHAPTER 129. The Cabin.
20333: 
20334: (_Ahab moving to go on deck; Pip catches him by the hand to follow._)
20335: 
20336: “Lad, lad, I tell thee thou must not follow Ahab now. The hour is
20337: coming when Ahab would not scare thee from him, yet would not have thee
20338: by him. There is that in thee, poor lad, which I feel too curing to my
20339: malady. Like cures like; and for this hunt, my malady becomes my most
20340: desired health. Do thou abide below here, where they shall serve thee,
20341: as if thou wert the captain. Aye, lad, thou shalt sit here in my own
20342: screwed chair; another screw to it, thou must be.”
20343: 
20344: “No, no, no! ye have not a whole body, sir; do ye but use poor me for
20345: your one lost leg; only tread upon me, sir; I ask no more, so I remain
20346: a part of ye.”
20347: 
20348: “Oh! spite of million villains, this makes me a bigot in the fadeless
20349: fidelity of man!—and a black! and crazy!—but methinks like-cures-like
20350: applies to him too; he grows so sane again.”
20351: 
20352: “They tell me, sir, that Stubb did once desert poor little Pip, whose
20353: drowned bones now show white, for all the blackness of his living skin.
20354: But I will never desert ye, sir, as Stubb did him. Sir, I must go with
20355: ye.”
20356: 
20357: “If thou speakest thus to me much more, Ahab’s purpose keels up in him.
20358: I tell thee no; it cannot be.”
20359: 
20360: “Oh good master, master, master!
20361: 
20362: “Weep so, and I will murder thee! have a care, for Ahab too is mad.
20363: Listen, and thou wilt often hear my ivory foot upon the deck, and still
20364: know that I am there. And now I quit thee. Thy hand!—Met! True art
20365: thou, lad, as the circumference to its centre. So: God for ever bless
20366: thee; and if it come to that,—God for ever save thee, let what will
20367: befall.”
20368: 
20369: (_Ahab goes; Pip steps one step forward._)
20370: 
20371: “Here he this instant stood; I stand in his air,—but I’m alone. Now
20372: were even poor Pip here I could endure it, but he’s missing. Pip! Pip!
20373: Ding, dong, ding! Who’s seen Pip? He must be up here; let’s try the
20374: door. What? neither lock, nor bolt, nor bar; and yet there’s no opening
20375: it. It must be the spell; he told me to stay here: Aye, and told me
20376: this screwed chair was mine. Here, then, I’ll seat me, against the
20377: transom, in the ship’s full middle, all her keel and her three masts
20378: before me. Here, our old sailors say, in their black seventy-fours
20379: great admirals sometimes sit at table, and lord it over rows of
20380: captains and lieutenants. Ha! what’s this? epaulets! epaulets! the
20381: epaulets all come crowding! Pass round the decanters; glad to see ye;
20382: fill up, monsieurs! What an odd feeling, now, when a black boy’s host
20383: to white men with gold lace upon their coats!—Monsieurs, have ye seen
20384: one Pip?—a little negro lad, five feet high, hang-dog look, and
20385: cowardly! Jumped from a whale-boat once;—seen him? No! Well then, fill
20386: up again, captains, and let’s drink shame upon all cowards! I name no
20387: names. Shame upon them! Put one foot upon the table. Shame upon all
20388: cowards.—Hist! above there, I hear ivory—Oh, master! master! I am
20389: indeed down-hearted when you walk over me. But here I’ll stay, though
20390: this stern strikes rocks; and they bulge through; and oysters come to
20391: join me.”
20392: 
20393: 
20394: CHAPTER 130. The Hat.
20395: 
20396: And now that at the proper time and place, after so long and wide a
20397: preliminary cruise, Ahab,—all other whaling waters swept—seemed to have
20398: chased his foe into an ocean-fold, to slay him the more securely there;
20399: now, that he found himself hard by the very latitude and longitude
20400: where his tormenting wound had been inflicted; now that a vessel had
20401: been spoken which on the very day preceding had actually encountered
20402: Moby Dick;—and now that all his successive meetings with various ships
20403: contrastingly concurred to show the demoniac indifference with which
20404: the white whale tore his hunters, whether sinning or sinned against;
20405: now it was that there lurked a something in the old man’s eyes, which
20406: it was hardly sufferable for feeble souls to see. As the unsetting
20407: polar star, which through the livelong, arctic, six months’ night
20408: sustains its piercing, steady, central gaze; so Ahab’s purpose now
20409: fixedly gleamed down upon the constant midnight of the gloomy crew. It
20410: domineered above them so, that all their bodings, doubts, misgivings,
20411: fears, were fain to hide beneath their souls, and not sprout forth a
20412: single spear or leaf.
20413: 
20414: In this foreshadowing interval too, all humor, forced or natural,
20415: vanished. Stubb no more strove to raise a smile; Starbuck no more
20416: strove to check one. Alike, joy and sorrow, hope and fear, seemed
20417: ground to finest dust, and powdered, for the time, in the clamped
20418: mortar of Ahab’s iron soul. Like machines, they dumbly moved about the
20419: deck, ever conscious that the old man’s despot eye was on them.
20420: 
20421: But did you deeply scan him in his more secret confidential hours; when
20422: he thought no glance but one was on him; then you would have seen that
20423: even as Ahab’s eyes so awed the crew’s, the inscrutable Parsee’s glance
20424: awed his; or somehow, at least, in some wild way, at times affected it.
20425: Such an added, gliding strangeness began to invest the thin Fedallah
20426: now; such ceaseless shudderings shook him; that the men looked dubious
20427: at him; half uncertain, as it seemed, whether indeed he were a mortal
20428: substance, or else a tremulous shadow cast upon the deck by some unseen
20429: being’s body. And that shadow was always hovering there. For not by
20430: night, even, had Fedallah ever certainly been known to slumber, or go
20431: below. He would stand still for hours: but never sat or leaned; his wan
20432: but wondrous eyes did plainly say—We two watchmen never rest.
20433: 
20434: Nor, at any time, by night or day could the mariners now step upon the
20435: deck, unless Ahab was before them; either standing in his pivot-hole,
20436: or exactly pacing the planks between two undeviating limits,—the
20437: main-mast and the mizen; or else they saw him standing in the
20438: cabin-scuttle,—his living foot advanced upon the deck, as if to step;
